webTitle: McAllister prevails in battle of Dad's Armies

fields.headline: McAllister prevails in battle of Dad's Armies
fields.trailText: Coventry 1 - 0 Everton
fields.body:
There were so many senior citizens on parade here last night that it would have been no surprise to see Captain Mainwaring on the touchline. In his absence this footballing version of Dad's Army was as tiresome and predictable as some of the repeats on UK Gold.

For a side whose feats of escapology have become near-legendary during three decades of top-flight football, Coventry's continued tenure would appear to be secure after Gary McAllister's late goal broke the deadlock as the match seemingly petered towards a scoreless draw.

With Mark Hughes making his debut for Everton in front of 37-year-old Richard Gough and Coventry's ageing pair McAllister and Colin Hendry also proving they can be a durable lot north of the border, the home manager Gordon Strachan had billed this as potential sequel to Jurassic Park. After failing to register a goal during four successive defeats, the natural concern among City supporters was that a few dodos had infiltrated the cast.

Much of their predicament is due to their midfielders Mustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo. From stars of the cast to bit-part roles, it has been a swift and sudden decline and the Moroccans were culpable once again, going walkabout for long spells of an opening period controlled by an Everton side showing no great class.

Instead the visitors played with the carefree abandon of a team for whom meaningless end-of-season matches have come blissfully early for a change, but they lacked an incisive edge in the absence of Kevin Campbell and Francis Jeffers.

Mark Hughes was the nuisance that he always is but the days when defences shuddered at the sight of him are long gone and neither goalkeeper could lay claim to dirtying his knees before Joe-Max Moore extended Coventry's Magnus Hedman late in the first half.

Everton had a remarkable escape when Cédric Roussel was presented with an open goal only to strike the post as the match entered its closing stages. The second time he hit the upright, McAllister was on hand to scoop home the rebound and register Coventry's first goal in more than 500 minutes of football.

fields.headline: Arsenal 2 - 0 Werder Bremen
fields.trailText:
Arsenal: Seaman, Dixon, Adams, Luzhny, Silvinho, Parlour, Vieira, Grimandi, Ljungberg, Bergkamp, Henry.
Substitutes: Winterburn, Keown, Suker, Overmars, Manninger, Malz, Kanu.
fields.body:
Arsenal: Seaman, Dixon, Adams, Luzhny, Silvinho, Parlour, Vieira, Grimandi, Ljungberg, Bergkamp, Henry.
Substitutes: Winterburn, Keown, Suker, Overmars, Manninger, Malz, Kanu.

Werder Bremen: Rost, Eilts, Baumann, Wiedener, Tjikuzu, Frings, Herzog, Dabrowski, Barten, Bode, Ailton.
Substitutes: Flock, Maximow, Trares, Bogdanovic, Brasas, Skripnik, Schierenbeck

Referee: C Colombo (France)

This is Arsenal's eleventh European tie of the season, two more than they played to win the Cup Winners' Cup in 1994. The good news for the Gunners is that Tony Adams starts after recovering from a troublesome groin injury. Bremen should not be written off whatever happens tonight - they overturned a 1-0 deficit against Parma in the last round and went through against Lyon despite losing the first leg 3-0 in France.

1 min Arsenal kick off this UEFA Cup quarter-final, first leg. Bremen start the match in what must be one of the worst strips ever seen on at a Premiership ground.
2 Arsenal start brightly through Bergkamp on the left. The move breaks down and possession is lost. Bremen are physically a large side, and score many goals from headers and corners.
4 Grimandi and Adams place themselves poorly for a long throw from Herzog. A corner results and Seaman is able to gather and clear.
6 Great link-up play between Vieira and Parlour through the middle on the break, but the Englishman's final ball to release Henry on the right side of the area is overhit. Goal kick.
8 Great determination from Vieira in midfield as he digs the ball out in the challenge with Dabrowski. His pace carries him away from two defenders and the ball is played through to Henry on the right. The angle is acute but his shot beats the keeper Rost and slips agonisingly wide of the far post.
12 Arsenal are winning the lion's share of the midfield tussles, but the Bremen defence looks to be holding steady as Bergkamp and Henry press for an opening. They look like a tough team to break down.
15 Henry does well to keep the ball in play on the right touchline after Vieira had intercepted Barten's pass and released his countryman down the flank with a floated through-ball. The cross deflects off Tjikuzu for a throw. Possession is wasted and Bremen clear again.
18 In possession on the right, Grimandi sees the Bremen defence pushing back but fails to see Adams peeling away at the far post. His shot is always curling away from the far post. Goal kick.
20 Arsenal sustain the pressure through a cross from Grimandi that is just too high for Adams hovering over the penalty spot. The visitors clear deep into the Arsenal half.
21 GOAL Arsenal 1 - 0 Werder Bremen After winning the ball by the left touchline deep in his own half, Vieira looks up once and plays a 70-yard ball for Henry to run on to. The French international needs two touches to control it before rolling it past Rost's outstretched left foot and into the net. A cool finish cements a great start for the home side.
24 Arsenal continue to press their advantage through pressuring the man on the ball. Vieira is playing like a man possessed and the Bremen defenders look uneasy when confronted with Henry's pace.
28 Parlour and Henry scrap for the ball on the right side of the visitors' area. Parlour almost manages to squeeze the ball through to Bergkamp, but Baumann manages to hoof the ball clear.
30 Vieira (who else?) swings the play out wide to Henry, who traps the ball on his chest by the left touchline and then simply kicks it past the right-back Eilts into the area. His pace is more than enough to win the race to the ball, but the low cross is poor a one and easily intercepted.
36 Henry wins a corner from the left. Bergkamp hits the cross deep to the back post as Adams peels away from the penalty spot to meet the centre. The Arsenal skipper chests the ball down and strikes a volley at goal from an acute angle. His rising drive is powerfully struck and Rost does well to parry the ball out. A relieved Bremen clear.
39 Bremen have a corner on the left. Vieira heads away at the near post but the header lacks distance. Parlour slices his clearance away for another corner. This time Seaman comes and claims with confidence.
40 From the clearance Henry and Bergkamp link up on the left of the Bremen area. Bergkamp eventually threads a through-ball for Parlour. The midfielder gets to the ball before Rost but the keeper has done enough to prevent Parlour from hitting the target.
44 Henry gets past Tjikuzu on the left touchline. A sterner tackle from Eilts wins the corner from the left. Bergkamp takes and Rost punches away well.
45 Dixon has pushed up now from right-back to deliver a cross by the corner flag. The centre is blocked but Arsenal are looking to attack at every opportunity.
46 Half time.

45 Bremen restart and surrender possession immediately. The visitors were very disappointing in the first half and will be looking to impose themselves more in the remaining 45 minutes.
48 Henry uses his strength to force his way to the by-line on the right. His pull-back evades everyone and the German side can clear.
49 Bremen have a free kick from 35 yards out centre-left. Herzog starts his run-up in his own half and then manages to hit the two-man Arsenal wall.
50 Herzog again from the right touchline. His centre is plucked out of the air by Seaman and the clearance is seized on by Henry, this time force right by the double team of Baumann and Wiedener. Parlour assists but can only force the ball out of play.
54 The German side are looking ore lively as Weidener and Bode combine well to produce two good crosses. Seaman is finally able to gather and Arsenal can regroup.
57 Lee Dixon is fed by Grimandi as he storms through the middle. The Bremen defence backs off and he accepts in invitation to strike. The ball is deflected for a corner. Bergkamp takes from the right and Rost gathers well at his far post.
60 Dixon the provider from the right this time, and Baumann intercepts the centre well. Another corner from the right is taken by Grimandi. Rost palms the ball away.
65 Henry again, this time on the left. After forcing his way to the by-line the cross is over-hit and clears Bergkamp's head by three metres.
66 Arsenal substitution: Kanu for Bergkamp; Overmars for Parlour. Arsenal will be looking to make the most of their advantage here to take a handsome lead to the return leg next week.
69 Adams intercepts Bode's pass and releases Henry down the right. His cross is too low and cut out before Kanu can pull the trigger.
72 Arsenal double the pressure on the visitors through Kanu, Overmars and Henry. The Nigerian international feeds Henry on the left edge of the Bremen area. Henry drives a low, powerful shot which Rost does well to block with his legs.
75 Bremen are really pushing for the away goal, leaving them looking under-represented at the back. If Arsenal can gain possession, the pace of Overmars and Henry could punish the German side for their adventurous spirit.
77 GOAL Arsenal 2 - 0 Werder Bremen A serendipitous goal for the home side. Kanu tries a netbuster from 30 yards and scuffs his shot so badly that it mutates into a through ball for Ljundberg. Withstanding the challenge of Baumann and Wiedener, the Swede slips the ball past the right hand of Rost and into the bottom corner. Arsenal deserve this margin on the balance of play.
78 Arsenal substitution: Suker for Henry.
81 Arsenal turn the screw. Kanu, Vieira and Suker all exchange passes for fun until Grimandi hits a dipping, curling shot from 25 yards that only just clears the crossbar.
83 Werder Bremen substitution: Schierenbeck for Ailton.
87 The game is just winding down now as Bremen seem to have accepted their fate.
89 A free kick from Silvinho on the left. Dabrowski meets the ball over the penalty spot with what may have been his arm, at least 38,000 North Londoners seemed to think so, but the referee remains unmoved.
93 Full time: Arsenal 2 - 0 Werder Bremen.

fields.headline: Pakistan secure consolation win
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan won by 222 runs
Sri Lanka win the Three Test Series 2-1
fields.trailText: Pakistan restored some damaged pride with a 222-run win over Sri Lanka in the third and final Test at Karachi's National Stadium.
fields.body:
Pakistan restored some damaged pride with a 222-run win over Sri Lanka in the third and final Test at Karachi's National Stadium.

The tourists, needing a mammoth 451 to seal a clean sweep in the series, were dismissed for 228 in their second innings.

Sri Lanka wickets fell at regular intervals after captain Sanath Jayasuriya departed in the seventh over, trapped lbw for 10 by Waqar Younis and things didn't get much better after tea as Shahid Afridi virtually finished things off to finish with three wickets for 50.

Afridi trapped Indika de Saram lbw for 18, then benefited as Shoaib Akhtar caught Chaminda Vaas for 28.

Pakistan maintained their 33-Test unbeaten record at the venue, while off-spinner Muttiah Muralitharan was the pick of the visiting bowlers, taking four for 107 to finish with a Sri Lankan record of 26 wickets in the series.

webTitle: Warne dumps Lillee out of record books

fields.headline: Warne dumps Lillee out of record books
fields.trailText: Shane Warne took a giant stride towards cricketing immortality yesterday, eclipsing the 16-year-old record of another Australian folk hero, Dennis Lillee, to become the country's leading Test wicket-taker.
fields.body:
Shane Warne took a giant stride towards cricketing immortality yesterday, eclipsing the 16-year-old record of another Australian folk hero, Dennis Lillee, to become the country's leading Test wicket-taker.

His dismissal of the New Zealand tail-ender Paul Wiseman at Eden Park carried him past Lillee's record of 355 wickets and clinched Australia's eighth consecutive Test win - equalling the national record set by Warwick Armstrong's all-conquering team of 1920-21.

But the blond-haired, earring-wearing, headline-grabbing leg-spinner, who will always be remembered in England for that ball to Mike Gatting in the 1993 Ashes series, will not rank the delivery that brought wicket No356 among his finest. It was a leg-break that Wiseman attempted to sweep, but succeeded only in gloving a gentle catch to the wicketkeeper Adam Gilchrist.

A relieved Warne, who started his 82nd Test needing five wickets to surpass Lillee, admitted he had bowled "a bit of trash" as the pressure of the record weighed down on him.

"I probably tried too hard, although I told myself to relax," he said. "Hopefully now the record is out of the way I can bowl normally."

The 30-year-old said he aimed to play for another three or four years and Australia's captain Steve Waugh predicted his star match-winner could become the first man to take 500 Test wickets. He currently stands ninth on the all-time list, trailing Kapil Dev's record of 434 wickets.

"He's been great for cricket," Waugh said of his vice-captain. "People have come back to cricket, particularly young kids, [and] leg-spin [bowling]. He's exciting to watch."

Lillee, who set his long-standing record from just 70 Tests, was among the first to congratulate Warne. "I'm very honoured to have achieved the record in my time, but I'm just as pleased that a bowler and a bloke as great as Shane Warne has overtaken it," Lillee said.

Another past holder of the record, Richie Benaud, said: "The guy who's just taken the record is the best I've ever seen in his particular role. And the guy he's taken over from was the best I've seen in his role. Standing next to each other, they're each in the highest company."

Warne's record is all the more remarkable considering the setbacks - including major shoulder surgery and his controversial involvement with bookmakers - that have hurt him since his Test debut eight years ago.

While Warne hogged the spotlight, Colin Miller was the unlikely hero of Australia's 62-run triumph in the first Test. The off-spinner took five for 55 as New Zealand, despite a brave 78 by Craig McMillan, were bowled out for 218.

 The Pakistan vice-captain Inzamam-ul-Haq has been fined 25% of his match fee after criticising Sri Lanka's players for sledging during the third Test at Karachi. Pakistan wrapped up the match by 222 runs but lost the series 2-1.

His dismissal of the New Zealand tail-ender Paul Wiseman at Eden Park carried him past Lillee's record of 355 wickets and clinched Australia's eighth consecutive Test win - equalling the national record set by Warwick Armstrong's all-conquering team of 1920-21. But the blond-haired, earring-wearing, headline-grabbing leg-spinner, who will always be remembered in England for that ball to Mike Gatting in the 1993 Ashes series, will not rank the delivery that brought wicket No356 among his finest. It was a leg-break that Wiseman attempted to sweep, but succeeded only in gloving a gentle catch to the wicketkeeper Adam Gilchrist. A relieved Warne, who started his 82nd Test needing five wickets to surpass Lillee, admitted he had bowled "a bit of trash" as the pressure of the record weighed down on him. "I probably tried too hard, although I told myself to relax," he said. "Hopefully now the record is out of the way I can bowl normally." The 30-year-old said he aimed to play for another three or four years and Australia's captain Steve Waugh predicted his star match-winner could become the first man to take 500 Test wickets. He currently stands ninth on the all-time list, trailing Kapil Dev's record of 434 wickets. "He's been great for cricket," Waugh said of his vice-captain. "People have come back to cricket, particularly young kids, [and] leg-spin [bowling]. He's exciting to watch." Lillee, who set his long-standing record from just 70 Tests, was among the first to congratulate Warne. "I'm very honoured to have achieved the record in my time, but I'm just as pleased that a bowler and a bloke as great as Shane Warne has overtaken it," Lillee said. Another past holder of the record, Richie Benaud, said: "The guy who's just taken the record is the best I've ever seen in his particular role. And the guy he's taken over from was the best I've seen in his role. Standing next to each other, they're each in the highest company." Warne's record is all the more remarkable considering the setbacks - including major shoulder surgery and his controversial involvement with bookmakers - that have hurt him since his Test debut eight years ago. While Warne hogged the spotlight, Colin Miller was the unlikely hero of Australia's 62-run triumph in the first Test. The off-spinner took five for 55 as New Zealand, despite a brave 78 by Craig McMillan, were bowled out for 218.  The Pakistan vice-captain Inzamam-ul-Haq has been fined 25% of his match fee after criticising Sri Lanka's players for sledging during the third Test at Karachi. Pakistan wrapped up the match by 222 runs but lost the series 2-1. Scoreboard Australia: First innings 214 (M Waugh 72no, Langer 46; Vettori 5-62). New Zealand: First innings 163 (McGrath 4-33, Warne 3-68). Australia: Second innings 229 Gilchrist 59, Langer 47; Vettori 7-87). webTitle: King of spin who set cricket in a whirl

fields.headline: King of spin who set cricket in a whirl
fields.trailText: Frank Keating on why Shane Warne deserves to be acknowledged as one of the most influential cricketers of an ancient pastime's whole history, legend, and lore.
fields.body:
Just eight winters ago was inked into the legend on these pages a single line of a small-print, downpage Test cricket scorecard from Sydney:

RJ Shastri c Jones b Warne 206.

A few lines below was logged the Australians' bowling analyses against India. It included:

Warne 45 - 7 - 150 - 1

Nothing to write home about. Nor did any reporter. Unlike yesterday, when a similar one-liner bounced off the satellites:

P Wiseman c Gilchrist b Warne 9.

Now all the world leaps to its feet to acclaim the wizard, and quite right too. In between, and inclusive of, those wickets of the Indian Ravi Shastri and the Kiwi Paul Wiseman, the spin-bowling maestro Shane Warne has taken 356 Test match wickets and overtaken the true-great Dennis Lillee's long-standing Australian record.

When Warne had Shastri caught by Dean Jones in the deep at Sydney in January 1992, the young man had tiptoed into a worldwide arena dominated by one-shot bingo, blast-'em-for-pace fast-bowling batteries with every Test captain happily tit-for-tatting the West Indians by choosing up to five out-and-out head-hunting bumper bowlers. These they would alternate through five days with relentless, not to say dangerous, tedium. Warne quite simply readjusted Test cricket.

In so doing, and singlehandedly, the exuberant Warne revived a just-about dodo-dead skill, resuscitating it with such gay garlands and flamboyant streamers that in just eight years he deserves to be acknowledged as one of the most influential cricketers of an ancient pastime's whole history, legend, and lore.

And not only Test cricket - Warne's not proud. His spin-bowling pre-eminence and his dauntless daring at the same time opened up myriad possibilities in the one-day game, hitherto also queasy and sick with the tedium of dobbing, run-saving, defensive bowling. Witness Warne's truly spectacular mid-innings incursions during Australia's three crucial last matches which brought them the 1999 World Cup - two for 33 against South Africa in the thriller at Headingley, four for 29 against the same opposition in the "greatest" at Edgbaston, and four for 33 in the final at Lord's against Pakistan.

In all, that was 29 overs, six maidens, 95 runs, 10 wickets, and not one tail-ender among them. Sheer genius: Warne, for me, was the Man of the Cup.

With Wisden's millennium edition due next month, everyone is pre-empting its choice of Five Cricketers of the Century - the quintet whose excellence made the greatest contribution to the game, taking into account "leadership, personality, character and impact on the public".

The knights, Donald Bradman and Garfield Sobers, are obvious musts. I then went for Sydney Barnes, incomparable bowler, and George Headley, pocket Atlas, who carried and fashioned the whole game for the West Indies - and Shane Warne. (In this month's Wisden Cricket Monthly, its retiring editor Matthew Engel nominates Bradman, Sobers, plus Wilfred Rhodes, Denis Compton, and Sir Viv Richards).

Sunday's Observer nicely asked "Sir" Frederick Trueman for his comments. How we are going to miss Fred on Test Match Special. I only wish I'd taped his last Test commentary. If anyone did, they could make a fortune together. But all is lost in the ether now, alas. How's this for vintage Fred and true greats?

"Viv Richards? No, no, no, bloody hell, no. I was 45 years of age when I played him, and I only did him second ball... Shane Warne? Don't get me wrong, a fine bowler, but the people playing against him don't have the faintest idea."

Nice one, Fred. And most assuredly, to quote Ian Healy, "Nice one, Warney!"

webTitle: Captain Adams faces trial by Trinidad

fields.headline: Captain Adams faces trial by Trinidad
fields.trailText: BC Pires Caribbean cricket is so volatile right now... Zimbabwe are unlikely to have a better chance to do well against anyone, though they do follow this tour with one to England for two Tests.
fields.byline: BC Pires in Port of Spain
fields.body:
After the whitewash by New Zealand and with Brian Lara retired psychologically hurt, even the most patriotic of West Indians cannot dismiss the possibility of a Zimbabwe win in the first Test, which begins here in Trinidad this morning.

Prudent punters would back West Indies, but Caribbean cricket is so volatile right now that no scenario can be ruled out. Zimbabwe are unlikely to have a better chance to do well against anyone, though they do follow this tour with one to England for two Tests. West Indies follow them, for five more.

The former captain Lara, the only West Indian capable of turning a match by walking to the wicket, is not only gone but went at the worst possible moment, his legacy controversy and Trinidadian resentment.

Jimmy Adams is now captain - he was the only candidate, given the ageing Courtney Walsh's obvious fatigue - managed only one fifty in the recently concluded regional Busta Cup and would be unlikely to make the team were he not leading it.

Walsh, who has 426 Test wickets, struggled in New Zealand, not just for line and length but even to reach the bowling crease. His strongest motivation for this two-match series would seem to be the hope of breaking Kapil Dev's Test record of 434.

Moreover Curtly Ambrose has not played Test cricket since this time last year, though not being on the New Zealand tour must be a sort of plus.

Additionally, when the first ball of the series is bowled, the only Trinidadians at the Oval will be in the stands. West Indian territories feel entitled to have at least one player in the team, regardless of form, the more so when the Test is at home, and a fortnight ago a Trinidadian was captain.

The importance of inter-island rivalry in West Indies cricket cannot be overstated. Anything could happen here - and as sending West Indies in to bat these days can be like throwing phosphorus on troubled waters, it may very well do so tomorrow.

fields.headline: Historic win for Spanish right
fields.trailText: Spain's conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, won a historic victory for the right in last Sunday's general election as voters heeded his call for an absolute majority in his second term.
fields.body:
Spain's conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, won a historic victory for the right in last Sunday's general election as voters heeded his call for an absolute majority in his second term.

Mr Aznar's Popular party took 183 seats in the 350-seat parliament while the main Socialist opposition dropped to 125, their worst showing since the early 1980s.

The Socialist leader, Joaquin Almunia, resigned before the count had finished to take responsibility for the defeat. "We have not been able to convince Spaniards with our project for the future; we have not been able to connect with their hopes and aspirations," he said.

The results were a resounding endorsement for Mr Aznar's softly-softly approach to economic reform that has led to high growth and a job creation rate three times that of any other European country.

The prime minister has also dispelled doubts that his party was a reincarnation of the old, autocratic right rather than a modernising centralist force.

It is the first time that the conservative party has obtained a majority since Spain became a democracy following the death of the fascist dictator General Francisco Franco in 1975.

Mr Almunia's attempts to rally the left through an electoral alliance with the Communist-led United Left appeared to have failed miserably. "We have not been able to motivate leftwing voters, even though they are the majority in society," he said. "That project remains for the future."

Mr Almunia's claim that the government had practised "crony capitalism", enriching a few personal friends of the prime minister at the expense of the population as a whole, fell on deaf ears.

Instead, voters heeded Mr Aznar's warning that the Socialist-Communist pact, modelled on France's government led by Lionel Jospin, would jeopardise Spain's economic success and reduce the country's chances of becoming a top European power.

The polls had given Mr Aznar a slim lead of 4-5 percentage points. His supporters gathered outside the Popular party's headquarters in Madrid overjoyed that he would not have to rely on regional nationalists to form a government. "Torero! Torero!" they shouted when he appeared on the balcony.

Mr Aznar insisted that even with a majority he would continue to seek consensus on the important issues facing Spain.

"I want to insist that the attitude of the next government will be as open to dialogue with other political parties and social groups as this one has been," he said, "because they're all necessary for the progress of Spain. Dialogue, agreement, consensus - those are the foundations of an open country which will enable us to reach our objectives in the next few years."

Voter turnout was down nearly 10% compared with the last election in 1996. Mr Almunia said that this accounted in part for his defeat.

Mr Aznar's greatest challenge remains the relationship between the regions and Madrid. The threat of Basque terrorist violence had overshadowed the campaign.

webTitle: Swiss use ballot box to bar new citizens

fields.headline: Swiss use ballot box to bar new citizens
fields.trailText: The Avramovic family's application for Swiss citizenship satisfied all the criteria set out by the authorities in their adopted hometown of Emmen.
fields.byline: By Peter Capella  and  Elizabeth Olson in Geneva
fields.body:
The Avramovic family's application for Swiss citizenship satisfied all the criteria set out by the authorities in their adopted hometown of Emmen.

The parents have lived in Switzerland for more than 12 years, have no criminal record, speak Swiss-German dialect and hold steady jobs at a local engineering firm. Their two sons were born and educated in Switzerland and play for the local football team.

But when the Yugoslav couple's bid for Swiss passports was submitted to a local referendum last weekend, along with that of 52 other applicants, their neighbours in the industrial town said no to citizenship. Armed with a brochure with the address, photograph, CV and tax details of the 56 applicants, Emmen's electorate - on a 54% turnout - accepted only eight of them, all Italians.

None the less the Avramovics and the others, mainly Yugoslavs, are still entitled to stay in Switzerland with their existing work permit. The exercise appears to be little more than an outlet for fear and prejudice.

The result also confirmed a trend that emerged last year in neighbouring regions, where only European Union nationals gained widespread acceptance.

Under pressure from the rightwing Swiss People's party, the practice of asking the electorate to pick new citizens has slowly gained ground in central Switzerland over the past two years. Emmen's result indicates that the process is institutionalising xenophobia.

While it is limited to only a few dozen nationality applications every year, the People's party wants to expand the process to big cities such as Zurich and Berne - to the alarm of anti-racism groups.

Switzerland's unique system of direct democracy is coveted, and reactions from opponents of the People's party have been muted. Even the official racism watchdog is waiting for the results of a comparative study of the country's complex array of local citizenship procedures.

"We don't know if there's a link between democratic choice and racial discrimination," Boël Sambuc, the vice-president of the Federal Commission against Racism, said. "But this method implies that people judge you on something that's inherent, your origin - not your individual behaviour. So we have to ask about the limits of direct democracy."

Last year 20,363 people were granted Swiss citizenship. With some towns and cantons introducing voting rights for foreigners, they may end up voting for themselves if the referendum on citizenship is extended.

Sanela Omerhodzic, 20, whose parents came here 27 years ago from Bosnia, saw it differently. "I'm very discouraged," said Omerhodzic, one of those turned down, on learning the results. "I feel Swiss. I was born in Switzerland, I went to school in Emmen, and I live there now. I work in Switzerland. It's not right."

Ms Omerhodzic, a secretary in an international accounting firm in Zurich, said she was undecided about whether to try again. "The details they ask are so personal," she said.

Swiss officials have decided to review naturalization in part because population growth is dependent on immigration. Switzerland's current population of 7.2m people grew last year only because of an increase in the number of people arriving to join relatives. The number of Swiss citizens increased by only 0.3 per cent, according to federal statistics.

webTitle: Saddam thrives on the West's failed policies

fields.headline: Saddam thrives on the West's failed policies
fields.trailText: Saddam Hussein is winning the Gulf war. Western and Arab opinion, once united in condemning and reversing his 1990 invasion of Kuwait, affords little support for the sanctions regime imposed on Iraq. The American and British governments find themselves alone in defending a policy held responsible for the deaths of tens of thousands of children and elderly people and for the impoverishment of 23m people. The sanctions are justified as the means of enforcing Security Council resolutions, particularly the demand that Iraq scrap its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programmes. But the inspections remain incomplete after the United Nations team withdrew from Baghdad in December 1998. A large-scale Anglo-American attack failed to persuade Saddam to change course. Despite a new UN resolution, the inspectors have not returned. Meanwhile the US and British air strikes in the northern and southern no-fly zones have become a symbol of allied impotence.
fields.body:
Saddam Hussein is winning the Gulf war. Western and Arab opinion, once united in condemning and reversing his 1990 invasion of Kuwait, affords little support for the sanctions regime imposed on Iraq. The American and British governments find themselves alone in defending a policy held responsible for the deaths of tens of thousands of children and elderly people and for the impoverishment of 23m people. The sanctions are justified as the means of enforcing Security Council resolutions, particularly the demand that Iraq scrap its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programmes. But the inspections remain incomplete after the United Nations team withdrew from Baghdad in December 1998. A large-scale Anglo-American attack failed to persuade Saddam to change course. Despite a new UN resolution, the inspectors have not returned. Meanwhile the US and British air strikes in the northern and southern no-fly zones have become a symbol of allied impotence.

Ten years on, Saddam's envoys have managed to destroy the Security Council consensus. France has joined Russia and China in undermining Anglo-American policy. Iraq is also making steady advances in its return to the Arab and regional fold. Last month it signed a trade deal with Turkey. A Syrian interests section has opened in Baghdad, and there is talk of reopening the Iraqi-Syrian oil pipeline shut since 1982. Leading Jordanians launch a pan-Arab campaign to normalise relations; last week Baghdad's representatives attended an Arab League meeting in Beirut. Meanwhile the flouting of the sanctions regime proceeds apace. Supplies for Iraq's elite flow across the land borders. Turkey is said to be illegally importing 1.1m barrels of Iraqi oil. US naval commanders in the gulf report an increase in Iraqi oil smuggling, aided by the Russians and Iranians. Rising oil prices are another uncomfortable indicator of Saddam's returning strength: Iraq, after all, has the world's largest crude oil reserves after Saudi Arabia. Saddam hopes to wield this power with a vengeance one day. Some believe Washington's purpose is to deny him this weapon.

Saddam's success can be measured against the West's premature victory declaration in 1991. The Clinton administration's attempts to mobilise Iraqi opposition groups, and the CIA's covert efforts to overthrow the Iraqi leader, have been half-hearted. The policy of "dual containment" of Iraq and Iran has unravelled. Despite continuing tough posturing from its UN ambassador, Richard Holbrooke, the US has lost the argument at the UN. The latest resolution proposes to ease sanctions after weapons inspections are resumed for an initial 120 days. Iraq's flat refusal to accept these conditions would once have been squashed quickly. Now most countries sympathise with Baghdad. The new chief weapons inspector, Hans Blix, may make a difference. But the inspection process remains a political minefield. Meanwhile the resignation of Hans von Sponeck, over the inadequacy of the UN's oil-for-food programme for which he was responsible, marked a new low. US and British officials insist in vain that it is Saddam who is responsible for his people's agony. The finger of blame is pointed at them.

The unstated purpose of sanctions was to isolate and bring down Saddam. This policy has failed. The human cost has been horrendous. Few believe it is morally justifiable. Few believe it will work. But to abandon the attempt to deny Iraq its weapons of mass destruction would be grossly irresponsible, surrendering the little leverage the outside world has. It would ensure that Saddam could again threaten his neighbours and Western Europe. It would be a gamble with the security of the Middle East. To drop sanctions without conditions or fulfilment of Security Council resolutions would be to shatter the credibility of the UN.

So one more effort to find a way. Suspend the non-military sanctions; bring the inspectors home; maintain the no-fly zones; watch carefully for dual-use technology imports; then press hard at the end, say, of a six-month trial period, for a settlement that will last. For at present we have the worst of all worlds. Saddam advances steadily, the UN is discredited, the West divided, and the suffering goes on.

Meanwhile the flouting of the sanctions regime proceeds apace. Supplies for Iraq's elite flow across the land borders. Turkey is said to be illegally importing 1.1m barrels of Iraqi oil. US naval commanders in the gulf report an increase in Iraqi oil smuggling, aided by the Russians and Iranians. Rising oil prices are another uncomfortable indicator of Saddam's returning strength: Iraq, after all, has the world's largest crude oil reserves after Saudi Arabia. Saddam hopes to wield this power with a vengeance one day. Some believe Washington's purpose is to deny him this weapon. Saddam's success can be measured against the West's premature victory declaration in 1991. The Clinton administration's attempts to mobilise Iraqi opposition groups, and the CIA's covert efforts to overthrow the Iraqi leader, have been half-hearted. The policy of "dual containment" of Iraq and Iran has unravelled. Despite continuing tough posturing from its UN ambassador, Richard Holbrooke, the US has lost the argument at the UN. The latest resolution proposes to ease sanctions after weapons inspections are resumed for an initial 120 days. Iraq's flat refusal to accept these conditions would once have been squashed quickly. Now most countries sympathise with Baghdad. The new chief weapons inspector, Hans Blix, may make a difference. But the inspection process remains a political minefield. Meanwhile the resignation of Hans von Sponeck, over the inadequacy of the UN's oil-for-food programme for which he was responsible, marked a new low. US and British officials insist in vain that it is Saddam who is responsible for his people's agony. The finger of blame is pointed at them. The unstated purpose of sanctions was to isolate and bring down Saddam. This policy has failed. The human cost has been horrendous. Few believe it is morally justifiable. Few believe it will work. But to abandon the attempt to deny Iraq its weapons of mass destruction would be grossly irresponsible, surrendering the little leverage the outside world has. It would ensure that Saddam could again threaten his neighbours and Western Europe. It would be a gamble with the security of the Middle East. To drop sanctions without conditions or fulfilment of Security Council resolutions would be to shatter the credibility of the UN. So one more effort to find a way. Suspend the non-military sanctions; bring the inspectors home; maintain the no-fly zones; watch carefully for dual-use technology imports; then press hard at the end, say, of a six-month trial period, for a settlement that will last. For at present we have the worst of all worlds. Saddam advances steadily, the UN is discredited, the West divided, and the suffering goes on.

webTitle: Go on Graeme, prove me wrong...

fields.headline: Go on Graeme, prove me wrong...
fields.standfirst: When Saturday Comes have a funny feeling that Souness' reign at Blackburn will not be a glorious one
fields.trailText: No matter how much football changes, it seems, one thing remains constant: there is always a job open somewhere for Graeme Souness. Blackburn's appointment of the man described by the Guardian as "an authentic teacup-throwing manager" hardly came as a surprise, but it must have had a few coaches in this country (not to mention Turkey, Italy and Portugal) shaking their head.
fields.body:
No matter how much football changes, it seems, one thing remains constant: there is always a job open somewhere for Graeme Souness. Blackburn's appointment of the man described by the Guardian as "an authentic teacup-throwing manager" hardly came as a surprise, but it must have had a few coaches in this country (not to mention Turkey, Italy and Portugal) shaking their head.

It's not so much Souness's record that makes him such a doubtful choice to lead Rovers back to Premiership glory, though to call it "patchy" would be stretching it, since it suggests there were some good patches in there. Rather, it's the idea that anyone is likely to succeed in management these days by the old-fashioned methods represented by Souness.

At the time of writing, three of the top five places in the Premiership are occupied by the three teams coached by foreigners. Although each has their own style, they clearly have several things in common: they are calm, articulate, capable of keeping big squads of big-name players happy, tactically authoritative and masters of the transfer market (Gianluca Vialli partially excepted in the last two categories).

Of course there are plenty of ranters and ravers left in the top division, though the ones who continue to prosper, such as Harry Redknapp, are those whose bluster masks a sharp footballing brain. Yet, with the exception of Alex Ferguson, it's hard to see any of the old-school managers winning the Premiership ever again.

Souness is not stupid by any means. But what the success of Wenger, Houllier and Vialli suggests is that you need the whole package to succeed now. A certain intelligence and a stack of medals is not enough.

Take the transfer market, for example. Souness, remember, is the man who gave Aly Dia a Premiership game on the say-so of someone who phoned him claiming to be George Weah. It's true that among the players he brought to Southampton was Eyal Berkovic, but then so was Ulrich van Gobbel. At his various European ports of call he trailed around a coterie of average English players, some of whom can presumably expect a call from Ewood Park (come in, Michael Thomas).

Souness doesn't score well on diplomacy either, whether towards players or the media. The latter doesn't necessarily make you a good manager, but it does at least buy you time before the pack turns on you. And turn they surely will, no matter how much of Jack Walker's crockery Souness destroys between now and his acrimonious departure.

fields.headline: Surveys, Contracts, and Reports
fields.trailText: TAX A MILLION
fields.body:
TAX A MILLION

You are the Premiership. In the 1997-8 season you raked in £569m (quite literally, seeing as the money just fell from footballing trees). When the figures for last season come out they are expected to reveal that your pockets are stuffed to the tune of £700m. So it's only natural that the last thing you want to do when you're in danger of drowning in £50 notes is to pay any tax.

Deloitte and Touche, top accountants and coincidentally the boys employed by the Premiership to assess their finances every season, claim that the government is expecting too much of Manchester United and their monetarily robust pals. Currently 25% of the Premiership's turnover ends up in the hands of Gordon Brown (that's a whole 2% more than the base rate of income tax). And as Deloitte see it, the government's greed is killing grassroots football.

Richard Baldwin, Deloitte's tax man, was seething with fiscal indignation this afternoon. "The government should actually put its hand in its pocket" he said. "It could be putting more into football initiatives rather than expecting further investment from the top clubs." A Premiership spokesman described these remarks as "a timely reminder" to the government. So Gordon, in next week's budget, why not drop the tax burden and increase public spending! It's the prudent economic sense that made the Premiership what it is today.

MR PHILLIPS

In the past few weeks, Peter Reid has persuaded five Sunderland first-team players to agree to new contracts with the club: Thomas Sorensen, Gavin McCann, Chris Makin, Alex Rae and now Kevin "born with a six yard box in his mouth" Phillips. It's also rumoured that Reid's powers of persuasion got him out of his last fine at the video shop. Perhaps there is hope for Northern Ireland yet.

The man with the simian skull was chuffed with the deal that keeps Phillips at the Stadium of Light until 2005. "Kevin is the leading goalscorer in the Premiership and an England international", said Reid. "It's a long time since we have had that at the club so I'm understandably very pleased." Phillips won't be too unhappy either. His new deal is the biggest in Sunderland's history and is believed to have made the former Baldock Town man one of the Premiership's top earners.

Since signing for Sunderland from Watford in 1997 for £650,000, Phillips has scored 85 goals in 105 games, the sort of rate your mate's little brother used to have when he played for the cubs. Along the way he broke Brian Clough's club scoring record and became the first famous person with an over-developed upper lip since John Major. With a monkey's head and a gibbon's lip, no wonder they're going bananas for Sunderland (this final sentence was brought to you in association with the UK Monkey Lover's Association).

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BOOK OF THE DAY

This wasn't meant to run and run, but what else could we do when we heard of not one, but two novels penned by Huddersfield Town boss Steve Bruce? Striker! and Sweeper! feature the adventures of totally fictional Steve Barnes, manager of First Division Leddersfield Town. Whether being framed for the murder of his star striker (Clyde Wijnhard watch out!) or foiling international terrorists, Steve never takes his eye off his real goal: promotion to the Premiership.

Striker! and Sweeper! are available from Paragon press priced £6.99 (each, unfortunately).

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ROBINSON SQUASHED

Peter Robinson today announced he will be retiring from his position as Liverpool's executive vice-chairman at the end of the season after 35 years in the job. Not usually a cue for public outpourings of grief (unless somebody had Robinson in their Fantasy Football Executives team - minus 40 points for retirement). But Robinson's impending departure is different because, for some reason, it appears he's quite popular.

Helping the club to a few trophies may have had something to do with it. "I am extremely proud that during my time with the club 27 major trophies have been won, a total which includes the league championship 12 times and the European Cup on four occasions," said Robinson at Anfield this morning, while obscuring a portrait of Graeme Souness. Liverpool's actual chairman, David Moores, said: "We shall never be able to thank Peter Robinson enough for everything he has achieved."

But before you start getting teary-eyed at the thought of a suit working his hands off for the good of the club, the Fiver must say "Pah!". Using football executives as role models can only send the wrong message to impressionable young fans. If the practice continues to its logical conclusion, nine-year-olds will start gathering at the park for a quick game of "Three grand-a-week and you're in", before returning to their bedroom to build an executive den. Peter Swales, where are you?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds manager David O'Leary O'Leeds is believed to be lining up a £6m move for West Ham's England U-21 midfielder Frank Lampard.

Inter Milan and Parma are both reportedly eyeing up Chelsea striker Tore Andre Flo. But Chelsea boss Gianluca Vialli is desperate to hang on to the £15m-rated Norwegian international.

Everton keeper Thomas Myhre could leave the club and return to Norway. He told a Norwegian newspaper he was deeply surprised at being dropped by Walter Smith.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Aberdeen are ready to offer coach Ebbe Skovdahl an extended contract, despite the Dons' historically bad start to the season. With an unlikely cup double now on the horizon, Aberdeen chairman Stewart Milne said: "Ebbe is the manager the club has been looking for since Alex Ferguson left."

Spurs winger Ruel Fox is poised to rejoin Norwich City on loan for the rest of the season. Fox, who started his career at the club, could return in time for Sunday's local derby against Ipswich.

fields.headline: Alchemists move in
fields.trailText: Rover, the last remnant of the once-mighty British car industry, is to be run by an obscure company of venture capitalists whose main experience has been in running pubs and restaurants.
fields.body:
Rover, the last remnant of the once-mighty British car industry, is to be run by an obscure company of venture capitalists whose main experience has been in running pubs and restaurants.

Details of the extraordinary deal are still emerging. German car maker BMW is selling the Rover and MG brands to Alchemy Partners, along with the ailing Longbridge factory in Birmingham, where Rover 25 and 45 models will continue to be produced alongside the MGF sports car and the 41-year-old Mini.

BMW will retain the more modern plant at Cowley, outside Oxford, where it will continue to produce the Rover 75 saloon under contract for Alchemy. Pre-production work on the new Supermini will move from Longbridge to Cowley, and the new car will remain a BMW model.

As a further complication, the German company is reported to be negotiating the sale of the highly profitable Land Rover division to an unnamed car company. Most analysts had assumed that of all the remaining Rover assets, the four-wheel-drive specialist was the most attractive to BMW.

The Munich-based company says that the disposal of Rover and MG will cost it nearly £2bn. It is not clear how much of that money will end up in the hands of Alchemy, or whether the venture capital company is paying anything for its startling new asset.

Alchemy is a relatively small company, set up in January 1997. It has £491m of funds invested in management buy-outs, company ''turnarounds'' and other speculative ventures. It also manages some £225m of outside investors' funds.

The company website stresses its eagerness for big challenges: "We welcome complex transactions and turnarounds. We are not dissuaded by difficulty - rather we see it as an opportunity. Our contribution is that we are prepared to make the necessary effort to evaluate a proposed transaction using our wide skill base and industrial experience.

"Alchemy are generalists and invest in most business sectors. However, an area of special expertise and experience is brewing, pubs, restaurants and hotels."

Alchemy clearly believes in getting quickly off the mark: "We respond very quickly to proposals. Our internal process is driven towards an early consideration of a transaction by our investment committee to provide assurance of our commitment as early as possible."

The website also warns potential investors that putting their money into Alchemy "will involve a high degree of risk".

Jon Moulton, managing partner of Alchemy, is a graduate in chemistry and a chartered accountant. His past chairmanships and directorships include Parker Pen, Sheffield Forgemasters, Xenova, Hornby Hobbies, RJB Mining plc, Technology plc and Brands Hatch. The other partners are similarly devoid of experience in the management of large manufacturing enterprises. None has any obvious connection with the automotive sector.

The company's home page proudly offers the dictionary definition of its own name as "medieval chemistry, esp. pursuit of transmutation of base metals into gold".

fields.headline: Gloom greets Rover's new owners
fields.standfirst: Reaction to BMW's sale of Rover to venture capitalists Alchemy Partners
fields.trailText:
"Longbridge will be reduced in size. but not closed. We are not asset strippers. There will be a reduced workforce, but that workforce will be in rewarding jobs with security. "

Jon Moulton, Alchemy's managing partner
fields.body:
"Longbridge will be reduced in size. but not closed. We are not asset strippers. There will be a reduced workforce, but that workforce will be in rewarding jobs with security. "

Jon Moulton, Alchemy's managing partner

"Alchemy is a company with no track record. I find it difficult to believe that they have the finance in the medium and long term to keep this car plant open. Certainly, it would be impossible in my view for them to fund the design, development and introduction of new models. Therefore if these proposals are not changed, Longbridge has no future."

TGWU representative Tony Woodley

"There is an air of uncertainty hanging over the workforce. We are back to square one again. Everybody in there is worried."

Ali Khan, Longbridge worker

"There is a sense of inevitability about what has happened and there is a sense of being betrayed. A lot of people thought this would happen in the long run. We are here to support the workers if they want to come to us with their worries. There is anger among the workers at the way they are being told. They wanted to know what was happening before the press did."

The Rev Peter Thomas, one of three chaplains at the plant

"Alchemy will have to demonstrate their commitment to the loyal workforce. The next stage is to sit down with Alchemy to discuss their proposals."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of engineering union the AEEU

"I can't believe that these decisions have been taken and that Longbridge is being, in a sense, cast to the wolves."

Councillor Albert Bore, leader of Birmingham City Council

"Our members bought into changes to working practices 15 months ago and during that period there has been significant improvement and productivity and quality in return for job security, in as much as the new medium-sized car going into Longbridge was providing them with a long-term future. We see this abrogation of that agreement as a betrayal of the people's good faith and trust in the company. We are not about to stand around idly and let that happen."

AEEU representative Duncan Simpson

fields.headline: Violence 'driving women from their homes'
fields.standfirst: Housing charity Shelter has identified domestic violence as one of the chief causes of homelessness.
fields.trailText: Housing charity Shelter has identified domestic violence as one of the chief causes of homelessness.
fields.body:
When the beatings got so bad that Christina finally left her husband, she never dreamed that three years later she and her children would still be living in a two-bedroom "temporary" council flat.

"I thought having three children would make us eligible for a house," said Christina, 31, who sleeps in the living room. "They never made it clear we would be in this position and it would take so long."

Christina's case is one of hundreds handled by Shelter, the housing charity, which today identifies domestic violence as one of the chief causes of homelessness.

During the first 12 months of the charity's free telephone advice service, Shelterline, domestic violence accounted for almost 2,700 calls.

All but 600 were from women facing the loss of their home because they needed to leave for their own safety.

Shelter is calling for a change in the law so that people fleeing domestic violence are automatically accorded priority need when applying to councils as homeless.

The charity says such people have often suffered severe trauma and have complex needs.

"Many will have suffered years of domestic violence before seeking advice. It is vital that when they do there is an effective response."

Christina, which is not her real name, spent four months in a women's refuge after leaving the family home in Hertfordshire. A court order had not stopped harassment by her husband and he moved back into the home as soon as it expired.

When the local council subsequently allocated the flat to Christina and her children, aged four, seven and eight, she was told it would be for at least six months but no longer than two years.

"There is no space for the children to play and nowhere to put their toys," said Christina, who is studying at college.

"What we really need is a house with a garden where we can settle and stay, so that they are settled down before they go to secondary school."

Shelter says the problems facing homless families are being compounded by acute shortages of housing in many parts of southern England, causing some councils to refuse to re-house women and their children even where social services recommend it under the children act.

The charity reports that almost 60% of the domestic violence calls to its advice line came from single women. A majority of those were from women without children, leaving them with less legal protection and fewer housing rights.

Almost one in 10 callers saying they had suffered domestic violence, and faced loss of their home, was a man.

Shelterline, which is supported by BT, took 82,000 calls in its first year. Almost 47,000 were from people already homeless, or about to become so, and more than 27,000 were from people who said they risked sleeping rough that night.

As well as domestic violence, Shelter identifies financial troubles and the lack of a safety net for single people as the main causes of homelessness.

Chris Holmes, the charity's director, said some vulnerable people were getting no help under housing law. "Only substantial government investment in new homes and legislative action will turn this situation around to ensure these people have a future."

 Shelterline is on 0808-800-4444.

webTitle: Speculation links Yahoo and Ebay link

fields.headline: Speculation links Yahoo and Ebay link
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: There was strong speculation last night that Yahoo, the California-based internet portal, is poised to play a role in the consolidation beginning to grip the new media sector.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in Detroit  and David Teather
fields.body:
There was strong speculation last night that Yahoo, the California-based internet portal, is poised to play a role in the consolidation beginning to grip the new media sector.

Shares in online auctioneer EBay rose sharply following reports on CNBC, a US financial cable company closely followed by day traders, that the two companies had held talks about a possible alliance or merger. The station quoted sources which said there was a 50-50 chance of a partnership between the companies being struck in the next two weeks.

A separate report in USA Today said negotiations between the pair had already fallen apart on price. Neither Yahoo nor EBay would comment on what they described as "market speculation". Yahoo has a broad range of alliances in place with other companies, from media organisations, such as Reuters, to e-commerce businesses.

It has also held talks with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation about investing in the media group's satellite operations in recent months. In public, Yahoo, which has the second most popular portal after America Online, has committed itself to an independent future. But the $190bn (£121bn) merger between America Online and Time Warner earlier this year has worried rivals fearful of being left behind.

Yahoo has grown from a business four years ago which had two employees and no users or revenues. Its revenues run at $300m a year and the company claims to have 50m users a month.

Last year it did two deals valued at $10bn when it acquired Geocities and Broadcast.com aimed at building its presence in key internet markets. Yahoo has launched its own auction market but trails far behind EBay.

The deals last year were financed by Yahoo paper, although the price of its shares more recently has stalled. Separately EBay announced a deal with First-e, the internet bank making it easier for auctions to be settled between the US and Britain.

webTitle: How much can you pay for . . .

fields.headline: How much can you pay for . . .
fields.standfirst: . . . a coathanger
fields.trailText: . . . a coathanger
fields.body: Anyone who has worked in a cloakroom for any length of time knows that coathangers are not objects to be regarded with affection. They're evil, selfish things: they bend obstinately into the wrong arm, just as the going-home queue disappears out of sight round the corner, or pretend suddenly to be too weak to hold the coat at all and flop in a helpless, girly sort of way. So why womenswear chain Whistles has seen fit to set a designer on them is anyone's guess: £180 they're charging for Anna Bang's dolled-up coathanger, for any fool stupid enough to pay it. And what do you get for that? A bit of silk wrapped round your metal bits, and then some dingly-dangly sequins. And where are you going to keep it? Not in your wardrobe, with clothes on it, obviously. On a nail on the wall perhaps, or next to the pile of coffee-table books and the copy of Wallpaper magazine.

fields.headline: Are you being served?
fields.standfirst: Dirty work has become big business. There are now 4m cleaners, nannies and gardeners in Britain - and blue chip firms such as Unilever are moving in on the act.  Esther Addley  reports
fields.trailText: Dirty work has become big business. There are now 4m cleaners, nannies and gardeners in Britain - and blue chip firms such as Unilever are moving in on the act.
fields.body:
'If you've got a minute, read on," reads the myhome website, the new laundry and domestic cleaning service launched by Unilever on the internet this week. And while its purpose is to attract people who are short of time, myhome thinks the minutes you spend finding out what it can do for you will be worth it. Its big selling point is that more than ever before, time is more precious than money.

The economy may be booming and wage levels rising but Britons still work the longest hours in Europe. The "cash-rich, time-poor" generation brings home bumper bonuses but never quite finds the time to spend them. Unilever, the soap and soup manufacturing group behind myhome, is gambling on today's solvent but stressed execs wanting to spend its surplus cash on freeing up a few more hours in the day. Via myhome, it finds someone else to do those nasty little time-consuming jobs everyone hates.

Four million people work in domestic service, which is the UK's biggest growth industry, expanding faster even than new media companies. There are more cleaners, gardeners and nannies in the workforce than accountants. According to the office for national statistics, more people are employed in household help and childcare than in 1900, reversing the trend of slow decline over the first threequarters of the past century. Servants, it would appear, are back.

"Domestic staff are now seen as an essential rather than a luxury," says Katherine Shields, manager of Staff of Distinction, a London domestic help agency. "There's a definite rise in people needing staff, but the type of people looking for staff is changing. It's not just the upper classes now."

Increasingly, she says, clients are middle-class couples both of whom work. "They need someone to do the chores they don't have time to do, like housekeeping, preparing the meals, running for the dry cleaning, and picking up the kids from school."

The agency also supplies butlers, nannies and "housekeeping couples", where the wife is housekeeper/cook and the husband gardener-cum-chauffeur. However, if your time is money, so is theirs. A live-in housekeeper can expect £250 a week net, plus full board, including, perhaps, use of a car. A nanny in London is paid about £300 a week.

For significant numbers of people, that sort of money is no longer an obstacle. Last year the Inland Revenue launched a helpline for people who employ household staff, such was the demand for advice on tax and national insurance from the new time-strapped employer class.

Jonathan Wallace is one of those who claims to be able to "buy people back time". As client service director of Entrust, a concierge company in London which promises to organise away any problem thrown at it, he compares himself to a freelance PA. "Because people are having to work very hard to earn their good money, it's important that they have assistance at hand," he says. "Who wants to work silly hours all week and have to traipse all round 15 estate agents at the weekend? Why not get a home search agent to do it for you? People these days are earning good salaries and are prepared to pay a little extra to save time."

A payment of £125 a month buys the personal attention of Wallace or one of his colleagues, and subscribers may phone him as many times a day as they like; no request is too much trouble. He has been asked to ship an entire wine cellar to Singapore, to organise a marquee for a wedding in Sri Lanka, and to lay his hands on a Winnie the Pooh bear in 20 minutes.

"People will ask us to find a dog-walker or a tailor-made travel agent, or perhaps they need tax and wealth advice. Obviously it's for a fee, but it cuts out the whole degree of hassle."

The company's clients, he says, are "reasonably wealthy, but very busy" lawyers, accountants and people working in media or in the City. "The trend is for people to put a monetary value against their free time," says Mike Godliman, director of Verdict, a retail analyst. "We have an ageing population in this country. The number of people between 40 and 60 is increasing and their time is precious. The last thing you want when you have limited time is to spend it doing chores."

He sees Unilever's diversification into the service industry as instructive at a time when we spend half our household income on services, compared to less than 30% in the 60s. "The old distinctions between company roles are disappearing; supermarkets are becoming banks, fast food companies are going into hotels."

The fuss over the spectacular ascent of internet companies, several of which have just unceremoniously kicked established companies such as Whitbread and Imperial Tobacco out of the FTSE 100 index, conceals the fact that most of the newcomers offer services rather than products. No wonder Unilever, Sainsbury's and the others want to invest too.

"Manufacturing companies are not the growth area," says Godliman. "They are being overtaken by other companies that are usually service companies. More and more, people are diversifying into new areas."

Having someone else do the dirty work means never having to face a big pile of ironing after a 10-hour day at the office. "We are all interested in having a clean home and clothes without the hassle of either doing the task or worrying about how it is going to turn out," says Esra Erkal-Paler, of Lever Brothers, a Unilever subsidiary. "We all just want to come in from work and relax in a brilliantly clean home, or open the wardrobe to a beautifully ironed shirt first thing in the morning.

"People want to achieve the end result without having to go through the hassle themselves, especially when they could be doing something more enjoyable."

A multinational like Unilever clearly thinks it can make money by going into domestic service supply, rather than just making the soaps and chemicals used in the cleaning process. A "Jif Homeclean" of a three-bedroom flat costs £61, while a quick rustle through my laundry bin, calculator in hand, turned up the slightly alarming estimate of £60.55 for a "Persil Service" next-day wash and iron. So far, myhome only only operates in south west London but will be available in 88 areas all over the UK within 18 months.

Britain's new employer class may be time-poor, but myhome will be banking on a significant enough number of them being cash-rich enough to use it. But for those whose wage slip bottom line isn't quite there yet, a bottle of Jif and a pair of Marigold rubber gloves cost about £2.34 at the local supermarket.

fields.headline: Online restaurant booking
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is no longer good enough to dine at the trendiest restaurants in town - if you really want to demonstrate that you have style, you need to book online.
fields.body:
It is no longer good enough to dine at the trendiest restaurants in town - if you really want to demonstrate that you have style, you need to book online.

www.Book2eat.com claims to be the UK's first "real-time" online booking service, linking diners directly to restaurants. Each of the 50 restaurants involved is in London, although there are plans to expand. If you have decided where you want to eat, complete the online form and you will receive an immediate response, either confirming the booking or suggesting the nearest time available. The site links into restaurants' homepages and will let you browse through menus and wine lists. As the service is free, there's no need to part with credit card details.

At www.toptable.co.uk you can "book the unbookable" - Le Gavroche, City Rhodes and Momo included. There are more than 500 restaurants on the site, which has venues in Manchester, Leeds, Glasgow and Birmingham. Toptable has a number of exclusive table allocations at all of the featured restaurants, but will book more as required. Checking table availability is straightforward - click on a restaurant and a list of dates and available time slots will appear on screen. There are other nice touches, like the 360-degree room tours.

The London and Paris restaurants at www.lastminute.com, also work on the basis of allocated tables. If you can't see the table you want on screen, they will try to help. Credit card details are required and you could face a "no-show" charge if you fail to turn up without cancelling.

fields.headline: Free to all comers

This knowledge belongs to us all

Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton and Tony Blair's joint statement on Tuesday calling for the genetic code for human beings to be freely available was a useful signal. But in reality, Mr Clinton and Mr Blair's urging that scientists share their research will have little or no effect on the activities and patent applications of the US biotechnology company Celera and its scientist-entrepreneur, Craig Venter.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton and Tony Blair's joint statement on Tuesday calling for the genetic code for human beings to be freely available was a useful signal. But in reality, Mr Clinton and Mr Blair's urging that scientists share their research will have little or no effect on the activities and patent applications of the US biotechnology company Celera and its scientist-entrepreneur, Craig Venter, who is pledged to produce the first map of the human genome this year - for subscribers only.

What lies ahead is a battle which will help define the 21st century. On one side are those - including Mr Clinton and Mr Blair - who argue that the composition of human DNA must remain in the public domain, accessible to future researchers and inventors. On the other are the growing number of US biotechnology companies such as Celera which have applied for wholesale patents on large lumps of genetic material, rather as mining prospectors will stake claims to huge tracts of land in a gold rush.

The battle will primarily take place in the US because it is the world leader in biotechnology. At stake is an unprecedented avalanche of information about human beings which could revolutionise medicine; who will use that information and for what purposes? The one thing we do not have to work this out is time; the slow development of patent case law is not the answer. On one side are those - including Mr Clinton and Mr Blair - who argue that the composition of human DNA must remain in the public domain, accessible to future researchers and inventors. fields.headline: Venture capitalists buy Rover for £2bn
fields.standfirst: Fears that car company is being 'thrown to the wolves'
fields.trailText: The London-based venture capitalist company Alchemy is to take over the Rover motor company in a dramatic £2bn deal, it was announced today.
fields.body:
The London-based venture capitalist company Alchemy is to take over the Rover motor company in a dramatic £2bn deal, it was announced today.

Rover's owners, BMW of Germany, confirmed that negotiations had started for the sale of the Rover and MG brands, as well as its production facilities at Longbridge, Birmingham, to Alchemy Partners.

Alchemy, which is to call the new business the MG Car Company, confirmed the acquisition in a brief statement.

"The new company will focus on development of a state-of-the-art British-built product range worthy of the sporting heritage of the MG name," it said.

Jon Moulton, managing partner at Rover's new owners Alchemy, said Longbridge would be reduced in size, but not closed. He said Alchemy planned to sell Rover again in five to six years once it had been returned to profitability.

The leader of Birmingham city council, Albert Bore, described the news from Munich as devastating: "I can't believe that these decisions have been taken and that Longbridge is being, in a sense, cast to the wolves."

Union leaders called for talks with the relatively unknown Covent Garden-based venture capitalist group, which has no previous motor industry involvement. Its partners compare themselves to a "pack of hunting dogs".

Bill Morris, general secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, said: "We very much regret the decision to sell off parts of Rover and we are now urgently trying to meet with Alchemy."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the engineering union AEEU, also called on Alchemy to "demonstrate their commitment" to the workers of Longbridge. "The next stage is to sit down with Alchemy to discuss their proposals," he said.

Sir Ken said the last few years had "shattered" the confidence of Rover workers and Alchemy would have to restore the lost trust.

He added: "I am certain the government will offer the new owners the financial support they will need and we will play our part in this partnership."

In an official statement, BMW chairman Professor Joachim Milberg said that BMW had successfully turned around the loss-making Rover since buying it in 1995, but Rover had been undermined by the strength of the pound.

"With exchange rates versus the pound continuing to decline, mass producers on the European continent have a growing advantage in competition," Prof Milberg said. "Precisely this is why the board of management has decided to take a clear and consistent step."

"A further point is that the product offensives we initiated with the Rover 75, 25 and 45 were not as successful as we had hoped," he said.

Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster-general, one-time chief executive of Jaguar and Labour MP for Coventry North West, said it was not exchange rates but BMW that was to blame.

"It's not an issue of the exchange rate, though that's certainly unhelpful," Mr Robinson told BBC Radio 4. "The fundamental issues are the productivity and the quality of the Rover factories and the products they produce, and there BMW quite clearly have not put in the efforts that were required to do the job."

BMW will retain the new Mini, with production moving from Longbridge to BMW's Cowley plant for its launch in summer 2001.

But rumours surround the future of Range Rover, with TGWU representative Tony Woodley saying that Prof Milberg had told him that Land Rover too was to be sold off to another European buyer.

BMW's official statement also confirmed its intention to hold on to its £400m engine plant at Hams Hall in the Midlands, which will begin operations as planned when its construction is completed.

Alchemy will take over the production of Rover 25 and 45 with BMW continuing to supply Alchemy with the Rover 75, produced at Cowley in Oxford, on the basis of a "job contract".

The disposal of Rover and MG is costing BMW 3.15 billion euros [nearly £2 billion], BMW said.
