fields.headline: Black gold
fields.standfirst: The fluctuating price of oil has always had a corresponding effect on the economy. But there is now a political dimension to the equation
fields.trailText: The fluctuating price of oil has always had a corresponding effect on the economy. But there is now a political dimension to the equation
fields.body:
The 70s have returned to haunt us with a vengeance. First it was flares and disco, now the soaring price of oil is threatening a re-run of that decade's energy crisis. Then the spike in oil prices heralded the onset of a global recession. Some economists think the seeds of the next one have already been sown. Yet there are good reasons for believing the impact of dearer oil will not be anything like as damaging this time around.

The first is that the real level of oil prices is not that high, after taking inflation into account. Now at around $30 a barrel, oil prices have tripled from the near record lows they were at a year ago and are higher than at any time since the Gulf war. But they are not that far off their long term average. Moreover, the price is likely to fall.

Until now prices have been propped up by two things, First there is rising world demand as the global economy recovers from the slowdown associated with the financial crisis which swept markets in 1997 and 1998. Then there are cutbacks in production by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec). A one-year Opec supply cut agreed last March slashed about 4m barrels per day from its production.

Although the global economy is likely to strengthen, oil production will almost certainly begin to rise soon. Opec is due to meet on March 27 to decide on output from then onwards. Under heavy pressure from the United States, where cheap petrol for vehicles is almost a constitutional right, Opec is widely expected to ease supply restrictions. Whether its increase in production will be enough to close the 2m-barrels-per-day gap between demand and supply remains uncertain.

But even if it is not, there are grounds for optimism that the strength of the oil price will not end in economic disaster.

Since the 70s, the industrialised economies have become much less dependent on oil. Energy conservation and industrial restructuring, which has shifted the emphasis away from heavy manufacturing towards services, means that oil is a less significant factor of production. America, for example, now burns only half as much oil per dollar of real GDP as it did back on the early 70s, according to the American economist Paul Krugman. "So the odds are against a full-dress replay of the energy crisis."

Even in those parts of the economy where high oil prices still have the potential to cause harm, there is less of a threat then before. Take manufacturing, for example. Figures published on Monday showed that the energy component of the UK's producer prices index is increasing at its fastest rate since 1974. In the past, firms would have simply raised their output prices to compensate, triggering the sort of wage/price spiral that did so much damage in the 70s.

But increased global competition and the waning power of trade unions means that sort of knee-jerk response is no longer possible. Instead, manufacturers are having to take the hit on their profit margins and devise ways of becoming more efficient. As a vivid illustration of this point, UK output prices rose by just 0.1% in February. Eventually, strengthening domestic and global demand might mean that manufacturers and retailers are able to pass on some of the cost increases they are experiencing as a result of the oil price surge. Such a development would not, however, go unnoticed by central banks, which are now much more vigilant than they were about inflation.

At a meeting in Basle this week, the Group of 10 (G10) central banking committee, representing the most powerful central banks, signalled that the oil price was one of the main inflation danger signals that they were watching closely. "There was a recognition that an excessive rise in oil prices is not in the interest of any part of the world economy," said Bank of England governor Eddie George, speaking as chairman of the committee. "It is obviously not in the interests of oil-consuming countries because of the factor linked to inflation, and that would be a factor in a tightening of monetary policy at some point."

His remarks made clear that the first hint of dearer oil passing along the price chain will almost certainly be met with a barrage of increments in interest rates, which are already on their way up.

In this scenario, aggressive tightening of monetary policy over and above that already expected in financial markets could well be the trigger for a global recession. But a further precondition for this happening would be continuing restriction in supply by Opec. While the modern day Sheikh Yamanis may be relishing the power they now have over the west, they know that the strategy of continuing to restrict supply in the face of a global recession would ultimately be self-defeating.

Opec has a strong self interest in a high oil price because it boosts revenue for its members, many of whom produce little else for world markets. Beneficiaries include Venezuela, which was devastated by mud slides last year and will be able to use the cash to repair its damaged infrastructure. But Opec must also keep prices low enough to permit continued global expansion. Other wise, demand for oil dries up and the price plunges. After their economic woes in recent years from the low oil price, most Opec countries are going to be reluctant to revisit the past so quickly.

Added to economic self interest, there is also a powerful political and diplomatic side to the oil price equation. Having fought off Saddam Hussein with the help of Uncle Sam, countries such as Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are reluctant to face American ire. While mindless greed can never be discounted as a determinant of human behaviour, it seems highly unlikely that the gulf states which make up Opec's core membership will be foolish enough to risk losing armed American protection. Next time a ruthless dictator invades, they might find themselves alone on the battlefield.

 Mark Atkinson is the Guardian economics correspondent

fields.headline: BMW's full statement
fields.trailText: Reorientation
fields.body:
Reorientation

All new BMW model series for the lower midsize range Rover and MG brands should be continued by Alchemy Partners

1999 year of business

Annual surplus of the BMW Group prior to extraordinary result with 663m million(£408m) far higher than last year
Dividend remaining stable in 1999
Reorientation involves one-off, non-recurring expenditure of euro 3,150 million.

Munich The board of management of the BMW group has decided this week on the principal considerations in reorienting the company and the supervisory board today agreed to the new strategy. This means that the BMW group will be focusing on brands which already have a leading position in their respective segments.

The distribution of the Rover and MG brands as well as their production facilities for these vehicles in Birmingham are to be maintained and continued by Alchemy Partners. Negotiations have started on the basis of an offer submitted by Alchemy Partners for this purpose.

All-new BMW model series

The BMW brand is currently as strong as hardly any other car brand the world over. Now the BMW group will capitalise on and further expand this position of strength. The BMW group has therefore decided to build on all-new model series under the BMW brand for the upper end of the lower midrange segment. The decision on where this model series will be built has not yet been taken.

Joachim Milberg, the chairman of the board of the BMW group, announced this new development in Munich on Thursday: The new model series will consistently expand and strengthen BMWs entry-level position with the BMW standard. It will be a typical BMW! And it will therefore occupy and maintain a unique position in the upper part of the lower midsize range.

Restructuring of the Groups corporate units in Great Britain

In this process of the reorientation of the BMW group, the corporate units belonging to Rover Group Ltd are to be restructured. The Rover and MG brands as well as the production facilities for these vehicles in Birmingham are to be continued by Alchemy Partners. Negotiations have already started on the basis of an offer submitted by Alchemy Partners for this purpose.

The BMW group will continue to supply Alchemy Partners with the Rover 75 on the basis of a job contract. For a certain period of transition the BMW group will furthermore support Alchemy Partners in All necessary areas. Milberg says, We will do this in order to provide the quality of support. On that our customers can rely. Following successful conclusion of the negotiations the Rover and MG brands will be regrouped together within a new company under British management.

The original strategy was to compete through the Rover brand with mass-produced cars in the lower midrange segment. According to Professor Milberg, however, this Rover strategy within the BMW Group has turned out to be inappropriate for various reasons. Although the Rover turnaround was successful last year, the constant increase in the value of the British pound has more than set off this success. Milberg says, A further point is that the product offensive we initiated with the Rover 75, 25 and 45 was not as successful as we had hoped.

Yet a futher point was that new investments of the amount forseen at the Birmingham plant, in particular for a new lower midrange Rover, had to be reviewed and considered more conservatively due to the high value of the British pound. With exchange rates versus the pound continuing to decline, mass producers on the European continent have a growing advantage in competition. Precisely this is why the board of management has decided to take a clear and consistent step. Millberg: "Even with an extreme increase in productivity or through an extreme shift in sourcing into Euroland, we would no longer have been able to set off such burdens beyond our control.

Reorientation of the BMW Group - summary

 Responsibility for the Rover and MG brands, for the Birmingham plant and for sales of cars built in Birmingham is to be assumed by a new owner. Negotiations have already been started on the basis of an offer submitted by Alchemy Partners and we wish to quickly wind up these negotiations with a successful result.

 Investments for the production of the new Mini in Birmingham are being stopped and will be continued instead at the Oxford plant. The new Mini will be launched into the market in early summer 2001.

 Production of the Rover 75 will be continued at the Oxford plant on behalf of Alchemy Partners. Sales and distribution of the car will then be handled by Alchemy Partners itself.

 An all-new model series will be developed within the BMW brand for the upper end of the lower midrange segment. This model series will then hold a special, unique position in that part of the market.

 The BMW group's new engine plant in Hams Hall in the British Midlands will be completed and enter operation as planned.

 The group's plans regarding the location of the plant in Britain for production of an all new Rolls-Royce as of 2003 are not affected by this reorientation.

The board of management submitted this reorientation of the group to the supervisory board on March 16 and the supervisory board expressed their approval.

fields.headline: Alchemy Partners' full statement
fields.standfirst: 'The new company will focus on developing a state of the art British-built product range worthy of the sporting heritage of the MG name'
fields.trailText: Alchemy Partners is pleased to announce the impending launch of the MG Car company following today's outline agreement with BMW to acquire Rover Group.
fields.body:
Alchemy Partners is pleased to announce the impending launch of the MG Car company following today's outline agreement with BMW to acquire Rover Group.

The new company will continue with Rover's current model range of the 25, 45 and 75, the old Mini and the MGF will provide ongoing service to Rover's customers.

The new company will focus on developing a state of the art British-built product range worthy of the sporting heritage of the MG name.

The product will use the latest developments in composite and aluminium body technology and will appeal to the motoring enthusiast well versed in the history of the marque going back to the former Morris Garages which started modifying standard Morris Cowleys in 1922.

The MG Car Company will be synonymous with British technology and manufacturing know-how at its best, producing cars which are sought after in the medium volume segment of the market.

The new company will be a responsible custodian of the MG brand and the entire current Rover model range investing in and taking its product to new levels of desirability.

It is expected that the MG Car Company will employ a significant workforce and will rapidly develop into a self-standing highly viable British car manufacturer.

fields.headline: Come, friendly pigeons
fields.standfirst: Bill Woodrow's new sculpture for Trafalgar Square isn't a patch on the last occupant of the 'fourth plinth', says  Adrian Searle . He has a solution
fields.trailText: Bill Woodrow's sculpture, the second of three projects for the empty "fourth plinth" in Trafalgar Square, was unveiled yesterday at noon.
fields.body:
Bill Woodrow's sculpture, the second of three projects for the empty "fourth plinth" in Trafalgar Square, was unveiled yesterday at noon.

A head rests on its side on the top of the plinth, as though sleeping. A big, closed book lies on top of the head. A tree grows atop the lot, its roots writhing over the head and book, growing down over the lip of the plinth, finding purchase on the vertical granite sides below. The tree is bare, its branches jagged and stormswept. The roots are gnarly and intestinal, grabbing the plinth like an octopus grasping its prey. Woodrow's Regardless of History is cast from bronze, just like all the other statues in the square. Unlike Mark Wallinger's Christ, which recently vacated the plinth, and which was disconcertingly life-sized, it shares the self-important scale of its surroundings.

Wallinger's sculpture was both exceptionally simple and metaphorically rich - both a meditation on the real and the symbolic, and a mediation between the everyday and the allegorical. Woodrow also asks us to look at his sculpture in terms of its possible meanings and symbolism. Both Woodrow's bronze head and Wallinger's Christ have their eyes closed. There the similarities end.

Woodrow, like Richard Deacon, Tony Cragg, Richard Wentworth and Antony Gormley, was one of the generation of new British sculptors who provided a bridge between the redoubtably modernist sculptors who preceded them (and taught them) and the YBAs. But lineage is deceptive, and Woodrow's career has appeared to run in reverse.

He first came to public attention with witty manipulations of real objects - car doors, old sofas, filing cabinets and washing machines - which he tin-snipped, cut and folded into other objects. A washing machine transmogrified into a guitar; an old car door, an ironing board and a washing machine were cut and folded into a native American head-dress. Woodrow abandoned these witty recyclings in the late 80s. His recent work adopts the monumentality of the 19th-century heavy metal public bronze.

However much it strains for potency and a shared symbolic language, Woodrow's work (like Anthony Caro's) has become irredeemably crass. Little remains of the genuine pleasure, lightness and inventiveness of what went before. I have tried not to write about Woodrow's work for 10 years, hoping that things would get better.

But the sculpture for the plinth is a woefully inept kind of schoolboy symbolism. Woodrow's failure could not be more nakedly apparent than it is here in Trafalgar Square. He may want to speak in the plainest common language, but that doesn't mean he has to lose all his formal ingenuity. Yet he has. The modelling of the sleeping bronze head is unconvincingly generic and inarticulate. The book, with its dull red cover, seems to say "weighty tome". The tree (let's not forget that Giacometti made the most deliciously articulate, simple tree for the first production of Beckett's Godot) is a sort of cartoon - cue lightning flashes and sound- effects wolf howl.

The whole effect is similar to a kids' movie. More than this, the sculpture is orientated so that the most essential part of it, the head, remains in shadow for most of the day. Surely sculpture is articulated by light, as well as mass and form. It's all wrong. The best thing about the sculpture is to imagine birds alighting on the branches, like the crows on the climbing frame in Hitchcock's The Birds.

"Regardless of History," says the caption fixed to the plinth, "makes reference to the never-ending relationship between civilisation, knowledge and the forces of nature." History is a nightmare, in other words, and Woodrow's sculpture is trying to get a good night's sleep.

Earlier this week Antony Gormley called for a debate about contemporary public sculpture in our cities. Regardless of History won't help; nor does it do anything but offer an awful warning. We should see this sculpture as not so much profound as profoundly mistaken - a saddening folly.

fields.headline: What the German papers say
fields.trailText:
Berliner Morgenpost
Christine Berg of the DG bank understands why BMW wants to concentrate on top-of-the-range models, where the profit margins are larger. "For BMW a niche position is better than owning a failing middle range of motors." Porsche, highly profitable and independent, point the way. Ms Berg does not believe that shifting the Rover factory from Britain to Hungary is not a realistic solution: "That also becomes expensive," she says.
fields.body:
Berliner Morgenpost
Christine Berg of the DG bank understands why BMW wants to concentrate on top-of-the-range models, where the profit margins are larger. "For BMW a niche position is better than owning a failing middle range of motors." Porsche, highly profitable and independent, point the way. Ms Berg does not believe that shifting the Rover factory from Britain to Hungary is not a realistic solution: "That also becomes expensive," she says.

Sueddeutsche Zeitung
BMW's plan to sell Rover does not solve all its losses at one blow. No one would be so stupid as to buy a car firm that is losing billions. One assumes that BMW must pay the purchasers of Rover to encourage the sale, which could cost further billions.

It would also be an unpleasant decision to close Longbridge factory with its 9000 workers. But it would leave [BMW chairman] Milberg to finally concentrate on the management of BMW, without having to constantly think about Rover losses. Milberg has many opponents, and those are not eliminated just because three members of the board are fired.

Wolfgang Ehrensberger, Die Welt
The strategy of the 90's, inextricably linked to former chief executive Bernd Pischetsrieder and his mentor Eberhard von Kuenheim, stipulated that BMW would only survive as an independent car maker if it increased the volume of its production and became a mass market business. For fear of watering down its own brand, it bought Rover to expand its mass production.

This strategy failed. BMW's Munich workers only half-heartedly took to the British. New models did not succeed. And the expensive pound did the rest.

webTitle: Push to remove diplomatic status of BNFL employee

fields.headline: Push to remove diplomatic status of BNFL employee
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has been pressing the foreign office to withdraw diplomatic status from a British Nuclear Fuels employee working at the British embasssy in Tokyo.
fields.body:
Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has been pressing the foreign office to withdraw diplomatic status from a British Nuclear Fuels employee working at the British embasssy in Tokyo.

It is understood that Mr Meacher has been given a sympathetic hearing by Robin Cook, the foreign secretary.

Mr Meacher first raised the issue with foreign office officials about a year ago. He is understood to believe it is outrageous that BNFL has been paying £500,000 a year for one of its employees to have full diplomatic status.

The department of trade and industry insists that no precedent or protocol has been breached by allowing the employee to work from the embassy as counsellor (atomic energy).

Conservative sources have admitted that reports from the embassy in the name of the ambassador, written by the employee, Tom McLaughlan, gave an excessively optimistic view of BNFL markets.

The foreign office said its officials had no record of any representation from Mr Meacher, but other sources close to the environment minister insist he made direct verbal representations to foreign office officials.

The foreign office said Mr McLaughlan had a brief to advise on British nuclear interests and to increase trade with Japan's nuclear industry, and that he was answerable to its officials rather than BNFL. The nuclear industry has been paying for a diplomatic post for 20 years.

The Whitehall row over his diplomatic status reflects a wider dispute in government over the future of BNFL following the disclosure that its employees had been falsifying records of safety checks.

BNFL is losing the bulk of its contracts to reprocess nuclear waste following the revelation of the poor safety culture. The disclosure of the poor safety record has placed a question mark over the government's plans to sell a minority stake in the company.

The foreign office minister, Peter Hain, insisted the government had no plans to remove the diplomatic status from the employee. He also admitted yesterday that eight businessmen were working in British embassies with full diplomatic status.

In written asnwers to the Labour MP Alan Simpson, he refused to disclose their names, but revealed that since 1979 there had been 56 secondments to British diplomatic missions from 40 private sector companies

The eight were fully answerable to the head of the diplomatic post. In total, 14 secondments had been completed over the past year. All the secondees held diplomatic passports.

Mr Hain insisted it was not a breach of the Vienna convention on diplomatic relations for the businessmen to be given diplomatic status.

fields.headline: Get a pizza the action
fields.standfirst:
Don't starve while you surf. Justin Hunt tells you 
how to snack without leaving the screen
fields.trailText: Don't starve while you surf. Justin Hunt tells you how to snack without leaving the screen
fields.body:
The infamous legend of Milton Keynes lives on. The new city first hit the headlines with its concrete cows. Now it's becoming famous for its e-pizzas. Thanks to the aggressive e-commerce strategies by Domino's Pizza, the city is fast-becoming the UK's leading factory for cyber-pizza.

Domino's, with its headquarters deep in the heart of Milton Keynes, is currently the only pizza company in the country to offer a nationwide online delivery service. You can access it in two ways. If you're surfing the net and feel like a slice of hot Pepperoni Passion with double mozzarella cheese, log on to www.dominos.co.uk and place your order. While waiting for your cyber-pizza to bake, you can go to the games page for a quick session of Asteroids.

Or if you're slumped in front of the TV, exhausted after a long day at the office, and fancy a large Hawaiian pizza with ham, pineapple and some garlic bread, press a few buttons on your interactive TV's remote control and it's normally on your doorstep within 30 to 40 minutes.

Domino's says it's selling about 6,000 pizzas a month through Open, Sky's interactive TV service. Overall about 2% of pizza sales (worth hundreds of thousands of pounds) are e-commerce based. In the last set of financial figures, group turnover was up 24%.

Domino's has a national delivery service infrastructure in place, which is a big advantage, but its e-pizza pilots using email soon became unworkable. "Dial-up email is not reliable enough when you are delivering someone's food," explains Paul Murray, technical director of Fernhart New Media, consultants to Domino's. "Orders were not being recognised and often ended up on the PC in the manager's back office."

Domino's tried to keep email going by playing tapes of Homer Simpson's voice in pizza stores. As soon as an e-pizza order came in, it would be announced over the PA system by Homer. But even Homer could not swing it.

Next, pizza orders were sent to the stores by fax through the central Domino's server in Milton Keynes. But it takes time for staff to input the fax details into the computer systems and the machines often ran out of paper. So the entire fax system is being scrapped and over the next few months the e-pizza ordering service is being digitised: customer orders wil be sent directly to the bank of computer screens above the heads of the pizza-makers.

There have been other difficulties. E-pizza customers do not always believe their order has been received via the net and so they usually ring to check, which defeats the whole purpose. Confusion arose over payment. Some customers thought they could pay on the doorstep with a credit card. But they can't - cash is needed.

It has been tricky setting up the online service on Sky Digital's Open channel. Pizza orders have had to be standardised for the TV and only a fixed number of pizza types can be offered at designated times. Despite these hurdles, Domino's is starting to enjoy the benefits of e-commerce.

"We are not talking about huge numbers yet. But we did get a 10% increase last month on internet ordering. We are definitely moving in the right direction," says marketing manager, Anna Taylor-West.

The e-pizza team expects the greatest growth in the short to medium term to come from the TV. Young men are the biggest pizza buyers. Research shows they usually can't be bothered to cook and want something quickly - especially during key sporting events.

"There are two types of company who will do well out of the e-commerce binge," predicts Domino's marketing director, Chris Moore. "The top internet sites like Yahoo and Amazon, and those businesses who have an existing business operation where e-commerce is just an additional sales model."

Moore is baffled by arch-rivals Pizza Hut and Perfect Pizza. Neither has launched an online delivery service. "Around 1998 we started piloting e-pizzas in Milton Keynes and they would have known. Now we are trying to create enormous distance between us and them."

E-commerce analysts are equally mystified. "You would think the other pizza operations would have followed them already rather than waiting and seeing," says Fletcher Research analyst, Shobhit Kakkar. "Setting up the technical systems is not an easy process at all. The longer the others wait, the more of a head start Domino's will be allowed to get."

Pizza Hut has no immediate plans and is taking its time because it's such "a massive project". The company recently announced the introduction of a single national pizza-delivery order number in association with BT. Customers call a central number, charged at a local rate, to place their order, which is sent through to their local store for despatch.

However, rumours within the industry suggest that some marketing insiders at Pizza Hut believe the company should have invested the money in e-commerce.

Perfect Pizza, which has just been taken over by US-based Papa John's, says it is testing an online delivery service which should go live in three or four months. This is all music to the ears of Domino's which is enjoying all the benefits associated with being the first-mover.

However, the pizza business is traditionally very competitive. Domino's has a column in its in-house magazine called Know Your Enemies, and is preparing staff for cyber-pizza wars.

Every day, Domino's large dough production factory in Milton Keynes serves a fresh supply of dough balls to Domino's stores around the country. The head office has a pizza university and staff are trained in dough management and pizza-base making. "Whether orders come from the TV or a computer, our main aim is still to make sure we deliver a hot quality product within 30 minutes," says training coordinator, Tina Johnson.

All e-pizzas (just like your bog standard pizza) are hand-made. Which means covering them with cornmeal so they don't rip, creating a border and stretching them (or "slapping" as it's called in the trade), before the toppings are added and they are baked.

The internet delivery service has seen a rise in people wanting to create their own toppings. On the computer or TV screen, surfers can clearly see what they are buying and read about the ingredients. During training, Johnson insists all e-pizzas are cut to the right diameter; baked to an even golden brown colour with correct portions of cheese and they don't go out if there are any burned bubbles.

With no competitors in sight, it looks as though the e-pizza team at Milton Keynes will continue to produce large helpings of fresh cyber-dough. For the time being, at least.

fields.headline: MPs' interests
fields.standfirst: In the light of the revelations about Ken Livingtone's undeclared earnings, Derek Brown answers some key questions
fields.trailText: Thursday March 16 2000
fields.body:
Thursday March 16 2000

Why is "Red Ken" Livingstone red-faced?

He is in trouble with the House of Commons, for failing to declare £158,000 of income on the register of MPs' interests. He is now required to apologise to the House for breaching its code of conduct - a public admission which could gravely damage his Mr Clean image, and his campaign to become the London mayor.

If his income is undeclared, how did the Commons come to hear about it?

It was the subject of a complaint to the parliamentary standards commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, who passed it on to the house select committee on standards and privileges. All very straightforward, except that the complainant, a Leicestershire postgraduate student, says he had nothing to do with it.

Dirty tricks?

Livingstone thinks so. But the provenance of the complaint has no bearing on the committee's finding that he did indeed fail to declare the small fortune he made from writing columns and through celebrity speaking engagements. And that means in turn that he breached the Commons code of conduct.

What is the code of conduct?

It was adopted by the Commons in July 1996, in the last year of a Conservative administration plagued by accusations of sleaze. It was intended to tighten the rules on registration of MPs' interests, which first came into effect in May 1974.

What must be included on the register?

Paid directorships, paid employment, membership of Lloyd's, consultancy work, sponsorship, gifts, hospitality and other benefits, overseas visits not paid for entirely by the MP or public funds, land and property other than the member's own home, substantial shareholdings.

So Ken Livingstone didn't have to register his income from speaking engagements?

Oh yes he did. In a catch-all clause, the register requires that: "Any relevant interest, not falling within one of the above categories, which nevertheless falls within the definition of the main purpose of the register which is 'to provide information of any pecuniary interest or other material benefit which a member receives which might reasonably be thought by others to influence his or her actions, speeches, or votes in parliament, or actions taken in his or her capacity as a member of parliament,' or which the member considers might be thought by others to influence his or her actions in a similar manner, even though the member receives no financial benefit."

Come again?

In plainer English: "it is a cardinal principle that members are responsible for making a full disclosure of their own interests in the register; and if they have relevant interests which do not fall clearly into one or other of the specified categories, they will nonetheless be expected to register them."

How up to date is the register?

The register of members' interests is published soon after the beginning of a new parliament, and regularly updated. It now includes a breakdown of the income pulled in by the industrious MP for Brent East. The latest internet version, curiously, is rather behind the times, being dated December 2, 1998.

In a catch-all clause, the register requires that: "Any relevant interest, not falling within one of the above categories, which nevertheless falls within the definition of the main purpose of the register which is 'to provide information of any pecuniary interest or other material benefit which a member receives which might reasonably be thought by others to influence his or her actions, speeches, or votes in parliament, or actions taken in his or her capacity as a member of parliament,' or which the member considers might be thought by others to influence his or her actions in a similar manner, even though the member receives no financial benefit." Come again? In plainer English: "it is a cardinal principle that members are responsible for making a full disclosure of their own interests in the register; and if they have relevant interests which do not fall clearly into one or other of the specified categories, they will nonetheless be expected to register them." How up to date is the register? The register of members' interests is published soon after the beginning of a new parliament, and regularly updated. It now includes a breakdown of the income pulled in by the industrious MP for Brent East. The latest internet version, curiously, is rather behind the times, being dated December 2, 1998. fields.headline: Clockwork Orange
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about tomorrow's re-release of Kubrick's banned movie
fields.trailText: 1. "Why did they ban Chocolate Orange?" Ali G asked James Ferman, the former British film censor, in an interview last year.
fields.body:
1. "Why did they ban Chocolate Orange?" Ali G asked James Ferman, the former British film censor, in an interview last year.

2. The film (correct title: A Clockwork Orange) is one of the most controversial films of all time and, luckily for the violence-loving movie buff, goes on general release tomorrow.

3. But it had nothing to do with the censor: the late Stanley Kubrick chose to withdraw the film himself.

4. From the Korova Milkbar in a future Britain of tunnels and tower blocks a teenage gang speaking Nasdat - a Russian-influenced English slang - carry out an orgy of violence.

5. In Anthony Burgess's novel, Alex - the 15-year-old leader of the gang - is arrested for murder and subjected to aversion therapy that leaves him incapable of distinguishing between good and evil.

6. The film translates this into several notorious scenes, including one where the gang beat a tramp for fun. Kubrick argued that this scene was concerned with the question of free will - "Do we lose our humanity if we are deprived of the choice between good and evil? Do we become, as the title suggests, A Clockwork Orange?" he said in 1971.

7. But at the culmination of several decades of juvenile-delinquent movies that started with Marlon Brando's The Wild One (banned in Britain until 1968), the director recognised that West Side Story was the acceptable face of teenage gang warfare.

8. So Kubrick stylised and choreographed the violence, setting it to music that ranges from Rossini overtures to Singin' in the Rain. You can watch the film trailer - though beware ... it takes a while to download.

9. No one knows why Kubrick withdrew the film: some suggest the police asked him after several copycat crimes; in one instance a 17-year-old Dutch girl was raped in Lancashire by a gang chanting Singin' in the Rain, and in another a child was beaten by a 16-year-old boy wearing Alex's uniform of white overalls, black bowler hat and combat boots.

10. Kubrick died in March 1999. His other films include Dr. Strangelove, 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Shining and Full Metal Jacket.

fields.headline: BMW to sell Rover
fields.trailText: BMW have confirmed the sale of Rover Cars to Alchemy Partners, a small venture capital group, whose partners compare themselves to a "pack of hunting dogs".
fields.body:
BMW have confirmed the sale of Rover Cars to Alchemy Partners, a small venture capital group, whose partners compare themselves to a "pack of hunting dogs".

Negotiations have started for the sale of the Rover and MG brands, as well as their Longbridge production facilities to Covent Garden-based Alchemy Partners, BMW said in an official statement.

Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union (AEEU) officials said they would contact Alchemy Partners to get details of the purchase.

"We will be contacting Alchemy Partners and seek to discuss their plans for Rover. We would not wish to make any hasty judgements on the deal, should it take place, as it affects the jobs of thousands of people," not only at Rover's Longbridge plant but throughout the Midlands," said an AEEU official.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said today he would be talking to Alchemy about its plans after the firm indicated its interest in acquiring parts of Rover, including the giant Longbridge car factory in Birmingham and the Cowley plant in Oxford. Executives at Alchemy were locked in meetings this morning and not commenting to the media - although a security guard came out to provide 'Alchemy' chocolate bars to waiting reporters.

Buying Rover would be the biggest deal yet for Alchemy, known for its revival of the Fatty Arbuckles restaurant chain and Fads DIY store. Alchemy has no direct experience in the car industry via any of its previous deals but former Rover marketing director Kevin Morley sits on Alchemy's industrial advisory board and is expected to play a leading role in any deal.

Founded just three years ago, Alchemy has already made a big splash in the booming private equity market - where firms invest on behalf of private clients - under the leadership of managing partner Jon Moulton, who arrived as usual around 7 am at his office this morning. In 1998, the group invested £234m in 21 deals, placing it second only to 3i in the British private equity league tables. A small company, Alchemy has only five partners in London and one in Frankfurt.

Alchemy is expected to receive a payment to take on loss-making Rover, with BMW retaining the profitable Land Rover four-wheel-drive business and the new Mini. That would leave Alchemy with Rover's 25, 45 and 75 car production. Alchemy would also get the Rover sales network to form a business expected to be led by Mr Morley. The move would not be Mr Morley's first attempt to take over a leading British car maker. He led a consortium in early 1998 which failed to prevent Rolls-Royce Motors falling into BMW's hands for £340m.

A deal for Rover would be in keeping with Alchemy's general approach to finance. "We can finance very large transactions...We welcome complex transactions and turnarounds. We are not dissuaded by difficulty - rather we see it as an opportunity," the group declared on its website. Major investors in Alchemy include Chase Capital Partners and major US institutions as well as big pension funds such as that of British Aerospace.

webTitle: How Nirvana breached the cultural divide

fields.headline: How Nirvana breached the cultural divide
fields.trailText: Right inside the door of the Virgin Megastore was a vast section of popular music labelled Rock/Soul, which ran the gamut from the Eagles to Al Green to Pere Ubu, with vast stretches of irony, allusiveness, camp, and boring stuff in between. This giant culture deposit was thick with association. Here were bands that were the pop cultural equivalent of the pencil marks parents put inside the closet door to show how much Junior has grown since last year. Jackson Browne, James Taylor, Neil Young, and the early '70s folk rockers, many of them on the Asylum label started by the young David Geffen, oozing that peaceful, easy feeling that was my first pop love, and that I listened to in my bedroom, a sullen and mopey twelve-year-old with the lights out.
fields.body:
Right inside the door of the Virgin Megastore was a vast section of popular music labelled Rock/Soul, which ran the gamut from the Eagles to Al Green to Pere Ubu, with vast stretches of irony, allusiveness, camp, and boring stuff in between. This giant culture deposit was thick with association. Here were bands that were the pop cultural equivalent of the pencil marks parents put inside the closet door to show how much Junior has grown since last year. Jackson Browne, James Taylor, Neil Young, and the early '70s folk rockers, many of them on the Asylum label started by the young David Geffen, oozing that peaceful, easy feeling that was my first pop love, and that I listened to in my bedroom, a sullen and mopey twelve-year-old with the lights out.

Punk rock rescued me from the Dan Fogelbergian miasma of folk rock: Iggy Pop, Patti Smith, the Sex Pistols, then the Talking Heads, who made punk mainstream. Although I did not understand it at the time, the shift from California folk rock to British punk rock - from the "fake" mainstream California sound to the "real" British underground punk sound - was the decisive antithesis that would in one way or another determine all my subsequent pop musical experience. After Talking Heads came the bands like Duran Duran, the Cure, and the Cars, who marketed the "authentic" sound of punk into the "fake" New Wave and turned me off pop music in my early twenties. Then the big-hair bands of the '80s like Van Halen, Guns n' Roses, and the second coming of Aerosmith, which had kept me away from pop. And then Nirvana, the band that changed everything.

Before Nirvana my cultural experience had followed a more-or-less stately progress up-hierarchy from commercial culture to elite culture. But after I heard Nirvana, at the age of thirty-one, the stream of culture as it flowed through me slowed, stopped, and started moving in the other direction. After Nirvana, I began to pursue pop music with an energy I had never devoted to it as a teenager, when I was too worried about how my adult life was going to turn out to pay that much attention to pop. Pop became a way of hanging on to my teenage self, which had become a kind of touchstone for me as an adult. I got into hip-hop, and then the subgenres of hip-hop, like gangsta, and then techno, and now I was into the rich ground between techno and hip-hop - acid, trance, jungle, big beat, ambient - which seemed to be where the future of pop music lay.

As a kid I thought that becoming an adult would mean putting away pop music and moving on to classical, or at least intelligent jazz. Cultural hierarchy was the ladder climbed toward a grown-up identity. The day you found yourself putting on black tie and going to enjoy the opening night of Aida as a subscriber to the Metropolitan Opera was the day you crossed an invisible threshold into adulthood. But for the last five years, pop music had provided me with peaks of lyrical and musical transcendence that I long ago stopped feeling at the opera and the symphony, those moments when the music, the meaning, and the moment all flowed together and filled you with the "oceanic feeling" that Freud said characterizes powerful aesthetic experience.

A month earlier I had had an oceanic experience at a Chemical Brothers' show that my friend had taken me to hear at the Roxy. The Chemical Brothers were two young musician/programmers from the dance/Ecstasy subculture of Manchester, England, who had begun by deejaying in the clubs that flourished in the dark satanic mills left over from the nineteenth-century industrial revolution, and that were now dark satanic malls of late-twentieth-century street style.

We waited in a long line outside the Roxy for an hour, freezing, while scalpers in big down parkas cruised by murmuring "whosellingticketswhosellingticketswhosellingtickets." As usual when we went gigging, we were just about the oldest people there. Going out to hear hot new pop acts was one of the greatest cultural pleasures of our grown-up lives. These intense moments of ectastic communion with youth stood out from our otherwise predictable diet of respectable culture - interesting plays, the Rothko show, the opera, and, sometimes, downtown happenings at the Kitchen or the Knitting Factory. Afterward, we would go home to our wives and kids and our tasteful diet of highbrow and middlebrow culture, but here in the oceanic present of pop music, we felt alive in a way we never felt when experiencing elite culture.

Finally we got inside and worked our way down into the crush of kids on the dance floor. Most were trying to figure out the optimum time to drop the drugs they had brought along, so that they peaked when the music peaked. After a long time somebody walked out onto the darkened stage and a buzz rippled through the crowd. An evil-sounding pulse started to beat, pumping a black squishy liquid out of a computer and swirling it around the room. Then came a sampled sentence from a Blake Baxter song, repeated four times: dabrothersgonnaworkitout.

With each set of four beats a new computer-modulated drum sound entered the mix, and on the last set a distorted-sounding guitar made an appearance. Because the music was made on synthesizers it had the geometric regularity of code, and this made it possible to feel intuitively where the lines of sound were headed and when they would converge. It was like reading a sonnet: you anticipated the shape of the form before the content arrived. Such a sonic convergence was coming up. All the rhythmic variations and distortions that had previously been at counterpoint with one another were about to come together into what promised to be an amazing blast of unified sound

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Ian Broudie, musician
fields.trailText: Ian Broudie, musician.
fields.body:
The Lightning Seeds have kind of changed direction recently, so now we're just letting everyone get their heads round the way we sound. I think there's always the expectation that we'll make some big, fast, shiny single, but the new one, Sweetest Soul Sensation, is a little bit of a change of pace. But don't worry, it's still very us. Personally, I think the new stuff has got more of a groove to it. I'd call it soul music, emotional slow songs - just very, very soulful (apart from my vocals). In the past, we've always been pop, but now the meaning of the word has changed. Are we still pop? Well we're off to Germany to do a Rolling Stone tour with Gomez and Andreas Johnson. I guess that's pop. I don't even really know anymore.

I used to feel very uncomfortable being onstage or TV, but with this stuff I'm much more relaxed. I love playing live, now. It's probably my favourite thing at the minute. I'd like to do more of it. There's four of us on stage now and it all seems to have slotted together. There's chemistry both onstage and off, and we seem to have a laugh.

I'm in no hurry to get back in the studio. Every now and again someone wants me to produce or collaborate with them, but I don't want to do much of that these days. To be honest, at the moment I'm just thinking about our video - it's set in a hotel during a convention for pantomime animals. A front end of a horse has lost its back end and is shocked to find itself attached to the front end of a zebra . They have a fight. We're in the video, but unfortunately not in the horse. I suppose we are a bit better turned out these days. We have stylists when we do videos though not for TV. Ultimately, we're just good-looking people.

webTitle: Downbeat Labour hand Ayr to Tories

fields.headline: Downbeat Labour hand Ayr to Tories
fields.standfirst: If the Tories are victorious in the Ayr by-election tomorrow the seat will have been handed to them thanks to a lacklustre and unenthusiastic Labour campaign, says Kirsty Scott
fields.trailText: If the Tories are victorious in the Ayr by-election tomorrow the seat will have been handed to them thanks to a lacklustre and unenthusiastic Labour campaign, says Kirsty Scott.
fields.body:
There should be another small, blue corner in the Scottish map tomorrow. If the polls are right - and they have been unusually consistent - the Conservatives will reclaim Ayr, the seaside constituency up for grabs in the Scottish parliament's first by-election.

The Tory leader, William Hague, has already made several triumphal visits to the town, claiming the party has transformed itself in Scotland and that a victory in Ayr will mark a resurgence of Tory fortunes.

Let him have his fun, but don't be fooled into thinking this election has been won by the Conservatives. If the seat does change hands, it will have been lost by Labour, who hold it with the slimmest of majorities. Twenty five votes, give or take the odd recount.

Hampered by the lacklustre performance of the Scottish executive and attacked for their handling of local issues, they have run a decidedly downbeat campaign. Not even the prime minister could be persuaded to visit the constituency, although he was only 30 miles away in Glasgow last week.

Labour have been quick to blame the furore over Section 28 for their troubles in Ayr. Traditionally Conservative as well as conservative, the town has been portrayed as the main battleground for those fighting against repeal of the controversial clause. In truth, Section 28 has been of little consequence to the local electorate. Not when jobs are disappearing, tourism is suffering, local services are being cut and the once prosperous market town is taking on a tired and faded air.

Of all the parties, it is the Scottish National party who seem to have understood this best, and analysts say they will be the kingmakers if the Tories do triumph. The SNP campaign has been by far the slickest. They have gone online in a community with 6,000 students, and have worked the doorsteps relentlessly, speaking directly to two-thirds of potential voters. For the disaffected Labour supporters - and there are plenty of them - the SNP is the natural alternative. They started the campaign in third place and have since been moved up to second.

The press conferences have already been planned for Friday morning. Labour are likely to put a positive slant on any outcome. But no amount of spin can change the message already sent by the electorate in Ayr. And it's one that should be heard as loudly in Downing Street as it has been at Holyrood. Not good enough. Could do better.

fields.body:
What is the highest number of runs scored off one ball, and how was it achieved? asks Jean De Reuck

The highest recorded in first-class cricket is ten, by Samuel Hill-Wood off Cuthbert Burnup for Derbyshire v MCC at Lord's in 1900. There was a peculiar trial scoring system in some matches at Lord's that year, whereby a net was stretched around the boundary, and the batsmen had to run for all their hits (unless they hit it over the net, which was worth three runs). You got a bonus of two if you hit it into the net. Presumably Mr Hill-Wood hit the ball to some remote part of Lord's - or maybe the fielders got tangled up in the nets. "Wisden" called the idea "clumsy", and it was abandoned after a few matches, although the net stayed around the Lord's boundary all that season. There have been 14 recorded instances of nine runs being scored off one ball in first-class cricket: only one of those (by The Hon. FGB Ponsonby for MCC v Cambridge University in 1842) did not involve overthrows or penalty runs.

For which country did Vivian Richards play football? asks J Lewis

Sir Viv played for his native Antigua in the qualifying rounds of the football World Cup in the early 1970s. He was a midfielder. When he first came to England he had a trial with non-league Bath City, but was not signed up.

Which bowler has the most Test hat-tricks? asks Douglas Rome

Three bowlers have taken two: Australians Hugh Trumble and Jimmy Matthews, and Wasim Akram of Pakistan. Matthews's pair both came in the same match, against South Africa at Old Trafford in 1912. Wasim, whose hat-tricks came in successive Tests against Sri Lanka last winter, has also taken two in one-day internationals. In all first-class cricket the most hat-tricks by one bowler is seven, by Doug Wright, the Kent and England legspinner who played either side of the Second World War.

Who are currently the oldest surviving English county and Test players? asks Steve Clarke

Jim Hutchinson of Derbyshire is the oldest surviving county cricketer: he celebrated his 103rd birthday on November 29th last year. England's oldest surviving Test player is Alf Gover, who was 92 on Feb 29.

How does the lbw law work? asks superkuku

This is probably the hardest law to explain - and the one that causes the most arguments! Basically you can't be out lbw to anything pitching outside leg stump, or if you're hit outside the line of the off stump (unless you haven't played a shot). But if the ball strikes you in line with the stumps (or if it hits outside the line of off and you haven't played a shot) and the umpire thinks it would have hit the wicket, then you can be out. If you want the exact wording you can find it in the laws section on the Lord's website.

Who won the 1995 Test series with West Indies? Which cricket umpire runs a post office in north Devon? And how many stumps are used in a game of cricket? asks Sonrojbar

Do I smell a sports quiz here? The 1995 England-West Indies Test series was drawn 2-2. David Shepherd is the post-office-running umpire. And normally there are six stumps (and four bails) in a game of cricket.

What are the dates for this summer's Tests in England? asks Will Fielder

Good question - there are seven Tests, the most England have ever had in a home season. There are two Tests against Zimbabwe, at Lord's (starting on May 18) and Trent Bridge (June 1). They're followed by five Tests against West Indies - at Edgbaston (starting June 15), Lord's (June 29), Old Trafford (August 3), Headingley (August 17) and The Oval (August 31). In between the second and third Tests against West Indies there is a three-way one-day series also involving Zimbabwe. That starts on July 6 (West Indies v Zimbabwe at Bristol), and the final is at Lord's on July 22.

I recently saw the Antiques Roadshow programme which was filmed at Lord's. On a bat I spotted the name "Cranford", which was my wife's maiden name, and we wondered whether we had a Test cricketer in the family? asks Alan Gottschald from America

Sorry to disappoint you but there has never been an English first-class cricketer called Cranford. I think the name was probably "Crawford": John Neville Crawford, a Surrey allrounder, played 12 Tests for England between 1905-06 and 1907-08. He later fell out with Surrey and played in Australia and New Zealand, before resolving his differences and returning to The Oval after the First World War.

Who did Garry Sobers score his six sixes against? asks James Rodgers

The unfortunate bowler was Malcolm Nash of Glamorgan. He was usually a left-arm fast bowler, but was experimenting with slower spinners and cutters at the time when Sobers collected his six sixes in an over, playing for Nottinghamshire at Swansea in 1968. Nash, who was also hit for 34 in an over by Lancashire's Frank Hayes in 1977, played on for Glamorgan until 1983, and captained them in 1980-81. His spinners never caught on, though.

How can you turn a bunch of hard drinkers, with respect and a flair for the game, into winners? asks Andy Bird, newly elected captain of the Sow & Pigs Cricket Club

I think you'll have to play teams who are harder drinkers, with less flair and respect for the game.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

webTitle: Raoul Ruiz to direct Rushdie adaptation

fields.headline: Raoul Ruiz to direct Rushdie adaptation
fields.trailText: Salman Rushdie's The Ground Beneath Her Feet appears set to make the transition from printed page to silver screen in a deal instigated the author himself
fields.body:
Salman Rushdie's The Ground Beneath Her Feet appears set to make the transition from printed page to silver screen in a deal instigated by the author himself. The picture will be produced and distributed by the small Paris-based production house Gemini and will be produced by Gemini president Paolo Branco. Chilean director Raoul Ruiz is on board to direct and the film is budgeted at $15m - small potatoes in Hollywood terms but a hefty increase on anything that Gemini has handled before.

A veteran of some sixty films, Ruiz last collaborated with Branco on his elegant adaptation of Proust's Time Regained, starring John Malkovich and Catherine Deneuve. Time Regained won decent reviews when it released in the UK at the start of the year, but Rushdie first saw the film at last year's Cannes Film Festival. Impressed by what he saw, he contacted Ruiz directly and agreed to sell the film rights to Gemini on the condition that Ruiz serve as director.

Published in 1999, The Ground Beneath Her Feet is widely regarded as Rushdie's most accessible and purely filmic novel, a heady tale of the love affair between two Indian rock stars. The lead female character is allegedly loosely based on Madonna and there have been rumours that she is the author's first choice to play the role. If so, it looks unlikely to happen. Madonna has admitted that she is no fan of Rushdie's work and is reported to have deposited her complimentary copy of Rushdie's book in the nearest waste-paper basket.

webTitle: Jude Law in talks for Spielberg film

fields.headline: Jude Law in talks for Spielberg film
fields.trailText: Still with one eye on this month's Academy Awards, Oscar-nominated Jude Law is in negotiations with both Warner Brothers and DreamWorks to take a starring role in Steven Spielberg's AI
fields.body:
Still with one eye on this month's Academy Awards, Oscar-nominated Jude Law is in negotiations with both Warner Brothers and DreamWorks to take a starring role in Steven Spielberg's AI.

The project was long the property of the late Stanley Kubrick who acquired the rights to the source story by Brian Aldis in 1982 and hoped to direct it immediately after finishing what was to be his film swansong, Eyes Wide Shut. Set in the future, AI (Artificial Intelligence) tells the story of a childless woman who adopts an android in a world submerged beneath the melting polar ice-caps.

Having deliberated for months over his next choice of project, Spielberg now looks to be moving at a startling speed. The news that he was to direct AI was only announced on Tuesday and already the casting is well under way. The picture begins production on July 10 and will be released in the summer of 2001.

Reports over the past weeks have linked the director, variously, with both the conspiracy thriller Minority Report, Memoirs of Geisha and an adaptation of JK Rowling's Harry Potter stories. Spielberg dropped out of the Potter project due to rumoured "creative differences" with Rowling, who objected to the director's determination to cast Haley Joel Osment (the child star of The Sixth Sense) in the lead role. Significantly, he is now reported to have secured Osment to star as the boy android in AI.

For Jude, AI will be his third futuristic thriller in as many years. The actor starred alongside Ethan Hawke and Uma Thurman in the genetic saga Gattaca and last year impressed audiences as a bewildered computer-gamer in David Cronenberg's virtual-reality escapade Existenz. Law is nominated as Best Supporting Actor for his role as the pampered Dickie Greenleaf in The Talented Mr. Ripley but now has a gap in his schedule after pulling out of a remake of the tally-ho British war movie The Four Feathers. The Spielberg production promises to be the 25 year-old's most high-profile picture to date.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Another role for Frances McDormand with the Coen brothers, Guillermo del Toro to direct Blade 2: Bloodhunt, The Mummy 2 prepares to roll at Pinewood, and Traffic gets moving again
fields.body:
 The Coen Brothers are in negotations to secure Frances McDormand as the star of their as-yet-untitled new movie. Presumably, the negotiations will be no more than a formality, since McDormand is married to director Joel Coen and won an Oscar for her last collaboration with the film-making siblings when she played a dogged, pregnant cop in 1996's Fargo. According to Variety, the new movie will cast McDormand in a very different role as a vixenish femme-fatale who cheats on her husband and ends up in hot water when her lover winds up dead. The project will be backed by Working Title and begins shooting in the summer.

 Nigel Hawthorne is reported to be poised to sign on as Jack the Ripper in the period Fox thriller, From Hell. Johnny Depp is to co-star as the detective on the Ripper's trail, and the picture will be directed by the Hughes brothers (Dead Presidents).

 Mexican director Guillermo del Toro (Cronos, Mimic) has prolonged his stay in Hollywood by agreeing to direct Blade 2: Bloodhunt. The sequel to 1998's slick horror-actioner will again star Wesley Snipes as a vampire hunter in New York. But production on the film will have to wait until November, when del Toro has completed work on his current picture The Devil's Backbone, a personal, independently-financed horror movie about a Catholic children's orphanage in Spain.

 The Mummy 2 (again starring Rachel Weisz and Brendan Fraser) is preparing to roll before the cameras at Pinewood studios. Ain't it Cool news points out that the production is currently hunting extras (presumably to play terrified Egyptians and panicking archeologists). Interested parties should check out www.castingcollective.co.uk

 Steven Soderbergh must be breathing a vast sigh of relief today with the news that Michael Douglas has genuinely-definitely committed to play the lead role in his trouble-hit drugs drama Traffic. The role has already been passed between Harrison Ford and Kevin Costner (who both apparently backed out over money wrangles) and the production was sailing perilously close to its scheduled starting date of April 9. Douglas will play an upstanding federal judge turned drugs tzar and TV actress Erika Christensen his crack-addicted teenage daughter. In a parallel plotline, Douglas's high-profile wife Catherine Zeta-Jones will play a middle-class mum turned drugs courier. Variety reports that Soderbergh is still attempting to secure both Benicio del Toro and the brilliant Don Cheadle (who previously collaborated with the director on Out of Sight) for supporting roles.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
No guarantees

Stuart McClure recently moved into a house in Totnes, Devon, where double-glazed windows had been fitted two years previously. They were guaranteed for 10 years, but only if he paid £25 to register the guarantee in his name. "Surely," he protests, "a guarantee is for the product, regardless of who bought it."

 Not so. Trading Standards says a guarantee is in addition to statutory rights and is issued at the manufacturer's discretion. "Guarantees don't have to be transferable. Someone who didn't buy the product has no civil law rights over it."

Why register?

Ernest Evans from Bradford on Avon wonders why he had to register his dishwasher with Hoover after purchase.

 Registering gives the customer rights over and above the sale of goods act, and allows the manufacturer to keep track of the product, says Trading Standards. "The customer can bin the registration card if he wishes and his statutory rights will not be affected."

Medical problems

More readers have written in to say that they have received unsolicited medical kits plus an invoice from Royal-Consulting, a Dutch company whose activities we reported. The British Red Cross and other charities are upset that the firm has, without authorisation, been claiming that part of its proceeds go to them, - a practice the company's MD says stopped in September. This surprised C Taylor who applied for a job at one of their British call centres last November and reports: "During the training session I was told the use of charities' names was their major selling point and it was the first thing mentioned in the scripts provided."

A little local difficulty

A number of readers have written to complain about goods ordered from a certain company. The cheques were cashed but orders were not received and phone messages and letters often went unanswered. That company is, er, The Guardian and the orders were for a special issue of our New Year's Day edition.

According to our marketing department, the problems were caused largely by the huge demand for the special edition. When it emerged that the company appointed to distribute the issue was unable to cope with demand, The Guardian began distributing copies directly.The paper offers sincere apologises to any readers who have experienced delays or disappointment and asks anyone still waiting to call: 0171-713 4544.

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Browsing for buyer power
fields.standfirst: They are auctions with a twist: you name your price and sellers try to match it.  Jim McClellan  reports
fields.trailText: They are auctions with a twist: you name your price and sellers try to match it.  Jim McClellan  reports
fields.body:
Dylan Schlosberg might be only 26 years old, but he has plans to revolutionise online shopping. He wants to make the consumer king.

Convenience is supposed to be one of the great attractions of net shopping. You can buy when you want, at a good price, with the minimum of hassle, or so we are told. In practice, you often waste time struggling with slow net connections and badly designed sites. Consumers have yet to be freed from high prices and tedious procedures.

Schlosberg thinks his site, Ybag, might change all that. Launched only last week, it aims to let you sit back while retailers come to you. Finally, he claims, the customer is king: power has finally shifted from sellers to buyers.

Inspiration for the site came last summer, when Schlosberg found himself perplexed by the frustrating nature of much net shopping.

His concept is simple. Users register and describe a particular item they want - like a TV, a computer or even a car. The requests are passed on to suppliers, and they send details of the deal they can offer to the user, who can check in at their leisure to see what has turned up. If something appeals, they get in touch with the seller. They don't need to buy via the net.

Schlosberg expects many of the sales Ybag enables to take place on the telephone. "The idea is to offer a quicker, more user friendly, more personal shopping experience on the net," he says. "It's very much what's happening in America at the moment." Indeed, shortly after Schlosberg came up with the idea, several similar sites launched in the US the best-known being Respond.com and Buyers Edge.

In fact, sites like Ybag and Respond.com are just one example of the new kinds of retail ideas being tried online. So far net shopping has focused mainly on giving users access to databases of products, all at fixed prices. At its most basic, it is catalogue shopping with a few multimedia knobs on. Though it can be very convenient, online the consumer still does a lot of the work, such as searching databases and keying in payment information, previously done by the seller.

But these new net retailers plan to take advantage of the net's great strength: its ability to allow users to swap information. The retailers hope not simply to shift product but to shift power as well: to build new kinds of relationships between buyers and sellers, relationships in which the buyer sets the pace and could even affect prices in real time.

New sites have sprung up, like Priceline - where buyers name the price they want to pay for travel tickets, hotel rooms, cars and even groceries and sellers then compete to pick up the proposed deal. There is also the aggregate buying site Let's Buy It, where buyers can link up to force down prices.

According to co-founder John Palmer, the net has the ability to put the consumer in the driver's seat. "We are consumer-to-business as distinct to business-to-consumer. That means that the consumer tries to direct proceedings. That's not going to happen in the real world of bricks and mortar - there you are told what products you can have and how much it's going to cost."

The pitch of Let's Buy It is very seductive: buyers can either join in with ongoing sales of products, or suggest a thing they want to buy; the site will then try to source something suitable. The more people who sign up to a particular sale, the more the price goes down, so there is an incentive for buyers to tell friends about the site and so build its traffic.

"Compare it to an auction site where the price is always being bid up and there's only one winner," says Palmer. "At our site, the more people come together, the more the price goes down and everyone's a winner. If you like the idea you want to tell everybody about it because it's going to help you achieve a better price."

Then again, do you want all your friends to have the same TV set as you? Palmer says this doesn't seem to be an issue at all. He also rejects the idea that the site is a fad. People enjoy the buying process, he says. They like coming back to see if the price has gone down.

But some of the sites that promise consumer empowerment do involve an element of risk. Though the US site Priceline.com does let consumers name their price, well over 80% of the deals are never done because the company cannot find a willing supplier.

If a supplier comes up with a deal at the right price, the consumer has to take it. But the deal may not be quite what the customer wanted - Priceline may have to make a couple of changes on route. So Priceline customers get power but they have to be flexible.

That said, when it moves into a product sector, Priceline often subsidises deals, so that customers do get what they want and have a good experience. It's good for building traffic, but it's one reason why the site has yet to make a profit. It seems likely that Priceline will move here shortly, perhaps in conjunction with Lastminute.com (the Lastminute network has registered the priceline.co.uk name).

Now that it has floated, Lastminute.com will at least have the deep pockets needed to get this kind of reverse auction model off the ground. In the meantime, Ybag's Schlosberg suggests that his site is one of the UK's first reverse auction sites, though he doesn't want to trumpet the fact too loudly, for fear of confusing consumers.

Disadvantages: If the site in the middle doesn't do a good job, your mailbox will fill up with junk mail.

A dedicated search engine you can use to find the best price on a product. Over here the best known include Shopsmart www.shopsmart.com and Valuemad.

Disadvantages: Shopping bots don't search all the sites on the web, so you don't know if you're getting the best price, and they usually only search for specific items - you can't look for "a printer with a scanner".

In practice, you often waste time struggling with slow net connections and badly designed sites. Consumers have yet to be freed from high prices and tedious procedures. Schlosberg thinks his site, Ybag, might change all that. Launched only last week, it aims to let you sit back while retailers come to you. Finally, he claims, the customer is king: power has finally shifted from sellers to buyers. fields.headline: Young Goethe's love poems found
fields.trailText: Two hitherto unpublished love poems by the 18th century German literary giant Johann Wolfgang von Goethe have been discovered in a collection of more than 26,000 documents held by a library in Strasbourg in eastern France.
fields.body:
Two hitherto unpublished love poems by the 18th century German literary giant Johann Wolfgang von Goethe have been discovered in a collection of more than 26,000 documents held by a library in Strasbourg in eastern France.

Researchers at the city's university library revealed yesterday that a 26-year-old Goethe wrote the love poems to Lili, the 17-year-old daughter of a wealthy Frankfurt merchant.

The verses were recorded in a 1775 diary Goethe compiled during a journey he made to Switzerland and Lake Zurich.

In one of the verses, the poet argues with himself about his love for the girl, whose real name was Anne-Elisabeth Schonemann.

"The work is important because it shows how Goethe fought against all feelings of love that threatened to place limits on his freedom and genius," said the library's Goethe researcher, Jules Keller, yesterday.

Researchers at the Strasbourg library discovered the poems in November while carrying out an inventory on the documents. The Goethe museum in Frankfurt and the Goethe archives in Weimar have verified the poems' authenticity, a library spokesman said.

Goethe's passion for Lili was short-lived, and in 1789 he wrote another version of the poem.

But the brief relationship appears to have made a deep impression on him. In a letter written to Lili more than 30 years later, Goethe said that the time spent with her had been one of the happiest periods in his life.

A year before Goethe wrote his love poems to Lili, he completed the essay Sorrows of Young Werther, which warns of the futility of unrequited love and ends with the main protagonist's suicide.

The essay was written while Goethe was studying at Strasbourg university.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: A bumper crop of gossip from today's papers
fields.trailText: The Mirror Arsene Wenger has targeted Coventry's Mustapha Hadji as a possible replacement for the unsettled Emmanuel Petit. The Arsenal boss is said to have been impressed by the Moroccan's form this season, particularly his ability to get goals from midfield.
fields.body:
The Mirror Arsene Wenger has targeted Coventry's Mustapha Hadji as a possible replacement for the unsettled Emmanuel Petit. The Arsenal boss is said to have been impressed by the Moroccan's form this season, particularly his ability to get goals from midfield.

Leeds are closing in on Frank Lampard. David O'Leary is looking to strengthen his midfield, and the youthful, skilful (not to mention English) Lampard fits the bill. A fee above £6m has been mooted.

PSV Eindhoven will look to bring Spurs' Steffen Iversen to Holland if they lose star striker Ruud van Nistelrooy to Arsenal this summer.

The Express George Weah wants to move into management, and he's keen to start his career at Fulham. Chelsea's on-loan forward recently made an approach to Fulham owner Mohammed Al Fayed about taking over from current boss Paul Bracewell, but sadly for the Liberian it came to nothing.

Arsenal have joined the list of clubs interested in signing Barcelona's Josep Guardiola. The midfielder does not appear to figure in coach Louis van Gaal's plans and could be set to move this summer, perhaps in the opposite direction to Marc Overmars.

Daily Mail Chelsea are set to rebuff approaches from Parma for the services of Tore Andre Flo. The Serie A side hope to include the Norwegian striker in their sizeable summer rebuilding plans.

Sunderland are planning a £4.5m move for Argentinian international defender Mauricio Pochettino. Negotiations are being held with the highly rated centre back's club Espanol, with a view to a summer move.

Nottingham Forest manager David Platt may be forced to sell off midfielder Chris Bart Williams for a bargain £2m. Both Tottenham and Everton could be interested in the 26-year-old.

The Sun Forgotten Bradford winger Lee Sharpe has been offered a fresh start by First division Huddersfield and Nottingham Forest.

Fulham have signed Eddie Lewis from American MLS side San Jose Clash. Dubbed 'the American Beckham', Lewis has won 18 international caps on the right wing.
