webTitle: Irving: rabid racist or vilified victim?

fields.headline: Irving: rabid racist or vilified victim?
fields.standfirst:
Revisionist historian accused of denying the Holocaust as dramatic libel trial reaches climax

The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: David Irving is a "rabid anti-semite" who prostituted his reputation as a serious historian by falsifying history to exonerate Adolf Hitler for the Holocaust, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
David Irving is a "rabid anti-semite" who prostituted his reputation as a serious historian by falsifying history to exonerate Adolf Hitler for the Holocaust, the high court heard yesterday.

The assault on the alleged Hitler apologist came from Richard Rampton QC, the barrister for the author Deborah Lipstadt, whom Mr Irving is suing for libel.

Professor Lipstadt and her publishers, Penguin Books Limited, both deny libelling Mr Irving by branding him "a Holocaust denier" in a book which attacked revisionists alleged to have denied or downplayed the slaughter of 6m Jews during the second world war.

Yesterday both sides made their closing speeches after a three-month trial seen as one of the most emotive in a generation.

In his closing speech Mr Irving, 62, said the book, Denying the Holocaust, was the culmination of a 30-year campaign against him that had left him the most "vilified" historian ever.

Mr Rampton told the packed court that Mr Irving's Holocaust denial, shown in his work and speeches to far-right audiences, was caused by his anti-semitism.

Mr Rampton said: "Holocaust denial, in the form in which it is purveyed by Mr Irving, is an obvious example of anti-semitism, and is music to the ears of the neo-Nazis and other rightwing extremists. Mr Irving is a Hitler partisan, who has falsified history on a staggering scale in order to 'prove' Hitler's innocence; which like Holocaust denial, is obviously very appealing to his fellow travellers - after all, if the Holocaust were a 'myth' then, obviously, Hitler could have no responsibility for it.

"How far, if at all, Mr Irving's anti-semitism is a cause of his Hitler apology, or vice versa, is unimportant. Whether they are taken together or individually, it is clear that they have led him to prostitute his reputation as a serious historian for the sake of a bogus rehabilitation of Hitler and the dissemination of virulent anti-semitic propaganda."

Mr Rampton accused Mr Irving of being a racist and of perpetrating a string of historical falsehoods throughout his work, all designed to rewrite Hitler's role in the Holocaust: "By the defendants' estimate, there are, in relation to Hitler alone, as many as 25 major falsifications of history, as well as numerous subsidiary inventions, suppressions, manipulations and mistranslations employed to support the major falsifications.

"If those relating to Auschwitz, Dresden and other matters are added in, the number goes well over 30."

The final statements in the marathon libel trial were heard by Mr Justice Gray, who is hearing the case without a jury.

In his four-hour closing speech, Mr Irving told the judge he was the victim of an international hate campaign led by Jewish groups across the world. He claims Prof Lipstadt's book was part of the "climax" of the conspiracy and severely damaged his career as a historian.

"I know of no other historian or writer who has been subjected to a campaign of vilification even one-tenth as intense," said Mr Irving, best known for his book Hitler's War.

He said the case was not about the Holocaust but about his reputation "as a human being, as a historian of integrity".

To win the case, Prof Lipstadt and Penguin must prove that their allegations that Mr Irving wilfully distorted history are true.

Mr Irving said it was not enough for the defendants to show he had got facts wrong: "The matter at issue, as pleaded by the defendants, is not what happened but what I knew of it, and what I made of it, at the time I put pen to paper.

"The defendants have invested a sizeable fortune in re-researching the Holocaust. Fearing or finding that they were unable to prove wilful fraud, in effect, they have fallen back on the alternative plea, that 'Mr Irving ought to have known'."

Mr Irving admitted making mistakes, but said these were made innocently. He stressed he accepted that Hitler, "as head of state and of the government", was responsible for the Holocaust.

"Where I differed from many historians was in denying that there was any documentary proof of detailed direction and initiation of the mass murders by Hitler," Mr Irving said.

"In Hitler's War, I differed from other historians in suggesting that the actual mass murders were not all or mainly initiated by Hitler."

Mr Irving accused Prof Lipstadt of reckless lies, and said: "The defendants are saying that I am not entitled to continue to earn a living in the way that I have earned it for nearly 40 years.

"A judgment in my favour is no more than a judgment that disputed points which I have made about some aspects of the narrative are not so absurd, given the evidence, as to disqualify me from the ranks of historians.

"A judgment in my favour does not mean that the Holocaust never happened; it means only that in England today discussion is still permitted." He did admit occasional lapses in taste but said: "If a writer's books are banned and burned, his bookshops smashed, his hands manacled, his person assaulted, his printers burned down, his access to the world's archives denied, his family's livelihood destroyed and a wreath sent to him with a foul and taunting message upon the death of his oldest daughter, then it ill behoves people to offer cheap criticism if the writer commits the occasional indiscretion and finally stops turning the other cheek and rounds upon his tormentors."

Judgment in the case was reserved and is not expected to be delivered for three weeks.

He did admit occasional lapses in taste but said: "If a writer's books are banned and burned, his bookshops smashed, his hands manacled, his person assaulted, his printers burned down, his access to the world's archives denied, his family's livelihood destroyed and a wreath sent to him with a foul and taunting message upon the death of his oldest daughter, then it ill behoves people to offer cheap criticism if the writer commits the occasional indiscretion and finally stops turning the other cheek and rounds upon his tormentors." Judgment in the case was reserved and is not expected to be delivered for three weeks.

fields.headline: Lauris Edmond
fields.standfirst: She found poetry in family life and motherhood
fields.trailText: The New Zealand poet Lauris Edmond, who has died aged 75, began writing seriously just 25 years ago. She subsequently published 11 collections of verse, a novel, three volumes of autobiography (1989-92), and radio and stage drama.
fields.body:
The New Zealand poet Lauris Edmond, who has died aged 75, began writing seriously just 25 years ago. She subsequently published 11 collections of verse, a novel, three volumes of autobiography (1989-92), and radio and stage drama.

Personal turmoil accompanied her emergence as a writer. Edmond's daughter Rachel died in 1975; she and her husband parted in the mid-1980s, and in the 1990s, post-autobiography, tensions arose between Edmond and some of the children over her exposure of their family life. It provoked her son to publish his version of his father's life in response to hers.

In dealing with these events, as well as in more public encounters that at times became confrontational, Edmond displayed a philosophical acceptance, forgiveness and compassion. Her poetry, essentially a meditation on her experience, also conveys these qualities; a strength in facing the dark side of life with which she became so familiar, a perception of the everyday as humorous or incongruous. Always accessible, Edmond wrote often about family life: the responsibilities of motherhood, the connectedness with children. The sequence of poems in Wellington Letter (1980), written out of grief after the death of Rachel, are among the most moving.

Other poems celebrate the dignity of the individual, and display understanding of people and relationships. Those in Season And Creatures (1986) are probably the most assured technically. Edmond's major themes such as childbirth, friendship, love, growing old, loneliness, loss, the encroachment of death, are commonly held to represent the woman's point of view.

But although her main readership was undoubtedly women, she also wrote about cities (especially Wellington, which she loved), exotic places, and contemporary events in ways which mark her out as a traveller in her own time. In particular, her preoccupation with the momentariness of life, in poems which weigh up gain against loss in a transient world, has relevance to all readers of poetry. In later works her search at the borders of empirical certainties, defining herself in relation to the unknown dimensions of the life beyond, while simultaneously remaining anchored in the present, became a serious act of self-repositioning.

Edmond's inspiration was rooted in her New Zealand identity, and it was this which gave her work a wider appeal. She was friend to several generations of women, especially writers, who admired her as a pioneer for breaking with social convention and carving out a successful literary life at a time when this seemed risky.

For years before she was published, she scribbled - poems, diaries, letters - in the hours left over from raising six children and moving round rural New Zealand with her schoolteacher husband. She had trained as a teacher at Wellington teachers' college, and then worked as a teacher before the children arrived. Only later did she take a degree and an MA in English literature.

She edited Selected Letters of ARD Fairburn (1981) under the auspices of the poet Dennis Glover, and co-founded the periodical New Zealand Books in 1990. She was president of PEN 1980-81, a frequent speaker at writers' festivals, and her writer in residence posts included Deakin university in Melbourne.

She enjoyed her role in New Zealand's literary life, as much as she was engaged in family life. Literary passions were inseparable from her devotion to family and friends; she was known as the great New Zealand poet of parents and children.

Edmond was awarded the Katherine Mansfield Memorial Fellowship, the Commonwealth Poetry Prize for her Selected Poems in 1985, and the OBE in 1986.

She continued to see her husband Trevor after their divorce, and indeed nursed him until his death. She is survived by four daughters and a son.

 Lauris Edmond, poet, born April 2 1924; died January 28 2000

fields.headline: The best supportive parents scene
fields.standfirst: American Beauty
fields.trailText: American Beauty
fields.body:
Lester and Carolyn Burnham (Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening) have been to see their teenage daughter Jane (Thora Birch) perform in her high-school cheerleading squad. During the show, Lester found himself stricken with lust for a beautiful blonde cheerleader. The same girl, Angela (Mena Suvari), now waits outside the school with Jane. Jane catches sight of her parents.

"Shit, they're still here."

Carolyn and Lester approach, both beaming.

"Hey, I really enjoyed that."

"Congratulations honey, you were great."

Lester turns to Angela. He lowers his voice to a gruff approximation of Barry White.

"Hi. I'm Lester. Janey's dad."

"Hi."

Jane scowls at her father.

"This is my friend, Angela Hayes."

"OK. Good to meet you. You were also good tonight. Very precise."

"Thanks."

"Nice to meet you Angela", smiles Carolyn. She turns to Jane.

"Honey, I am so proud of you. You know, I watched you very closely - and you didn't screw up once! OK, we have to go."

"So," enquires Lester, "what are you girls doing now?"

"Dad!"

"We're going for pizza."

Lester stares at Angela.

"Really? Do you need a ride? We can give you a ride. I have a car. Do you want to come with us?"

"Thanks, but I have a car."

"That's great, because Janey's thinking about getting a car. Aren't you honey?"

"Dad! Mom's waiting for you."

See also: Society, Happiness, Willy Wonka And The Chocolate Factory

Don't see also: Psycho

Pointless trivia: The closing credits of American Beauty offer thanks to "Dr Bill and Alice" - a reference to Stanley Kubrick's Eyes Wide Shut.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst:
Which film is most likely to be delayed by legal problems (unreleased by December 2002)?
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Which film is most likely to be delayed by legal problems (unreleased by December 2002)?
fields.body:
Takedown 3-1

Beyond The Mat 5-1

Cash 6-1

Smoke And Mirrors 7-1

The Informer may be on its way to Oscar success, but it has had its fair share of negative publicity. Lucretia Nimocks, the former wife of Jeffrey Wigand, the tobacco-industry whistleblower who is the subject of the film, has announced that she is going to sue the Walt Disney Studio for using her life story without permission and portraying her "disparagingly".

Smoke And Mirrors is set to star parents-to-be Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones, and tells the true story of nineteenth-century illusionist Jean Robert Houdin and his sidekick Colette, who were sent to Algeria by the French government to expose a religious sorcerer inciting revolution. "I don't think there will be too many family members around to take this particular film to court", says Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler, alluding to a US law whereby film companies cannot use a person's life story without the subject's permission.

The documentary on wrestling, Beyond The Mat, has already had it's ad campaign mysteriously pulled from one wrestling show. The distributor, Lion's Gate, is apparently pondering legal action against the World Wrestling Federation for it's negative influence on the project.

"Cash is all about Johnny Cash, the grand old man of Nashville. So much has gone on in his life, drugs and alcohol abuse, religious conversion, and a recent illness, that it was always odds-on that a movie would be made. Producers will have to ensure they receive the green light from Cash's friends and family but it's unlikely to be a negative film", says Ed.

Takedown is about the hacker Kevin Mitnick, who was tracked down by high-tech genius Tsutomu Shimomura. "It's the most likely film to run into trouble, as attorneys are allegedly being consulted over defamation of character", says Ed. The film has been held up from release since January by a lawsuit from Mitnick.

fields.headline: Carol Reed: The Third Man
fields.trailText: There are at least two extraordinary sequences - the first showdown between Lime and Martins on the slowly revolving ferris wheel of an almost deserted fairground, and the chase through the sewers of Vienna
fields.body:
Carol Reed directed films for 40 years, but his golden period was brief. It covered three years in the late 40s when he made Odd Man Out, The Fallen Idol and The Third Man. These three films alone put him in the forefront of British directors of the period, and the last-named, his second collaboration with Graham Greene, is probably the best film noir ever made out of Britain. Like all the best of the genre, the film is deeply romantic, despite its surface cynicism, and it's this that has caused it to remain in the public memory for so long. It was also a popular film that did not underestimate its audiences' intelligence.

It is set in a crumbling, depressed post-war Vienna, divided up by the Allied occupying forces - a city Reed knew well from his wartime experiences. Beautifully shot by Robert Krasker in atmospheric black and white, the city almost seems to be a character in the story. The insistent, haunting zither music is by Anton Karas, whom Trevor Howard discovered playing outside a restaurant in Vienna.

The film is further distinguished by several performances, particularly that of Orson Welles, who only took the part of Harry Lime to help finance his Othello and later regretted asking for a salary rather than a share of the profits. Curiously, David O Selznick, the American co-producer (with Alexander Korda), had wanted Noël Coward for the part. If Coward had played it, we would never have had the most famous lines in the film, written by Welles himself: "In Italy for 30 years under the Borgias, they had warfare, terror, murder and bloodshed. But they produced Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci and the Renaissance. In Switzerland, they had brotherly love; they had 500 years of democracy and peace. And what did that produce? The cuckoo clock!"

Greene dreamt up the part of the wicked but charming Harry Lime - the old schoolfriend Holly Martins (Joseph Cotten) searches for - after finding an envelope on which he had written, some time before: "I had paid my last farewell to Harry a week ago, when his coffin was lowered into the frozen February ground, so it was with incredulity that I saw him pass by, without a sign of recognition, among the host of strangers in the Strand." It was, of course, first a novel and then a screenplay, but it was one of the few Greene adaptations that was more successful on the screen than on the page.

There are at least two extraordinary sequences - the first showdown between Lime and Martins on the slowly revolving ferris wheel of an almost deserted fairground, and the chase through the sewers of Vienna that ends with Lime's death. Hitchcock could not have accomplished these sequences better, and there is no doubt that Reed owed some debt to him.

Perhaps melodrama is never very far away, and the romance between Martins and Anna Schmidt (played by Alida Valli), once Lime's girl, could be seen as stretching the film a little too far in the direction of Casablanca. But we shouldn't forget the serious core of the film, which embodies in the figure of Harry Lime the corruption and exploitation of the post-war years in central Europe. Lime was, after all, a precursor of the contemporary drug dealer, a fact that makes the film oddly relevant today.

fields.headline: Save our schools
fields.standfirst: Innovation can hurt, but we need it
fields.trailText: It would be easy for an education secretary then to ignore failing schools. In a system of 20,000 primary and 4,500 secondary schools, there are always success stories to highlight. To its credit, this government has not ducked difficult education issues.
fields.body:
It would be easy for an education secretary then to ignore failing schools. In a system of 20,000 primary and 4,500 secondary schools, there are always success stories to highlight. To its credit, this government has not ducked difficult education issues. Sensibly, it made primary education its first priority. It is the foundation for all other levels of education and the sector with the most intractable problems. Four years ago, more than half of all 11-year-olds were failing to reach expected standards. Now, thanks to the focus which ministers applied and new schemes like numeracy and literacy hours, standards have risen dramatically. Seven out of 10 pupils are reaching required standards and the schools are in line to reach the ambitious targets set for 2002 - 75% achieving the standard for numeracy and 80% that for literacy.

Now ministers have turned their attention to secondary schools where there are equally difficult challenges. Last year, 424 schools were recording no more than 15% of pupils passing five GCSE subjects at grades A* to C. That was almost 100 fewer failing schools than in July 1998, but still far too many. So the education secretary introduced a tough new target: schools which fail for three years in a row to get at least 15% of pupils through five good passes at C or above would be subject to closure and put into a "fresh start" programme involving a new name, a new "superhead", and with all existing teachers required to reapply for their jobs.

With some justification, teachers complain that they are being made the scapegoats for society's failings. Worse still, they note that if teachers in the most deprived areas facing the most difficult educational challenges are to be given the most insecure jobs, even the heroic may turn away and opt for an easier life in a school in the leafy suburbs. But David Blunkett has not been deflected. This is tough on teachers, but the right course for an education secretary to pursue. He has to put children's interests first. Ten schools have so far been placed in the fresh start programme. All were given ample warnings through inspections, the introduction of "special measures", or protracted negotiations with department of education officials.

With the third "superhead" resigning this week, Blunkett's critics are having a field day. His response yesterday was the right one: an honest admission that "fresh start" is a risky option, but still better than doing nothing. Heads do make a difference, as Michael Rutter's research of 20 years ago demonstrated. But there are limits to what even the best heads can do on their own. They need support teams and extra resources.

Mr Blunkett unveiled a second option yesterday: new city academies which would be beyond local education authority (LEA) control and rely on local businesses, voluntary bodies, and religious foundations, plus central government subsidies. They would have the right to operate their own curriculum outside "core requirements", and the freedom to "reinvent" the school day as well as to pay teachers more. LEAs are outraged. But they need to keep a sense of perspective. Initially, we are only talking about six institutes. True, they look like a reinvention of Tory city technology colleges, much derided by Labour. But they should be given a chance. We need new ways of making education more relevant for the seriously disaffected. That must include work-based training routes and work-based qualifications. Local business links make sense. We need more experiments, not fewer. We need institutes which will embrace change, not reject it.

fields.headline: Broadside for Blunkett over 'betrayal'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: David Blunkett's latest solution to problems of school failure in the inner cities was vigorously attacked yesterday by leaders of local government and the teaching unions, who saw it as a final betrayal of Labour's 30-year commitment to comprehensive education under local democratic control.
fields.body:
David Blunkett's latest solution to problems of school failure in the inner cities was vigorously attacked yesterday by leaders of local government and the teaching unions, who saw it as a final betrayal of Labour's 30-year commitment to comprehensive education under local democratic control.

In an address to the Social Market Foundation, the education and employment secretary announced plans for "city academies" to be built and managed by businesses, churches and charities in partnership with the government without the involvement of local education authorities.

The academies will get freedom to change the length of the school day and the pattern of terms and holidays. They will have more scope to adjust the curriculum to make space for subject specialisms. And they will be allowed to pay bonuses to attract and retain the best staff. The first is likely to be teaching pupils by September next year.

Graham Lane, Labour education chairman of the Local Government Association, said the scheme was "a half-baked idea" borrowed from the charter school movement in the US. "This is not acceptable. It is the beginning of removing education from local government."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said Mr Blunkett's statement "must be the final nail in the coffin of the traditional comprehensive system, hailed by Labour politicians of the 1960s and 1970s as the answer to many of our educational and social problems."

But, as fuller details of the scheme emerged yesterday, it became clear that Labour ministers were trying to adopt new ideological responses to the problems of educational under-achievement in the inner cities without abandoning the old ones.

Mr Blunkett maintains that he is sticking to the ideal of the all-purpose neighbourhood comprehensive. But he is adding to it a full range of alternative models, including some that were roundly attacked by Labour when they were introduced by Tory ministers in the 1980s. The government intends to run all the models in parallel. What will survive is what works.

"My vision is one of excellence and diversity; a vision of transformation. It is already starting to change the way every secondary school operates ... But we must go further and faster."

The city academies will replace failing or under-achieving schools, usually in the inner cities. They will be newly-built or totally refurbished and run by business, religious or charitable groups in partnership with the government.

The closest models in the British system are the 15 business-led city technology colleges, launched by Conservative ministers in 1988.

These non-selective schools achieved good results. Last year 67% of their GCSE candidates got at least five good passes at Grade A*-C, compared with 40% for the other schools in their areas. Three of the colleges obtained over 90%.

The scheme did not achieve the momentum expected by Tory ministers because business sponsors were unwilling to provide the large investment required, worth about £10m at current prices. Mr Blunkett has not spelled out the sums he wants this time round and he is being more cautious about the eventual number of city academies. Initially there will be "about half a dozen."

Sir Cyril Taylor, chairman of the technology colleges trust, said businesses welcomed Mr Blunkett's plan and were already volunteering as partners. But he suggested that new-build schemes were "not on", due to the heavy investment costs.

The academies will be an alternative to trying to turn round failing schools by giving them a fresh start with a new head and a new name. But in spite of the resignation of three fresh start "superheads" since Friday, Mr Blunkett is not dropping that policy. There are likely to be more fresh starts than academies over the next few years.

In a further experiment in diversity, Mr Blunkett yesterday invited existing independent schools to join the state sector. They may include schools attached to religious denominations, such as the Greek Orthodox church, and educational philosophies, such as the Rudolf Steiner Foundation.

The government wants more successful LEA-run comprehensives to specialise in technology, languages, sport or the arts. There are 480 committed to doing this already and the target for 2003 is 800. Other initiatives include beacon schools, education action zones and additional programmes in the six biggest conurbations.

There is no single model of secondary education in England on which the government will hang its reputation. It will be hard to tell the direction ministers are taking because they will wait to see which bits are working.

Mr de Gruchy said: "This whole business smacks of a touch of panic ... They will not confront the brutal reality which is that these 'fresh start' schools need brilliant leadership backed up by the ability to deal with disruptive youngsters."

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "The net consequence of his blizzard of contradictory initiatives is high staff turnover, headteacher resignation and general dismay and demoralisation."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "The proposal for city academics is the sticking plaster over the government's failure to provide adequate support for schools serving the most disadvantaged communities."

Theresa May, the shadow education and employment secretary, said: "He has had to adopt Conservative policies to provide freedom for all these schools. We want to see the same freedom of self-management and self-determination given to all schools."

But he is adding to it a full range of alternative models, including some that were roundly attacked by Labour when they were introduced by Tory ministers in the 1980s. webTitle: Treasury trumpets power of private sector

fields.headline: Treasury trumpets power of private sector
fields.trailText: Downing Street has overridden Whitehall's doubts to push through the controversial decisions announced yesterday to extend the role of the private sector in the provision of health and education.
fields.body:
Downing Street has overridden Whitehall's doubts to push through the controversial decisions announced yesterday to extend the role of the private sector in the provision of health and education.

Tony Blair has been pushing the health and education departments to swallow ideological doubts and embrace greater private sector provision in an attempt to improve standards.

Downing Street aides insisted: "It is part of the Blair mantra 'Use whatever works'. He is completely unideological about how services are delivered, so long as they are delivered efficiently."

To underline the point the treasury yesterday published a document championing the success of the private sector in financing £12bn public sector projects and promising another £20bn of such projects over the next three years.

In a foreword, unthinkable in tone even five years ago, the treasury chief secretary, Andrew Smith, asserts: "in the modern world, governments are not judged on what they own, or what they spend, but on whether they deliver. In place of the debates between Left and Right, nationalisation versus privatisation, our goal is the modernisation of Britain."

The Treasury paper relishes the way in which business now has a direct role not just in providing former state services, such as school services but also in advising ministers on key policies such as the New Deal, an agenda for economic competitiveness and exploiting the value of Britain's creative industries.

Mr Smith promises every government service over the next five years will be subject to what he describes as a bet ter quality service review.

The review of every government service will consider five options - abolition, introduction of private sector strategic contracting out to the private sector, market testing or internal restructuring.

This may be New Labour hyperbole, but judging by the announcement yesterday to bring in the private sector to run some failing inner city schools, and the assertion by Mr Blair to the British Medical Association that NHS trusts should look to the private sector to provide some services, Mr Blair wants a revolution in the delivery of public services.

webTitle: Problems that fresh start cannot solve

fields.headline: Problems that fresh start cannot solve
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The resignation of Tony Garwood as "superhead" of the East Brighton college of media arts after less than two terms does not tell the full tale of the difficulties faced by failing schools.
fields.body:
The resignation of Tony Garwood as "superhead" of the East Brighton college of media arts after less than two terms does not tell the full tale of the difficulties faced by failing schools.

The fresh start initiative allows failing schools to have a new headteacher, new name and new staff, but it does not banish the old problems.

When the Stanley Deason school, briefly renamed Marina High, became the East Brighton college of media arts the problems were apparent. One staff member left immediately, and by half term a further five had gone.

Now a total of 12 staff have left, and three more have handed in their resignations. One teacher claimed that no one had left for promotion reasons and some had left with no job to go to.

Last year the school had poor GCSE and SAT results, and only 72%of pupils were turning up for classes.

Since September eight pupils have been permanently excluded. Negotiations are under way with the education authority on the issue of unruly behaviour in class.

The problems were long-term ones and unlikely to be solved overnight, said the director of education for Brighton and Hove council, David Hawker. "None of these difficulties is insuperable. The college needs to get sound, solid management to tackle these issues, and I am quite sure they will be able to appoint someone suitable."

The school's intake is largely from the Whitehawk estate, a poor district where more than half the households are without a car, a disproportionate number of children are on free school meals and unemployment is high.

fields.headline: Rover on the brink
fields.standfirst:
The soaring pound is part of the problem

Read what Victor Keegan has to say about Rover
BMW in the UK
Rover home page
Department of Trade and Industry
Transport and General Workers Union
fields.trailText: The main responsibility for the crisis at Longbridge must obviously lie with the Rover company. It has failed to sell enough cars to make the troubled plant viable, even when some of its recent products - like the Rover 75 - have enjoyed critical acclaim.
fields.body:
The main responsibility for the crisis at Longbridge must obviously lie with the Rover company. It has failed to sell enough cars to make the troubled plant viable, even when some of its recent products - like the Rover 75 - have enjoyed critical acclaim. It almost beggars belief that what was once the flagship of the British motor industry has seen its market share wither away to only 5.4% in January, compared with 40% in the 1960s (and 70% in the 1930s). BMW can be criticised for not pulling it round, but it can also be praised for taking on a formidable task that had defeated earlier owners including British Aerospace, the government, and previous private sector owners which ran it into the ground while continuing to pay dividends.

But it is not just Rover's fault. The government is heavily involved too, having wilfully acquiesced in the overvaluation of the pound. This has put a price handicap on Rover's products of up to 20% in export markets. It has also made it more difficult to sell at home because the strong pound has made the sterling cost of imported cars cheaper. This hits Rover much harder than other companies like Ford, because it has traditionally sourced nearly all of its components in the UK. It does not mean Longbridge would have been prosperous with a lower pound - but survival would have been easier.

While Rover was suffering from an overvalued currency during serious world overcapacity, it took another body blow when the European Commission challenged the validity of the government's £150m subsidy to persuade BMW to expand at Longbridge rather than in Hungary. The EC was technically correct, as there were suggestions that BMW had not really seriously considered Hungary and was taking the government for a ride. But the time taken to conduct the inquiry has destabilised Rover.

The uncertainty it cast over its future gave consumers - already postponing purchases in the hope that car prices generally would fall - yet another reason for not buying Rovers. Even now it is possible that a last-minute UK consortium could buy the assets cheaply and, coupled with a speedy response by the EC, that might give Longbridge a last chance. The trouble is that last chances have been coming off the assembly line at Longbridge almost as frequently as cars. Even if it survives yet again, the plant will still have to live with a crazy exchange rate. The government cannot escape responsibility.

fields.headline: White knight hope for Rover
fields.standfirst: Secret British bid lined up to save ailing car firm
fields.trailText: A wealthy British "white knight" has offered to buy BMW's loss-making Rover car plants in a deal that could save thousands of jobs and avert an economic catastrophe in the West Midlands.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire and Mark Milner in Munich
fields.body:
A wealthy British "white knight" has offered to buy BMW's loss-making Rover car plants in a deal that could save thousands of jobs and avert an economic catastrophe in the West Midlands.

Detailed plans tabled by an international financial consortium put together by the businessman will be considered today in Munich by the German company's supervisory board after senior BMW executives decided to cut its losses and dispose of unprofitable plants.

The former UK motor industry executive and his backers have been in secret talks for months with BMW.

He is believed to have submitted proposals to take over Rover's mass production at the Longbridge and Cowley factories, seeking state aid to modernise assembly lines in an effort to make them profitable.

Union leaders flew to Munich last night for crisis talks and Sir Ken Jackson, head of the AEEU engineering union, will seek a meeting in Brussels today with the European Commission president, Romano Prodi, or vice-president Neil Kinnock.

BMW will reveal today that Rover is costing it more than £2m a day with losses totalling around £800m in the last year, and a £1.4bn shortfall over the past two years. The effect is threatening the future of the world's 14th biggest car maker.

Rover sales slumped 26% to 143,343 cars compared with 193,919 in the year before, giving it just 6.25% of the British market.

BMW's share price jumped a record 12.8% when the Rover plan leaked out, indicating it will not backtrack.

Industry secretary Stephen Byers spoke to BMW chief executive Joachim Milberg yesterday as Tony Blair, fearing a political backlash if key Rover plants close, promised the government would do everything in its power to save jobs.

Ministers are all but resigned to BMW shutting or disposing of Longbridge and Cowley, keeping only the money-spinning Solihull Land and Range Rover complex and the Mini. The Mayflower engineering group is in negotiations to buy Rover's Swindon body pressing plant.

BMW directors are to consider the businessman's bid or invite other offers, though one senior Whitehall source suggested the ex-motor industry man's team may be the best option.

"He has the financial backing and has put in a bid. It is now up to BMW. The bottom line is we want to keep all the plants open," said the government insider. A German report claimed the consortium was based in the Cayman Islands.

As many as 50,000 workers could lose their jobs if BMW pulled the plug on Rover without finding a buyer.

The prime minister, DTI and unions were all kept in the dark by BMW, which is on the brink of a major u-turn after insisting in recent months it wanted to maintain the company it bought six years ago.

Mr Blair fears a political backlash if factories go to the wall with as many as 20 marginal seats in the West Midlands alone at risk.

Former Rover managing director Kevin Morley last night denied he was behind the bid. "It's not me - I wish I knew who it was," said Mr Morley.

Other names who industry insiders speculated could be involved included entrepreneur Douglas Llambias who backed a failed bid for Rolls Royce, ex-Jaguar boss Sir John Egan, City management buy- out specialist Doughty Hanson and even Formula One supremo Bernie Ecclestone.

Mayflower was also mentioned as a possible bidder for more than Swindon but the company refused to comment.

The prime minister is to pile pressure on the European commission to approve a £152m aid package for Longbridge. Brussels has held up the aid, crucial to Longbridge's revival, for six months and competition commissioner Mario Monti's office indicated it could be three more months before a decision is reached.

Downing Street fears Eurosceptics will use the delay to whip up another anti-Brussels campaign, ultimately undermining support for the single currency.

The German firm appears to have lost faith in Rover and signalled that the strong pound, with sterling jumping 35 pfennigs to 3.15 marks since a £3bn investment plan to rescue Longbridge was agreed early last year, was also a factor.

"Each pfennig means £8m of increased losses," a spokesman was reported as saying.

Mr Blair said that the government placed "enormous strategic importance" on Rover and declared: "We will do everything we can."

Union leaders fear thousands of jobs will go if Rover is broken up and sold off - and believe Longbridge and Cowley could not survive alone.

"Who's going to buy Long bridge in its current state? Toys 'R' Us?" asked one senior union official while another added: "The maths just don't work."

Tony Woodley, T&G transport union chief motor negotiator, accused the German company of treating its British workforce as "cannon fodder" by keeping them in the dark.

Sir Ken Jackson said: "It will be a catastrophe... the equivalent of dropping a nuclear bomb on the West Midlands."

The damaging uncertainty is likely to cost the company even more customers, adding to its troubles.

BMW pinned many hopes on the award-winning Rover 75 executive model, dubbed the "last chance saloon", yet despite picking up awards around the world it has failed in the showrooms.

Half the 50,000 Rover 75s built are still in the company's car parks awaiting buyers.

Three BMW directors - Henrich Heitmann, Wolfgang Ziebart and Carl-Peter Forster - were reported yesterday to have quit the BMW board over moves to sell parts of Rover.

webTitle: English patient proves an emergency case

fields.headline: English patient proves an emergency case
fields.trailText: The English Patient - as Rover is known rather rudely in Munich - is in intensive care. Today, the men in white coats, in the form of the BMW board, will give their diagnosis of the patient's condition. Whatever the details of the proposals that will be tabled at today's meeting, one thing stands out. After pouring hundreds of millions of pounds into the British car manufacturer, BMW is now looking for the exit.
fields.body:
The English Patient - as Rover is known rather rudely in Munich - is in intensive care. Today, the men in white coats, in the form of the BMW board, will give their diagnosis of the patient's condition. Whatever the details of the proposals that will be tabled at today's meeting, one thing stands out. After pouring hundreds of millions of pounds into the British car manufacturer, BMW is now looking for the exit.

True, the options do include sticking to the plan to turn the group around - although the European commission may be preparing to put a modest-sized spanner in the works there, or indeed looking for yet more savings in order to get the Rover group back into the black.

But neither of those options seems particularly attractive.

Efforts to get the car business back on track are invariably going to run up against the strength of the pound, which shows no sign of dissipating.

Nor does either option suggest BMW has cracked the fundamental problem at Rover, which is that it is not sufficiently upmarket to be a niche player with a premium priced product and does not make enough cars to compete successfully in the volume end of the market.

Selling the bulk of Rover - that is keeping Land Rover and the Mini - must seem a very attractive option in Munich. It would leave BMW with its own profitable upmarket marque, a top level sports utility and one of the most famous cars ever produced in Britain - while gracefully disposing of what has proved to be a huge drain on the group's cash and management resources.

But can it find a buyer? On the face of it selling Rover, especially without the crown jewels, appears an uphill task.

But there are indications that BMW may have more than pious hopes.

There is talk of a bid from a consortium of British investors, for example, and there is no doubt that a serious proposal would have strengthened the hand of those BMW directors opposed to pouring more money into the group and who, according to local reports, seem to have won an internal power struggle.

Whatever the outcome of today's meeting the government is likely to face criticism for not doing enough, and the EC may well come under fire because of the threat to block state aid for the planned investment in Longbridge. Meanwhile, Rover's workforce faces yet another period of worrying uncertainty.

Do or die

There was never really any debate about which way the 298 members of the London stock exchange were going to vote on the subject of demutualisation. It was a case of do something constructive right now - or die.

The business of running a trading forum for financial assets is one of those segments of business where it is all too visible how technology has changed the rules. If the LSE were to disappear at lunchtime today, the market's participants would have a rough and ready replacement up and running by teatime. By early next week, the construction of a new and better system would we well under way. Demutualisation now is a visible symbol of a process which has been under way since Big Bang in 1996, whereby share trading has been progressively concentrated in fewer and fewer hands.

Whether smaller broking firms and the institutions - both large and small - like it or not, it is the Merrill Lynches and Warburgs of this world which do the vast bulk of the business. They are the market.

At the same time these investment banking powerhouses have become global in their reach - as have the needs of their clients. Ask an investment banker over lunch what he or she thinks of the euro and they will tell you that they just do not care - they will invoice clients in whatever currency they want.

For these players, national boundaries represent little more than administrative or bureaucratic divisions. The vast majority of the investment industry has already gone pan-European.

This is why it was no surprise to learn yesterday that the Paris Bourse is in "co-operation talks" - read merger talks - with its counterparts in Amsterdam and Brussels. This is why it is so embarrassing for the City that London's own talks about an alliance with Frankfurt, aimed at bringing all big European exchanges on to one technical trading platform, appear to have been going on for the thick end of two years with little visible evidence of anything constructive being achieved.

There is now a real chance that one day soon we will wake up to news that, say, a dozen American and European investment banks have set up their own electronic trading network, netting 90% of Europe's equity business between them - and that will be that.

Today, the men in white coats, in the form of the BMW board, will give their diagnosis of the patient's condition. Whatever the details of the proposals that will be tabled at today's meeting, one thing stands out. After pouring hundreds of millions of pounds into the British car manufacturer, BMW is now looking for the exit. True, the options do include sticking to the plan to turn the group around - although the European commission may be preparing to put a modest-sized spanner in the works there, or indeed looking for yet more savings in order to get the Rover group back into the black. But neither of those options seems particularly attractive. Efforts to get the car business back on track are invariably going to run up against the strength of the pound, which shows no sign of dissipating. Nor does either option suggest BMW has cracked the fundamental problem at Rover, which is that it is not sufficiently upmarket to be a niche player with a premium priced product and does not make enough cars to compete successfully in the volume end of the market. Selling the bulk of Rover - that is keeping Land Rover and the Mini - must seem a very attractive option in Munich. It would leave BMW with its own profitable upmarket marque, a top level sports utility and one of the most famous cars ever produced in Britain - while gracefully disposing of what has proved to be a huge drain on the group's cash and management resources. But can it find a buyer? On the face of it selling Rover, especially without the crown jewels, appears an uphill task. But there are indications that BMW may have more than pious hopes. There is talk of a bid from a consortium of British investors, for example, and there is no doubt that a serious proposal would have strengthened the hand of those BMW directors opposed to pouring more money into the group and who, according to local reports, seem to have won an internal power struggle. Whatever the outcome of today's meeting the government is likely to face criticism for not doing enough, and the EC may well come under fire because of the threat to block state aid for the planned investment in Longbridge. Meanwhile, Rover's workforce faces yet another period of worrying uncertainty. Do or die There was never really any debate about which way the 298 members of the London stock exchange were going to vote on the subject of demutualisation. It was a case of do something constructive right now - or die. The business of running a trading forum for financial assets is one of those segments of business where it is all too visible how technology has changed the rules. If the LSE were to disappear at lunchtime today, the market's participants would have a rough and ready replacement up and running by teatime. By early next week, the construction of a new and better system would we well under way. Demutualisation now is a visible symbol of a process which has been under way since Big Bang in 1996, whereby share trading has been progressively concentrated in fewer and fewer hands. Whether smaller broking firms and the institutions - both large and small - like it or not, it is the Merrill Lynches and Warburgs of this world which do the vast bulk of the business. They are the market. At the same time these investment banking powerhouses have become global in their reach - as have the needs of their clients. Ask an investment banker over lunch what he or she thinks of the euro and they will tell you that they just do not care - they will invoice clients in whatever currency they want. For these players, national boundaries represent little more than administrative or bureaucratic divisions. The vast majority of the investment industry has already gone pan-European. This is why it was no surprise to learn yesterday that the Paris Bourse is in "co-operation talks" - read merger talks - with its counterparts in Amsterdam and Brussels. This is why it is so embarrassing for the City that London's own talks about an alliance with Frankfurt, aimed at bringing all big European exchanges on to one technical trading platform, appear to have been going on for the thick end of two years with little visible evidence of anything constructive being achieved. There is now a real chance that one day soon we will wake up to news that, say, a dozen American and European investment banks have set up their own electronic trading network, netting 90% of Europe's equity business between them - and that will be that.

webTitle: Big is better becomes motto for car makers' survival

fields.headline: Big is better becomes motto for car makers' survival
fields.standfirst: Pressure to cut costs and reduce product ranges
fields.trailText: The motive behind the rush of motor industry takeovers and alliances in recent years has been the belief that car makers have to be big to survive.
fields.body:
The motive behind the rush of motor industry takeovers and alliances in recent years has been the belief that car makers have to be big to survive.

Ford has bought Jaguar and Volvo Cars, while Daimler Benz, maker of Mercedes, has merged with Chrysler, the third largest US car manufacturer, to create a £21bn group.

Renault has rescued the heavily indebted Nissan, the largest Japanese car maker after Toyota, and last week General Motors bought a stake in Fiat, Italy's leading vehicle manufacturer.

The thinking behind these mergers was that size would bring stronger purchasing power as well as economies of scale in an increasingly global market. Volkswagen, Europe's biggest car maker, followed this thinking when it bought Skoda and Seat, and BMW thought likewise when it bought Rover.

The cost of developing and building new models has soared as consumers have demanded more features and governments have insisted on better safety and environmental standards.

The industry's response has been to concentrate on having fewer basic vehicle structures, or platforms, which can account for up to 70% of a car's cost, while offering a wider range of models on each platform.

Volkswagen, for example, offers seven different cars ranging from an upmarket Audi to a humble Skoda on just one platform. Different bodywork and interior trim create a new model at a fraction of the cost of a new platform.

In addition, the big car makers want a presence in all sectors of the market. Daimler and BMW were essentially up-market manufacturers which added volume production by acquiring Chrysler and Rover respectively. Conversely, Ford plugged a gap at the top end of its range by buying Jaguar and Volvo.

Volkswagen bought the Rolls-Royce motor company after a long drawn out bidding battle with BMW to get into the luxury market. But its scheme received a setback when BMW won the rights to the Rolls-Royce car trade mark. VW, however, retained the Bentley marque for its luxury car.

Consolidation within the industry has been driven by takeover bids, where price has been the determining factor, and by financial woes.

Nissan was forced to seek a cash-rich partner after reporting losses for six out of seven years. Renault finally bought a 37% stake for $5.4bn and put in its own man to turn the company around.

Not all car makers are convinced that big is better. PSA, the French company which owns Peugeot and Citroen, believes that a smaller player can find scope to be successful. It has proved its point in the UK, where it is number three for sales behind Ford and Vauxhall but way ahead of Rover.

webTitle: Speaking in foreign tongues is cool

fields.headline: Speaking in foreign tongues is cool
fields.trailText: An $8m campaign to make Tony Blair's concept of a modern-minded, more pro-Europe "Cool Britannia" attractive to overseas students (Learning English, February 24) is all very well, but it will take more than a marketing makeover to make it happen.
fields.body:
An $8m campaign to make Tony Blair's concept of a modern-minded, more pro-Europe "Cool Britannia" attractive to overseas students (Learning English, February 24) is all very well, but it will take more than a marketing makeover to make it happen.

The keys to a positive attitude to mainland Europe and to its students lie in openness and exposure to the cultures, people and institutions of other European countries. All these are mediated through language. For this reason the European Union has repeatedly stressed the importance of language learning, both in achieving socio-political objectives such as mutual understanding, respect and the development of European citizenship, and in achieving economic aims such as the mobility of capital and labour in a multicultural, economic area.

But while language learning is thriving in most European countries, in Britain the market share of "specialist" language learning among 18-year-olds taking A-level exams and beyond is in decline, with French particularly hard hit.

The problem is visible in Britain's schools. The increase in the number of candidates taking GCSE in a modern foreign language, at 16 years, is not being matched by a corresponding increase in the number taking a language at A level.

So what is putting them off? Perhaps the lack of congruence between GCSE and A level in terms of syllabus and methodology has made the transition from GCSE to A level too daunting for many students.

Perhaps the national curriculum has left less space for students to study two foreign languages than was previously the case, and has thereby undermined early specialisation in languages - a 1997 Teacher Training Agency report identified the dwindling number of dual linguists at GCSE and A level as one of the causes of the shortage in teacher supply.

Perhaps young people are now finding their role models and preferred lifestyles elsewhere in the English-speaking world, and are not aspiring to live in countries where English is not the mother tongue.

Or perhaps the view that the rest of the world speaks English is now being consolidated by the belief that emerging language technologies will soon be able to sort out translation problems in the odd corners of the globe where it is not spoken.

Whatever the causes, the introduction, from next year, of cash incentives to entice languages graduates into teaching is a very public admission of just how bad things have become.

The fact that around one-third of modern foreign language teacher trainees in Britain are from overseas further illustrates the depth of the problem.

The Higher Education Funding Council for England has recognised that languages are expensive to teach, and has made more money available (though not yet for French). Yet the council's recent suggestion that universities should consider "rationalising" language departments collaboratively and on a regional basis has not been thought through, and may lead to further decline.

Language associations believe that the funding council has failed to recognise the enormous growth in "non-specialist" language learning over the past decade, and therefore badly underestimates the total volume of language learning in universities. These students are not "visible" in the statistical returns made by universities to the council.

It has already been suggested that Britain needs a collective, long-term perspective that recognises the need to stimulate demand rather than cut supply if a bad situation is not to become much worse.

Closing down, selectively pruning or otherwise "rationalising" languages departments will not help "Cool Britannia" one iota, and existing funding arrangements may need further modification to support modern foreign languages through this difficult period.

There needs to be the kind of serious thinking that can only be provided by a national policy on modern languages encompassing the various branches of compulsory and post-compulsory education.

Perhaps the forthcoming final report of the Nuffield inquiry into British higher education will help bring the country one step closer to realising that objective.

Meanwhile the UK needs to take every opportunity to challenge the myth that monolingualism is somehow "cool".

"Cool, mon cul," as the French pop star Zazie might have said.

 Derrik Ferney is head of languages and intercultural studies at Anglia Polytechnic University, England

fields.headline: Rwanda builds with English
fields.trailText: One consequence of Rwanda's social upheaval in the aftermath of the 1994 genocide has been the reshaping of the country's linguistic identity. Since colonial times Rwandans have spoken French as a second language to their native Kinyarwanda. But the return of English-speaking refugees from Anglophone countries has opened up the prospect of French being supplanted by English as the language of education and international trade.
fields.body:
One consequence Rwanda's social upheaval in the aftermath of the 1994 genocide has been the reshaping of the country's linguistic identity. Since colonial times Rwandans have spoken French as a second language to their native Kinyarwanda. But the return of large numbers of English-speaking refugees from Anglophone countries, some of whom fled as long ago as 1959, has opened up the prospect of French being supplanted by English as the language of education and international trade.

In recent years Rwanda's coalition government has implemented an unofficial policy to introduce English into education, motivated more by necessity than by choice. In order to rebuild the education system and meet the needs of returned anglophone refugees, the government has had to rely on both francophone and anglophone manpower from neighbouring countries. Foreign donors, especially anglophone countries, have also pledged aid and books to help the struggling system assimilate this third language.

There is strategic economic reasoning behind this policy. Geographically Rwanda is well placed between francophone Central Africa and anglophone East Africa, so adopting a bilingual policy, it is hoped, will open the doors to both regions, and encourage greater trade, commerce and cultural exchanges with its neighbours. Rwanda has already developed increased trading ties with South Africa, has joined Comesa, and hopes to join the East African Community by the end of the year.

Rwanda is unusual in that all the ethnic groups in the country share a common mother tongue in Kinyarwanda. Even those born in exile kept the language alive. This reduces the opportunities for French or English usage which, in turn, makes it harder for learners of second languages to practise outside the classroom.

In the country's three main tertiary-level educational institutes lectures are conducted in French or English, depending on the lecturer available for the subject. Therefore, all students are required to be proficient in both languages, and a range of pre-sessional training and on-going language support is provided.

Yet one of the main hurdles facing these institutes and their lecturers is the lack of commitment from some anglophone students to learn French. The strong anglophone contingent within Rwanda's political, administrative and military hierarchy merely reinforces the perception that English is the preferred language of political influence and power.

Last June anglophone students from the three main higher-education institutions marched to the parliament to protest that they were being forced to study in a language that they had no interest in learning. The response by the ministry of education (Mineduc) was to expel the ringleaders from their colleges.

Fractious students, however, are in the minority. Most francophone students are keen to adopt English as a third language, understanding that it will increase employment and further educational opportunities for them, as well as strengthen Rwanda's human resource base.

But Mineduc faces an even greater challenge in persuading young people to take up teaching as a profession. A teacher's salary in Rwanda is low - $100-$160 a month - and most schools are poorly equipped. Mineduc hopes to encourage newly trained teachers to stay in Rwanda by offering free training in return for a commitment to work in the education system for at least four years after graduating.

Rwanda's current climate is one of optimism for the future, and most people are dedicated to the vision of an integrated, trilingual society. The general feeling is that although this is a highly ambitious undertaking, it is the right strategy for the country's social and economic reconstruction.

 John and Emma Whelan are VSO volunteers working in Rwanda as EFL teachers

fields.headline: Taking up references
fields.standfirst: Christopher Tribble tests the new online Oxford English Dictionary, but finds other resources more useful to learners
fields.trailText: Christopher Tribble tests the new online Oxford English Dictionary, but finds other resources more useful to learners
fields.body:
This week Oxford University Press launches a new version of its flagship Oxford English Dictionary - the OED Online. But it's not the first dictionary on the Web, it's not cheap ($550 for a single subscriber - compared with $400 for the CD-rom version), and it wasn't designed with English language learners in mind. However, as an inveterate dictionary user, I was still interested to find out what it had to offer, and if teachers who aren't able to get online are missing out.

When I am teaching or teacher training, I usually work with the main learners' dictionaries, all of which are excellent in their different ways. They focus on the needs of language students, and give information about pronunciation, grammar and usage that you don't find in a dictionary written for experts. But will new online dictionaries such as this edition of the OED take over from paper or CD-Rom, and do they give us yet another reason for getting connected to the internet?

Oxford University Press claims that with the OED Online users will be able to see at least 1,000 new and revised entries each quarter, search through the whole dictionary with speed and ease, display entries according to users' needs. This edition lets you turn pronunciation, etymologies, variant spellings and quotations on and off, and compare revised entries with entries from the Second Edition to see how the language has changed. But is this useful?

I decided to look up the word "bother" (as in "Why bother?", or "What a bother!") and logged on to the site. After I'd given my name and password I was sent to a query page where I typed in my word, and waited. The first problem was that it was slow to process my query - it took around a minute-and-a-half for the answer to come up. This may be a problem local to Sri Lanka, where I live, but it shows one of the disadvantages of online reference sources for those of us who don't have really fast Web access, and is a major disincentive to using online dictionaries in the classroom.

Once the result came up I was presented with a basic choice between "bother v" and "bother n" - not exactly user-friendly for English language students. I chose bother v and after another couple of minutes I got a page giving me the following information: "1 trans. To bewilder with noise; to confuse, muddle; to put into a fluster or flutter. Obs."

Fine. But what if I don't know what muddle, fluster and flutter mean? And what about "Obs."? Does it stand for "obsolete"? The quotations that followed, left me feeling that it did: "1718 T SHERIDAN To Swift in Swift's Wks (1824) XV. 107 'With the din of which tube my head you so bother. 1832-53 Whistle-Binkie (Sc Songs) Ser I 22 The hearts of the maids, and the gentlemen's heads, were bother'd, I'm sure, by this Irishman'."

When you strip the entry down to a bare definition, it's still difficult to understand, and if you have the full OED account of the word, you spend ages getting to the more recent (and more relevant) entry. An historical approach to dictionary making, the fundamental principle behind OED, does not work well for people who are mainly concerned with here-and-now problems of understanding what words mean, and how to use them. Even the carrot of the "1,000 new entries a quarter" is not much consolation for someone who is trying to get to grips with the 1,000 most common words in the language.

Which takes us to alternatives, and there are several. Staying on the Web, there are two sites that have an immediate appeal. The first is the Collins Cobuild Students' Dictionary. This is a free service available from Cobuild and hosted by Bochum-Ruhr university in Germany. If you look up "bother" in this dictionary the first entry you get is determined by its frequency of occurrence in the "Bank of English" at Birmingham university, a huge corpus of contemporary written and spoken English.

This means that what you see on screen is: "1 If you do not bother to do something, you do not do it, because you think it is unnecessary or would involve too much effort. [VB] 'I never bother to iron my shirts.' 'Don't bother with the washing-up'."

You are immediately taken to useful information, and it is presented in a form that is easy to understand. In addition, if you click on the pair of lips next to the head-word, you get a natural "live-audio" example of how the word is pronounced.

A competitor to the Cobuild is the Cambridge International Dictionary from Cambridge University Press. This is also a free service, but carries a lot more advertising content - and doesn't have live audio. However, the interface is simple and easy to use, response times are reasonable and the information is useful.

Looking at "bother" again, the first entry from CUP is: "bother (MAKE AN EFFORT) verb to make the effort to do something, or to take the trouble to do something". This is then followed by a large number of informative examples - a good demonstration of where electronic dictionaries can win out over their paper parents.

These are the only two free offerings from the big British publishers. Longman is introducing a new paid service, which looks as if it will be good, but which isn't free. Meanwhile Oxford University Press is developing an online version of its Advanced Learners' dictionary.

Putting the needs of learners aside, the OED remains a wonderful Rolls Royce of a dictionary, and I have always enjoyed using it in its different incarnations. For my personal use, apart from the learners' dictionaries, I use the Shorter Oxford because I like the etymologies and the more concise historical approach. However, I have also to admit a preference for the Microsoft Encarta World English Dictionary on CD-Rom. I like the definitions it gives and enjoy the ease of working with it. But I wouldn't use it if I had to pay for a phone call every time I needed to remind myself of the difference between "principle" and "principal".

Dictionaries online

OED Online
Collins Cobuild Students' Dictionary
Cambridge International Dictionary

 Christopher Tribble is a freelance consultant in applied linguistics, based in Sri Lanka

If you look up "bother" in this dictionary the first entry you get is determined by its frequency of occurrence in the "Bank of English" at Birmingham university, a huge corpus of contemporary written and spoken English. This means that what you see on screen is: "1 If you do not bother to do something, you do not do it, because you think it is unnecessary or would involve too much effort. [VB] 'I never bother to iron my shirts.' 'Don't bother with the washing-up'." You are immediately taken to useful information, and it is presented in a form that is easy to understand. In addition, if you click on the pair of lips next to the head-word, you get a natural "live-audio" example of how the word is pronounced. A competitor to the Cobuild is the Cambridge International Dictionary from Cambridge University Press. This is also a free service, but carries a lot more advertising content - and doesn't have live audio. However, the interface is simple and easy to use, response times are reasonable and the information is useful. Looking at "bother" again, the first entry from CUP is: "bother (MAKE AN EFFORT) verb to make the effort to do something, or to take the trouble to do something". This is then followed by a large number of informative examples - a good demonstration of where electronic dictionaries can win out over their paper parents. These are the only two free offerings from the big British publishers. Longman is introducing a new paid service, which looks as if it will be good, but which isn't free. Meanwhile Oxford University Press is developing an online version of its Advanced Learners' dictionary. However, I have also to admit a preference for the Microsoft Encarta World English Dictionary on CD-Rom. I like the definitions it gives and enjoy the ease of working with it. But I wouldn't use it if I had to pay for a phone call every time I needed to remind myself of the difference between "principle" and "principal". webTitle: Only the organised will survive in-service teacher training

fields.headline: Only the organised will survive in-service teacher training
fields.standfirst: Sarah Nicholson says prepare to have your life taken over for the duration of a diploma-level course
fields.trailText: Sarah Nicholson says prepare to have your life taken over for the duration of a diploma-level course
fields.body:
When I was told, before I started a University of Cambridge Diploma in English Language Teaching to Adults (DELTA) course, that it would completely take over my life, I didn't believe it. I naively thought I would be able to work full-time, do the course work and have a life. It wasn't long before I realised my mistake. So let me give a word of warning: the DELTA demands will eat up every last minute of your time, and the only way to minimise the effects of unrealistic requirements is to be organised from the start.

Candidates are required to write about 23,000 words throughout the course, and the quicker you get down to it, the less traumatic it will seem. Colleagues who studied for the old-style Cambridge diploma may claim that they had a harder time because they had to do seven observed lessons, and DELTA requires only five. But they didn't have to write a 2,000-word essay before each one. (Nor did they have to write a 500-word assessment of the lesson afterwards, which is even more difficult.)

On the other hand, feel free to pick their brains as to what constitutes a good "diploma lesson" and do let them check your lesson plan - especially the aims - as the wording doesn't change much. You will fail the lesson if your aims aren't perceived to be clear and to have been achieved.

The 4,000-word case study is a worthwhile task, but it does eat up your time. If you're doing the nine-month course (from September to June), I'd suggest collecting the data (eg, photocopying a student's homework, recording him or her, etc) in the first term, but writing up the results at the end of the second term, by which time you should be able to incorporate some of what you've learnt.

You can also make life a bit easier for yourself by choosing a student whose first language you know. I took a two-week break at Easter so that I could have a much-needed rest as well as write up the case study. If you're brave enough to do an intensive 10-week DELTA course, then quite simply, you've got to take some time off, or you'll go mad.

Another practical point if you choose to do the nine-month course is to check that your school will have students all year round. Observed lessons require a minimum of five students, which can be difficult in small schools over a holiday period. You may have to "borrow" students for the lesson, but the procedure needs some forward planning.

As far as the actual lessons are concerned, my advice would be to involve the students wherever possible. Most students will do their best to be co-operative on the day if they are aware how important it is. One group I taught insisted on knowing all about the exam, the qualification and what benefits it would bring me.

If you have a young family, as one of my DELTA colleagues did (his son was born five days before the exam) then prepare to live your life in a state of perpetual exhaustion. His advice was: enlist the help of your family - get them to help with typing up the essays, for example.

Whichever course you do, it is vital to keep up. The work piles up relentlessly, and the only way not to fall behind is to do each assignment as soon as possible. (Don't be like one of my colleagues, who finished his case study at 5am on the morning of the written exam.)

Remember also that the exam itself differs from the old-style DipTEFLA not just in the fact that it is only written (the case study counts as part of the written exam and must be passed) but in its practical, classroom-based nature. Rather than requiring facts to be reproduced in essay format, the DELTA exam consists of nine "tasks" for which the data is already given.

The DELTA is not a difficult course, but the workload makes it a demanding one - it has to be done regardless of what else is happening in your life. Like any teaching qualification, you have to "play the game" if you want to pass. You may need to keep your mouth shut if your personal teaching style diverges from what is prescribed by the course.

However, I certainly found the DELTA a lot less prescriptive than the certificate course that I did. The tutors were more willing to see us as individuals with experience to build on, rather than as robots who had to be programmed to teach in a certain way. And it was that very willingness of the tutors to accept that there is no "magic formula" in teaching that made the DELTA course one that, with hindsight, was worth doing.

 Sarah Nicholson is a lecturer in English for Academic Purposes at Hertfordshire University, England. For more information on DELTA contact the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate

fields.headline: Labour's ethical arms body outgunned
fields.standfirst: Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: Labour was accused yesterday of abandoning its ethical foreign policy after it emerged that the government's budget to promote overseas arms sales is more than 40 times the size of a flagship initiative to convert Britain's defence industries to civilian use.
fields.body:
Labour was accused yesterday of abandoning its ethical foreign policy after it emerged that the government's budget to promote overseas arms sales is more than 40 times the size of a flagship initiative to convert Britain's defence industries to civilian use.

In a series of parliamentary answers, the defence minister, Lewis Moonie, admitted that the diversification agency, which was set up as a key element of Labour's new ethical foreign policy, has a budget of just £1.1m. By contrast the defence exports services organisation, which promotes British arms sales, was given £45m last year.

The Tories last night seized on the discrepancies between the two budgets to claim that the government is failing to uphold its ethical foreign policy, which was launched immediately after the election to place less emphasis on British overseas arms sales. Robert Key, the shadow defence minister, said: "We believe it is right to support the defence industry but this two-faced attitude is yet another example of Labour saying one thing and doing another."

In its manifesto for the last election, Labour held up its plans to establish the defence diversification agency as a powerful example of its determination to break free from the Tories' blind support for the arms industry.
