fields.headline: Weary Russia turns to Putin
fields.standfirst:
Voters yearn for stability after a decade of mayhem

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Voters yearn for stability after a decade of mayhem
fields.body:
Nikolai Ivanov strode into the mining institute on the banks of the river Neva yesterday with a fistful of dog-eared documents, yellowing education certificates and type-written letters to the Russian government and Vladimir Putin.

On the day that Russian sailors at sea and others in remote regions went to the polls to crown Mr Putin, a native son of St Petersburg, Russia's most liberal and most crime-ridden city, as the new ruler of Russia in presidential elections, Mr Ivanov, a 73-year-old pensioner, had a message for the president-to-be.

"I'm only getting the average monthly pension of 650 roubles [£14 ] and I should be getting 800. I want the acting president to do something about it. He's young, he's a lawyer, he's smart, and he's not compromised. We're proud of him around here."

He slapped his papers down on the desk and told a young student working on the Putin campaign to make sure the acting president got his letter.

The mining institute, where Mr Putin once completed a doctoral thesis on the regional economy, is doing its bit to get its former PhD student elected. The 250-year-old institute hosts one of dozens of "Putin reception points", swiftly established in cities such as St Petersburg and Moscow to show that the candidate is listening.

Mr Putin himself says he is too busy with affairs of state to descend to the vulgar world of electioneering; he recently likened television campaigning to selling "Tampax or Snickers bars" and announced that his campaign was forgoing TV spots.

However, the mining institute is being inundated with pleas for help from the public. Widows arrive demanding financial support, young mothers show up to plead for housing help, war veterans complain they are not getting the respect they deserve.

"We're the filter between the people and the acting president of the Russian Federation," explains Alexander Kudryavtsev, 24, an engineering student working for Mr Putin. "Sometimes there are queues here. We try to help and pass on the requests to the relevant government departments."

Vladimir Litvinenko, the institute's rector and a friend of Mr Putin, is in charge of 15 such centres across St Petersburg. "We get 200 people looking for help every day, plus letters and phone calls," he said.

The people come to the Putin courtiers with their pleas and petitions in the hope that, just maybe, some of them will get lucky. Fate will not smile on most, but they will vote for Mr Putin anyway on March 26.

"Don't know much about Putin," admits Mr Ivanov. "But I see him on TV. He's a good sportsman. Old Yeltsin was sick. Putin will be better. I'll definitely be voting for him. We just want some stability."

The yearning for stability after a decade of upheaval and confusion is a key factor in Mr Putin's appeal to Russians. Where Mr Yeltsin was unpredictable, capricious and often drunk, Mr Putin projects an aura of discipline, rationality and sobriety.

The Putin camp has cast their candidate in the role of pioneer of a new brand of Russian "anti-politics", engaged in a "non-campaign" for the presidency. No TV spots, no set-piece speeches, no manifesto, no rallies.

If his comparison of electioneering to selling sanitary towels suggests mild contempt for the electoral process, then he went further in a book of revealing interviews published this week, in which he appeared to view elections as tiresome distractions.

Musing about the Romanov dynasty's role in Russian history, Mr Putin said: "The sovereign does not have to think whether he will be re-elected. He can think about the destiny of his people without being distracted by trifles."

A pre-election distribution ban has been slapped on the book, so it cannot be sold in shops, but Mr Putin's camp is thought to supplying it to all who express an interest.

The precaution will probably be unnecessary; opinion polls put him at 60%, with his nearest challenger, Gennady Zyuganov, the communist leader, at around 25%.

But the fact that the election is a foregone conclusion does not mean that Mr Putin is not campaigning. It does, however, mean that state television can afford to dispense with the smear tactics against Mr Putin's opponents that characterised the runup to last December's parliamentary elections.

The president-to-be is on television every night, shown crisscrossing the country, visiting factories and hospitals, handing out arts awards and mingling with women for International Women's Day. The broadcasts depict voters remarking on how well Mr Putin walks, or how his 16 years in the KGB prove how clever he is since the KGB "does not employ fools".

The party's or candidate's policy details are utterly absent because Russians are weary of political parties, programmes and squabbling; an ambitious programme setting out Mr Putin's 10-year development plan for Russia, drafted by a think-tank he had set up, was to be issued before the election, but has now been postponed until after March 26.

But the well-crafted image of the 47-year-old does not wash with everyone, not even in his home town. Sasha, a St Petersburg building worker, is disgusted by the war in Chechnya and does not trust Mr Putin.

"Anyone willing to spill another's blood like that will soon enough spill the blood of his own people," he says.

However, Sasha is in the minority; Mr Putin's vague promises of a revitalised Russia restored as a great power are striking a chord across the country.

webTitle: Regent Pacific puts on a hi-tech face

fields.headline: Regent Pacific puts on a hi-tech face
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Surfing the technology tsunami is not as a big challenge as it might have been a year ago with investors gaining confidence to pour money into companies that have still to deliver real earnings and customers.
fields.body:
Surfing the technology tsunami is not as a big challenge as it might have been a year ago with investors gaining confidence to pour money into companies that have still to deliver real earnings and customers.

Among those investors making the leap of faith have been the more conservative and deep-pocketed pension funds, including Hong Kong-based Regent Pacific Group.

Jim Mellon, chairman of Regent Pacific which has $1.1bn (£700m) under management, said: "We want to focus on finding hi-tech companies with global opportunities but which are resource poor. We have been an early investor in a number of Asian internet companies and have built up an excellent portfolio."

In fact, Regent Pacific's convictions about technology and the web yesterday saw it announce a major corporate restructuring aimed at focusing on those two sectors in Asia.

Regent Pacific will change its name to Interman Holdings, an internet investment group it acquired. It will spin off its eastern European operations, which account for half of its funds under management but are not core to the group's strategy. The remainder of its funds under management are in Asian equities where the group will build up its technology fund investments for clients.

Regent Pacific also wants to expand its venture capital arm, which has taken stakes in 26 internet companies in the past two years averaging between $250,000 and $3m a start-up. Those investments include shopping site bigsave.com, financial services group techpacific.com and Chinese-language search engine Netease.

Mr Mellon and Peter Everington, the British fund managers who run Regent Pacific, have also reduced the group's shareholding in internet firm KoreaOnline from 60% to 46.2% to raise $117m to reinvest in that business. Korea Online is aiming to be that country's primary insurance portal and will seek a listing on Nasdaq in the summer.

Yet what the reshaping of Regent Pacific may be more about is its sagging share price which was near $HK2.575 yesterday (21 pence). The group listed in 1997 at $HK2.62.

The Nasdaq listing of KoreaOnline is also a tactic in trying to realise the value of that investment to the Regent Pacific share price, estimated at $HK1.97 a share.

They defend the share price by saying the company has paid out $94m in dividends to its shareholders, which include investment guru Sir John Templeton and Japan-based Total Marine and Fire Insurance, in the past three years. It also boasts a 50% unleveraged return on equity over six of the past seven years.

"We shall continue to target a return on unleveraged equity in excess of 50% and believe this to be entirely consistent with our focus on the internet," Mr Mellon said.

webTitle: Chat room trades result in charges

fields.headline: Chat room trades result in charges
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The first big insider dealing case involving the internet has opened in New York with two of the main defendants pleading guilty to their part in a £5m fraud. In total, 19 people have been charged with trading secrets in chat rooms.
fields.body:
The first big insider dealing case involving the internet has opened in New York with two of the main defendants pleading guilty to their part in a £5m fraud. In total, 19 people have been charged with trading secrets in chat rooms.

The case is likely to fuel concerns, voiced recently by financial services authority chairman Howard Davies, that similar practices will distort market activity in Britain.

FBI assistant director Lewis Schiliro said many fraudsters hoped the internet would provide a cover for their illegal activities.

"Those who rely on the myth of anonymity in using the internet to pursue their criminal activity should understand that law enforcement has the ability to pierce the veil they hide behind," he said.

At the core of the scheme, authorities said, was John Freeman, a part-time computer graphics worker who allegedly stole information from two investment banks, Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston, for whom he was working.

The criminal complaint filed in United States district court in New York, accused Freeman of starting the scheme in mid-1997 after he lost money investing in a helmet manufacturer.

He made contact over the net with other disgruntled investors and suggested they trade on inside tips he was able to pick up in the course of his work.

Freeman, 34, of Brooklyn, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit insider trading and other charges.

Also pleading guilty was insurance agent James Cooper, who had traded on Freeman's information.

Sentencing has been deferred until September 15, when both men could face 10 years in prison each plus fines of about £700,000.

Freeman himself took a cut of the profits made by his "virtual" circle of investors, said the securities and exchange commission (SEC), the American financial regulator.

He staked none of his own money, believing the stock market to be too risky.

SEC enforcement chief Richard Walker said the case was "one of the most elaborate insider trading schemes in history".

He said he found it alarming to see a resumption of widespread insider dealing similar to the economic boom days of the 1980s.

The SEC said this is the first insider dealing case in which it is alleged that sensitive information was passed over the internet.

Among others accused of participating in the fraud are a dentist, a retired schoolteacher, a car salesman and a waiter. Associated Press

He made contact over the net with other disgruntled investors and suggested they trade on inside tips he was able to pick up in the course of his work. Freeman, 34, of Brooklyn, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit insider trading and other charges. Also pleading guilty was insurance agent James Cooper, who had traded on Freeman's information. Sentencing has been deferred until September 15, when both men could face 10 years in prison each plus fines of about £700,000. Freeman himself took a cut of the profits made by his "virtual" circle of investors, said the securities and exchange commission (SEC), the American financial regulator. He staked none of his own money, believing the stock market to be too risky. SEC enforcement chief Richard Walker said the case was "one of the most elaborate insider trading schemes in history". He said he found it alarming to see a resumption of widespread insider dealing similar to the economic boom days of the 1980s. The SEC said this is the first insider dealing case in which it is alleged that sensitive information was passed over the internet. Among others accused of participating in the fraud are a dentist, a retired schoolteacher, a car salesman and a waiter. Associated Press

webTitle: Sema grabs telecoms software firm for $4.7bn

fields.headline: Sema grabs telecoms software firm for $4.7bn
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Anglo-French computer services group Sema bolstered its presence in the United States yesterday with an agreed all share $4.7bn (£3bn) takeover of mobile telecommunications software company LHS.
fields.body:
Anglo-French computer services group Sema bolstered its presence in the United States yesterday with an agreed all share $4.7bn (£3bn) takeover of mobile telecommunications software company LHS.

But the the company immediately ran into trouble after it was accused of overpaying and investors reacted by wiping £1.2bn from its market value.

Sema's shares slid 227p to £14.43 on concerns that it was paying too much for LHS. Sema has offered 2.6 of its shares for each LHS share, valuing LHS stock at $69.70 each. The offer was well above LHS's closing price of $39.62 on Tuesday.

Richard Hunter, head of dealing services at NatWest stockbrokers, said: "It's not something the market has taken a shine to. It thinks Sema is overpaying."

He said compounding Sema's problems had been a drop in Nasdaq this week "and that has kicked some of the stuffing out of technology shares".

LHS, which operates in Germany and America, would give Sema greater geographic coverage, expertise in mobile billing and operations support systems, product cross-selling opportunities and further development of mobile e-commerce products, the company said.

Pierre Bonelli, Sema's chief executive, said: "The main rationale behind this merger is the ability to create substantial opportunities for revenue enhancement through market share."

Sema says it will command between 35%-40% of the mobile software communications market after the acquisition with 140m subscribers.

Mr Bonelli denied the price offered for LHS was too much. "There will be some cost reduction, but this is minor compared to the synergies in revenue enhancement," he said.

The group did not state how much revenues would be boosted from the acquisition, however, analysts were forecasting it would increase 2001 earnings per share of 21p by a further 10%. The turnover it sources from mobile telephony will leap from 16% to 25% with the breakdown of its other revenues spread over the public sector and finance sectors each representing 18%, transport and industry each at 12%, energy and services both 6% and defence 3%.

LHS chief executive Gary Cuccio said the merger would give his firm scale and access to big-name clients. "Sema gives us that power to address the very largest mobile carriers."

fields.headline: Sitting pretty
fields.standfirst:
Lastminute.com is Britain's newest business bestseller - and it got there using the oldest trick in the book. Liz McGregor joins the dots
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com is Britain's newest business bestseller - and it got there using the oldest trick in the book. Liz McGregor joins the dots.
fields.body:
One can't open a newspaper or switch on the television these days without being confronted by the smiling face of Martha Lane Fox of Lastminute.com, yesterday launched on the stock market for a cool £733m. Yesterday's London Evening Standard carried no fewer than four pictures of her. Lane Fox, 27, has hit the two zeitgeist buttons: youth and internet. A picture of her hangs in the National Portrait Gallery. She has become the face of the youthful dot.com companies transforming the City.

It's refreshing that the giant strides of cyberspace appear to have put a Prada trainer through the glass ceilings still cramping old-fashioned companies. Not only is Lane Fox a woman, she's also a young woman. In a traditional company, she might have made assistant brand manager at 35; the dot.com industry has made her joint boss of her own company and a virtual millionaire in her 20s. But does MarthaLane.com really represent a victory for women or is the new female face of the internet as big a confidence trick as sceptics claim the whole dot.com boom to be?

The truth is that Lane Fox is something of an anomaly in the internet world, which is still overwhelmingly male-led. Lastminute.com was in fact the brainchild of her partner, Brent Hoberman. The decision to make Lane Fox the public face of Lastminute.com is yet another of the smart moves of this extremely smart pair. He is frank about it: "She's prettier than me and a good ambassador for the internet. It makes people realise it's not just run by geeks eating cold pizza."

Their company is innovative, dynamic, exciting. So are hundreds of other dot.com companies, yet theirs boasts the second highest recognition factor of all internet sites after Amazon.com. The promotion of Lane Fox as brand icon has given Lastminute.com a huge competitive advantage. Her image is glamorous, sexy, spontaneous, successful, fun-loving: everything Lastminute wants to convey about what it has to sell. And, crucially, she is female.

Lane Fox is netty totty, her role not a million miles from that of the models draped over car bonnets. But the big difference is that she owns the product she is promoting: she is in control. In this way, the Lane Fox phenomenon is indeed a victory for women. She has, in a cool, calculated way, observed the sexist ways of the world and made them work for her. And she has done it on her own terms. She has not compromised her femininity - the pink cardies, the flirtatiousness, the expressed desire to have several babies - yet she can be as tough and aggressive as any man. She is evidence that women no longer have to pretend to be blokes to get on. And that women, too, can conquer cyberspace.

But none of this would have worked if the media had not colluded. MarthaLane.com was devoured by newspapers and TV stations anxious to show they are keeping up with a more feminised world. In the British Journalism Review, the Guardian's Katharine Viner cites a Women in Journalism survey showing women featured in only 30% of pictures. Viner points out that over a million women have entered the workplace in the past decade but newspapers have yet to reflect the vast change this has made to their lives.

She writes: "At a time when newspapers are under threat ... the only commercially and culturally viable way forward is to be in tune with readers, who must include women. It's about reflecting who women are, what they've become, how their role in society has changed."

The very modern Martha Lane Fox succeeds because she fits the old sexist criteria for visibility: young, blonde, beautiful, posh (Westminster, Oxford, descended from the Marquis of Anglesey). If she had been black, working-class, middle-aged - or, worst of all, plain - she probably would have been consigned to the same invisibility as most women. So the net value of LaneFox.com to the female cause is limited but might yet turn out to be profitable.

fields.headline: Doing the right thing
fields.standfirst:
The sacked Tory frontbencher ponders Hague's claims that a tax-cutting crusade is morally virtuous

Tories in opposition: special report
Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: Sacked Tory frontbencher, John Redwood, ponders Hague's claims that a tax-cutting crusade is morally virtuous
fields.body:
Saying that tax cutting is a moral crusade has stirred an old controversy. To many on the left tax increases are moral. By definition all tax reductions are not.

In the red corner people argue passionately that, left to their own devices, voters will become yuppies, spending their money on internet mobiles and champagne. They will leave the poor begging on the other side of the road. Only good old-fashioned redistributive taxation can set the record straight: a powerful state taking from the strong and giving to the weak.

In the blue corner we have a different view. Leaving people with more of their own money gives them the chance to make moral choices. Some will decide to spend more on their families. They may be more generous to the elderly and frail close to them. They may take more responsibility for their own health, or insure themselves against life's chances that otherwise the state would have to underwrite. They may well give more to charity to help people they do not know personally.

It's a nice question, as the philosophers might say. If we look at the extreme positions we can see the weaknesses of both arguments. If the state took all our money away and gave us back what it thought we deserved, individuals would lose all opportunity to act in a moral way themselves. We would depend entirely on the state, and would only live in a righteous society if the rulers were wise and altruistic. They rarely are.

If we went to the other extreme, and left everyone with what they could earn or received from family and friends, those most in need would be left suffering and without proper care. No one pretends that everyone would behave in a moral and charitable way if we allowed incomes and spending to go untaxed.

In between we need to make a judgment about how much the state should do. I believe that if we lower taxes from the current level we will encourage more people to take more care of themselves and their families. We may also tempt more to pay their dues or to be honest with the benefits agency.

Tax cutting can encourage people to do the right thing. Tax relief for charitable giving, and a tax holiday for charities, is accepted by both major parties, and does help increase the amount of charitable money.

Tax relief for families, and tax relief for those who take care of an elderly or disabled relative has traditionally been accepted by both sides for similar reasons. Although Labour is now sweeping away family tax relief, it still uses tax relief to help those who care for others.

Tax relief for those who insure against ill health has proved more controversial, but the idea behind it is the same as in tax relief for carers. So is the principle behind tax relief for pensions and savings, encouraging people to provide for their own futures rather than depending on the state.

The assumption that state expenditure is always good and moral should not go unchallenged. State expenditure can be both things. Most of us willingly pay tax to give the disabled a better life. It is a good purpose of government to take some care of those who do not have all of life's chances at their feet. But taxing someone only to send money back in another form is not obviously a just cause. The welfare state churns so much money around. It taxes me more heavily in order to pay my family child benefit. It taxes me to provide me with a pension in retirement in addition to the occupational pension I also hope to enjoy.

Worse still, as Labour is slowly discovering, the churn of tax and benefits can send the wrong signals to people. The rate of tax and benefit withdrawal, if too high, can trap people in relative poverty, or put them off returning to work. As the realities of government catch up with ministers, they are slowly realising that the more you tax and the more the state pays back, the more people it will ensnare in poverty or unemployment. As Gordon Brown applies the Calvinist principles of the manse to the welfare state, he sees the need for reform, and for lower welfare spending.

There is a moral case for lower taxes than we currently enjoy. If tax reductions provide incentives for people to look after themselves and their families, or to give more to those in need, it will have proved worthwhile. Sometimes extra tax and spending by the state, far from making a more just society, merely makes a more muddled one. That is the tragedy of welfare, when expenditure is so high and goes to so many people. At times it taxes the poor to pay the cheat or the better off.

 John Redwood is Conservative MP for Wokingham.

fields.headline: Smiths hits at NHS priority
fields.standfirst:
Trusts criticised for delays in capital spending

The future of the NHS: special report
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Smiths Industries, the avionics and medical equipment group, yesterday criticised health trusts for putting off essential capital spending.
fields.body:
Smiths Industries, the avionics and medical equipment group, yesterday criticised health trusts for putting off essential capital spending.

The group said that government promises of increased funding for the national health service had yet to generate higher levels of purchasing by the health trusts.

Keith Butler-Wheelhouse, the group chief executive, said the health trusts had being using extra funds to improve pay or attract people back to the health service.

"Capital spending at the NHS has been kept to a minimum," he said. "This, for example, has had an effect on our business which makes operating tables.

"But it cannot last for ever, operating tables will have to be replaced eventually."

He said spending on pay did not improve operating procedures or increase the number of operations. "It is the throughput which drives our business," he added.

Despite the poor home market its medical division had moved ahead strongly in the first half after two years of flat performances. The growth stemmed from the US, where there had been a sustained rise in the number of operations, mostly reflecting an increase in surgery people had asked to have rather than had to have.

The slowdown in the group's civil aerospace business had been offset by its defence and aerospace operations, where a number of projects using Smiths Industries' equipment, such as the Apache helicopter and the Eurofighter, were moving into production.

Overall, first half pre-tax profits before goodwill amortisation rose by 10% to £110m, with the interim dividend 9.5% up at 8.1p a share. With a £1bn takeover fund, Smiths spent £157m on acquisitions in the same period.

webTitle: More money for NHS if doctors modernise

fields.headline: More money for NHS if doctors modernise
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The prime minister yesterday offered a new deal to GPs, holding out a promise of more money for the health service if they were prepared to embrace plans for modernisation.
fields.body:
The prime minister yesterday offered a new deal to GPs, holding out a promise of more money for the health service if they were prepared to embrace plans for modernisation.

Tony Blair braved a conference of GPs in Harrogate to make his offer of cash for change by live video link, and made it plain that funding to solve the dilemmas described by cash-strapped doctors would only be forthcoming if they fulfilled their part of his bargain.

"I know the deep commitment... GPs have to the NHS, but if you don't make these changes and modernise the health service, then the agenda will move to those people who don't want to rebuild the NHS at all," he warned.

Doctors questioning both Mr Blair and Alan Milburn, the health secretary, who spoke after him, told of their distress at being unable to get patients in pain into hospital for orthopaedic surgery, or pay soaring drugs bills, or spend enough time with each patient.

But there were signals that the hostility of the British Medical Association to the government's modernisation programme was on the wane.

John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's GP committee, which called the conference to look at the future of family doctors, agreed that Mr Blair's proffered bargain could look like a gun to the head. He said: "GPs aren't hostile to change. We recognise change is required."

While there was an element of "change is required and you had better bloody well like it" in Mr Blair's comments, GPs wanted to see a publicly-funded health service succeed, and were well aware that the NHS was under threat from "certain voices in the political arena and the media" as well as from a lack of resources.

Doctors questioning Mr Blair on the video link raised the fraught issues of the telephone helpline NHS Direct and walk-in clinics - initia tives that are highly popular with the public who want instant access to medical advice, but which GPs complain were introduced without consultation. They also feared the initiatives would encourage people to seek medical help for minor ailments they might have looked after themselves at home.

Mr Blair made it clear he could not understand the opposition to some of his initiatives, which he claimed were designed to reduce the burden on GPs. NHS Direct found favour with 90% of the public. "I don't think there is anything wrong with trying to fund new ways of delivering healthcare," he said.

webTitle: 'Polluting' cars face penalty of higher road tax

fields.headline: 'Polluting' cars face penalty of higher road tax
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is to introduce a four-tier system of road tax for new cars which will penalise gas guzzlers and reward owners of more environmentally-friendly vehicles.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is to introduce a four-tier system of road tax for new cars which will penalise gas guzzlers and reward owners of more environmentally-friendly vehicles.

The chancellor is also thought to be planning to increase fuel duty in the budget by no more than the inflation rate to cushion the impact on the retail prices index of soaring oil prices.

In a move aimed at bolstering his green credentials, Mr Brown is expected to announce that, from the autumn, the vehicle excise duty payable on new cars will be based on their emissions of harmful greenhouse gases, which are directly linked to fuel efficiency.

New cars will be divided into four bands, with the owners of those emitting the most carbon dioxide paying around £180 a year for their tax disc and those at the bottom of the scale paying around £100.

It is thought the two middle bands, into which most vehicles will fall, will be priced at around £120 and £150.

Cars registered before the system is introduced will continue to be taxed under the existing regime which is based on engine size.

There are currently two categories of vehicles for excise duty purposes, with the owners of those with engines of less than 1100cc qualifying for a £55 discount on the standard fee of £155. The treasury estimates that 1.8m motorists receive the small car discount, introduced in last year's budget.

The shake-up of the road tax system, which was introduced in 1909 as a charge for road building and maintenance, forms part of the government's effort to encourage cleaner cars.

To appease motorists who believe that the government is anti-car, Mr Brown is expected to announce that petrol duty will be indexed to inflation for the first time since 1992.

In the pre-budget report, the chancellor said he was abandoning the so-called fuel duty escalator, which automatically puts duty up by 6% more than inflation each year, and in the future would decide policy annually.

Motoring organisations had expected Mr Brown to opt for a 2% rise over and above inflation.

But soaring oil prices at a time when Britain is well on its way to achieving its internationally-agreed target for reducing carbon dioxide emissions convinced him of the need to be lenient towards car owners.

It will also minimise the impact on the retail prices index, which in recent years has risen sharply as a result of budget measures, threatening to start a wage/price spiral.

High carbon dioxide emissions tend to come from bigger engines, but experts say that is not always the case.

Motorists can check emission rates and fuel efficiency of car models in a booklet published by the vehicle certification agency.

webTitle: More money for the health service if doctors modernise

fields.headline: More money for the health service if doctors modernise
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The prime minister yesterday offered a new deal to GPs, holding out a promise of more money for the health service if they were prepared to embrace plans for modernisation.
fields.body:
The prime minister yesterday offered a new deal to GPs, holding out a promise of more money for the health service if they were prepared to embrace plans for modernisation.

Tony Blair braved a conference of GPs in Harrogate to make his offer of cash for change by live video link, and made it plain that funding to solve the dilemmas described by cash-strapped doctors would only be forthcoming if they fulfilled their part of his bargain.

"I know the deep commitment _ GPs have to the NHS, but if you don't make these changes and modernise the health service, then the agenda will move to those people who don't want to rebuild the NHS at all," he warned.

Doctors questioning both Mr Blair and Alan Milburn, the health secretary, who spoke after him, told of their distress at being unable to get patients in pain into hospital for orthopaedic surgery, or pay soaring drugs bills, or spend enough time with each patient.

But there were signals that the hostility of the British Medical Association to the government's modernisation programme was on the wane.

John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's GP committee, which called the conference to look at the future of family doctors, agreed that Mr Blair's proffered bargain could look like a gun to the head.

He said: "GPs aren't hostile to change. We recognise change is required."

While there was an element of "change is required and you had better bloody well like it" in Mr Blair's comments, GPs wanted to see a publicly-funded health service succeed, he said, and were well aware that the NHS was under threat from "certain voices in the political arena and the media" as well as from a lack of resources.

Doctors questioning Mr Blair on the video link raised the fraught issues of the telephone helpline NHS Direct and walk-in clinics - initiatives that are highly popular with the public who want instant access to medical advice, but which the GPs complain were introduced without consultation. They also feared the initiatives would encourage people to seek medical help for minor ailments they might have looked after themselves at home.

Mr Blair made it clear he could not understand the opposition to some of his initiatives, which he claimed were designed to reduce the burden on GPs. NHS Direct found favour with 90% of the public. "I don't think there is anything wrong with trying to fund new ways of delivering healthcare. I think it would be a real mistake if you saw that as a threat. It isn't a threat," he said.

webTitle: Rail firms warned on late running

fields.headline: Rail firms warned on late running
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Nearly nine trains in every 100 were late last year but the proportion of cancellations fell by 15%, the shadow strategic rail authority declared yesterday.
fields.body:
Nearly nine trains in every 100 were late last year but the proportion of cancellations fell by 15%, the shadow strategic rail authority declared yesterday.

The government-backed body responsible for policing the industry warned the 25 rail companies that it would tighten its control.

Mike Grant, the authority's chief executive, said: "Punctuality levels are failing to meet passengers' expectations and much remains to be done." Rail companies will be required to improve performance targets or their franchises will not be renewed.

The authority says that the proportion of trains delayed is 10% up on two years ago, amounting to 27,085 additional delays, or 520 a week. Compared with two years ago, 18 train companies performed worse last year.

Delays to services operated by LTS Rail, Merseyrail electrics and ScotRail increased by between 50 and 70% last year. All commuter and long distance train operators experienced delays above the national average last year.

Steward Francis, chairman of the central rail users' consultative committee, said: "We are waiting to see the emergence of a sustained picture of overall performance improvements. For many passengers, the experience of rail travel is poor."

In another move yesterday, Sir Alastair Morton, the authority's chairman, wel comed a decision by the train companies to simplify the range of tickets they supply. "Less complex fares, promotion and use of new technology smart cards were all identified for improvements to bidders for new franchises."

The Association of Train Operating Companies is working on a new system to replace the 90 different types of ticket on offfer to the public. It said last night that its simplified system could be introduced by the winter. A team was reducing ticket types to around a half a dozen. Keith Harper

fields.headline: Pakistan's nuclear strength revealed
fields.standfirst:
Photographs showing missile bases capable of targeting Indian cities turn up heat on Clinton visit to south Asia

The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
fields.trailText: Satellite photographs said to reveal a Pakistani plutonium reactor and missile base within range of targets inside India were released yesterday by US scientists, just days before President Bill Clinton begins a ground-breaking trip to south Asia.
fields.body:
Satellite photographs said to reveal a Pakistani plutonium reactor and missile base within range of targets inside India were released yesterday by US scientists, just days before President Bill Clinton begins a ground-breaking trip to south Asia.

The Federation of American Scientists (Fas) said Pakistan had nearly completed work on a plutonium reactor at Khushab, near the Punjabi city of Lahore, and had built a dozen garages for missile launchers at a nearby airbase in Sargodha.

The publication of the photographs will raise tensions between Islamabad and New Delhi, which earlier this year warned of possible conflict in their bitter dispute over the Himalayan state of Kashmir.

"Pakistan has laid the groundwork for a force of dozens of nuclear-tipped missiles capable of striking Indian cities and military bases," said John Pike of the FAS, a non-profit-making group funded by members of the Manhattan Project, America's programme to develop the atomic bomb.

It said the plutonium from the reactor would probably be used in lightweight nuclear warheads on M-11 missiles bought from China in the early 1990s.

"But Pakistan is in danger of having most of its nuclear eggs in one basket, which would be a tempting target for a pre-emptive Indian attack in a time of crisis," Mr Pike said.

Photographs of Sargodha, the group said, showed an ammunition depot in the hills where the missiles were stored and missile garrison, support and deployment facilities on the base itself. The group said that Pakistan may have up to 84 M-11 missiles at the site and up to 20 launchers.

Images of the circular Khushab site showed a heavy water research reactor with the ability to produce enough plutonium for up to five bombs a year.

President Clinton, who has described Kashmir as one of the world's most dangerous flashpoints, will press both countries to restrict their nuclear ambitions during his five-day trip to India and his five-hour stopover in Pakistan.

He has offered to help resolve the Kashmir row, a move welcomed by Pakistan but opposed by India.

Despite 10 rounds of special talks on nuclear security between India's foreign minister and the US deputy secretary of state, concrete results have proved elusive.

On Tuesday, the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, warned New Delhi it must curb its development of nuclear weapons and exports of nuclear technology before ties with the US could be strengthened.

"Significant progress in this area is necessary before India and the United States can realise fully the vast potential of our relationship," she said.

New Delhi hopes to balance America's traditional support for Pakistan and to win lucrative business deals.

But analysts there admit that huge differences remain with the United States over nuclear proliferation.

"It is a lump in the throat. The two sides can neither swallow it or spit it out," said a retired Indian army general.

Since independence in 1947, India and Pakistan have fought three wars. In May 1998, both countries tested nuclear weapons and last summer clashed in the Kargil mountains of Kashmir.

Since seizing power in a coup in October, Pakistan's army chief, General Pervez Musharraf, has insisted that his country will keep its nuclear arsenal, and last month set up a nuclear command and control centre.

Last night the military regime announced an immediate ban on political meetings, strikes and processions ahead of President Clinton's visit.

"There are reports that elements working against the interest of the state are preparing and planning hostile acts to create chaos and portray Pakistan as an irresponsible state," the interior ministry said.

Although there have been few protests against the military government, some supporters of the deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, had arranged a rally for next week.

Although President Clinton's stopover in Islamabad will be brief, Pakistan's military regime is relieved that he is willing to come at all.

Yet Gen Musharraf will come under uncomfortable pressure from Mr Clinton to promise a return to democracy, prove his willingness to ease tensions with India and curb the threat of terrorism.

webTitle: China warns Taiwan not to trigger war

fields.headline: China warns Taiwan not to trigger war
fields.trailText: The Chinese prime minister, Zhu Rongji, issued a stark warning yesterday to the people of Taiwan to vote the right way in Saturday's presidential election - or run the risk of war.
fields.body:
The Chinese prime minister, Zhu Rongji, issued a stark warning yesterday to the people of Taiwan to vote the right way in Saturday's presidential election - or run the risk of war.

"We advise all the people of Taiwan not to just act on impulse otherwise, I'm afraid you won't have another opportunity to regret," he told a news conference in Beijing.

Mr Zhu said the election of a pro-independence president in Taiwan "may trigger a war between the two sides of the Taiwan strait".

The prime minister's words were seenas an open threat in Taiwan last night, even though he avoided mentioning by name Chen Shui-bian, the pro-independence candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Speaking on the last day of the national people's congress in Beijing, Mr Zhu also committed the people of China to "use all their blood and even sacrifice their lives to defend the unity of the motherland..."

But there was no way to assess how popular Mr Zhu's sentiments were with the Chinese people. Observers feel most people want to see the country reunified eventually, but they do not necessarily share the leadership's sense of urgency.

"We don't want war with Taiwan," said one Beijing worker during the congress. "The ordinary people don't understand it at all. We look at Taiwan and see that they have a high standard of living. Why should they want to rejoin us now?"

Non-communist delegates at the political consultative conference (CPPCC), which meets concurrently with NPC, have avoided making fiery statements about Taiwan.

In a typical comment, the delegate, Zhang Ze, said that "unification should be done peacefully and we hope that force will not be used".

CPPCC discussion groups, convened to discuss national policy, focused on corruption, poverty, education and other domestic issues, but stayed clear of the Taiwan issue.

At a meeting of university professors, only one out of 15 speakers mentioned Taiwan. "None of the people of Taiwan want to take drastic action," the speaker said, implying that there was no need to get alarmed about the pro-independence DPP.

"Dialogue between the mainland and Taiwan must be on equal terms," commented one retired, Beijing-based Chinese historian.

"It's like the situation in 1945, but in reverse. Then, [Nationalist leader] Chiang Kai-shek said he would agree to peace talks with Mao Zedong - but Mao had to accept Chiang's supremacy first of all. Now the Communist party wants the Taiwanese to talk - but only on Beijing's terms."

Some NPC delegates were reported to have said that they had not been consulted about China's policy towards Taiwan - they were simply asked to approve it. Delegates from Fujian province, which faces the Taiwan strait, repeated the official line but refused to answer questions.

The only delegates who spoke freely on Taiwan were those of the People's Liberation Army (PLA), which has taken the most hawkish stand. One senior officer insisted that the PLA would "take all necessary action to thwart the splittists in Taiwan. We are fully prepared and ready to act whenever necessary."

China raised the stakes last month by issuing a "white paper", in which it threatened military force against Taiwan if the island refuses indefinitely to discuss reunification.

Mr Zhu's warning is thought to reflect China's increasing anxiety that the DPP's Mr Chen will win on Saturday.

"No matter who comes into power in Taiwan," Mr Zhu said, "Taiwan will never be allowed to be independent. This is our bottom line and the will of 1.25bn Chinese people."

webTitle: Mongolian guests learn lie of the land

fields.headline: Mongolian guests learn lie of the land
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament:Special report
fields.trailText: The team from the Mongolian parliament came to prime minister's question time yesterday. They were there to learn about our democratic traditions, the cut and thrust of honest dialogue, and old-fashioned respect for the other man's point of view.
fields.body:
The team from the Mongolian parliament came to prime minister's question time yesterday. They were there to learn about our democratic traditions, the cut and thrust of honest dialogue, and old-fashioned respect for the other man's point of view.

So it was a waste of time. No wonder they looked puzzled.

By far the most important news of the day was, of course, the threat to Rover. That took mere moments: Mr Blair will do everything he can to avoid it closing. So if you're at Longbridge, prepare to work in a call centre.

Mr Hague raised Alastair Campbell's admission on Tuesday that taxes had, indeed, risen under Labour. "The prime minister said he had no plans to increase taxes. Was that a joke, a rib-tickler from the education secretary?" Mr Blair had been systematically dishonest and misleading. "Will you admit your broken promises?"

"He's a liar!" shouted an anonymous MP. Some people fall into a stunned silence; MPs lapse into a stunned hubbub. You can accuse someone of systematic dishonesty, or allowing the collapse of the entire British motor industry, and that's fine. But to call them a liar is a crime.

"Where did that come from?" barked Madam Speaker. The Tories shuffled nervously, like schoolboys terrified of sneaking on a classmate.

"I see no one is going to own up to it, but I distinctly heard it!" she went on. Surely she wasn't going to keep them all in? Or cancel the school fact-finding trip to Barbados?

Mr Hague returned to the theme. Unlike the prime minister, his own press secretary had finally admitted the increased taxes. "He'd better get used to it. 'Less honest than Alastair Campbell' is not something anyone wants on their tombstone."

(Or less slim than Ann Widdecombe, less fluent than John Prescott, less sane than ... I'd better stop there.)

And so it went on. Harry Barnes, who is bald, then complained that "the trouble with the leader of the opposition is that he gives slapheads a bad name".

The Mongolians looked slightly more puzzled than before, if that were possible. What on earth is "slaphead" in Mongolian? (Thanks to email and the erudition of Guardian readers, I shall probably know by tomorrow.)

The Mongolians would have been more baffled when Mr Barnes went on to sug gest a tax on international currency speculation, "which would raise money for causes such as Mozambique".

The place collapsed. The very idea! Taxing rich people to help destitute people! Whatever next? Tories rolled around and smirked, and even Mr Blair laughed merrily at such naivety.

Moments later David Blunkett had to answer a question about the no-selection-under-Labour "joke", which has brought him so much trouble. Here is that answer in full:

"Yes, in 1995, for those whose memories stretch back that far, for journalists who have come out of school since then, for aged beloved politicians who have campaigned from that October day to this against what I said on the day, of course 'watch my lips' was a parody.

"The difference is, since level 2, 3 and 4 achievements in primary schools, even an 11-year-old will know the difference between a parody and a joke about a speech. A parody is a parody on someone else's words, at which that conference laughed."

Mr Blunkett resembled a landed pike, flopping and thrashing round in the net before the kindly fisherman ends the agony with a mallet.

What the Mongolian MPs might have made of this I do not know, since they had left in search of further enlightenment, possibly in the home supporters' end at Millwall.

My message is: go back to your yurts and prepare for government!

"I see no one is going to own up to it, but I distinctly heard it!" she went on. Surely she wasn't going to keep them all in? Or cancel the school fact-finding trip to Barbados? Mr Hague returned to the theme. Unlike the prime minister, his own press secretary had finally admitted the increased taxes. "He'd better get used to it. 'Less honest than Alastair Campbell' is not something anyone wants on their tombstone." (Or less slim than Ann Widdecombe, less fluent than John Prescott, less sane than ... I'd better stop there.) And so it went on. Harry Barnes, who is bald, then complained that "the trouble with the leader of the opposition is that he gives slapheads a bad name". The Mongolians looked slightly more puzzled than before, if that were possible. What on earth is "slaphead" in Mongolian? (Thanks to email and the erudition of Guardian readers, I shall probably know by tomorrow.) The Mongolians would have been more baffled when Mr Barnes went on to sug gest a tax on international currency speculation, "which would raise money for causes such as Mozambique". The place collapsed. The very idea! Taxing rich people to help destitute people! Whatever next? Tories rolled around and smirked, and even Mr Blair laughed merrily at such naivety. Moments later David Blunkett had to answer a question about the no-selection-under-Labour "joke", which has brought him so much trouble. Here is that answer in full: "Yes, in 1995, for those whose memories stretch back that far, for journalists who have come out of school since then, for aged beloved politicians who have campaigned from that October day to this against what I said on the day, of course 'watch my lips' was a parody. "The difference is, since level 2, 3 and 4 achievements in primary schools, even an 11-year-old will know the difference between a parody and a joke about a speech. A parody is a parody on someone else's words, at which that conference laughed." Mr Blunkett resembled a landed pike, flopping and thrashing round in the net before the kindly fisherman ends the agony with a mallet. What the Mongolian MPs might have made of this I do not know, since they had left in search of further enlightenment, possibly in the home supporters' end at Millwall. My message is: go back to your yurts and prepare for government!

webTitle: Healthy eating means a return to roots

fields.headline: Healthy eating means a return to roots
fields.trailText: The message being promoted by the health education authority initiative could hardly be more damaging and seems to remove the connections between food, taste, nature and knowledge, let alone pleasure (In fear of fruit and veg, March 14).
fields.body:
The message being promoted by the health education authority initiative could hardly be more damaging and seems to remove the connections between food, taste, nature and knowledge, let alone pleasure (In fear of fruit and veg, March 14). The pressures of modern consumerism already mean that (say) apples are the same size, shape and flavour in supermarkets from Inverness to Truro irrespective of season, maturity or local growing conditions. In any case such apples may have been sprayed many times with pesticides, herbicides and fungicides before reaching the table.

The importance of healthy eating is borne out by, for example, almost 50 deaths a day in the UK from bowel cancer; by the fact that the Scottish diet is cited as one of the worst in the EU; that supermarkets rarely stock affordable healthy produce and that budget lines are often of low nutritional value.

Good food, as celebrated chefs insist, relies on fresh ingredients and on the process of preparation. These both require knowledge - of growing and cooking - and the desire to learn. Hygiene considerations are integral to this knowledge but mud may be the most benign addition to a potato.

Our work with primary and secondary schools, many of which have now planted their own school orchards, shows that they are used across the curriculum, are looked after by pupils and are celebrated along with their harvest on Apple Day - October 21. Our work on Community and School Orchards consistently unearths the curiosity and excitement which is at the heart of real education.
Daniel Keech
Common Ground
london@commonground.org.uk

 Fifteen years ago while we were operating overland safaris in Africa, my wife sent our passengers into the market in Arusha, Tanzania. Each person had a short list of foods to buy. Everyone was successful in their quest, except one young woman who returned empty handed. In a market teeming with fresh produce, she hadn't found any peas. My wife, who had seen numerous stalls selling peas, took the woman back into the market and pointed to a large mound of green pods. The woman remarked, "Oh, are those peas?" She was from California.
Robert Irwin
Meltham, W Yorks

fields.headline: I will not be censored
fields.trailText: Hysteria surrounding my attendance at a conference sponsored by American Renaissance is undoubtedly due to an article in the Guardian (Leeds don to attack Lawrence findings, March 2).
fields.body:
Hysteria surrounding my attendance at a conference sponsored by American Renaissance is undoubtedly due to an article in the Guardian (Leeds don to attack Lawrence findings, March 2).

On the same day that this article appeared the university decided "in the light of the information" now available to it "that this was not an appropriate academic conference". So far, despite numerous requests, the university either cannot tell me or refuses to explain the nature of this information or why this is not an appropriate conference.

The university's initial request that I make disclaimers to the effect that the views to be expressed by me at the conference are mine and not the university's is unprecedented. I have never been asked anything like this before. Unprecedented too was the demand that I provide a copy of my paper in advance. The only possible reason for this request is so that what I have written could be vetted in advance, and, presumably, were something found which was not to the university's liking, pressure would be brought to bear on me to sanitise my paper. I am having none of it. I am not aware that other members of the university have ever been asked to comply with such requests.

Yesterday, I gave an interview to the Jewish Chronicle and the Leeds Student. I invited both of them to fly out with me, observe the conference and make up their own minds instead of recycling unsubstantiated allegations from unreliable sources.
Dr Frank Ellis
University of Leeds

fields.headline: Fertility and feminism
fields.trailText: Occasionally you read an article such as Sarah Boseley's on the pill that makes you want to punch the air and shout "Yes, yes." As a family planning nurse of some years, I have always given information and advice similar to that in her excellent article (Keep taking the pill, March 14).
fields.body:
Occasionally you read an article such as Sarah Boseley's on the pill that makes you want to punch the air and shout "Yes, yes." As a family planning nurse of some years, I have always given information and advice similar to that in her excellent article (Keep taking the pill, March 14). The benefits of using the pill outweigh the disadvantages. If women choose to use it, we should give them information about how they can make it work for their particular lifestyles. When, and this happens often, it is suggested that the pill is "unnatural", the response should be that it is not natural for a woman to be ovulating and menstruating over 400 times in her lifetime.

When we hear of someone dying while taking the pill (this seems quite rare), we invariably find that the woman should never have been prescribed the pill, due to some health problem. This is where the importance of medical professionals taking extra training in contraceptive practice is essential. It is so good to read some sensible, up-to-date information about the pill for a change.
Vicky Padbury
Reigate, Surrey
 I'm a feminist, but I've been an artist's model (nude, bronze, paper), a photographer's muse and a jungle dancer in sequins. Ms Vernon, confront your semiotic phobia: don't bury it and erase the history and voices which have privileged you with your column (I'm not a feminist, March 13). For the benefit of the semiotically challenged, I propose we add an S. Nothing is lost, but feminisms and feminists are gained.
Penelope Wickson
Birmingham
penelope.wickson@virgin.net

 Polly Vernon asks us to join her as "a woman who sometimes tsks angrily to herself on the top of a bus". Well, I might be wrong, but somehow I don't think that's going to change the world. Join me, a feminist and proud of it.
Denise Kelly
Prague, Czech Republic
dkelly@vol.cz

fields.headline: Low tax and high morals
fields.trailText: The Tories put up VAT from 8% to 15%, to 17.5% and extended it to take-away food and domestic fuel (Low tax a moral duty says Hague, March 15). What they did do was to cut income tax - not the same as reducing the total tax burden.
fields.body:
The Tories put up VAT from 8% to 15%, to 17.5% and extended it to take-away food and domestic fuel (Low tax a moral duty says Hague, March 15). What they did do was to cut income tax - not the same as reducing the total tax burden. Income tax is high profile - we can see the amount we pay each month on our salary slips; VAT we pay to the shopkeeper, and it is less obvious when it goes up. That is a stealth tax.
Peter Effer
London
EfferMcCann@compuserve.com

 William Hague is advancing a moral justification for low taxation, so what's new? As JK Galbraith said, more than 30 years ago: "The modern conservative is engaged in one of man's oldest exercises in moral philosophy, that is the search for a superior moral justification for selfishness." The real issue is why a Labour government is trying to beat them at their own game.
Prof Alan Walker
University of Sheffield
A.C.Walker@sheffield.ac.uk

 Has Roy Hattersley (The secret socialist at Number 11, March 13) forgotten that when John Smith in 1992 advocated a minimal rise in taxation, we got John Major and another five years of Tory government? Any party member would agree that a Labour chancellor should be preaching redistribution. But if he did so he would be courting ultimate defeat so long as we have the Tory party, the Daily Mail and our present electoral system. So Roy should ponder his continued dogmatic opposition to electoral reform (and thus, by implication, the possibility of another two decades of Tory rule).
Joe Patterson
London
jp2b@beeb.net

fields.headline: Red card for Leeds
fields.trailText: What kind of message to the community is Leeds United sending if it fields either of the players charged with grievous bodily harm (Leeds footballers charged, March 15)?
fields.body:
What kind of message to the community is Leeds United sending if it fields either of the players charged with grievous bodily harm (Leeds footballers charged, March 15)? Is there not someone less myopic in the higher echelons of the football world who can take the Leeds manager to one side and have a loud word in his ear that to field either player would be insensitive and of no benefit to the game?

rjhardy@waitrose.com

They are hardly a riveting read but if lobby accountability is to mean anything, we must be able to see these minutes regularly, not just when the press decide they are interesting. Why not publish them on the internet every day?

London
allan.kelly@bigfoot.com

davidprothero@hotmail.com

Siamak Rastan

London

fields.headline: Affronted by barebacking
fields.trailText: The pernicious claptrap purveyed by Nigel Wrench in defence of "barebacking" is an insult to the intelligence, although I can only applaud the fact that the article advertises to a much wider audience the current thinking amongst a deluded section of the gay community (Sex on the edge, G2, March 14).
fields.body:
The pernicious claptrap purveyed by Nigel Wrench in defence of "barebacking" is an insult to the intelligence, although I can only applaud the fact that the article advertises to a much wider audience the current thinking amongst a deluded section of the gay community (Sex on the edge, G2, March 14). So it's OK now, is it, to spread Aids to the community at large as long as it's done as the "ultimate expression of intimacy"?

I suppose we hets can now go out and acquire syphilis, gonorrhea and herpes as long as our loved ones realise we did it all for them. There is no need for rational debate on an issue such as this. The tolerance and understanding rightly accorded gay men by society generally is sorely stretched by the attitudes and practices highlighted by this article. The cost to the exchequer for keeping an Aids patient alive for one year is of the order of £15,000 at least. Perhaps the real debate should be whether those who contract Aids voluntarily should absolve the state from any responsibility for their welfare.
Wyn Evan
Bridgend
 What needs to be addressed is what psychological meaning do condoms and HIV have for gay men 20 years into the epidemic. A condom can represent an emotional as well as a physical barrier between people. Non-use of a condom can be seen as a symbol of trust and intimacy.

Gay men who are HIV negative can feel excluded by their status. This is particularly so for the bereaved or those with positive friends. It makes them feel that their identifications are with those who are different from them. To belong means you need to get infected. Additionally, some gay men are caught up in the guilt of the survivor.

Health promotion is right to concentrate on risk reduction rather than a blanket "Just say no" but it also needs to explore, "Why say yes".
Alan Pope (Psychotherapist)
London

 Here in rural Suffolk near Newmarket, "barebacking" means riding a horse without a saddle, and only garage mechanics have a wrench sticking out of their jeans. How surprised we were.
Dr Duncan Hannant
Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk
duncan.hannant@lanecott.keme.co.uk

 In an otherwise useful article, Matt Wells is simply wrong to suggest that the picket of the Guardian offices in September 1991 was in protest at the suggestion, in Rupert Haselden's article "Gay abandon", of the prevalence of "unprotected" gay sex. As organisers of the protest, neither David Bunnett nor I accepted the "HIV=Aids" argument so the issue of sex with or without a condom was completely irrelevant.

Rather, it was the consistent failure of the Guardian to give credible coverage to the broad experience of lesbian, gay and bisexual lifestyles and, specifically, to provide space for a reply to Haselden's proposition, that since gay men were "biologically maledaptive" and "unable" to have children they "went around the world" indulging themselves in material and sexual gratification to "find some meaning" to their lives.

Haselden merely used the issue of casual sex to give credence to a negative and ill-founded argument. Fortunately, Peter Preston (then editor of the Guardian) subsequently held a series of meetings with long standing readers and, separately, representatives of lesbian and gay organisations. These led to a quantum leap in the quality and diversity of the paper's coverage of our lifestyles.
Stephen Stannard
London

Since I'm disabled and unwaged, I don't have a credit card, nor do many others in my position. As a result we are effectively being denied cheap net access. webTitle: Britain to lead fight against drug runners

fields.headline: Britain to lead fight against drug runners
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is to take the lead role in helping the United Nations administration in Kosovo tackle the growing threat from organised crime, Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain is to take the lead role in helping the United Nations administration in Kosovo tackle the growing threat from organised crime, Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, announced yesterday.

Mr Cook said around 20 British police and customs officers would set up a criminal intelligence unit in Pristina. Other countries would also send police and the new unit would work closely with intelligence agencies in neighbouring Balkan states.

The move comes amid rising concern about the increase in drug-running from Turkey through Serbia, Kosovo, Montenegro and Albania to Italy and western Europe. Senior figures in the now disbanded Kosovo Liberation Army are suspected of being involved.

Although yesterday's announcement aimed to rebut criticism that the west is failing to give enough help for Kosovo's post-war return to law and order, it coincided with a setback in the divided city of Mitrovice. French troops retreated in the face of Serb demonstrators, abandoning an attempt to widen the security zone on the northern side of one of the two bridges. Teargas and stun grenades were fired, injuring at least nine Serbs.

webTitle: Passions run high over village with a view

fields.headline: Passions run high over village with a view
fields.standfirst:
Israeli right fights to hold on to Abu Dis, at the heart of plans for Arafat's new Palestinian state

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli right fights to hold on to Abu Dis, at the heart of plans for Arafat's new Palestinian state.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Abu Dis, West Bank
fields.body:
Just beyond the Mount of Olives, amid a sprawl of houses and roads lined with sacks of rubbish, an imposing stone edifice is rising. Five storeys high, the building is believed to be the new parliament for the state that Yasser Arafat has said he will declare by September - a concrete expression of the Palestinian claim to a part of Jerusalem.

Abu Dis barely straddles the boundaries of Jerusalem - 90% of the village is officially outside the city, in the West Bank. But when the parliament is complete, Mr Arafat will be able to look out on to a stunning view of the Dome of the Rock, where, according to tradition, the prophet Mohammed rose to heaven.

In Jerusalem, where sightlines and symbols assume enormous significance, that view is all-important - in the eyes of both the Israeli right and the Palestinians.

The right argues that surrendering Abu Dis would be a monstrous betrayal by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, of the "eternal and undivided capital" of Israel. The Palestinian Authority needs Abu Dis to show it has extracted some concessions during the slow and halting peace process.

"Arafat will see the Dome of the Rock from the window, that is why they are building it," says Ali Shehadeh, who lives next door. "Jerusalem for the people is the Dome of the Rock, the Haram al-Sharif [noble sanctuary] and the Wailing Wall."

Abu Dis and other villages on the boundaries of Jerusalem have become such an explosive topic that Mr Barak has been forced to exclude them from the next slice of the West Bank to be handed over to Palestinian control this Sunday. Instead, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators compromised on less coveted land around other towns in the West Bank.

But Abu Dis is bound to be on the table when the peace talks resume in Washington next week. And the ferocity of the right's objections to its handover indicates the difficulties ahead for Mr Barak.

The opposition Likud party and settlers' organisations claim the loss of Abu Dis, and of even more distant suburbs, would violate the notion that Jerusalem would remain entirely within the Jewish state.

This week, settlers' groups announced a mass protest outside Israel's parliament, the Knesset, to coincide with a no-confidence motion against Mr Barak's coalition.

But the protesters have overlooked two basic facts: despite the fine views, Abu Dis is in the West Bank, and it has been under Palestinian civilian control since the end of 1995. Israel shares control of its security.

But reason rarely rules when the status of Jerusalem is under discussion.

"There is a mythical cloud which is spread over any issue which demands thinking about a solution for Jerusalem which would take into account Palestinian needs," says Ron Pundak, an Israeli historian. "It is the easiest thing to sell to the public that this risks our existence in Jerusalem. Here you have a suburb very close to Jerusalem, and there is a direct sight from Abu Dis to the heart of Jerusalem."

In 1995 Mr Pundak was an adviser to negotiators who eventually agreed on a formula under which the Jerusalem municipality would first be expanded, ahead of a re-organisation of the northern and eastern areas into a new entity.

Abu Dis would be at the core of the new state, but few Palestinians would be satisfied if the village alone served as a substitute for Jerusalem. "To me, it is something outside the city as I understand it as a Jerusalemite," says Zakaria al-Qaq of the Israel-Palestine centre for research and information.

"The Palestinian parliament may be closer to Jerusalem than the Knesset, but it is not an acceptable alternative to Jerusalem. However, the Palestinian leadership wanted to show it as a step forward so that we can present that we are in Jerusalem, here is Jerusalem, and that Arafat can say he can see the minarets of Jerusalem."

Nevertheless, the 1995 plan proposed what would once have been unutterable: ceding full Israeli control over the city of Jerusalem. In recent days, Mr Barak's ministers too appeared to have accepted such an eventuality, and dared to speak of the transfer of other villages. They were promptly criticised by the Israeli right.

"Giving Abu Dis and other neighbourhoods around Jerusalem to the Palestinians is the beginning of the process of the division of Jerusalem," says Danny Naveh of Likud.

But others argue that the idea of a united Jerusalem is a fiction, and that since 1967 the secular city - as opposed to the holy places within the old city walls - has existed as two parallel universes which rarely intersect: one Jewish, the other Palestinian.

"Basically, it is more divided than any city I know, except Nicosia," says Meron Benvenisti, a former deputy mayor. "Belfast is nothing compared to this division - this whole thing of 'us' and 'them' that you have in Jerusalem."

Although Mr Barak was caught off-guard this week by the ferocity of the right's opposition to any Israeli withdrawals from territory near Jerusalem, many believe that such moves are inevitable within the next few months, as Israel gives up control of other areas on the West Bank.

But convincing Israelis of that would require a degree of dispassion that is exceedingly rare when it comes to discussing the holy city.

webTitle: West fails to put money where its troops are

fields.headline: West fails to put money where its troops are
fields.standfirst:
The last in our series: The province's budget for this year is equivalent to the cost of half a day's bombing by Nato
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Petrit Dushi waited patiently in the street, in sub-zero temperatures, for his pension. Eight months after the United Nations Mission in Kosovo (Unmik) set up shop in Pristina, the word had gone out that it was finally going to give money to the over-70s.
fields.body:
Petrit Dushi waited patiently in the street, in sub-zero temperatures, for his pension. Eight months after the United Nations Mission in Kosovo (Unmik) set up shop in Pristina, the word had gone out that it was finally going to give money to the over-70s.

Although Unmik runs the old Yugoslav television station, it had not seen fit to make a formal announcement of the new payments, let alone create an orderly handout system. So thousands of elderly people besieged the office on the strength of the rumour. "I waited for three days and then caught a cold and gave up," Mr Dushi said later, smiling.

Had Mr Dushi received his money, it would have amounted to DM30 (£10) a month. He can afford to make light of it because his son, Besar, a fluent English-speaker, gets a reasonable monthly salary of £360 from Oxfam.

UN officials acknowledge that the pensions which Serbs over 65 get in northern Mitrovice are roughly double the UN payments. The Serbs get extra money from President Slobodan Milosevic's government in Belgrade.

But the blame for the stinginess lies with western governments which have refused to give generously for a budget which is only £184m for a population of 2m. "Kosovo's entire budget for the year 2000 is equivalent to the cost of around half a day's bombing," says Bernard Kouchner, the UN administrator.

Public service salaries are pitiful. The average is £90 a month. What every Kosovo Albanian with language skills - from doctors to engineers - wants is a well-paid job as a translator.

"We have no English teacher in my school. They're all working with non-governmental organisations," says Arben Kajtazi, 18. "I kid my French teacher that if he gives me a decent mark, I'll find him a job with Médecins sans Frontières."

Serbs, too, do well as translators. It is almost the only job they can get, although they do have to travel to work with an armed escort along streets they can no longer walk safely.

Next rung up the pay ladder are the foreigners who work for one of the 340 non-governmental organisations (NGOs) or, better still, one of the big international organisations. Their Japanese four-wheel drives whoosh up and down Pristina's roads.

But visible signs of the international community's success are scarce. Power cuts interrupt the cold evenings for three hours at a time. Water comes patchily, and telephones do not exist in large parts of the town. The massive destruction of houses by the Serbs in the countryside has brought tens of thousands of people to Pristina, doubling its prewar population to almost 600,000. This partly explains the pressure on public services which, UN officials claim, received no investment in the last decade of Serb rule.

On the military front and across Kosovo, coordination is little better. When French troops put on their masks and launched tear gas at Albanian demonstrators in Mitrovice last month, they did not bother to warn the British soldiers who were trying to hold back the crowd. The French got a brisk lesson in English bar-room abuse.

General Klaus Reinhardt, the commander of K-For, the Nato-led international peace force, has been trying without success to get authorisation to deploy men from any of the five sectors (US, British, French, German and Italian) into which Kosovo was carved.

Meanwhile, Russia is stepping up its complaints that the UN has gone too far in separating Kosovo from Yugoslavia by giving it the deutschmark as its currency and setting up customs points on the border.

For the residents of Kosovo, there are more shocks coming. Donor governments have made it clear they will not finance any more current expenditure after this year and will only pay for large investment projects.

The European Union has also made it clear it sees Kosovo as a typical communist economy "in transition". The old welfare system must go, to be replaced by "means-tested social welfare payments to the needy instead", says Joly Dixon, the EU official in charge of the economy.

On the housing front, although 50,000 houses were destroyed by Serb forces during the war, the EU has only budgeted for 20,000 to be rebuilt with state aid this year. "We prefer a needs assessment to a damage assessment, which concentrates on the household rather than the house," says Mr Dixon.

Families who struggled back from refugee camps to find mass graves and ruined homes are getting a tough message.

Pristina's streets are already filling up with a generation of bored young people, demobilised guerrillas, country-to-town migrants, and school-leavers with no chance of a good job except as drivers and translators for an international circus which will soon start pulling out. Welcome to peacetime Kosovo.
