fields.headline: Search for a safe harbour
fields.standfirst:
One year on and Kosovo still suffers from the tragic consequences of unresolved conflict

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Father Sava Janjic is one of the bravest Serbs left in Kosovo. A soft-spoken figure whose scholarly appearance masks passionately held views, his rare quality is his willingness to acknowledge the crimes done to Albanians by the Milosevic regime.
fields.body:
Father Sava Janjic is one of the bravest Serbs left in Kosovo. A soft-spoken figure whose scholarly appearance masks passionately held views, his rare quality is his willingness to acknowledge the crimes done to Albanians by the Milosevic regime.

Yet as sits in the high-ceilinged refectory of the monastery of Gracanica, he has little to feel cheerful about. A leader of the Serb National Council in Kosovo, he became the articulate voice of those Serbs who felt they should cooperate with the United Nations administration when it arrived in the territory in June.

Now he feels let down and under pressure. Kfor, the international peace force, is failing to protect Serbs enough to give them freedom of movement beyond their prison enclaves, let alone create conditions for those who left Kosovo to want to come home. In the northern city of Mitrovice which has been effectively partitioned, pro-Milosevic Serbs boast that their success in keeping Albanians out shows a tough line is the only solution. Father Sava senses Slobodan Milosevic's support in Kosovo is growing and that the hard-liners who denounce Kfor as nothing more than an occupation force are gaining strength. The trouble in Mitrovice is not just a battle between Serbs and Albanians but a struggle for the allegiance of Kosovo's Serbs.

Amid his many disappointments Father Sava's regrets the lack of support which he and his boss, Bishop Artemije, Kosovo's senior Orthodox clergyman, have had from opposition politicians in Belgrade. At a recent meeting, the two clerics asked the anti-Milosevic politicians to sign a joint declaration which would stress two points. First, that it was not an act of treason for Kosovo's Serbs to work with the United Nations. Second, that "injustices" had been inflicted on Albanians. Although this was deliberately softer than the clergymen's usual formulation "crimes", even this was too much for Belgrade's opposition.

Had it been signed, the statement would have had far-ranging political benefits. Father Sava and Bishop Artemije are convinced that unless more Serbs acknowledge that the atrocities done in their name are the prime cause of the hatred which bedevils Kosovo today, tolerance will take a long time to grow.

It is easy to see that Serbs cannot readily accept that their side bears the greater guilt. What is more depressing is the way this escape from the facts is beginning to creep into western public discourse on Kosovo's shaky peace. Allan Little's recent BBC2 programme, Moral Combat, was only the latest example of the tendency to say a plague on both houses - with the danger that the international community will wash its hands and withdraw from Kosovo, as Milosevic is no doubt calculating. Little produced an excellent discussion of the conflict among western politicians and military strategists over the conduct of the war, but he put it into a surprisingly one-dimensional framework which gave no political context beyond the tendentious claim that from the very beginning the Kosovo Liberation Army aimed at provoking a Nato intervention. If that was so, how come the KLA's man at Rambouillet did most to anger the Americans and endanger the talks? And what happened to the consensus among all who reported on Kosovo in 1998, including Allan Little, that the KLA was one of the least centralised and disparate guerrilla movements of recent times, with minimal overall leadership and no clear strategy?

The notion of "balance", in which a suffering Albanian family is juxtaposed with a suffering Serb family, culminated in the programme's final line that "the oppressed, now liberated, have become the oppressors", which created a false moral and historical equivalence. Is there really no difference between a state-machine whose security forces use arson, artillery, and cold-blooded murder on a mass scale against people still in their homes, and the hot-blooded revenge-seeking of bereaved people returning to destroyed villages and burning the houses of their Serb neighbours, usually after the Serbs had already left?

Now we have moved to a second post-war stage, where crime in Kosovo is random, opportunistic, urban and largely done by professional criminals who want to make money out of Serb flats rather than by former refugees in the countryside. It is the inevitable consequence of a law and order vacuum, for which the international community is mainly to blame for failing to provide the police it promised. Take away the police from London or Berlin, and see how quickly the crime rate would soar.

This is not to deny that the current violence against Serbs in Kosovo takes place in a vindictive atmosphere where most Albanians, regrettably, think ethnically. Moderate Albanian opinion keeps quiet and witnesses to repression do not come forward. Far from restraining them, parents encourage their children to stone Serb buses when they pass through Albanian areas under Kfor escort. The Albanian press does not feel able or willing to report fairly, let alone critically, on what is being done to Serbs.

This is where Father Sava comes back in. Albanians would start to differentiate and not lump all Serbs together as evil-doers if they felt more Serbs were able to accept the truth about what happened in 1998 and 1999, and even show some sense of collective responsibility. Albanians would also relax if more Serbs did not go on behaving, as those in Mitrovice do, as though the Serbs can still win the war and get Kfor to withdraw.

For western governments the message is clear. The ambiguity of UN resolution 1244 which left Kosovo's final status obscure has become a liability. It gives false encouragement to Serbs and real anxiety to Albanians. What is needed is a forthright statement by the western powers, and preferably the security council as a whole, that Kosovo will never return to Serb rule. This would help the cowardly opposition in Belgrade to break free of the nationalist cancer. They could correctly argue that it was Milosevic who lost Kosovo, and then go on to develop a modern political and economic agenda no longer distorted by territorial self-delusion.

For Albanians such a declaration would provide a reason to stop seeing every Serb in Kosovo as a potential fifth columnist. In exchange for an international commitment that Kosovo's return to Serb rule is off the table for ever, the leaders of the various Kosovo Albanian parties should be urged to agree to a formal statement that the territory will remain legally part of Yugoslavia, though under international protection, for three or five more years. In that period Milosevic might finally leave power or Yugoslavia, with the help of Montenegro, might dissolve - leaving Kosovo independent by default.

There are hard choices ahead for Serbs, Albanians, and the international community, but to trivialise Kosovo's current troubles as an endless Balkan cycle of violence does no service to anyone.

webTitle: Risk-free warfare: is it still just a pipe dream?

fields.headline: Risk-free warfare: is it still just a pipe dream?
fields.standfirst:
Future crises: Why smart bombs may not be enough

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato's high-altitude bombing campaign devastated Serbia's infrastructure. It also unleashed a debate about the prospect of "risk-free" military intervention, with the world's most powerful alliance policing the globe to avert humanitarian disasters and control "rogue" states.
fields.body:
Nato's high-altitude bombing campaign devastated Serbia's infrastructure. It also unleashed a debate about the prospect of "risk-free" military intervention, with the world's most powerful alliance policing the globe to avert humanitarian disasters and control "rogue" states.

This scenario was encouraged by politicians at the height of the Kosovo conflict, not least by Tony Blair. In a speech last April, he said: "Acts of genocide can never be a purely internal matter ... When oppression produces massive flows of refugees which unsettle neighbouring countries then they can properly be described as 'threats to international peace and security'."

He added a warning, posing a fundamental question which remains unanswered. "If we wanted to right every wrong that we see in the modern world," he said, "then we would do little else than intervene in the affairs of other countries."

It is now clear that it is one thing to strike targets in limited air operations against "rogue" states, quite another to sustain Nato unity and military commitments in longer-term operations nearer home or humanitarian missions further afield.

And the lesson of Kosovo is that in any future conflict the military will be under strict political control, to keep casualties on both sides to an absolute minimum, and to preserve allied cohesion.

Asked yesterday why Nato did not threaten the Serbs with a ground invasion of Kosovo, General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, replied: "The alliance was coming from different places ... We obviously had to go with what the market could bear."

He told the Commons defence committee that had Nato launched a massive attack on Serbia, including Belgrade, "we would have had a disaster on day one".

Kevin Tebbit, the top civil servant at the ministry of defence, told MPs that, had Nato faced opposition during a ground invasion of Kosovo, the casualties would have been enormous.

One answer to Nato's political and military restraints is to fill what Gen Guthrie called "capability gaps". During the Kosovo conflict, there was a shortage of "smart" bombs, guided by satellite, which do not depend on good weather.

Kosovo also showed up the European allies' almost total reliance on the US for large transport aircraft, a key requirement of Britain's new emphasis on expeditionary forces.

"Too many [EU] armed forces remain structured to deal with the threat from the Soviet Union," Geoffrey Hoon, the defence secretary, said yesterday. "Europe is in danger of being ready for the last war rather than the next."

The European allies have promised to assemble a corps of up to 60,000 troops trained to reach crisis spots quickly, and prepared to stay on for a year.Meanwhile, senior US commanders say the Kosovo experience shows that a deployable EU police force is also urgently needed.

The Europeans are beginning to realise that "smart" bombs are all very well, but that future crises will involve more commitment of both troops and equipment, and that next time they may not have the US to bail them out.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.standfirst: Quotes of the week
fields.trailText: Quotes of the week.
fields.body:
"Many husbands walk out on a pregnant wife and many on a wife with a new baby. And many threaten to walk out if a pregnancy should begin and not be terminated. It is not unknown for such a man, who has deprived a woman of the children she longed for, to leave her and become the ecstatic father of the children of a younger woman. If the bishop should choose to lash such men from the pulpit with the invective of a Savonarola, rather than his limp, parochial PR-speak, I would cheer him on"

Germaine Greer responds to the Right Reverend Dr Michael Nazir-Ali, Bishop of Rochester, after he voiced his opinion that marriages should produce children, Daily Telegraph.

"If only there was a woman we could vote for. The men have made quite enough of a mess in this country with their aggression, their drunkenness and their corruption. A woman could hardly do any worse. I would give her a chance"

Pavel, a middle-aged Russian man, on why his vote in the forthcoming presidential elections will go to liberal reformer and former social affairs minister Ella Pamfilova who, if she were to beat the other 11 candidates, would become Russia's first female leader since Catherine the Great (1762-96), Independent.

"Even if a marriage ends in divorce or widowhood, women can fall back on their friendship networks for emotional and social support. It may be that men form less meaningful and fruitful supportive social bonds. When a marriage breaks, men have no safety net"

Findings from a California University study which reveals that divorced and separated men are more than four times as likely as women to kill themselves, Daily Mail.

"The blow is absolutely all-encompassing. There is not one single facet of your personality or perception of yourself that is left unvanquished. You feel basically repellent. You feel emotionally wanting. You feel your personality must be riddled with appalling flaws. And you also feel like a pillock, a moron, a stupid cretin"

Vanessa Feltz, whose own response to marriage breakdown was to lose five stone and get back in the spotlight, London Evening Standard.

"Don't act over-the-top. Wealthy men always seem to find women fascinating if they don't say too much. If you can know a little bit about what's going on in the world, then that's great"

Actress and socialite Sally Farmiloe advises on snaring a millionaire, Sun.

webTitle: British chocolate is good enough for Europe, MEPs agree

fields.headline: British chocolate is good enough for Europe, MEPs agree
fields.trailText: Chocoholics all over Europe can now sample the delights of Milky Ways, Mars Bars and Kit Kats after Euro-MPs agreed yesterday that British chocolate was good enough to cross the channel.
fields.body:
Chocoholics all over Europe can now sample the delights of Milky Ways, Mars Bars and Kit Kats after Euro-MPs agreed yesterday that British chocolate was good enough to cross the channel.

Ending a long-fought battle, MEPs endorsed a compromise deal under which all EU member states will have to accept Britain's finest as long as it is clearly labelled "family milk chocolate" and contains no more than 5% vegetable fat.

Near universal acclaim greeted the final act in an often bitter 27-year saga, in the course of which Belgium and France repeatedly questioned whether the milky UK product could be accurately described as chocolate at all.

One earlier proposal was that it be named vegelate.

Keith Vaz, the famously sweet-toothed foreign office minister for Europe, wel comed the vote in the European parliament in Strasbourg.

"Today is a great day for the single market, the UK, the European Union and for chocoholics everywhere," he said.

But straw polling on the streets of Brussels brought mixed reactions.

One specialist retailer said he would not dream of selling British chocolate, although a gaggle of children queueing for mussels and chips sampled Cadbury's Fruit and Nut with gusto.

The European commission has been struggling for years to end discrimination against British chocolate as purists and protectionists insisted only products made from cocoa butter were worthy of the name.

Britain's most famous brands contain vegetable fat rather than pure cocoa butter while British chocolate in general uses more milk than continental rivals.

"It has taken nearly 30 years to be able to buy a Cadbury's Flake as easily in Madrid or Munich as in Manchester," said the Labour MEP and consumer affairs spokesman Philip Whitehead. "Consumers will now be able to buy the chocolate they want, where they want it."

Tony Bilsborough of Cadbury said: "It is a breakthrough that will encourage free trade and allow different chocolate making traditions to co-exist in a market where people can choose."

When the UK, Ireland and Denmark joined the EEC in 1973 all three governments refused to accept community standards requiring chocolate to contain only cocoa ingredients. It was Britain's first opt-out.

Last October the commission pushed through the final compromise, keeping France and Belgium at bay thanks to qualified majority voting.

fields.headline: Me and Ms Jones
fields.standfirst: We've had Bridget and Ally and a whole host of hand-wringing, neurosis-fuelled singletons bemoaning the lot of the man-less woman. Well maybe now,  Ekow Eshun argues, it's time for men to join in
fields.trailText: We've had Bridget and Ally and a whole host of hand-wringing, neurosis-fuelled singletons bemoaning the lot of the man-less woman. Well maybe now,  Ekow Eshun argues, it's time for men to join in.
fields.body:
In my early 20s, I met a girl called Maria. We fell in love, moved into a flat together and, for a few years, we were giddy with delight at our shared life. But gradually infatuation gave way to over-familiarity. We felt trapped and took to hissing and scratching at each other like two cats in a sack. Tired of misery, I told Maria I wanted to split up. My bags already mentally packed, I delivered my news with a detachment that belied the previous five years of intimacy.

"You're so cold," Maria protested. "It's like you don't have a heart." I left and decided I was done with relationships for a while. That was six years ago. Over that time, I've gone out with quite a few different women but never for longer than three or four months. Now I'm in my early 30s and almost all my friends are in established relationships. I'm the odd guy out at dinner parties. The only man I know who weighs up the single person supplement when planning a holiday.

I should, then, be a soulmate to all the thirtysomething women living alone, at odds with couple-centred society. Singletons have had their hand-wringing, neurosis-fuelled say over the past couple of years, courtesy of Bridget, Ally and the chorus that has chimed in after them to bemoan the lot of the man-less woman. So maybe it's time for men to join in with their own woes about the single life.

This is clearly a notion that resonates with Ally McBeal creator David E Kelly, who recently expressed his belief that "a lot of men feel exactly the same. And listen: some of us are even more emotionally neurotic."

It might also be welcomed as a cathartic exercise by the Metropolitan Police, who warned last week that increasing numbers of successful women are being stalked by ex-lovers. Humiliated at rejection by high-flying partners, emasculated men have taken to following women to work, barging into the office and shouting obscenities at them in front of their colleagues.

Unlike women, single men have no totemic figures like Bridget Jones. However caricatured Helen Fielding's creation is, women obviously recognise at least some of themselves in her. By contrast, men have suffered alone. And maybe we can't take it any more.

Yet when I look around at my male friends out in the woman-free wilderness, what do I see? Neither tears nor sorrow. Neither angst nor insecurity. In fact, something of the opposite. An insouciant belief that everything will turn out fine as long as you don't worry about it too much.

A friend of mine, Michael, split up from his girlfriend a few months ago. Wary of broaching a painful topic, I left off it until last week when I asked how he was coping. There was a long pause as though it was the first time he'd given the subject much thought. "I'm OK," he offered. "Obviously I'm upset, but to be honest it's a relief."

Later that day I spoke to my cousin Tony, again with some trepidation, given this was our first conversation since he'd cancelled his wedding plans and separated from his fiancée. He, too, admitted to being upset. But yes, he was OK and in fact "finding single life a relief". In both cases I felt like I was talking to men who'd just got a sudden reprieve from the salt mines.

Yet it's not as if men don't covet the security of relationships. Until Tony and Michael's newfound freedom, they were devoted, caring partners. But they felt baffled, and ultimately exhausted, by the unpredictability of their girlfriends' emotions.

"I never knew where I was," Tony reflected. "One minute she was all right, the next there were tears. She was very needy, and that was OK, but I think she resented that neediness and she was hostile and defensive with me because of the way she felt."

Although he's sad about ending their engagement, Tony believes it's for the best for both of them. "She begged me to reconsider but I genuinely think she needs some time alone to figure out who she really is."

Perhaps men can't help acting on logic. It seems sensible to us to prefer solitude to emotional entanglement. If a relationship has all the straightforwardness of Spaghetti Junction, we're more likely to seek the nearest exit ramp than stay the course. We say we hate commitment and insist we're happier on our own. We think of ourselves as carefree chancers. We revere men like the late Sir Alan Clark, an ageing roué who played the field and carried on scoring till the final whistle.

Yet deep down, we're motivated by fear. For a long time after I split up from Maria, I wondered if her parting words to me - "You don't have a heart" - might be true. I was with her for five years and watched her cry as easily as she laughed, because that was just another way she expressed herself. But each time she did so, I'd flinch. I felt I should be stroking her hair and whispering soothing words in her ear but the prospect was like gripping a sparking power cord. The rawness of her emotion was too much. It brought me closer to the wriggling mess of my own feelings, untended beneath blithe self-assurance. And it felt safer eventually to walk away than stick around for more discomfort.

This month's issue of US men's magazine Details carries a report on men whose partners have been raped and how the emotional aftermath of that event damaged and often destroyed their relationships. "It was a difficult state of mind which I didn't fully comprehend," admits one interviewee, Dave, of his wife's ordeal. Faced with reaching out to her or retreating into himself, though, he chose the latter. "Men try to be stoic," he concluded. "We decide we're just going to handle it. We don't go to doctors. We say: 'It'll pass in five minutes'."

Like Dave, most men will never feel comfortable opening up to their own feelings. They have never known the therapeutic power of a good cry on a mate's shoulder. They see emotional honesty as weakness because it threatens the whole structure of their self-esteem. That's why a bestseller like Mike Gayle's Mr Commitment, about a male Bridget Jones type, is as phoney as the Hitler Diaries. It is read by women imagining they are peering into the souls of men when in fact they are staring down at a reflecting pool.

For all men's shortcomings, though, I'm proud of how we approach life. We make things difficult for ourselves, true. But unlike Ally, Bridget and their real-life counterparts, for whom happiness comes in the form of the perfect man, we believe destiny is in our hands. We aspire to a life that is quiet, easy and untroubled by conflict or anxiety. And we chase that modest goal like knights questing for the holy grail. Sure, it's not much to ask for. But all we want to know is why it's so hard to get.

fields.headline: The left's Lawrence of Arabia
fields.standfirst:
He's been dubbed Saddam's stooge, but Labour MP George Galloway is resolute in his fight to help the millions of ordinary Iraqis suffering under UN sanctions. Ewen MacAskill travels with him on his mercy mission to BaghdadHM Customs and Excise
Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: He's been dubbed Saddam's stooge, but Labour MP George Galloway is resolute in his fight to help the millions of ordinary Iraqis suffering under UN sanctions.  Ewen MacAskill  travels with him on his mercy mission to Baghdad.
fields.body:
The Labour MP, George Galloway, smoking a large Cuban cigar, rolled up at the Jordanian border this week. In a Range Rover flying the British and Iraqi flags, he looked out across no man's land to Iraq. "There is the holy land," he said, with genuine affection.

For many, such a remark would be regarded as inflammatory - the "holy land" is the land of Saddam Hussein? And such enthusiasm for the country could be viewed as treacherous at a time when British warplanes, along with some from the US, still fly sorties over Iraq. The war is not over.

Galloway has no doubts where his loyalty lies on this issue. The Iraqi people are suffering on a devastating scale from the UN sanctions imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait. He says: "One million Iraqis, many of them children, have died, more than Pol Pot murdered in Cambodia."

On arrival at the Iraqi border post, a 50-strong welcome committee was waiting for him, holding up portraits of Saddam and chanting "Galloway welcome." He waved a victory sign from the car window. Another chant followed: "Saddam, the Americans shake at the mention of your name." They broke into song: "With blood and soul, we will sacrifice for Saddam."

The 45-year-old MP for Glasgow Kelvin, who for eight years has been campaigning for the lifting of sanctions, originally wanted to fly medical supplies from London to Baghdad but the flight, which would have been the first between the two capitals since the war, had to be cancelled after a row between the anti-sanctions campaigners on the one side and the British government and the UN sanctions committee on the other. In defiance, he and a handful of others went anyway, flying to Amman in Jordan and leading a small convoy 600 miles across the desert to Baghdad on Tuesday. He told those gathered at the border: "We are determined to break the stranglehold the Americans have on the country. One day we will win, because God is great."

He arouses strong emotions and has made lots of enemies. A British foreign office source, dismissive of the trip, described him as a "buffoon". But there is a lot of warmth for Galloway in the Arab world, much more than might be believed back home in a sceptical Britain. While the meeting at the border was stage-managed, elsewhere in Iraq, where he is almost universally recognised, and in other parts of the Middle East, the welcome is spontaneous and genuine.

In Jordan, sitting in traffic, a man in the next car rolled down his window to reach out and shake his hand. At a petrol station, another man walked up and offered him a sweet. It does not sound much but the man did not look as if he had much. Close to the Jordanian Iraqi border, a Bedouin, Sheik Abu-Hatam, who runs herds of sheep, insisted that he stop for lunch. Galloway told him he could not stop but eventually relented, agreeing to go in for a minute. Time passed, and a full-scale lunch appeared, the sheik saying: "Because you did not want any formalities, I have killed only one sheep."

Galloway, who joined the Labour party aged 13 and is on the left, has a wide range of interests, from Cuba to Pakistan through to Scottish devolution, but it is the Arab cause that he first embraced with a passion and for which he is best-known. Born in Dundee, he left school at 16 to work in a Michelin tyre factory. By his mid-twenties he had transformed himself into the most prominent and passionate British champion of the Arabs - socialism's answer to Lawrence of Arabia.

His life was changed by a chance encounter when he was 21. He was sitting in the Labour party's office in Dundee when a Palestinian came in, saying he represented Palestinian students at Dundee university and wanted to put his case to someone in the party. When the Palestinian left two-and-a-half hours later, he had made an important convert.

Galloway spent three months living in the Lebanon with Palestinian refugees, and had a Palestinian girlfriend. He now lives with a Palestinian, though not the same one as in the Lebanon. His partner now is Amineh Abu-Zayadd, a 33-year-old scientist from Jerusalem: they share a flat in London.

Back in Britain after his stint in Lebanon, he organised the twinning of Nablus and Dundee, where the Palestinian flag flew over the Labour-controlled council headquarters.

Earlier this week, on the Jordanian shoreline, looking across at the sun setting on the blue hills of what was once Israel but is now Palestine, he said wistfully: "I used to dream I would be part of the force that would wade ashore, Kalashnikov in hand, and return it to its rightful owners." Such rhetoric stems in part from romantic socialism, echoing heroes such as Lenin, Mao and Che Guevara, but in the main from a belief that the Palestinians are the victims of a huge injustice.

Eight years ago, he visited Iraq for the first time and was appalled by the condition he found people in. He had a new cause. Coming so soon after the formal end to the Gulf war, his involvement brought accusations of being a quisling, a traitor and Saddam's stooge. He was dubbed the MP for Baghdad Central.

At a public meeting on the Crusader hilltop town of Karak in Jordan on Monday night, packed with people fiercely sympathetic to Iraq and its president, he said bravely: "Saddam is not my hero." A shout came from the audience: "He's mine."

Galloway draws a distinction between Saddam, whom he does not support, and his campaigning on behalf of the Iraqi people. But he is valued by the Iraqi government. When he arrived at the border, the deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, unexpectedly sent two Mercedes to whisk him to Baghdad.

As part of his anti-sanctions campaign, Galloway took a young Iraqi girl suffering from cancer, Maria Hamza, to Britain for treatment, highlighting the crucial shortages in lraqi hospitals. Back in Baghdad now, the six-year old is still alive with the cancer under control, but is blind. Last year, he embarked on another stage of his campaign, driving a London double-decker to Baghdad.

webTitle: Thieves rob bodies after car wreck

fields.headline: Thieves rob bodies after car wreck
fields.trailText: Thieves robbed the bodies of two British tourists as they lay undiscovered in a ravine in Bolivia for six days following a road accident, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Thieves robbed the bodies of two British tourists as they lay undiscovered in a ravine in Bolivia for six days following a road accident, it emerged last night.

The women were among nine people killed when a four-wheel-drive vehicle plunged from a mountain road 400 metres into a narrow valley in bad weather as it was returning from a trip to the Amazonian jungle.

Valuables including watches and money had been taken from the group, which also included three young Irishwomen, when police finally found the wrecked Toyota 4x4.

The crash, happened early on March 5.

A Foreign Office spokesman said: "There was some delay in locating the bodies but when they were found it was discovered that valuables had been taken. The Bolivian authorities are investigating."

Relatives of the two Britons, aged 26 and 27, neither of whom has been named, were waiting for the bodies to be flown home from La Paz.

It is thought the group, which also included a German and a South African, had arranged for a lift with the Bolivian owner of the four-wheel-drive and another local, both of whom were also killed.

webTitle: Brady will go on with food strike

fields.headline: Brady will go on with food strike
fields.trailText: The moors murderer, Ian Brady, has vowed to continue his hunger strike, despite the high court ruling that he can be kept alive by force feeding.
fields.body:
The moors murderer, Ian Brady, has vowed to continue his hunger strike, despite the high court ruling that he can be kept alive by force feeding.

In a letter to his solicitor, Robin Makin, he said that the events of the last six months had merely confirmed and reinforced his resolve to die.

Brady, 62, said his eyesight had started to fail and his teeth were falling out as a result of the hunger strike.

He claimed Ashworth hospital was feeding him like a battery farm animal. Staff at the Merseyside hospital were also trying to break his spirit by depriving him of sleep and denying him medication, he claimed.

Brady said he was angry that he was not allowed to give evidence during last week's hearing at Liverpool high court.

fields.headline: Laird to sell ancestral home
fields.trailText: A house which has been in the same family for 900 years is for sale, it was confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
A house which has been in the same family for 900 years is for sale, it was confirmed yesterday.

Kirkconnell House, near New Abbey in Dumfries and Galloway, has been occupied by the Maxwell family since medieval times, but present laird of the manor, Francis Maxwell, said, though it was a difficult decision to sever ties, he was being forced to sell after losing a fortune with the insurance company Lloyd's.

He added his divorce in 1998 from Nicola Crichton-Stewart, with whom he has five children aged between seven and 15, also contributed to his decision to sell.

Mr Maxwell, 46, said that in 1760 the house became the first in Scotland to be built from brick thanks to French artisans constructing brick kilns near the site. The earliest part of the building dated from the 12th century, he added.

The property, due to be sold at a starting price of £375,000, includes the main house with three re ception rooms and four bedrooms, a keep with five apartments, stables, a coach house and a walled garden.

Mr Maxwell intends to retain around 80 acres of land and the barony with the title Kirkconnell.

webTitle: Jagger told to pay to support son model's son

fields.headline: Jagger told to pay to support son model's son
fields.trailText: Mick Jagger, 56, was yesterday ordered to pay £6,250 a month for the upkeep of his 10-month-old son by a Brazilian model, Luciana Morad.
fields.body:
Mick Jagger, 56, was yesterday ordered to pay £6,250 a month for the upkeep of his 10-month-old son by a Brazilian model, Luciana Morad.

He formally confirmed he was the father of Lucas in a telephone link from the London offices of his solicitors to a US family court in Manhattan.

A spokesman for the Rolling Stone said that the model's lawyers had asked for initial payments "to tide her over during the hearings" of $35,000 dollars a month, but he had agreed to $10,000. Jagger spoke to the court only to confirm his name and paternity, handing the phone to his solicitor for the remainder of proceedings. The next hearing will be in May.

Morad, who is reported to be seeking a £6m lump sum, flew to New York from Rio de Janeiro for yesterday's hearing.

An associate told the New York Post: "She wants it all wrapped up quickly and neatly. She has so many exciting projects in the works, but can't proceed until the child support matter is settled."

Morad gave birth last May, at 29. Jagger agreed a divorce with model Jerry Hall for a £10m settlement last August.

fields.headline: Violence 'driving women from their homes'
fields.trailText: When the beatings got so bad that Christina finally left her husband, she never dreamed that three years later she and her children would still be living in a two-bedroom "temporary" council flat.
fields.body:
When the beatings got so bad that Christina finally left her husband, she never dreamed that three years later she and her children would still be living in a two-bedroom "temporary" council flat.

"I thought having three children would make us eligible for a house," said Christina, 31, who sleeps in the living room. "They never made it clear we would be in this position and it would take so long."

Christina's case is one of hundreds handled by Shelter, the housing charity, which today identifies domestic violence as one of the chief causes of homelessness.

During the first 12 months of the charity's free telephone advice service, Shelterline, domestic violence accounted for almost 2,700 calls.

All but 600 were from women facing the loss of their home because they needed to leave for their own safety.

Shelter is calling for a change in the law so that people fleeing domestic violence are automatically accorded priority need when applying to councils as homeless.

The charity says such people have often suffered severe trauma and have complex needs.

"Many will have suffered years of domestic violence before seeking advice. It is vital that when they do there is an effective response."

Christina, which is not her real name, spent four months in a women's refuge after leaving the family home in Hertfordshire. A court order had not stopped harassment by her husband and he moved back into the home as soon as it expired.

When the local council subsequently allocated the flat to Christina and her children, aged four, seven and eight, she was told it would be for at least six months but no longer than two years.

"There is no space for the children to play and nowhere to put their toys," said Christina, who is studying at college.

"What we really need is a house with a garden where we can settle and stay, so that they are settled down before they go to secondary school."

Shelter says the problems facing homless families are being compounded by acute shortages of housing in many parts of southern England, causing some councils to refuse to re-house women and their children even where social services recommend it under the children act.

The charity reports that almost 60% of the domestic violence calls to its advice line came from single women. A majority of those were from women without children, leaving them with less legal protection and fewer housing rights.

Almost one in 10 callers saying they had suffered domestic violence, and faced loss of their home, was a man.

Shelterline, which is supported by BT, took 82,000 calls in its first year. Almost 47,000 were from people already homeless, or about to become so, and more than 27,000 were from people who said they risked sleeping rough that night.

As well as domestic violence, Shelter identifies financial troubles and the lack of a safety net for single people as the main causes of homelessness.

Chris Holmes, the charity's director, said some vulnerable people were getting no help under housing law. "Only substantial government investment in new homes and legislative action will turn this situation around to ensure these people have a future."

Shelterline is on 0808-800-4444.

fields.headline: Streets become alfresco gallery
fields.trailText: A square mile of streets in a suburb of Leeds is about to turn itself into an outdoor art gallery - and rid itself of the much-hated traditional estate agents' boards at the same time.
fields.body:
A square mile of streets in a suburb of Leeds is about to turn itself into an outdoor art gallery - and rid itself of the much-hated traditional estate agents' boards at the same time.

A scheme in Headingley will offer a choice of Mondrian, Leonardo da Vinci and contemporary painters to punters who are moving.

The paintings will decorate for sale boards in the area, whose handsome Victorian redbricks stand along tree-lined streets.

Small artworks will relieve the commercialism of the boards when properties are for sale, and then a full-size painting will mark success instead of a red 'Sold' sticker.

The idea, Art in the Streets, is being tested by Mac Maclean of Headingley Estates which will advertise the scheme by painting a Fauvist mural on its main offices in Leeds. It is also sifting through gallery guides for appropriate sign artworks.

"Clients will be offered a choice of about half a dozen different paintings to start with - probably including the Mona Lisa, Whistler's mother and a Mondrian - to mark or celebrate a sale," said Nick Wayne, a Leeds graphic designer, who suggested the idea after driving through part of Headingley forested with conventional boards. "We hope it's a scheme which will meet the commercial aim of the for sale signs - to get noticed - but at the same time look attractive and even enhance the streets."

Estate agents' boards have caused controversy for years, with scores of failed attempts to shrink the usual hoarding size, but the trade has also been a famous source of bright ideas. The London agent Roy Brooks became internationally famous in the 1960s for writing property descriptions so sarcastic and critical that they became a cult.

Mr Wayne said: "We hope that Art in the Streets will aid a permanent air of fun to Headingley. It's something to celebrate when you successfully sell, or buy, somewhere to live and the paintings will reflect that. If we can take things further and encourage work by local artists, that will be all the better."

webTitle: Key to life on Mars lies in the soil

fields.headline: Key to life on Mars lies in the soil
fields.trailText: Evidence for life on Mars might be in the soil - and overlooked because all previous missions had the wrong detector system.
fields.body:
Evidence for life on Mars might be in the soil - and overlooked because all previous missions had the wrong detector system.

Organic chemicals such as alcohol, vinegar or oxalic acid - the stuff that makes rhubarb leaves taste bitter - might have existed on Mars, but landing craft would have failed to detect their byproducts, according to a team of US scientists.

The harsh, thin Martian atmosphere would have altered such life-associated chemicals in various ways, Steve Benner of the university of Florida in Gainesville tells the New Scientist today.

The Florida team simply looked at the oldest evidence from Mars and saw a missed opportunity. In the fierce ultraviolet radiation of the Red Planet, organic carbon-based molecules would have been dismantled, or transmuted into something else. The most stable byproduct of acetic acid or oxalic acid or ethanol would be a carboxylic acid. In 1976 the Viking robot landers revealed a cold, arid desert after they scooped up Martian soil and heated it to 500C for 30 seconds and analysed the vapour. But, the scientists point out, carboxylic acid takes longer than 30 seconds to turn to vapour.

The argument will kick new life into the faltering life-on-Mars debate. Two weeks ago the journal Nature carried a blow for the faithful: the sulphur in the Martian soil could be explained without help from biological processes, a study said.

If there are traces of carbon-based life on Mars, says Colin Pillinger of the Open university, they will be detected by the British lander Beagle2, to be delivered by a European mission in 2003.

webTitle: McCartney and model 'an item' grow close

fields.headline: McCartney and model 'an item' grow close
fields.trailText: Sir Paul McCartney confirmed yesterday that he and the model Heather Mills were "an item" and asked photographers to leave them be.
fields.body:
Sir Paul McCartney confirmed yesterday that he and the model Heather Mills were "an item" and asked photographers to leave them be.

The former Beatle, whose wife, Linda, died of cancer two years ago, spoke out after he and Mills were seen walking in a London park.

Mills, 32, and McCartney, 57, are believed to have met a year ago at a charity event. The model, who lost a leg in a road accident in 1993, has aided fundraising appeals for disabled people. McCartney helped her to launch her charity single, Voice.

McCartney said: "Yes we're very good friends. She's a very impressive woman. We are an item. We've done charity work together and we've grown close. We have been on holiday together, and that's it.

"What we don't need at this stage is photographers lurking in bushes. If this is to develop, then give us a chance.

"I'm not a politician, and we're not spies. I don't want to be surrounded by photographers, because that could wreck something."

If this is to develop, then give us a chance. "I'm not a politician, and we're not spies. I don't want to be surrounded by photographers, because that could wreck something."

fields.headline: Bound in bronze
fields.standfirst: New tenant settles on square's fourth plinth
fields.trailText: The latest temporary occupant of Trafalgar Square was unveiled yesterday as the Goodwood foundation promised to continue commissioning pieces to fill the fourth plinth until a decision is reached on its permanent fate.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The latest temporary occupant of Trafalgar Square was unveiled yesterday as the Goodwood foundation promised to continue commissioning pieces to fill the fourth plinth until a decision is reached on its permanent fate.

The Sculpture at Goodwood foundation paid £300,000 for yesterday’s installation, Regardless of History, a gigantic bronze by Bill Woodrow showing the head of a man crushed under a giant book, both bound to the plinth by the roots of a dead tree.

The plinth had been empty for more than 150 years, until the Royal Society of Artists, and its deputy chairwoman, Prue Leith, decided to fill it with installations of contemporary sculpture, each lasting eight months. The first, much debated and much admired, was Mark Wallinger’s figure of Christ.

Rachel Whiteread’s upended cast of the plinth in transparent resin, which will take over the site next autumn, was planned to be the last - until the offer from the foundation.

Sculpture at Goodwood, founded in 1992, has commissioned almost 100 works by British sculptors, which it displays and sells from a sculpture park in West Sussex.

Wilfred Cass, co-founder, gazing up at Regardless of History, said: “Wonderful piece - better than I expected. This the most tremendous site for engaging directly with the public. We’ll go on commissioning pieces for it for as long as it’s available.”

Mr Woodrow said: “I’m quite surprised. It looks just like I thought it would look.”

Taxi and bus drivers were immediately debating his work: “Don’t know what it means,” one driver said, staring at the crushed head, “but I know just how that bloke feels.”

webTitle: Ex-Radio 1 DJ jailed in Prague for child sex abuse

fields.headline: Ex-Radio 1 DJ jailed in Prague for child sex abuse
fields.trailText: A former Radio 1 DJ who sexually abused young boys during holiday trips to Prague was yesterday sentenced to four and a half years in jail by a Czech court.
fields.body:
A former Radio 1 DJ who sexually abused young boys during holiday trips to Prague was yesterday sentenced to four and a half years in jail by a Czech court.

Chris Denning, aged 58, who was in the Radio 1 line-up alongside Terry Wogan, Jimmy Saville and John Peel when it began broadcasting in 1967, was told by the judge Viktor Mach, sentencing, that he was "a social danger".

He was convicted on eight charges of sexually abusing boys under the age of 15, and of corrupting the moral education of under 18-year-olds.

Denning was arrested in Prague in November 1997 on 10 charges of sexual abuse from June of that year until his arrest. He denied the charges.

The court heard how he and co-defendants, an American, Lindsay Shannon, 45, and two Frenchmen, Jean-Pierre Roffi and Jean-Marc Smadja, also in their forties, visited Prague's bars, gambling halls and swimming pools to make contact with the boys, some as young as 13. Denning then took them back to his flat, fondled them and had sex, paying them for their services.

The 16-month long trial, which heard statements from more than 50 witnesses and experts, has been the highest profile sexual abuse case in the Czech republic.

The former DJ's final defence statement took almost 40 hours to deliver, making it the longest such statement in the country's recorded legal history. He used the statement to protest his innocence and said that the boys he had met in Prague had "thrust themselves" upon him.

Ivana Vancurova, prosecuting, told the court how Denning and his co-defendants formed bonds of trust with the boys.

"They gave them financial aid and gifts and invited them to restaurants so the victims came to trust them ... the accused exploited this trust to have sexual relations with the victims," she said.

Denning, who has already spent two and a half years in custody in Prague's Pankrac prison, is likely to serve another two years.

He told the court that his diabetes made it impossible for him to perform sexually. If anything sexual happened between him and the boys, he said, it was "in the most friendly, consensual circumstances".

The court heard that Denning had a string of convictions for sexual assault and gross indecency in Britain going back to 1974, most recently from February 1996 when he received a 10-week jail term for possessing child pornography. He told the court that the boys he met in Prague were mostly from broken homes and in need of a father figure. They looked up to him as a friend and admired him because he had worked as a prostitute as a boy in London, he said.

After leaving Radio 1 Denning worked as a record promoter, working with the Beatles and helping to launch the careers of Gary Glitter and the Bay City Rollers.

Before his arrest he ran a music and video company from his home in Bracknell, Berkshire, but has since lost his 10 bedroom house and now faces bankruptcy.

"I've lost the entire structure of my private life," he said. "My property, house, vehicle, savings ... as well as my private company and clients."

Throughout the trial Denning described how he had struggled to come to terms with his sexuality, visiting a psychoanalyst for five years in the 1970s and becoming the youngest member of the homosexual law reform society in London at the age of 14.

His lawyer, Tomas Matusek, said Denning was a financially broken man whose value system had been turned on its head. He said that his client had filled a void by looking after his male "friends".

If he were to be deported to Britain, he warned that Denning would face persecution for his sexual orientation in his own country.

Shannon, Roffi and Smadja were all sentenced to three and a half years in jail.

As a foreigner, Denning will probably serve the full four and a half year term without probation, but he could apply to serve the sentence in Britain.

Judge Mach ordered him to be deported for an indefinite period at the end of his prison term. Under the 1997 sex offenders act Denning could face prosecution for the same case if he returns to Britain.

webTitle: Community on the brink fears coup de grace

fields.headline: Community on the brink fears coup de grace
fields.standfirst: Sense of pride ebbs from the next generation
fields.trailText: At St Columba's Roman Catholic school this term, Rover is sponsoring a scheme offering book tokens to encourage better attendance. Rover, whose 430 acre plant is directly opposite the playground, works hard on its links with the school: most of the 180 pupils have parents who work there, many others whose jobs directly or indirectly depend on it.
fields.body:
At St Columba's Roman Catholic school this term, Rover is sponsoring a scheme offering book tokens to encourage better attendance. Rover, whose 430 acre plant is directly opposite the playground, works hard on its links with the school: most of the 180 pupils have parents who work there, many others whose jobs directly or indirectly depend on it.

A good number of the pupils, aged four to 11, might have hopes of working at Longbridge.

Amid the uncertainty over the future of the plant last night, headteacher Pat Docherty said closure would be disastrous for the school and the parents. The "sense of pride" which the pupils felt about the plant was keen.

Last term an exhibition about the plant was put on at the school. Rover staff spoke and children brought in pictures of Minis and their favourite Rover cars.

"This community largely exists because of heavy industry. We wouldn't want to lose that. It would be very sad," Mrs Docherty said.

At the plant itself there was inevitably anger and bitterness. "Everybody in there has been feeling miserable all day long," said Donald Davies, 55, who has spent 10 years at the plant working on the MGF sports car. "We are really fed up with it."

Though the plant has experienced several crises in its 106 year history, especially over the last two years, Mr Davies was starting to fear that today's meeting of BMW management in Munich could really mark the end.

If there was a quieter quality than expected, it was partly through confusion. "The lull before the storm," said Ollie Thomas, a steward for AEEU, and chairman of the plant works committee.

When he joined Longbridge in 1962, there were about 45,000 people working there. Now it is 8,500. But that still means about another 40,000 jobs depend directly or indirectly on work generated by the plant

Longbridge dominates this corner of southern Birmingham, on the lip of Worcestershire and Tory-held Bromsgrove. There is prosperity here, prosperity built on manufacturing industry. Prosperity that still, despite the 1980s, relies on the car industry.

Despite efforts, backed by the Birmingham Chamber of Commerce, for diversification and modernisation, Longbridge is not yet ready to move into a new industrial era.

"I think we believed that in 15-20 years time there was always a potential that Longbridge might have to close," said Louise Beard, policy director at the chamber. "But in 15-20 years we might have had time to develop other businesses, other interests."

webTitle: Police claim Observer breached secrets act with former MI5 agent

fields.headline: Police claim Observer breached secrets act with former MI5 agent
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Police are investigating serious breaches of the official secrets act by Observer journalists over the newspaper's contact with the former MI5 agent David Shayler, the Old Bailey was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Police are investigating serious breaches of the official secrets act by Observer journalists over the newspaper's contact with the former MI5 agent David Shayler, the Old Bailey was told yesterday.

The Observer is fighting an order by special branch demanding it hand over any doc uments and emails relating to the newspaper's contact with Mr Shayler over a story it published last month.

The newspaper alleged Mr Shayler, who is being investigated by the police for alleged breaches of the official secrets act, had named two MI6 agents involved in an alleged plot to assassinate the Libyan leader Colonel Gadafy.

Detective Sergeant John Flynn, from the financial investigations unit of special branch, said the order was being sought to gather evidence against Mr Shayler. But in addition there were reasonable grounds for believing the journalist Martin Bright, and the Observer's editor, Roger Alton, had contravened section 5 of the official secrets act by re ceiving and then making damaging disclosures of secret information.

Ben Emmerson, representing Mr Bright, told the judge it would be unlawful to make an order for him to disclose evidence that could potentially convict his client of such an offence. The journalist was entitled to a defence against "self incrimination" he said.

"If you were to commit Mr Bright to custody for contempt of court, you would be making an order that a person be sent to prison for not providing the police with evidence that could be used against him," Mr Emmerson said.

Earlier Michael Tugendhat QC, representing the Observer, said the disclosure order should not be granted because the police had failed to produce any direct evidence from the security services to show that the article had in any way damaged the national interest.

Detective Sergeant Flynn said Detective Inspector Lerner, leading the Shayler investigation, had shown him a note he had written after being briefed by MI5. He said the security service claimed the arti cle had damaged the national interest. But Mr Tugendhat argued the policeman's evidence was based on hearsay, and the court should disregard it.

Earlier Judge Martin Stephens reserved judgment in a separate production order served on the Guardian, demanding the disclosure of an email sent by Mr Shayler.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Mother charged with killing baby
The mother of a baby found dead in a canal was yesterday charged with murder. Robina Hashim, 29, had reported four-month-old Emma-Jade Dyson missing on Tuesday morning, claiming she had been abducted from outside a public toilet in Burnley in Lancashire. After a search the body was found in the Leeds-Liverpool canal, near her home.
Helen Carter

After a search the body was found in the Leeds-Liverpool canal, near her home. Helen Carter

First blind judge appointed

The first blind judge to preside over jury trials was announced yesterday by the lord chancellor. John Lafferty, a solicitor in Stepney, east London, has been appointed an assistant recorder, a part-time post in crown courts on the ladder to a full-time judgeship. The first blind magistrate was appointed in 1998.
Clare Dyer

Table manners in birdland

Barn owl chicks have impeccable table manners, zoologists report in New Scientist magazine. Chicks monitor each other's hunger by the intensity of their cries, and the less hungry birds wait their turn; it had been assumed they cried out to parents, but in many bird species chicks call all night even in the adults' absence.

Parlez-vous anglais?

Millions cross the channel but few can recognise everyday French words, according to a survey for BookThat.com. Of 10 words - travail, entrecte, piscine, plage, été, soeur, pont, poulet and carte - Britons knew two on average; 80% did not know how to say swimming pool or beach, and 88% did not know the word for summer. The average rose to three in the south-east.

webTitle: Honouring Dando £5m appeal launched for crime science centre

fields.headline: Honouring Dando £5m appeal launched for crime science centre
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: The fiance of the TV presenter Jill Dando reflected yesterday on the way his life had been destroyed by her murder as he launched an appeal to raise £5m for a crime prevention project that will bear her name.
fields.body:
The fiance of the TV presenter Jill Dando reflected yesterday on the way his life had been destroyed by her murder as he launched an appeal to raise £5m for a crime prevention project that will bear her name.

Alan Farthing said the shooting 11 months ago had left him "disgusted by the injustice of it all" but determined to find a way of ensuring that some good came from the evil that had killed her.

Ms Dando's relatives and friends will honour her by establishing a crime research centre at University College London, which they hope will become a world focus for crime prevention projects.

Their plans were outlined in Claridges Hotel in London at a press conference chaired by Nick Ross, Ms Dando's co-presenter on the BBC's Crimewatch.

Among those on the platform were Sir John Stevens, Metropolitan police commissioner, the singer Sir Cliff Richard, the Countess of Wessex (above in front of a picture of Ms Dando), Nigel Dando, Ms Dando's brother, and the psycholo gist Ken Pease.

Between them they described how, with enough funds, a Jill Dando chair in crime science would be set up at the university.

A professor could be appointed in the summer, and undergraduate courses could begin in the autumn.

Professor Pease defined crime science as the study of criminal events to identify trends and develop prevention techniques.

The courses would draw from many d isciplines including criminology, psychology, geography, design and engineering to develop the best ways of fighting crime in the 21st century.

Sir John said the murder squad would "never give up" the hunt for Ms Dando's killer while there were still leads to be followed.

Donations can be made to the fund via the website jilldandofund.com, by phone on 0800 0150125, at branches of Lloyds TSB, or by cheque to The Jill Dando Fund, Lloyds TSB, 50 Notting Hill Gate, London, W11 3JD.

fields.headline: Mandelson abandons arms hope
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, was forced to admit yesterday that the government has abandoned any hope that the IRA would disarm by May 22, the date set in the Good Friday agreement endorsed two years ago by Sinn Fein.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, was forced to admit yesterday that the government has abandoned any hope that the IRA would disarm by May 22, the date set in the Good Friday agreement endorsed two years ago by Sinn Fein.

In some of his gloomiest remarks since the reimposition of direct rule last month, Mr Mandelson told MPs: "Realistically, I have to say that the prospects for achieving complete decomissioning by May 22 are poor."

The junior Northern Ireland minister, George Howarth, told MPs a few minutes later: "There is no evidence that decommissioning will be completed or started by May 22."

Their interventions will come as little surprise to the pro-agreement parties gathering in the US ahead of the St Patrick's day celebrations on Friday. On Tuesday the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, said that the deadline "no longer exists".

However, a failure to meet the deadline will have enormous symbolic significance. John Taylor, the deputy leader of the Ulster Unionists, has said that he will withdraw his support for the agreement if the deadline passes with no gesture from the paramilitaries.

Mr Mandelson, however, insisted that he would press ahead with efforts to revive the peace process. Decommissioning was still an essential part of it, but the agreement would still remain on the table if the IRA refused to disarm by May.

He was looking seriously at a six-point plan to revive the peace process, drawn up by the Northern Ireland Alliance party. This calls for the formation of the power-sharing executive after a series of carefully orchestrated moves which would see the IRA agreeing to a disarmament timetable and the army reducing its presence.

webTitle: Art sales threat as Europe sets levy

fields.headline: Art sales threat as Europe sets levy
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest auction houses could face serious losses of revenue and jobs after the government last night accepted European Union proposals to impose a levy on art sales.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and  Maev Kennedy
fields.body:
Britain's biggest auction houses could face serious losses of revenue and jobs after the government last night accepted European Union proposals to impose a levy on art sales.

EU ambassadors agreed a compromise under which artists or their descendants would receive a harmonised royalty payment each time their works were resold in the EU.

The idea is to reward young artists - suffering from the so-called "starving in a garret syndrome" - who would rarely command their highest price on the first sale. It is also intended to redress the balance with pop stars, authors and film makers who receive royalties every time their works are reprinted or re-shown. David Hockney, Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin should thus be treated the same way as the Spice Girls and Elton John.

webTitle: Russian held for spying for Britain

fields.headline: Russian held for spying for Britain
fields.trailText: A Russian citizen has been arrested and charged with spying for Britain, Russia's counter-intelligence service said yesterday, in a case which could sour newly forged bonds between Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, and the British prime minister, Tony Blair.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman  in Moscow and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
A Russian citizen has been arrested and charged with spying for Britain, Russia's counter-intelligence service said yesterday, in a case which could sour newly forged bonds between Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, and the British prime minister, Tony Blair.

No details of the offence have been released, but a spokesman for the FSB - the successor to the Soviet-era KGB - said the man was being interrogated in the high-security Lefortovo prison in Moscow. A criminal case has been opened against him.

The arrest came only days after Mr Blair met Mr Putin - a former KGB agent and more recently the head of the FSB - for informal talks and a friendly evening at the opera in St Petersburg.

The incident also cast a shadow on already strained relations between Russia and its former Soviet neighbour Estonia.

An FSB spokesman, Alexander Zdanovich, claimed the Estonian secret services had worked with the alleged spy to aid British intelligence.

British agents are said to have travelled to the Estonian capital, Tallinn, to work with the Russian citizen, who was also a regular visitor to the city. If no direct meetings with his British handlers had been set up, he would send information via the Estonian security police to Britain, another FSB source said.

Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Russia has repeatedly accused the secret police in former Soviet countries - particularly the Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia - of cooperating with Nato in its drive to recruit Russian agents.

A spokesman for Russia's foreign reconnaissance service said yesterday: "It is no secret that western intelligence services have used the Baltic states as a base for current work and for expanding their activities in Russia."

The British embassy made no comment on the incident. Estonia's security police also declined to comment, saying the issue was not yet being taken very seriously "since the information available is not adequate".

Another Russian citizen, Platon Obukhov, was arrested in 1996 for allegedly passing secrets of a "political and strategic defence character" to British agents while working as a diplomat for the Russian foreign ministry.

His trial, due to begin in Moscow this week, was again postponed on Tuesday.

Mr Obukhov's arrest prompted the worst spy row between London and Moscow since the end of the cold war, with Britain and Russia each expelling four diplomats.

Last November Russia expelled the US diplomat Cheri Leberknight for spying, claiming the FSB had caught her red-handed in a Moscow park in the act of receiving secret Russian military papers.

Despite the end of the cold war, Russia is still considered a priority target by Britain's MI6, which is keen, in particular, to gather information on Moscow's nuclear and conventional weapons programme and arms exports.

webTitle: Return of the lost planet to Holst's solar system

fields.headline: Return of the lost planet to Holst's solar system
fields.trailText: An incomplete musical solar system created by one of the leading British composers of the 20th century is to be given an extra planet 80 years after its first performance.
fields.body:
An incomplete musical solar system created by one of the leading British composers of the 20th century is to be given an extra planet 80 years after its first performance.

Gustav Holst completed his seven-movement Planets suite in 1917, 13 years before Pluto was discovered. He had four years to consider the new planet but, made anxious by the huge popularity of his best-known work, declined to add to his finished score before he died in 1934.

Now, thanks to a commission from Manchester's Hallé orchestra, Pluto will come out of the far distant cold. Composer Colin Matthews finished the score of the six-minute addition this week, and it will be given its first performance at the Bridgewater Hall, Manchester, in May.

"Kent Nagano [the Hallé's music director] also asked if I would compose an opening movement, which he sug gested could be Earth," said Mr Matthews. "I was rather reluctant. And I agreed with some reluctance to take on Pluto, partly because I felt I was laying my head on the block."

The Planets in its familiar form ends with Neptune and a wordless women's chorus (sung off stage) fading away ad lib into ethereal nothingness. Pluto will emerge from the moment just before silence.

"The initial thought was that if you were going to do Pluto, it had to be even more remote than Neptune, which was clearly not possible unless the whole orchestra joined the chorus off stage. So I went off in a completely different direction. Pluto is very quiet, apart from a couple of outbursts, but it scurries and is very fast indeed. At the end, the music disappears, almost as if Neptune had been quietly continuing in the background."

Holst was fascinated by astrology but Mr Matthews is a sceptic. "I didn't feel that I should rely on the astrological significance of Pluto, which is more than a little ambiguous, and, apart from choosing the title Pluto the Renewer, left that aspect to one side."

fields.headline: Charges in barmaid killing case
fields.trailText: A Leeds man was charged last night with the rape and murder of a barmaid six years ago.
fields.body:
A Leeds man was charged last night with the rape and murder of a barmaid six years ago. Wendy Speakes, 51, a mother of two, was found in a pool of blood at her home in Wakefield. She had been forced by her killer to wear an unusual pair of blue sandals and had been tied up with her tights.

The man charged, who has not been named but is aged 38 and from Horsforth, Leeds, will appear before Wakefield magistrates today. He was arrested early on Tuesday at his home.

The murder made headlines in 1994 when police said they were looking for a suspected foot fetishist. As well as forcing Mrs Speakes to wear the sandals, the killer left a pair of black shoes by the body and stole another pair, not yet recovered.

webTitle: Jail calls in police after fresh complaints against officers

fields.headline: Jail calls in police after fresh complaints against officers
fields.trailText: Police have been called in to Wormwood Scrubs jail in west London to investigate fresh complaints by prisoners against officers since the launch of a six-month emergency plan to keep the prison from closure.
fields.body:
Police have been called in to Wormwood Scrubs jail in west London to investigate fresh complaints by prisoners against officers since the launch of a six-month emergency plan to keep the prison from closure.

The governor, Stephen Moore, said last night there had been a "handful" of complaints, but if there was a hard core of officers who still believed brutality was acceptable in the prison they would be dealt with severely.

"They need to be on notice that they're heading for jail themselves, because that's what will happen, that's where I want them to be," he told BBC2's Newsnight.

In a damning report last year on the jail, the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, found that staff were brutal and racist, and 27 officers were suspended and charged with assault.

The emergency plan was intended to make fundamental changes toWormwood Scrubs and keep it open. But the new allegations will not help.

One former employee, Anne Lawrie, said she did not feel some members of staff were taking certain issues in the prison seriously.

Under the plan, officers were retrained to make them more sensitive to issues such as race, but Ms Lawrie said she did not feel officers treated it as a problem.

Mr Moore said he believed staff did take the retraining seriously. "I'm not going to sit here and say that 100% of all the staff are absolutely committed to any prison service initiative, whatever it might be. There will be some people who disengage with that process. The majority of staff take it seriously."

But allegations of racism remain. Ms Lawrie said another officer told her of a black inmate who on his first night in the prison was provoked to make him lose his temper, and then he was held down by two officers while others assaulted him.

Mr Moore said this sort of behaviour would not be tolerated, and action would be taken by the prison service.

"If I've got people like that working here, and if people give me the evidence so that I can investigate that allegation - and there's ample evidence that both I and the prison service will investigate thoroughly any allegation of misconduct by any member of staff - that's precisely what I will do."

Sir David revisited the prison two weeks ago and is likely to report that the problems with the old regime are being swept away, but it is unclear what further action, if any, he may propose.

The prison service said that if any there were any allegations made against officers they would be referred immediately to the police.

fields.headline: Anything goes
fields.standfirst: Tipper Gore - prospective first lady - has spent years waging a vendetta against the music industry, running campaigns for parental guidance stickers on some records. But now she's changed her tune.  Michael Ellison explains why
fields.trailText: Tipper Gore - prospective first lady - has spent years waging a vendetta against the music industry, running campaigns for parental guidance stickers on some records. But now she's changed her tune.
fields.body:
This time next year the former drummer in the high-school group The Wildcats could be kicking back in the screening room at the White House evaluating the movies nominated for the 2001 Oscars.

Of course, that would require Tipper Gore's husband to win the presidential election. Everyone knows that the incumbent likes a blow (on the saxophone) but Al Gore would be the first in the job to concede that he not only put the object in question to his mouth but inhaled too.

And inhaled rather more deeply and more often than he has said so far, according to a recent biography. Al's relaxation technique while he was a reporter on The Tennesseean in Nashville in the early 70s used to be set against a soundtrack provided by The Grateful Dead.

And last year Tipper clambered on stage in California with former members of the band to add percussion to their version of Bob Dylan's Queen Jane Approximately. The ultimate triumph of the bohemian and a golden age for the arts? Not exactly. Punks used to advise: "Never trust an old hippie." Mrs Gore is responsible for those parental guidance stickers on your CDs and her husband, while he goes to Springsteen and Clapton gigs, is more likely to whistle God's tune.

Between The Wildcats and The Dead, Mrs Gore somehow lost her cultural compass and instead found herself saying: "I'm a fairly with-it person, but this stuff is making my hair curl." This stuff was those "inappropriate" lyrics. Mrs Gore, the author of Raising PG Kids In An X-Rated Society, is not the first parent to survive her childhood and then fear that her own brood will not make it through theirs.

She is, though, one of the only people to run a vendetta against part of the entertainment industry whose husband then went asking the victims for campaign funds. She said she was sorry - all she wanted were those stickers - and the moguls and the stars have rewarded Mr Gore with more than $800,000 in campaign contributions.

One of her most fervent opponents in the words war was Frank Zappa; and one of her biggest supporters now is his widow Gail. Mrs Gore's country roads to Damascus indicate how little the entertainment industry has to fear from her husband or his Republican opponent, George W Bush ($577, 000 from the sector). Neither wants to alienate people replete with funds and who in any case have a vested interest in self-censorship to avoid the audience- repellant rating of NC-17, which keeps everyone of that age and under out no matter who is with them.

If Washington was ever going to square up to Hollywood it would have done so last year after two high-school students shot dead 12 other pupils and a teacher before committing suicide in Denver, Colorado. "There is still too much violence on our nation's screens, large and small", Mr Clinton chided. "There are too many creators and purveyors of violence, too many children who are steeped in this culture of violence."

But that was at a time when the country wanted immediate answers. How could two teenagers have done this? Answer: popular culture, in this case movies such as Oliver Stone's Natural Born Killers, and, because the Denver gunmen called themselves members of The Trenchcoat Mafia, gothic music. Which must have surprised members of The Cure and Siouxsie and the former Banshees.

The same day he scolded the industry, the president picked up $2 million at a Hollywood fundraiser. The movie industry knew just how to play it. "If a hurricane comes, you go to the cellar until it's over", said Ted Hartley, head of RKO Pictures. "You don't want to be a lightning rod that stands up against all this. This thing will blow over."

And it did. Mr Clinton held a youth violence summit, but not to apportion blame. The movie industry, broadcasters, the recording industry, not even the gun industry was to blame. It was not about blame but responsibility and everyone was responsible. The Juvenile Crime Bill has been deadlocked in Congress since last summer and with it the provision to spend $2 million on investigating whether violence is being used by the entertainment industry as a marketing tool.

"I don't see violent messages going away", says Dick Rolfe, president of the Dove Foundation, a family advocacy group specialising in entertainment and its effect on society. And he sees no prospect for anything altering under either presidential candidate.

"I don't think new laws by government intervention is the answer. Until we change the hearts and minds of the people and get parents to take responsibility we're heading down a slippery slope."

Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, which awards ratings, says: "I'm not saying that movies don't have an impact. I just don't know what it is." There is no reason to suppose that Mr Gore or Mr Bush have a better idea.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | Leading Edge
fields.body:
One-third of the world's tobacco addicts live in China, getting through an unbelievable total of 90,000 million packets of cigarettes a year. Duncan Hewitt, the BBC's Beijing correspondent, tells Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) that the government, having finally woken up to this immense health problem, has launched a vigorous anti-smoking campaign. There's little evidence that it's having much impact, to the undoubted relief of the Finance Ministry. The state tobacco monopoly accounts for 10 per cent of state revenues.

With the Mozambique floods still in the headlines, Geoff Watts considers the current scientific work on how disastrous tropical storms build up. As he notes in Leading Edge (9.0pm, Radio 4), the storms' destructive power and frequency have steadily increased over the past 100 years. There's hope that the historical sedimental record may offer evidence of how the storms develop, allowing an effective warning system to be devised.

fields.headline: Make mine a double
fields.trailText: ER | Modern Times | The Unforgettable... Richard Beckinsale
fields.body:
Like Man United, ER (Channel 4) keeps its fans hanging on till the bitter end. In this week's double dose, however, the writers had a cunning plan. There would be no last-minute twist: no air-sea rescue; no Bunsen-burner explosion; no siege; no Casablanca goodbye on a cold Chicago platform; no Doug. They played a few dummies: the Nashville choirbus in need of abdominal surgery; the psychotic knife man ("tell me where she is or I'll let you bleed to death") in order to make us believe something, anything might happen, but no.
