This was Carol's Big Birthing Day. Pottering round her flat to folky music, we knew that the imminent contractions would at least put pay to the Suzanne Vega.

The problem with giving birth on TV is that you need to beat the commercial break. The ER team sensed the urgency and performed a Caesarian. Consequently, Carol's twins were the first in history born either side of the watershed.

A tall, swarthy figure hovered at the door as #2 slopped out onto the mat. "My God, it's Doug!", 40 nations shouted at their TV (no, it's Mark). I've long imagined that Carol would end up with Mark, who's half-hourly being told by Carol to "take a raincheck"on his pathetic requests to "do coffee". Mark grabbed baby #2 before Carol had a chance to hold her, a proprietorial act totally in keeping with his creepiness.

Modern Times (BBC2) preview tapes arrive in shiny arthouse video boxes with lower case font. A cheeky little dog stares hard at you through the titles, and you're inclined to turn off after that. Luckily, Recipe For Success was considerably better than its box or title, following entrepreneur Mark Fuller as he prepared for the opening of his 1000-seat London gastrodome, Sugar Reef.

Cheap-looking, with cheap soundbites from a cheap man in an expensive suit, the film came on like a clever pastiche of by-the-yard television. "Image is everything in this game", Fuller puffed, never knowing whether he was talking at camera, a mobile phone, or his army of nodding-dog PAs.

Matthew Wright, "showbiz" editor of The Mirror, whose face is creased through years of permanent over-smiling at idiots, was granted an "exclusive interview". "Give us a breakdown of the customer profile", he suggested, disingenously. "Noel Gallagher sitting next to the Spice Girls, Andrew Lloyd Webber at the next table," Fuller answered nervously.

The film aimed to demonstrate the hysterical emptiness at the heart of the modern celebrity whirl, and was satisfyingly empty. Fran Cutler, who makes a living inviting her friends to openings, was stumped on how to describe the USP of Suger Reef to her er-herm '"friends": "It's Colonial Caribbean, a kinda Cajun kinda 'fing'". The architect - who carried two mobile phones - wasn't so sure. "Cuba, Florida, that vibe" he said, painting giant fluorescent flamingoes on the walls.

On the big night itself, the Cajun-Caribbean-Soho Lobster Pool wouldn't work. "It's a dog's breakfast", Fuller shouted at two flunkies in spray-on black dresses and head-sets. "Put yer hand in and swish it about, they're not going to bite." Doors opened and Joe from EastEnders, fresh from prison, was first through. Followed by Ricky from EastEnders, and Robbie_ from EastEnders.

The Unforgettable... Richard Beckinsale (ITV) arrived in a plain box, but the audio track had a strange hum over it, as if Beckinsale was making some editorial comment. "During his 10 years at the top, Richard was every girl's dream date, and every boy's best mate", the voice-over began dreamily, which at least rhymes.

The star of Porridge and Rising Damp might ostensibly appear to be an unusual subject for an ITV profile, but the voice-over was right: Beckinsale was Eric Morecambe in the body of David Essex. An underrated actor that deserved his 50 minutes (one break). Stephen Frears certainly had the hots for him: "'I'm an eighth Burmese', Richard would say, taking you to one side and showing you his cheekbones." Frears paused to sigh. "They were breathtaking."

The Unforgettable... was a strangely exotic piece of TV. This series has been criticised for lacking edge, but TV profiles derided as nostalgic actually look quite subversive in the new TV landscape. A Sugar Reef world of carrying two mobiles in which Beckinsale wouldn't even get an audition.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Indiscreet | Fat City | The Outlaw | Sibling Rivalry
fields.body:
Indiscreet

(Marc Bienstock, 1998)

8pm, Sky MovieMax

An almost unrecognisable Luke Perry, soap days long forgotten, stars in this slick but run-of-the-mill thriller. It's TV movie fodder, all moochy interiors and irritating dinner jazz music. Perry is good, actually, as Michael Nash, an ex-cop private investigator tailing the wife of a wealthy lawyer. Photographing the lissom beauty (Gloria Reuben) as she skinny dips in the Pacific, he's (strangely enough) soon drawn into a relationship with her, and (lo and behold) just as soon up to his eyes in plot twists.

Fat City

(John Huston, 1972)

10pm, FilmFour

In the little town of Stockton, California, veteran boxer Stacy Keach forms a fleeting friendship with up-and-coming Jeff Bridges. It's a world of boozy bar, sweaty gym, and bloody ring, starkly filmed by Conrad Hall, up to the final, pointless and savage bout. Tersely naturalistic, but infused with an air of nobility by Huston.

The Outlaw

(Howard Hughes, 1943)

1.50am, Sky Cinema

A deranged and wickedly sexy western that supposes a jealous rivalry between Pat Garrett, Billy the Kid and Doc Holliday. Jane Russell plays beautiful Rio, whose heroic cleavage throws the lads into disarray, and the censors into confusion: it was six years before the film was given a certificate. Jack Buetel, Walter Huston and Thomas Mitchell play the gunmen.

Sibling Rivalry

(Carl Reiner, 1990)

2.05am, Sky Premier

Bored wife Kirstie Alley beds handsome stranger Sam Elliott, and, before you can say "cheers", events are spiralling farcically out of control. He dies after their marathon lovemaking; enter salesman Bill Pullman, followed by his suspicious-cop brother Ed O'Neill, who falls for Alley's sexy sister, Jami Gertz. This sort of thing needs a more subtle touch: first job on Alley's wacky journey is to remove the corpse's condom. So much for safe sex.

fields.headline: The importance of being odd
fields.standfirst: If everything was right-handed, we might not be here, writes  Frank Close
fields.trailText: If everything was right-handed, we might not be here, writes Frank Close
fields.body:
Had it been possible to have placed bets at the dawn of time, what odds would have been offered against the emergence of life? Fifteen thousand million years later, here we are, complex systems of molecules that are self-aware.

Yet if the creation had been perfect, as modern science believes, and its symmetry had remained unblemished, nothing that we now know could ever have happened: there would have been no you to read this nor me to have written it. How such a "pock speckled universe" has emerged from an unspoiled perfection at the outset is one of the biggest unanswered questions in modern physics, but one that may soon be solved.

The world is an asymmetrical place full of asymmetrical beings. Life itself seems to thrive on a distinction between left and right. One in 10 of us is left handed, but otherwise we are superficially left-right symmetric apart from self selected cosmetic asymmetry, such as the parting of one's hair.

Such symmetry is only skin deep. In vertebrates, the heart and stomach are on the left, the liver and the appendix on the right, though one person in 10,000 has the heart in the wrong place, namely the right instead of the left. If the heart is on the "wrong" side, all the other organs tend to be also, which can give surgeons a nasty surprise.

Whatever determines the orientation for one organ, determines it for them all. The mirror inversion is absolute. Somehow the original microscopic spherical embryo becomes chiral, left-right asymmetric, the whole then choosing either the "standard" or the mirror version.

Many organic molecules have shapes that differ from their mirror images. While we cannot see molecules, we can smell them. The left and right handed forms of limone distinguish the smells of oranges and lemons. Life differentiates between mirror images. The milk in Alice's looking glass would not have been fit to drink; one form of a substance may be digested as food while its mirror form is passed through unprocessed or even poisons the host.

Amino acids and DNA in living things all go the same way, distinct from the mirror world: our amino acids are known as "left handed". Life as we know it does not make use of the right handed analogues of these molecules.

Did this preference arise through evolution - a chance small excess being magnified over aeons - or was it implanted even earlier? The discovery of left handed amino acids in meteorites suggests that left handedness was present in outer space maybe even before the earth was born. The discovery of polarised light in the Orion nebula, which may be what our environment was like 5 billion years ago, has led to the theory that the right handed forms were selectively destroyed by bombardment from polarised light at the dawn of the solar system.

Even given the existence of amino acids, their ability to build the complex proteins and DNA essential to life depend on very fundamental asymmetries without which the sun would not still be shining. It has taken 5,000 million years of sunlight for the chemical and biological processes of life to be energised here. Asymmetry has been essential to this.

That the sun has lasted this long is due to the fact that the arcane "W" particle has a mass greater than an atom of iron. This W beast is the quantum bundle of the "weak" force that helps power the sun. Had it been massless, like the photon that plays an analagous role for the electromagnetic forces, the sun would have burned out long ago (or may never have formed at all).

This is but one of many examples where mass, some particles having large amounts while other have small or even none, creates asymmetries that are critical to existence.

For example, most of the mass of an atom resides in its central nucleus while electrons flow from one atom to another; liberated as current they flow through wires and power modern industry; agitated by electric fields they radiate electromagnetic waves. These negatively charged electrons communicate and drive the biological processes while the heavier positives tend to stay at home and form the templates of solidity.

S cientists believe that mass is the seed of asymmetry, perhaps even of all asymmetries in the universal scheme of things. It is their differing masses that helps give many particles their distinct identities. The mathematical patterns that are emerging suggest to some theorists an explanation even for how matter defeated antimatter, thereby giving a chance for something rather than nothing in the universe.

So far, these are ideas andexperiment that will show if the universe is really like that. At Cern, the European nuclear research laboratory in Geneva, scientists are building the large hadron collider (LHC), a time machine that will try to recreate what the universe was like in its first moments, before mass had obscured its natural symmetry.

We can anticipate dramatic revelations from the LHC within less than 10 years. The tantalising prospect is dawning that we will be able to see, for the first time, the ultimate foundations of reality, because scientists believe that when the true symmetries of creation are known, the way nature spoiled these symmetries will also become clear.

These experiments may reveal a singular source of all asymmetry. And if they do, they will confirm the remarkable insight of Pasteur who in 1860 said: "The universe is asymmetrical. Life is dominated by asymmetrical actions. I can even imagine that all living species are primordially in their structure and in their external forms, a function of cosmic asymmetry."

 Lucifer's Legacy: The Meaning Of Asymmetry, by Frank Close, is published today (March 16) by Oxford University Press www.oup.com £16.99

webTitle: The trail of the virtual tomb raiders

fields.headline: The trail of the virtual tomb raiders
fields.standfirst: Today Indiana Jones would find a satellite more useful than a whip, writes  Claire Cockcroft
fields.trailText: Today Indiana Jones would find a satellite more useful than a whip, writes Claire Cockcroft
fields.body:
Under the relentless desert sun hundreds of Egyptian labourers are swinging picks and shovels in vast trenches while an archaeologist scrutinises their efforts, in the hope that all this labour will reveal some tiny shard of pottery from many millennia ago.

That's the archaeological stereotype we know. But today's archaeologists have adopted an approach that allows them to delve into the past and learn about ancient civilisations without turning a spadeful of soil. This old discipline is recruiting remote sensing, a technique used by companies looking for oil or by the military for locating submarines.

While many archaeological finds of the past required the painstaking pursuit of clues at ground level, others were stumbled upon by random digging.

But remote sensing provides a guiding eye for archaeologists, directing them to the most sensible spot to start while avoiding damage to valuable artefacts. It is particularly useful for uncovering information at sites where excavation is prohibited, for example in national parks or at ancient burial sites.

In this modern marriage of methods, archaeology teams up with soil science and geology and enlists equipment from medical research and even space exploration.

German archaeologists have recently discovered an immense metropolis under Qantir, a simple farming village nestling in the Nile delta, about 60 miles north east of Cairo. They think that this vast subterranean site, which extends for up to 12 square miles, could be the ancient capital of Egypt that was established more than 3,000 years ago by Ramses II, one of the most powerful pharaohs.

Ancient texts pointed to this region as the likely location of the lost city but excavations since the twenties, yielded little.

Edgar Pusch, leading the team of investigators from the Pelizaeus museum in Hildesheim, Germany, has been working with Egyptian and German geophysicists to map this intriguing zone. They use an ultra-sensitive, portable caesium magnetometer which measures changes in the physical properties of the soil, a little like taking a sophisticated X-ray through the earth. When the data are fed into a computer, a series of lines and shapes emerge which reveal meandering streets, buildings and even the shoreline of an ancient lake.

The archaeologists can then decide where to open up "excavation windows" in areas that seem particularly enticing. For example, one of the wonders of the city is a chariot factory and a colossal complex of stables, covering almost 17,000 square metres, which could hold up to 460 horses. There are holes in the floor of the sloping stable floor which they suggest allowed horse urine to be collected for fertilising crops and softening leather.

The main drawback of magnetic imaging is that it cannot pinpoint the depth at which the physical changes in the soil occur.

The team estimates that another 10 years will be required to complete the imaging of the city. Eventually Pusch hopes to make 3D computer images of it.

This is not the first time that hi-tech equipment has been used by archaeologists. Forensic anthropologist Prof Norm Sauer of Michigan State university has taken CAT scans of 3,000 year old Egyptian mummies. A technique called stereo lithogra phy is then used to duplicate the 3D images in epoxy resin. Clay is skilfully applied to the plastic skulls, gradually building up an image of the facial features.

Nasa has also been helping archaeologists with ground penetrating radar (GPR) devices to locate artefacts at historically significant sites in the USA. A series of radio waves are sent into the ground and the equipment records any discontinuities below the surface.

The depth at which these subtle changes occur can be extrapolated from the travel-time of the radar waves, which are measured in billionths of a second, and data-processing programmes generate 3D images of the site. Lawrence Conyers and Dean Goodman of Denver University, the original pioneers of non-invasive archaeology, used it to study sacred sites of the Anasazi people of the American West. They have also mapped ancient burial sites in Japan, a Mayan village in El Salvador buried under 15 feet of volcanic ash and located a large village buried in sand between two Peruvian pyramids.

Geophysicist Christian Pierce, from the department of archaeology in Cambridge, recognises that geophysics is very important in modern archaeology. "It is cheap and fast and therefore allows large areas to be systematically surveyed, areas of interest to be identified and subsequent excavations planned in detail.

"The basic advantage of 3D techniques over other standard techniques is that they enable the archaeologist to gain an insight into not only the spatial position of features, but also their stratigraphical (or depth) relationships.

"This is extremely important for archaeological research as it provides information on the relative ages of features, and also enables us to calculate their shape and volume which aids in their characterisation."

Because it can measure the depth at which artefacts or physical changes in the soil composition are found, GPR can be thought of as an ultrasound examination of the earth. The Cambridge team is using GPR to build up 3D images of interesting Neolithic sites in this country.

Remote sensing is paving the way towards a time when we can take part in "virtual tours" by computer or video of archaeological sites that have not even been excavated.

fields.trailText: Action stations in all areas
fields.body:
Action stations in all areas
In Bath, you can learn how to make a bas relief. You can also take part in classes in making automata, in preparation for the great robotics revolution. In Bristol, you can tune in to The Music of the Spheres - really a playlet about William and Caroline Herschel, astronomers and musicians. In High Wycombe, you can pack the kids off on a geological field trip round the Chilterns, and in Milton Keynes, you can start lobbying for less light, all the better to see the stars by. In Bidston, Cheshire, you can really get into the chicken-and-egg question by investigating hatching, incubators and other poultry entertainments. In London, Prof Nancy Rothwell will explain what goes in in human cells and Wakefield, the Caphouse Colliery will show off its coal-cutting machinery.

What strange thing is this?
There is only one explanation. It must be National Science Week. This exotic calendar event was announced, rather casually, several years ago by a Conservative science minister. British science bosses would much rather have had the money instead of the fete, but they got on with it. Rather to everybody's surprise, the notional science week went national and became a fixture: it starts tomorrow and ends on Sunday week and in between there will be more than 7,000 things people can do, see taste or cringe at, in all sorts of unexpected places. Like the Rhyming Slime Olympics at Barton on Humberside. Don't ask.

But if you really must know
Blame it all on the British Association for the Advancement of Science. Apply to its website www.britassoc.org.uk or ring Science Line 0808 800 4000 for up to date information on what's going on. Such as the Millennium Buggy in Enniskillen. Or a history of the flea circus at Tring. Or cloud drilling in Kidderminster. Or investigate dinosaur dinners in Glasgow. Or even...

fields.headline: The end is nigh - almost
fields.standfirst: We're all doomed, writes  Sanjida O'Connell, but not for a good few millennia
fields.trailText: We're all doomed, writes Sanjida O'Connell, but not for a good few millennia
fields.body:
Nostrodamus thought the world would end in the year 2000. We're still here, of course, but scientists now predict that the universe will terminate a hundred cosmological decades from now. The earth will become uninhabitable in a much shorter time - half a billion years, we will then be able to hitch a ride on every other planet in the galaxy as they become habitable before finally saying goodbye to life, the universe and everything.

The sun has been growing brighter by 1% every million years as hydrogen gas at its heart is converted into helium. This phenomenon was recognised in 1972 by Carl Sagan; what Dr James Kasting, from Penn State university, Pennsylvania, and Dr Ken Caldeira, at the Lawrence Livermore laboratory, California, have calculated is the drastic effect this will have on our climate.

In the short term, global carbon dioxide is rapidly increasing, mainly due to rapid deforestation and fossil fuel consumption. In a few hundred years this could result in six times more CO2 than is present now. Kasting optimistically says: "We won't do this - it's not acceptable."

In the long term, CO2 levels will drop naturally, although this will be of no comfort to us. As the ever brighter sun warms the planet much of this CO2 will dissolve in the oceans. Fossil fuels will run out, and in a million years, carbon dioxide levels will be restored to today's levels. In half a billion years, there will not be enough CO2 to support plant life, and unless we jump ship, we'll die. In one billion years, the sun will be 10% brighter - hot enough to evaporate the oceans.

The good news is that as the sun grows hotter, the area known as the habitable zone increases. This is the portion of space in which the earth orbits - not too hot nor too cold. As the habitable zone moves outwards, it will be possible to survive on each of the planets - even Pluto - one after another as they move into habitability before we have to move on again as they too become too hot and dry to sustain life.

According to Professor Lee Anne Willson, from Iowa State university, one thing is certain, the earth will go, the question is how? In a prescient poem, Robert Frost wrote: "Some say the world will end in fire, Some say in ice,/ From what I've tasted of desire, I hold with those who favour fire." Whether the earth ends in fire or ice depends how, when and how fast the sun sheds mass, says Willson.

If, as the sun burns up its own internal fuel source, it loses mass and collapses in on itself, the earth will end in ice. If mass loss occurs late on in the sun's life, it will expand outwards and earth will be "engulfed in the bloated sun".

The sun will become a red giant, and then an AGB - an asymptotic giant branch. Willson calculates that seven thousand million years into the future the sun is likely to enter into the AGB phase with a similar mass to now. If it were possible to sit on earth in a nicely air conditioned room and watch events (even though the outside temperature would be several thousand degrees Kelvin), we'd see the earth devoid of life, deserted by its oceans and with an atmosphere composed of vaporised rock.

In one direction the sky would be lit up a deep, vivid red by the dying sun; in the other it would be flushed with pink streaks - Mars and Jupiter hurtling past at supersonic speeds. And once a year that deep red would pulsate as the sun grew closer.

"It's a picture to keep you up at night," she says. Shortly after this, the moon will crash into us, the earth will then spiral into the sun.

"There is a way out!" claims Willson's ex-student, Dr Fred Adams, from the university of Michigan. A passing star could perturb the solar system and scatter the sun, the moon and the earth in separate directions. The earth wouldn't be consumed by flames, and although the oceans will freeze, life could continue in bacterial form around geothermal vents for 30 billion years. The odds of this happening are one in 100,000.

"It's not great odds," says Adams, "but it's better than winning the lottery."

However, most stellar evolution will continue after our demise. Stars will be born until the universe runs out of gas. This results in a sharp transition because even the longest lived stars can survive only 16 trillion years, therefore, once the universe has given birth to the last star, "The Stelliferous Era" must come to an end - in 100 trillion years at the very longest. There will still be stars left, but they will now be brown and white dwarfs (collapsed, defunct stars). This period Adams labels "the Degenerate Era" because, "these dwarfs are the ultimate stellar slackers, they'll sit around for trillions of years".

During this time, a star or two could yet be born. The brown dwarfs contain hydrogen and eventually a couple will collide and produce small stars. Given that the collision rate is bound to be somewhat low, Adams says: "In the far dark and distant future we'll have one to three stars shining one thousand times dimmer than the sun."

The Degenerate Era continues while the galaxies remain intact, but everything must die and they too will end when the dwarfs evaporate and are ejected into galactic space. So what's left? One per cent of the universe was devoted to black holes, and they, as the only things remaining, take on the role stars now play. They can live for a long time producing a small amount of energy and a minuscule bit of heat.

"The Black Hole Era" ends when the black holes evaporate. After that it's the aptly named "Dark Era" for now there is nothing left but atomic particles - positrons, electrons, neutrinos and the odd bit of cosmological radiation.

It's not all over, but there's not much happening. In one hundred thousand trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion, trillion years the end of the universe will be nigh.

 The Five Ages of the Universe by Fred Adams is published by Simon and Schuster, 1999 .

fields.headline: Poor suffer 'huge childcare gap'
fields.trailText: The government's drive to end child poverty is threatened by a "massive" shortage of subsidised childcare, according to a leading charity.
fields.body:
The government's drive to end child poverty is threatened by a "massive" shortage of subsidised childcare, according to a leading charity.

The Daycare Trust says in a report today that for parents in poor communities, access to quality childcare is as much a "pipe dream" as private education.

The report, published just days before the budget, is a blow to government claims to be pulling out all stops to abolish child poverty within 20 years. The charity says that a wide "childcare gap" exists for children under three.

Though government policy was expanding care for older children, the "vast majority" of the youngest were missing out.

There were 600,000 children under three living in poverty but only 42,740 free or subsidised places.

As a result, 13 in every 14 children from low income backgrounds were deprived of such help.

The trust director, Colette Kelleher, said: "In wealthier areas children have access to the whole range of services and in the poorer ones, where there are greater numbers of children, you have huge gaps in provision. Childcare is not a normal part of life for these children and their parents - it is a pipe dream."

The report calls for "centres for children" in every community to provide daycare, as well as training and job advice for parents.

The department for education said the government had asked early years development and childcare partnerships to look specifically at childcare for younger children in their 2000-2001 plans.

webTitle: Lib Dems back Blair in tax row

fields.headline: Lib Dems back Blair in tax row
fields.standfirst: Hague accuses PM of dishonest election pledges
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday won Liberal Democrat support for using buoyant tax revenues to fund higher public spending on health and education - in the face of William Hague's ferocious attack on Labour's "systematically and deliberately" broken tax pledges.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday won Liberal Democrat support for using buoyant tax revenues to fund higher public spending on health and education - in the face of William Hague's ferocious attack on Labour's "systematically and deliberately" broken tax pledges.

Amid renewed controversy over tax-and-spending in the week before Gordon Brown's fourth budget, the Conservative leader won some support from independent tax experts when he claimed that "stealth" taxes will have pushed Labour's total tax take up by 2.5% before the next election.

"Your government has increased taxes on mortgages and marriages, petrol and pensions, savers and the self-employed, large businesses and small businesses, air travel and insurance, homebuying and charities.

"The result is not only that taxes have gone up, but that they are continuing to rise," Mr Hague told Mr Blair.

During heated exchanges at question time he also told the prime minister he was dishonest to say "we have no plans to increase tax at all" before the last election - a pledge the prime minister says he honoured because he was referring to income tax rates.

But the Tory argument that lower taxes are a moral duty on politicians won short shrift from the cross-party coalition of MPs which sees redistributive taxes as a crucial component of a fair society, not least in the provision of good public services like schools and hospitals.

Mr Blair himself stuck to his guns. He countered by saying: "When we came into office we were paying more under Tory plans on interest payments on debt than we were spending on the whole of the schools system of the UK."

He won significant support from Charles Kennedy who warned against joining a Conservative-led "Dutch auction" on lower taxes and suggested a string of improvments to the NHS - including more cardiac operations - on which public money could be spent.

That may be a hint that the Liberal Democrat leader is about to transfer the famous 1p extra on income tax - Paddy Ashdown's formula to help public services - from 1p for education to 1p for health spending.

Behind the scenes senior Lib Dems have been embroiled in an internal row over such a switch.

Proponents of the change argue that the NHS is clearly perceived by voters to be in a needier state than schools, which have been quicker than hospitals to feel the effects of some extra investment. Opponents point to internal polling showing that the 1p on tax for education remains the Lib Dem's only memorable policy. Dropping the pledge will make the party look untrustworthy, they argue.

The Lib Dems will publish their "alternative budget" today. This week, Downing Street confirmed that taxes have risen since 1997 - partly to help pay off the £28bn borrowing requirement inherited from John Major - though they are currently dropping as a share of GDP before rising again in 2001-2.

Ministers say that the burden peaked at 37.4% in 1998-99, having been 35.3% in the last Tory year of office, and will be 37.2% in election year 2001-2.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, backed by many independent analysts, say the true figure by then will be 37.7% because they reject Mr Brown's insistence that the working families tax credit is not a spending item.

Downing Street says it has not changed its "prudent" fiscal strategy. But it has made it easier for Labour's pro-tax, pro-spending tendency and - Mr Kennedy admits - harder for the Lib Dems to exploit that gap in the centre-left market.

fields.headline: Mystery of student's role
fields.standfirst:
Postgraduate named as accuser denies any knowledge of allegations

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The postgraduate student whose name was used to make the parliamentary complaint about Ken Livingstone's income from after dinner speeches and journalism was last night holed up in his flat in the Leicestershire town of Shepshed denying any involvement in the affair.
fields.body:
The postgraduate student whose name was used to make the parliamentary complaint about Ken Livingstone's income from after dinner speeches and journalism was last night holed up in his flat in the Leicestershire town of Shepshed denying any involvement in the affair.

John "Chris" Jones insisted he had no idea why anyone might have used his name to write to Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, last December demanding an investigation into Mr Livingstone's declarations to the register of MPs' interests.

"Somebody must have used my name and address without my knowledge - I didn't write any letter and I have no connection with politics or with Ken Livingstone," he insisted, before barricading himself in his flat above the Shepshed post office where he has lived for the past three years.

His next door neighbour is Eileen Start, who chairs Shepshed Labour party, but she said she had never talked politics to Mr Jones "and he's never talked politics with me". Nor was he, she confirmed, a member of the Shepshed branch of the party.

Ms Filkin confirmed last night that Mr Jones had rung her clerk yesterday to say he had nothing to do with the complaint, signed in his name. "It's very strange; we're as bewildered as all of you," she said, adding that if Mr Jones's name had been used without his knowledge and there were evidence of manipulation, it would be in contempt of parliamentary procedure.

"There could be an innocent explanation for all this and it doesn't alter the findings, but I would be very concerned if someone has misused somebody's name."

The origin of the complaint appears to have been an article in the Evening Standard on December 1 last year, which quoted Shaun Woodward, then the Conservative spokesman on London, saying he planned to ask Ms Filkin to investigate why Mr Livingstone had not detailed the fees for his speaking engagements in the members' register.

But it was not until December 19, the day after Mr Woodward defected to the Labour party, that a letter of complaint was finally sent to Ms Filkin signed in the name of Mr Jones, referring to the Standard article. "It appears that no one has yet referred the matter to you," the complainant wrote.

Ms Filkin wrote back, saying she would investigate the complaint against the Brent East MP. Mr Jones, a Loughborough university student in his late 20s, said last night: "I did get a letter but I had no idea what it was about, so I just ignored it."

He was sent another letter on Tuesday, offering him the chance to inspect the report on Mr Livingstone an hour before publication. But he says he only called Ms Filkin's office yesterday after he was contacted by the press.

A statement from Mr Livingstone last night said he found it "difficult to believe" the timing of Mr Woodward's reported remarks was coincidental. Ann Keen, the Labour MP for Brentford and Isleworth, who played a key role in organising Mr Woodward's defection, is now working as Frank Dobson's lieutenant in the London mayoral race.

But both the Labour and Conservative parties said they knew nothing of Mr Jones and had not taken any steps to arrange the complaint.

A Labour spokesman said Mr Woodward had not followed through on his remarks and that the party would have hardly got involved in encouraging complaints about someone who might have ended up as Labour's official candidate. "We don't know who this guy is and we have nothing to do with the complaint," a spokeman said.

Mr Livingstone said of the John Jones mystery last night: "It's going to get dirtier than this - it's going to be unrelenting. But anything with Shaun Woodward's name attached to it will put people's election time bullshit barrier up."

Both Labour and Conservative parties were yesterday cock-a-hoop at Mr Livingstone's embarrassment, hoping that his portrayal as a "fat cat" politician might puncture his runaway lead in the mayoral election.

"This bloke knew this was coming and yet he's been putting ads in the papers this week asking old biddies for £5 postal orders for his campaign, while he's sitting on a quarter of a million pounds," Labour's spokesman said of the former Greater London council leader.

Mr Livingstone said that his income from journalism, his effort at advertising cheese and after dinner speaking had all been channelled through his company Localaction to pay for political research, the publication of his Socialist Economic Bulletin and his mayoral bid.

Apart from a £20,000 dividend he paid himself in 1996, he added, he lived exclusively on his parliamentary salary. The £158,599 earned for Localaction over 18 months, which was the subject of yesterday's rebuke from the Commons standards and privileges committee would go towards his independent mayoral bid after payment of 40% tax. "That won't even go a fifth of the way towards the £500,000 we need for this campaign," he said.

"This bloke knew this was coming and yet he's been putting ads in the papers this week asking old biddies for £5 postal orders for his campaign, while he's sitting on a quarter of a million pounds," Labour's spokesman said of the former Greater London council leader. Mr Livingstone said that his income from journalism, his effort at advertising cheese and after dinner speaking had all been channelled through his company Localaction to pay for political research, the publication of his Socialist Economic Bulletin and his mayoral bid. Apart from a £20,000 dividend he paid himself in 1996, he added, he lived exclusively on his parliamentary salary. The £158,599 earned for Localaction over 18 months, which was the subject of yesterday's rebuke from the Commons standards and privileges committee would go towards his independent mayoral bid after payment of 40% tax. "That won't even go a fifth of the way towards the £500,000 we need for this campaign," he said.

webTitle: Shock discovery that undermined retirement plans

fields.headline: Shock discovery that undermined retirement plans
fields.trailText: These are three typical case covered by the so called Serps (state earnings related pension scheme ) mis-selling scandal:
fields.body:
These are three typical case covered by the so called Serps (state earnings related pension scheme ) mis-selling scandal:

Case A

Mr A is 66. He paid into Serps from 1978 to 1997. He receives about £100 a week.

In 1998 he telephoned the benefits agency in Newcastle to check the position for his wife if she were to be widowed.

He was told that she would inherit all his Serps. On the basis of this he bought an annuity that only provided a 50% pension for his wife on his death.

After reading about the changes in the press he has decided to continue to work, as he is concerned about his wife's future financial position.

Case B

Mr C joined Serps in 1978 and contributed until his retirement in 1989. Believing his wife would inherit the full Serps, he felt confident that he was paying enough to ensure she would have a reasonable income if widowed.

He checked the position in 1992 and has a letter from the benefits agency confirming that his wife would inherit 100% of his Serps if she were to be widowed.

He learnt about the planned change to Serps in 1999. He points out that, even if he had been informed of the change in 1986, there was insufficient time for him to make alternative arrangements that would compensate for the changes.

Case C

Mr K worked in the financial industry, and his experience and knowledge of pensions led him to believe that being contracted into Serps was the best option for him and his wife.

On retirement he took the maximum lump sum, which reduced the amount of his pension and any widow's pension, but he did so in the knowledge that his wife would be able to inherit 100% of his Serps.

He is now concerned that his wife might have to rely on benefits if she gets a reduced Serps.

fields.headline: Livingstone caught in £158,000 earnings row
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's campaign to become mayor of London was last night dealt a severe blow after a committee of MPs found him guilty of failing to declare £158,599 of income from regular commitments - speech-making and newspaper articles - paid to his company. He will have to apologise to the Commons in the next few days.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's campaign to become mayor of London was last night dealt a severe blow after a committee of MPs found him guilty of failing to declare £158,599 of income from regular commitments - speech-making and newspaper articles - paid to his company. He will have to apologise to the Commons in the next few days.

Last night he also admitted he had twice failed to pay his taxes on time. Two county court judgments against his company ordered him to pay a total of nearly £13,500 - including £6,909 in 1996 and £4,514 in 1997. The company is also breaking the law by failing to declare its accounts on time - it is a year behind in making a declaration to Companies House.

Mr Livingstone said last night: "I believe that the demands were from the Inland Revenue. I am afraid one of the last things I do is pay my taxes and sort out my accounts."

The potentially damning disclosures were muddied last night by a mystery surrounding the man who lodged a complaint against Mr Livingstone with Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner. Ms Filkin received a typed and signed letter from John Jones, of Shepshed, Leicestershire, who last night insisted to the Guardian that he knew nothing about the complaint and had never written to the commissioner.

This immediately prompted speculation in the Livingstone camp that Mr Jones had been "set up" by someone to expose the popular MP who is front-runner for London's top job. However, the identity of the complainant made no difference to the findings by the committee and the comissioner that Mr Livingstone failed to disclose his substantial income.

Alan Williams, the Labour deputy chairman of the privileges committee, said last night: "I told my colleagues that when they came to their judgment on this case they should erase from their minds that they were dealing with Ken - they should think they were deciding about Joe Bloggs MP. The crucial point was 'wouldn't you think it registerable if you moved from making a few hundred pounds from the odd one-off speech to earning tens of thousands of pounds from contracts to make speeches?'"

MPs were heavily influenced by the fact that four years ago, when Mr Livingstone was making occasional speeches, Sir Gordon Downey, the former commissioner, advised he would have to declare them once they became regular events.

Accounts released to MPs by Mr Livingstone showed that between June 1998 and February 2000 he had made nearly £24,000 from the Independent, nearly £33,000 from the Evening Standard, £35,000 from Speakers for Business for 10 speeches and £11,000 from Prime Performers for four speeches.

MPs also felt strongly that Mr Livingstone was playing politics with the reply. He says he received the complaint on January 8 but did not reply until February 10 - when the ballot for Labour's candidate for mayor was due to close. Mr Livingstone says it took him four weeks to get all the accounts together.

Last night MPs in the Commons were astounded at the large sums Mr Livingstone was earning from articles and speech-making. Labour leftwingers joined Tories in accusing the MP of "cynically and systematically" misleading Parliament by not declaring the income for two years.

Brian Sedgemore, Labour MP for Hackney South, said yesterday: "It's one thing for Livingstone to lie to all party members about his intentions to stand for mayor but quite another for him to ask for grannies and granddads to send him £5 postal orders out of their hard-earned savings while at the same time he's got a secret stash of money on which he avoids paying income tax.

"While I make speeches for nothing on behalf of my constituents, Ken is away clocking up £70 a minute talking to various establishment groups for his own benefit. I wonder if he is fit to be mayor of toytown." Mr Livingstone said last night: "There is no suggestion of any impropriety or concealment on my part. My speaking engagements and newspaper columns are very much in the public domain and my company accounts are on public record." He said nearly all the money was spent employing researchers and subsidising socialist economic newsletters.

He also claimed that Shaun Woodward, the Tory defector MP who joined Labour, had prompted the complaint. But although Mr Woodward claimed he would complain to Ms Filkin about his income, he never did.

Undeclared income

January 31 2000 entry:

Remunerated directorships: Localaction Ltd ( formed to cover publication of Socialist Economic Bulletin and other writing and media work)

Sponsorship, or financial or material support: Temporary research, administrative and legal assistance from Campaign for Protection of Hunted Animals, linked to private member's bill

Overseas visits: January 1999 to Paris, with partner, to speak at student seminar. Trip paid for by European Study Tours of London

Registrable shareholdings: Localaction Ltd

Yesterday's additions:

Remunerated employment, office, profession, etc:

 Column in the Independent (£15,001-£20,000)

 Restaurant column in Evening Standard

 Book contract with Victor Gollancz

 Article for the Observer

 Regular speaking engagements for: Speakers for Business (£30,001-£35,000); Prime Performers (£1,001-£5,000); Interphiz (£5,001-£10,000); Norman Phillips (£1,001-£5,000); Right Address (£1,001-£5,000); JLA (£10,001-£15,000); CSA (£5,001- £10,000); Diane Boulter (£10,001-£15,000)

Speaking engagements for Localaction Ltd

fields.headline: Yesterday day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Anthony Steen, Conservative MP for Totnes, has achieved something of a parliamentary first. He has been asked if his book on political campaigning can be translated into Bulgarian. The country's Political Academy for Central and Eastern Europe has requested permission in the run-up to next year's elections.

Fight of the day

William Hague has claimed his second judo victim, it emerged yesterday. The Tory leader was in a bout with businessman Nicholas Gleave at the Budokwai gym in South Kensington when his opponent was forced to retire with damaged ribs. Mr Gleave was reportedly a stand-in for Hague's regular sparring partner Sebastian Coe who was injured earlier this year.

Bad day

Piped music. Tory MP Robert Key launched a campaign to ban it in public places like doctors' surgeries, swimming pools and bus and railway stations. Mr Key, who has sung with many choirs, complained that piped music or muzak was a "pollution from which there is no escape".

Line of the day

William Hague, in his weekly stand-up routine at prime minister's questions, goaded Tony Blair and called him less honest than his spokesman. "Less honest than Alastair Campbell is not something any of us would want on our tombstone," he said.

Today

Commons: Trade and Industry questions. Debates on the government's handling of the Mozambique crisis, Rover and service for mentally ill people. Lords: Financial services and markets bill, committee. Debate on impact of government policies on prospects for lone parents.

webTitle: Pensions blunder will cost £8bn to rectify lack of warning on Serps cut

fields.headline: Pensions blunder will cost £8bn to rectify lack of warning on Serps cut
fields.standfirst: Watchdog condemns 'extraordinary lapse' by officials as minister announces compensation deal and deferral of changes due next month
fields.trailText: The treasury is facing a bill of more than £8bn to rectify a "gargantuan" blunder affecting the pension rights of thousands of widows and widowers, the government disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The treasury is facing a bill of more than £8bn to rectify a "gargantuan" blunder affecting the pension rights of thousands of widows and widowers, the government disclosed yesterday.

As a national audit office report condemned an "extraordinary lapse" by civil servants, the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, announced compensation for people who had been misled over changes to the state second pension, together with a 2 year deferral of changes due to start next month. The package was immediately condemned by Help the Aged as "an appalling deal".

The government is seeking to pick up the pieces after a pensions cut introduced under the Conservatives in 1986 was left unpublicised for 10 years by the department of social security, which missed numerous opportunities to put the problem right.

The change would have halved the entitlement of a widow or widower to their spouse's state pension, bringing the system into line with occupational schemes. A 14-year "lead-in time" was intended to allow wide publicity of the measure and give those approaching pension age time to consider their own and their spouse's future pension arrangements.

A damning investigation by the audit office had uncovered a series of mistakes by the department, from a failure to inform the public of the change to its dismissal of warning signs about lack of information, and sluggish reaction once it was finally made aware of the problem. David Davis MP, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said the report revealed "an adminstrative blunder of gargantuan proportions".

In a separate report into the error, the parliamentary ombudsman, Michael Buckley, condemned the department for "maladministration" and delay in putting it right.

The cost of deferring the pensions change will be £2.5bn, with an estimated further £5.7bn to be paid out even assuming fewer than a third of pensioners make the case they were wrongly advised.

In a statement to MPs, Mr Darling acknowledged that "a number of people" were misled by benefits staff about the reduction in the state earnings related pension scheme, or Serps. Blaming the so-called "Serps mis-selling scandal" at the door of the Tories, he told MPs: "The last Conservative government has to take responsibility for the mess they created and I will take respon sibility for clearing it up."

Halving of the widow or widower's entitlement is now to be delayed until October 2002, and a consultation will be launched on a "protected rights scheme" for those pensioners misinformed about their Serps entitlement.

However, the Conservative social security spokesman, David Willetts, claimed Mr Darling had "ducked" the issue of whether people wrongly advised in a phone call would be covered, since no record of telephone coversations were kept by the department.

The government said the scheme would be worked out with the audit office and would be put to MPs, and Mr Darling told MPs that where there was no evidence it would be for the department to "challenge or disprove" the claim.

Steve Webb, Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, said Mr Darling's response was "wholly inadequate" because most pensioners assumed that, if their rights were being slashed, someone would tell them.

A Help the Aged spokesman, Mervyn Kohler, said : "This is an appalling deal. It seems that only those who have written to the DSS and received inadequate information will have grounds to complain."

A department helpline, 0845 600 6116, opens today at 7am to deal with inquiries.

Whitehall's timetable of inertia

 1986 Norman Fowler, then Tory social security secretary, legislates to halve level of the state earnings related pensions scheme widows and widowers can inherit when their spouse dies. Introduction of changes delayed until April 2000 to allow publicity.

 1987-98 Under John Moore, Tony Newton and then Peter Lilley, Sir Norman's successors at the DSS, the department fails to publicise the change and gives misleading information to public. Details are not incorporated into a 1987 leaflet, nor in updating of leaflets until 1995. Many benefits agency staff are not aware of the change until 1999.The problem was raised in parliament in 1995, in correspondence from concerned members of the public and by Age Concern in 1998.

 1999 Now aware of the problem, the DSS takes 10 weeks to issue bulletin to staff on the correct position on inherited Serps. Staff continue to give incorrect information to some people until April 1999. No effort made to contact the 3,500 people who had contacted the benefits agency, despite the government having taken powers in November to ensure changes to the Serps arrangements would not come into effect. Contradictory information given out in December in letters from the department and briefings to staff.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Bush story | ONdigital | NetVista
fields.byline: Ashley Norris, Jack Schofield  and  Neil McIntosh
fields.body:
Bush story
British consumer electronics stalwart Bush Audio has once again surprised observers by announcing a series of innovative products. Hot on the heels of the internet TV range it unveiled last week, comes the first ever digital terrestrial PC TV card that enables users to tune into all 11 free digital terrestrial channels.

The PCC3, which goes on sale in July priced at £150, also boasts a digital VCR option that stores up to an hour's worth of programming. The card can be upgraded to access Digital Text, and the company is hoping to offer a conditional access module that will allow PC owners to watch ONdigital's pay TV stations.

Bush also introduced what it is billing as the first truly mass-market convergence product. The Ultimate MM hooks up to a TV to enable users to store video programmes on its hard disk, play DVDs and CDs, record CDs, play and record MP3 and WMA files, surf the Net, send emails and run standard PC programs. The company hopes to have the product in the stores in the autumn, selling for around £1,200.

Bush has also given more details of its internet TV range. The company is offering two ways of getting TV users on to the net. The first is a £100 standalone box that can bring the internet to any standard TV. Bush is also offering three sets, a 14inch, 21inch and 28inch that have the internet facilities already built in. Internet functions can be controlled using either a traditional TV handset or the set's accompanying QWERTY keyboard.

ONdigital
ONdigital has become the latest company to take Tony Blair's words about bringing the internet to the masses to heart. In two weeks time it is set to launch its TV-based email system ONmail. For a one-off payment of £30, subscribers will be able to send and receive emails and use up to five different addresses.

As the system uses transparent graphics, users can also compose and send emails while watching TV programmes. The company is also promising its subscribers full internet access via the TV by the end of the year. Apparently, unlike Sky Digital's Open system, viewers will be able to watch a TV programme and surf the net at the same time. (AN)

NetVista
What is "the most dramatic and significant roll out of desktop technology since [the] first PC almost 20 years ago"? According to IBM, it's the new NetVista family of internet-ready PCs with flat-panel screens, designed for e-business use. In fact, IBM is following Toshiba, Gateway and others in the move to "legacy-free" PC designs, which are made more reliable by leaving out the ISA expansion bus and connection ports that IBM introduced in 1981 and 1983. The systems will run Microsoft Windows 2000 Professional, or Windows Millennium when that becomes available.

The range includes the small All-in-One with "a unique neck design" that provides space for the keyboard to fit under the 15in LCD monitor. This machine has a record seven USB ports for attaching peripherals, built-in Ethernet, and optional wireless networking. The NetVista Legacy-free (sic) version is a slimine tower system with five USB ports and two internal PCI expansion slots. Another version, the NetVista Internet Appliance, will be offered only via IBM partners, such as broadband service providers, internet service providers, application service providers, and big customers in data-intensive industries such as finance and healthcare. There will also be a NetVista Zero Footprint Thin Client version, which is designed to run as a terminal and which "minimises the amount of desktop real estate needed".

This will be aimed at banks, airlines and companies with similar applications. IBM's PC division has struggled to achieve profitability and has steadily lost market share over the past 15 years, with the matt black ThinkPad line of notebook PCs being one of its rare successes. However, it plans to invest more than $100m in marketing and advertising the NetVista line. See www.ibm.com/pc/europe/netvista (JS)

Robot rivals
Three of Japan's leading toy makers are getting together to bring robot football excitement to your living room. Bandai, Tomy and Takara announced this week that they are to collaborate to create dedicated football playing soccer machines. The small robots will be controlled by infrared remotes, with games being played on pitches the same size as a table tennis table. Robots will cost around £75. They will be developed in collaboration with the RoboCup Federation - the body which organises the Robot World Cup, whose aim is to create a robot team able to beat the winners of the real World Cup by 2050. (NM)

In two weeks time it is set to launch its TV-based email system ONmail. For a one-off payment of £30, subscribers will be able to send and receive emails and use up to five different addresses. As the system uses transparent graphics, users can also compose and send emails while watching TV programmes. The company is also promising its subscribers full internet access via the TV by the end of the year. Apparently, unlike Sky Digital's Open system, viewers will be able to watch a TV programme and surf the net at the same time. (AN) NetVista What is "the most dramatic and significant roll out of desktop technology since [the] first PC almost 20 years ago"? According to IBM, it's the new NetVista family of internet-ready PCs with flat-panel screens, designed for e-business use. In fact, IBM is following Toshiba, Gateway and others in the move to "legacy-free" PC designs, which are made more reliable by leaving out the ISA expansion bus and connection ports that IBM introduced in 1981 and 1983. The systems will run Microsoft Windows 2000 Professional, or Windows Millennium when that becomes available. The range includes the small All-in-One with "a unique neck design" that provides space for the keyboard to fit under the 15in LCD monitor. This machine has a record seven USB ports for attaching peripherals, built-in Ethernet, and optional wireless networking. The NetVista Legacy-free (sic) version is a slimine tower system with five USB ports and two internal PCI expansion slots. Another version, the NetVista Internet Appliance, will be offered only via IBM partners, such as broadband service providers, internet service providers, application service providers, and big customers in data-intensive industries such as finance and healthcare. There will also be a NetVista Zero Footprint Thin Client version, which is designed to run as a terminal and which "minimises the amount of desktop real estate needed". This will be aimed at banks, airlines and companies with similar applications. IBM's PC division has struggled to achieve profitability and has steadily lost market share over the past 15 years, with the matt black ThinkPad line of notebook PCs being one of its rare successes. However, it plans to invest more than $100m in marketing and advertising the NetVista line. See www.ibm.com/pc/europe/netvista (JS) Robot rivals Three of Japan's leading toy makers are getting together to bring robot football excitement to your living room. Bandai, Tomy and Takara announced this week that they are to collaborate to create dedicated football playing soccer machines. The small robots will be controlled by infrared remotes, with games being played on pitches the same size as a table tennis table. Robots will cost around £75. They will be developed in collaboration with the RoboCup Federation - the body which organises the Robot World Cup, whose aim is to create a robot team able to beat the winners of the real World Cup by 2050. fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Poor service

Hurrah...Blair's digital Britain is here, and everyone's favorite communications company, BT, is spearheading this advance into a cheaper realm of the web.

Errr, well if you don't include the constant busy lines to the free (0800 number) evening and weekend service, then when you do get through, the most sketchy line in internet history (constant disconnection and timeouts).

When I use the standard (0845 number) paying service, my authentication fails constantly although I have been a BT internet customer for three years.

So what can you do? Get charged 50p a minute for some school leaver telling you to download the latest software (not applicable for the Mac), and then to be told that you don't know anything about computers! Big company, big mess.

Mark Parsons

mikeparsonslc@hotmail.com

Wrong lines
If BT is determined to convince us all that it is internet friendly with the advent of Surf-time, will it stop fobbing off users who complain about DACS (which split a single line into two, effectively limiting the data transfer rate to 28.8Kbps) with the excuse that they only guarantee fax-quality lines (ie a maximum transfer rate of 14.4Kbps)?

It generally takes a lot of prodding from a customer before BT will remove them and install a full line.

Ian Warren

warrenl@gknwae.co.uk

Text trap
It is indeed a seductive notion to think that the educational experience can be created by hyperlinking ideas. In fact, the reverse is the case. As an educator, my interest is slightly less in teaching my students facts, rather more in teaching them the structures and relations between areas of knowledge and most of all in helping them develop the ability to form their own structures - which may be very different from mine.

Hypertext in whatever form crystallises the structure of knowledge and presents it (subtly) in as rigid and didactic a way as the periodic table shows atomic masses. It may make the acquisition of factual knowledge easier or more pleasant, but it makes the development of an inquiring and synthesising mind very much more difficult.

Ian Johnston

Staff tutor in technology, The Open University (in a personal capacity)

Cookie hell
Why do I have to suffer the continuing nuisance of cookies every time I use the net? More and more sites seem to be using them and most will not take no for an answer, but continue to flash up. Even if, in desperation, you return "yes" more often than not they return when you go to a new page, and will almost certainly re-appear when you revisit the site. I find that I often have to leave the net to avoid the irritation, both to myself, and anybody else in the room. Is there any solution?
William D Perry
info@rostra.co.uk

Whose mail?
Can anyone tell me what browsers are used by Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks in You've Got Mail? Neither Netscape Communicator nor Internet Explorer have the software and so far I haven't found a site that provides it.

GL Samson
gerald.samson@dtn.ntl.com

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Army Men: Air Attack | Dragon Warrior Monsters | International Track and Field 2
fields.byline: Jack Schofield,  Greg Howson and  Andy Bodle
fields.body:
Return of the tiny terrors

Army Men: Air Attack Sony PlayStation £29.99 3DO ***

The third game in the Army Men series lets you take to the air in one of four choppers, lay waste the Tan army, and blast any bugs that may stand - or fly - in your way.

The basic idea hasn't changed: this is war between plastic men of the sort seen in the Toy Story movies. The graphics haven't improved much either, being pretty basic in the Sony PlayStation version. However, it's fun to play, and if you liked EA's old Desert Strike series, you'll enjoy Air Attack as well.

The single-player mode has 16 missions, where you earn increasingly powerful helicopters, and destroy ever greater numbers of enemies. Although the first half dozen levels are easy, the later ones can get tricky. This is just as well, because the single-player game doesn't really have much replay value, and a keen gamer should be able to finish it in a week. Fortunately there are also two two-player modes. You can either co-operate and finish missions even quicker (a good parent-and-child game?), or play against one another in CTF (capture the flag) combat. The reduced field of view in the split-screen mode makes this less than entirely satisfactory, but at least it gives the game a bit more lastability.

Gameplay is much the same as millions of other games from Quake on down - keep moving, keep shooting - but using the helicopter to lug heavy things around provides a bit of variety. Because Air Attack is easy to learn and easy to play, it may appeal more to a younger market - under 12s, perhaps. The tongue-in-cheek humour would also amuse a wider audience, but not for long enough to make this a real winner. Get your mate to buy it. (JS)

Importance of good breeding
Dragon Warrior Monsters Nintendo Game Boy £24.99 Eidos Interactive ***
It had to happen. Pokémon may be an omnipresent force in the children's toy market, with plentiful supplies of trading cards and plastic Pickachus, but one fact needs to be made clear: Pokémon on the Game Boy is a simply fantastic game, mixing scarily addictive collect 'n' trade gameplay with above-average role playing game elements.

That it has taken so long for the copyists to arrive is surprising with Dragon Warrior Monsters the first of the chasing pack to reach these shores. And surprisingly good it is too, despite the derivative deformed characters and top down action.

That's because DWM packs some tighter plot into its Pokemon-esque nurturing antics. Terry, the unassumingly named hero, must rescue his kidnapped sister by becoming the head monster master. Achieving this goal involves more than simply gathering the beasties. Instead Terry gets to play monster procreation and indulge in some serious breeding.

By simply mating any male and female from the 215 species Terry can create one out of a possible 46,000 creatures. The offspring even inherit their parents' unique abilities - handy, as once they've done their work the parents disappear, leaving Terry to bring them up. And, while the monster breeding is key, the plot, unlike Pokemon's open-ended yarn, at least offers an end focus to the game.

You can, of course, battle on and link up with a human opponent with the winner keeping the defeated creature. Dungeons and monsters are encountered on an annoyingly random basis but if you can tolerate this you'll enjoy an engrossingly spiced up Pokémon-alike. (GH)

International Track and Field 2 Sony PlayStation £29.99 Konami *****

Once upon a time, the arcade athletics game was the duel of choice for idling adolescents. Invariably featuring a blob that was supposed to be Daley Thompson, it was the ultimate test of strength, skill and all-round machismo. Among those of us too weedy to play real sports, at least.

A cursory look at International Track and Field 2 suggests that little has changed. Sure, the competi tors are a little less bloblike now, but the old maxim still applies: whoever has the fastest fingers wins.

However, it soon emerges that not all the events here are designed specifically to break the joypad. There's now a much better balance between button-bashing, timing and coordination. This is thanks to the inclusion of six new events: weightlifting, springboard, horse vault, two cycling races, and canoeing.

Most of these have been ingeniously converted, and each requires its own distinct technique. Unfortunately, the new rounds come in at the expense of five classics - the 110m hurdles in particular is a grievous omission. Surely there's room enough on a PlayStation CD for more than 12 events?

The 3D graphics are smooth and perfectly adequate, although the age-old complaint of lack of atmosphere still pertains: the faceless crowd seems to have only two reactions (disinterested hubbub and hysterical applause), commentary is virtually non-existent, and there are no neat little touches to pique the interest of those not currently competing when you try this out on a boozy Friday night. (AB)

fields.headline: Public server
fields.standfirst: Diane Abbott was the first black woman elected to the British parliament and is MP for Hackney North and Stoke Newington
fields.trailText: Diane Abbott was the first black woman elected to the British parliament and is MP for Hackney North and Stoke Newington
fields.body:
Have you been using the net long? About three years. I'm not very technological, I can't type and I'd never used a computer before. So I got a Compaq Presario which is great because it does everything except make me breakfast! I'm a complete news junkie and, on a Sunday, that means that my house is no longer full of Sunday papers as I get it all off the net.

Are you happy with the way the net regulates itself? My son has just begun using the net so I am going to get one of those net watchers, but I think that's for families and individuals to decide. I don't think it's a government decision.

Any favourite websites? I use the Parliamentary Publications Database ) a lot because it has Hansard on it. One I use most is the Press Association website because they do a very useful summary of all the day's newspapers. I like the Electronic Telegraph site. It has very good links and the editorials are on a separate site so you don't have to look at them. I like the fact that The Times has every word printed in its newspaper on its website. And of course The Guardian. I also look at the New York Times, The Washington Post ) and The Jamaica Gleaner every day.

Do you ever use newsgroups or Usenet? I don't go to newgroups and I've never used a chat-room. One thing you're never short of as an MP is someone to talk to. I also think that anyone whose only means of conversing with the rest of the universe is through a chat-room is a deeply sad person!

Are you sick of hearing the phrase e-commerce? I am a little tired of hearing about all these e-commerce millionaires - that's such a South Sea bubble. I do think e-commerce is the way of the future. With people working more unconventional hours, the idea of using the net to shop has to be very attractive. I've just started using Tesco's website and I do use the net to buy books and CDs.

Is it the utopian place that many would like it to be? In some ways yes - in that it's basically free. However, there is an enormous pressure when you're on the internet to buy. So there are these two conflicting messages - one is very egalitarian and the other very capitalistic.

Where do you see the net going in the future? I think to my son's generation the internet will be as basic a utility in your house as electricity. I'm from the generation that made an absolute virtue of the fact that we couldn't use or own photo-copiers or typewriters so the fact that I got into the internet is quite significant. What attracted me most was the thought that in 10 years' time I could spend six months of the year in Jamaica writing articles and running my affairs all from my computer.

fields.headline: Going through the wringer
fields.standfirst: The Ericsson R250 mobile sells itself as a real hard case.  Ashley Norris calls its bluff
fields.trailText: The Ericsson R250 mobile sells itself as a real hard case. Ashley Norris calls its bluff
fields.body:
Mobile phones die in all kinds of horrible accidents. Some are smashed when they fall from speeding cars, others are buried alive by family pets, while the really unlucky ones land in the watery grave that is the family toilet.

So one company has come up with the novel idea of making a phone that's really tough. The Ericsson R250 PRO is so hard you feel you really ought to call it "sir".

This Schwarzenegger of cellular phones is not only big, bulky and orange but, say the makers, water, shock and dust resistant. Its first recipients are likely to be builders, though Ericsson reckons it will also appeal to outdoor sports fans and anyone who wants a macho-looking mobile.

We thought the ultimate test would be two weeks on the piste in Switzerland. There we'd push it to the limit, gauging how it dealt with freezing temperatures, soggy snow, and worst of all being submerged in a horribly sticky cheese fondue.

As the Online budget couldn't quite stretch that far we took the R250 to the next hardest place we knew - the streets of Hackney - to see if it really is indestructible.

Test one: The water torture

Ericsson claims "the phone is splashproof".

The test: five minutes use in the shower.

You are in the shower when the phone rings. Should you risk an all-too-common bathroom accident to answer it? It's not a dilemma with the Ericsson R250. You can hang it next to your body shampoo. The Goretex membrane finish and rubber gaskets were more than a match for running water.

Test two: The premature burial

Ericsson claims "the phone is dust and soil resistant".
The test: to be buried alive.

If you hear a faint bleeping coming from the direction of your geraniums it's probably because your dog has buried your phone in the garden. Most mobiles that suffer this get so choked with soil and dust that they stop working. We smeared the R250 with cream cheese and let greyhound Harry the Hoofer loose with it in a back garden.

Ten minutes later we rang the phone and heard a vague spluttering near the apple tree. We pulled the phone out, and after a quick rinse under the outside tap, it appeared largely unscathed.

Test three: He shoots, he scores

Ericsson claims it "is shock resistant".
The test: three minutes of being kicked around by local footy fans.

The R250's metal magnesium frame and rubber inlays are said to protect its electronics from the odd knock or two. So we persuaded our local under sevens footy team to temporarily swap it for their ball. A few Ginola-esque dribbles and Beckham-style free kicks later and the phone was starting to look as if it has been in a tussle or two.

Plastic had been chipped from the sides, and the once-pristine orange finish now looked a little grimy. But at the end of the game, our nine year old star striker still managed to use the phone to call his agent!

Test four: The ultimate baptism

Ericsson claims "the phone is splashproof".
The test: leave it bobbing about in the toilet for 10 minutes.

A splash-proof phone is one thing. Would the R250 cope with total immersion of the most sordid variety? Our men in white coats took the phone to the bath room where it was dropped down the toilet.

Several flushes later it was retrieved and taken to the lab for decontamination and analysis. The boffin who drew the short straw gingerly moved the phone towards his face and reported it was still functioning.

Test five: It's a long way down

Ericsson claims "the phone will survive being dropped from a ladder on to a hard surface".

The test: a series of drops on to concrete.

Finally, came the biggest test. Would the R250 survive being dropped two metres from a stepladder? Surprisingly, it came through relatively unscathed.

There was more chipping of the plastic, but it still worked well. When it survived a three metres drop, it was taken to the top of the house and tossed skywards out of the loft window on to concrete.

Incredibly, the outer casing was still intact. However, the glass inside of the phone had smashed and a runny liquid was creating wild psychedelic patters on the screen. There was no way you could see if you were connected to a network, let alone which number you were ringing, so our boffins pronounced it dead and ordered the wreath.

But in a last show of defiance, it still managed to ring when we called the number.

The conclusion

Thanks to our scientific test we have categorically proved that the Ericsson R250 is the toughest phone on the market. So come on Nokia and Motorola - if you think you're hard enough.

The R250 PRO is a dual band phone available on BT Cellnet and Vodafone networks, priced £200.

webTitle: Company puts itself in the frame to make money out of art

fields.headline: Company puts itself in the frame to make money out of art
fields.trailText: Starting up
fields.body:
Starting up
Easyart.com, which launched yesterday, is an unusual internet start-up. Claimed to be Britain's first online framing business, it actually employs people to manufacture - or at least assemble - the products it sells. Most other net start-ups merely sell other companies' products in a different way.

Founded by Simon Matthews, the company enables customers to choose a work of art or photograph from 10,000 currently available online, then choose a frame, its colour, and even check it against the colour of their own walls at home.

The pictures are then framed in a factory near Heathfield in Sussex, where seven people are on hand capable of framing and dispatching up to 150 pictures a day. Up to four more local craftspeople can be drafted in if demand exceeds expectations.

Customers can also get information about art exhibitions and read critical reviews.

Matthews says online art buying is a natural development because it combines three different activities: searching for a painting, finding a framer and then getting someone to deliver. Customers can change their minds about colours and frames without upsetting nervous assistants who are trying to satisfy several people at once.

Easyart is also unusual in that Matthews and his colleagues have all been in the art business before, so they are not coming to it without experience. He still runs the London Air Gallery which he founded. He fondly recalls having had to hang 200 pictures in a day.

So far, Easyart has spent £500,000 provided by Brainspark, the incubating firm (which is about to go public), in the form of equity and loans. Brainspark took a 25% stake in the company in return for financing it, providing it with offices, legal advice and backup.

"They were very important. I can't underestimate their contribution" , says Matthews. He is now looking for a further round of funding of up to £5m, half of which will be spent on marketing and half on selling pictures in two other ways - through screens in stores and by interactive television.

Matthews reckons that the framed decorative art market is worth £900m a year split 3:1 between consumers and business buyers. He and his directors have plans to expand into Europe and into the United States where he feels there is considerable potential despite the fact that online framers are already in business there.
