But she had managed to get out of that and was trying to launch herself as a singer. Her first single was a bouncy Eurodisco number wittily entitled Airbag Generation. Her second, recorded just before she died 11 days ago, aged 30, was rather more bluesy. It was called Set Me Free. Lolo - les lolos is French for knockers, jugs, melons, what you will - was running from something. "All this stuff," she once said, referring to the operations, "has been because I can't stand life. But it hasn't changed anything. There are moments when I disconnect totally from reality. Then I can do anything, absolutely anything. I swallow pills. I throw myself out of windows. Dying seems very easy then." The night before she did die, Ferrari wasn't well. She had taken her usual fistful of antidepressants and sleeping pills - she was on 12mg of prescription uppers a day - but also some antibiotics for a bad sore throat. The autopsy's verdict was death by natural causes, but the results of a more detailed drug test, due out later this week, will establish whether it was a drug overdose that killed her. Her husband and manager, Eric Vigne, found her body in the upstairs bedroom of their modest house on the hillside above Grasse in the south of France. "She had wanted to sleep alone," he says, "so she could feel at ease, and cough without waking me up. So for once I slept downstairs. When I went up on the Sunday morning, I thought she was still sleeping. Her body was cold." Ferrari had very few friends. But people who took the time to talk to her seriously were invariably charmed. "She would talk so intimately, so openly," says Elisabeth Alexandre, who spent several days with her for French Marie Claire magazine just after the big breast operation and the Cannes film festival of 1995 that really launched her on the world. "She was really very touching. You wanted to imagine her in a dream world with a big, airy house and white bunny rabbits and pink butterflies and friends who would like her truly for what she was, not for the money they could make out of her. The reality was very different." Born Eve Valois in the central French town of Clermont-Ferrand in 1970, Ferrari was the second of four children, a bright and pretty girl. Her father, a senior official in France's nuclear energy programme, was relocated to Brittany when she was a toddler, and the family moved to the chic resort town of La Baule. There Eve went to the local lycée, finishing up with a respectable baccalauréat. To her teachers and the rest of the outside world, she looked set for a solid and sensible career, perhaps in medicine or in teaching. But nobody, it seems, had seen how deeply a disastrously unhappy home life had already marked her. "My mother told me I was ugly and stupid," she told one interviewer. "She said I was only good for emptying chamber pots. I wanted to be an anaesthetist, but you can't learn with a mother like that. Actually, I'm like my mother. She thinks she's ugly too. When I was born, it was herself that she saw and she stuck all sorts of negative stuff on me. She did all she could to stop me living." To another interviewer, she went further: "My mother was always very unhappy with my father. My father was this macho guy who was never there and deceived her openly. So she revenged herself on me. She told me I was revolting too, that no one would ever want me. She hit me sometimes with a riding crop. I was frightened and I was ashamed; I wanted to change my face, my body, to transform myself. I wanted to die, really." Eve left school and launched herself on a small-time modelling career, appearing in a couple of girlie mags. And then she met Eric Vigne. She was 17; he was 39. He was big, bearded, cool. A laid-back, child-of-the-60s manner hid the sharp mind of an entrepreneur. Vigne's urgent desire to make lots of money perfectly matched the teenager's urgent desire to ditch her body: they were married within a year. Two years later, in 1990, the operations began. Vigne encouraged her; it was he who designed her mouth and eyebrows and came up with the plans for her mammoth breasts. The newly named Lolo Ferrari - the surname, which led to a three-year legal battle with the Italian car company, was her maternal grandfather's - felt scared at first, but soon got used to it. "For my mouth," she said in 1996, "we removed my Cupid's bow, tucked the mucous membranes up to my nose, and filled my lips with collagen. There's no particularly odd feeling or anything, but I have to put lipsalve on all the time. I adore being operated on. I feel wonderful in clinics. I love the feeling of a general anaesthetic - falling into this black hole and knowing I'm being altered as I sleep." The breasts went first to 41in, then to 46in. They were desensitised and the skin was stretched nearly to bursting point. Ferrari lived in constant fear, as she mimed her songs and took off her clothes in club after club around Europe, that some madman would jump up on the stage and try to puncture them. Beyond 46in, it became increasingly hard to find a plastic surgeon willing to take on the job. A couple of years ago, Vigne described the operation that made her a monstrous 54G. "I calculated the volume, the diameter, I drew up the plans and I took them to a guy I know who designs fuselage moulds for the aeronautics industry," he said. "The designer made the moulds, and I gave them to a prosthetics maker who produced the empty silicone implants. It took a long, long time to find a surgeon willing to perform the operation. He removed the old implants and replaced them with the new. Each one was filled with two litres of serum. A bit later we increased it to three." Ferrari insisted she was happy with the changes that were made to her body. "Having a big bust comforts me," she told yet another French interviewer. "It makes me more sure of myself. I'm like a transvestite - I've created a femininity that's completely artificial. But I'd like to have even bigger breasts. I can't because there are medical problems - you can't stretch the skin any more." It frightened her, she said, to think of herself as skin, bone and blood. She wore a ring on every finger and dozens of bracelets and bangles; she painted her long fingernails pink. Her skin was the one thing she couldn't change, so she covered it with jewellery and makeup. If she didn't, she would have anxiety attacks, feeling, she said, that she was suddenly back with her old face. And, of course, none of it worked. Ferrari became completely estranged from her family and had not spoken to them for years at the time of her death. "Every time they saw me, my parents told me to get my breasts shrunk and take off my rings and cut my high heels down," she said. "When someone tells me something like that, I just want to die." Without meeting her, psychologists said Lolo probably suffered from the rare condition of dysmorphophobia - an irrational conviction that one's body is repulsive. Once embarked on that path, says a Paris psychiatrist, François Chauchot, there is no going back. "It's a vicious downward spiral," he says. "It will never end, because no amount of operations will ever be enough to put the body right. Exterior appearance counts for more than personality; there's no distance any more. And when one more frustration appears, these people collapse easily - to the point, certainly, of suicide." Ferrari's progressive metamorphosis into a grotesquely proportioned inflatable doll looks like a long slow suicide. Vigne, who initially insisted she did not take her own life, now says Ferrari visited an undertaker before she died, chose a white coffin, and specified that she should be buried with her favourite teddy bear. "She wanted to be a star," he says, "but she couldn't bear living. She often said she'd kill herself if I wasn't there, and a few times she tried." But further than that he will not go. Nor will any of the other men who, despite all the signs that something here was dreadfully, horribly wrong, helped Eve to become Lolo, fuelled her fears and made money out of her malaise. The producers at Eurotrash, who were happy to show her dizzying cleavage fronting another dismal Eurohit or attempting some ordinary, everyday task for a laddish laugh, did not return phone calls. And Vigne, after five minutes of unashamed grief, hangs up with the words: "Enough people have exploited me and Lolo already. If you want me to talk any more, you'll have to pay."

fields.headline: No: 1595
fields.standfirst: Viscount Coke
fields.trailText: Viscount Coke
fields.body:
Age: 34.

Appearance: Closely shorn Jeremy Beadle.

Flavour: Effervescent cola with a hint of chocolate minty biscuits.

Really? Of course not. He's a real viscount. And that's his real name.

What's his first name? Charlie? Thomas, alas.

Status: Heir to the Earl of Leicester, noted conservationist.

What's he done then? Allegedly allowed poisons that were used to kill a protected kestrel to be stored on his estate.

Just like those kids in Belgium last year . . . Wrong Coke again. And they weren't poisoned, if our lawyer can just remind you.

What happened to the kestrel, then? It took a peck of poisoned pheasant, laid as bait by the estate's gamekeeper Martin Joyce, a court ruled this week.

Poor, unfortunate creature. Not as unfortunate as the two kestrels Joyce shot "in a fit of rage" for attacking a partridge chick.

What's old Hokey-Cokey got to say for himself? He denies knowledge of the poisons and says that he "deplores" the gamekeeper's actions.

So, the Leicesters. Done anything remarkable? Simon de Montfort, earl of Leicester, was a noted Crusader and governor of England from 1264 until he was kicked out a year later. Robert Dudley, another earl, was rather, ahem, close to the virgin Queen Elizabeth I. And Thomas William Coke was an 18th-century pioneer in agriculture and living in harmony with the environment.

Oops. Anything else? Not unless you count the less well-known bastard cousin, who sloped off to America to invent a soft drink.

Really? Of course not. The drink was named after one of its original ingredients, cocaine. Which is not, our lawyer hastens to add, how the Leicesters gained their name.

Childish taunts Tom will have endured at Eton: Off to powder your nose? Is it true you're a Virgin Cola?

Childish taunts he should endure now: Call that a beard?

webTitle: Wage rises biggest for eight years

fields.headline: Wage rises biggest for eight years
fields.standfirst: Latest figures show earnings growth running at 5.9% a year
fields.trailText: Wage inflation accelerated to its fastest rate for eight years in January. But with the earnings data clouded by "millennium fog" and the downward trend in unemployment showing signs of levelling off, it was unclear whether the Bank of England's monetary policy committee would respond by increasing borrowing costs in the short term to ward off the threat of a wage/price spiral.
fields.body:
Wage inflation accelerated to its fastest rate for eight years in January. But with the earnings data clouded by "millennium fog" and the downward trend in unemployment showing signs of levelling off, it was unclear whether the Bank of England's monetary policy committee would respond by increasing borrowing costs in the short term to ward off the threat of a wage/price spiral.

Kate Barker, chief economic adviser at the Confederation of British Industry, said: "The MPC should not overreact to the earnings figures, which have been pushed up by new-year bonuses. It will still take a couple of months for the trend to become clear. The economy is already set to slow after recent rises in interest rates."

Her message was reinforced by John Monks, TUC general secretary, who said: "Negotiated settlements remain much lower and are stable. There is no need for an interest rate rise next month."

The data, published by the office for national statistics, showed average annual earnings growth accelerating to 5.9% in the three months to January, the highest figures since July 1992, from 5.5% in the previous quarter.

Officials said the increase was driven by a combination of the standard annual bonus round and extra payments for staff working over the millennium weekend.

The surge in earnings growth was accompanied by mixed data on unemployment, with the number of people out of work and claiming benefit falling by 6,700 in February but the alternative measure favoured by the government recording an increase in the jobless total.

According to the ILO measure, which includes everyone who is job ready but not necessarily on benefit, unemployment rose by 21,000 between November and January compared to the previous three months, but was down 100,000 on the year. ONS officials said the unemployment trend was "close to flat".

The impression that the labour market is not necessarily tightening much further was reinforced by a small rise in the number of new vacancies notified to Jobcentres in February, up 2,800, although the total of 231,100 remains at an historically high level.

Despite the rise in ILO unemployment in the latest quarter, employment rose by 83,000 in the same period, meaning that all the new jobs were filled by new entrants to the workforce not tracked by either the claimant count or the ILO measure.

Dharshini David, economist at HSBC in the City, said this supported the Bank's theory that there might be a wide pool of labour just outside the workforce which could be tapped to reduce any upward pressure on wages.

All the new jobs are being created in the services sector, while manufacturing employment continues to fall. The latest figures show a drop of 122,000 in industry in the three months to January compared with the corresponding period a year ago.

The treasury renewed its call for pay restraint. "Today's figures, though influenced by the unusual circumstances surrounding the millennium holiday, reinforce the message that responsibility in wage bargaining across all sectors is necessary if we are to avoid higher interest rates and fewer jobs in the future," a spokesman said.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Vodafone takes lead in bid fight

The government's auction of five next generation mobile phone licences continued yesterday with 13 contenders switching their bids between licences as the auction moved to round 31.
fields.body:
Vodafone takes lead in bid fight

The government's auction of five next generation mobile phone licences continued yesterday with 13 contenders switching their bids between licences as the auction moved to round 31.

The highest offer of £541.4m by Vodafone was for licence B, while Eircom's subsidiary 3GUK muscled in with a £421m offer for licence A that has been reserved for a new operator. Telefonica was level pegging its bid for licence C at £211m, while NTL Mobile and TIW tied at £212m for licence E. News Corp backed One.Tel offered £206.9m for licence D.

The offers for five licences have crept to £1.6bn with the provisional announcement of the winners likely on March 24.

Andersen disappoints
Andersen, the international consultancy group, announced yesterday that it had boosted revenues 8% in 1999 to £5.6bn. UK managing partner James Hall said he was "a bit disappointed" by the lack of growth and blamed the fact that clients had drawn in their horns mid-year, ahead of anticipated Y2K bug problems. Mr Hall said Andersen had spent the relatively quiet second half of 1999 reinventing itself around the needs of electronic commerce.
Overall managing partner Joe Forehand said: "The electronic economy is too new and fast changing for consultants to offer advice from the sidelines". Ultimately, Mr Hall said, Andersen would like to drop the term "consultant" as its activities often overlapped with that of investment banks and other advisers. Andersen is in the middle of a lengthy divorce from Arthur Andersen, the accountancy practice from which it emerged. HSBC launches new service

HSBC Holdings

HSBC Holdings said that it had launched HSBC Premier, its first global banking service for personal customers.

Free access to current account funds through any HSBC cash machine and free cheque encashment are two of the services provided by the new service. In addition to these features are a global calling card and free internet services.

Unions take up euro cause
Four of Britain's big trade unions launched a campaign in favour of the euro, criticising the government for its lukewarm approach to the single currency. "Had arguments been pressed more heavily, Europe would be more popular," said John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB general workers' union.

webTitle: Testing time for the new triumvirate

fields.headline: Testing time for the new triumvirate
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: How will Labour's economic and financial policymaking framework stand up under pressure?
fields.trailText: Too many cooks, they say, spoil the broth - but that assumes they are all stirring the same pot. If each is doing their own thing with their own pan, the diner will at least have a choice.
fields.body:
Too many cooks, they say, spoil the broth - but that assumes they are all stirring the same pot. If each is doing their own thing with their own pan, the diner will at least have a choice.

Since 1997, three star chefs have been jointly responsible for cooking up policy aimed at guaranteeing the stability of the financial and economic system: chancellor Gordon Brown, Bank of England governor Eddie George and financial services authority chairman Howard Davies.

A memorandum of understanding created this three-legged stool upon which the equilibrium of the system rests. Its first big test - Black August in 1998, with the collapse of the Russian rouble - was passed with flying colours. A series of monthly tripartite meetings mapped out a strategy for shielding the City from the world crisis.

True, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the US federal reserve board, may ultimately have proved the real saviour, but it would be churlish to deny the treasury-Bank-FSA structure the credit for holding firm.

Now, however, with parts of the economy entering an exceptionally febrile and jittery phase there are signs that the diverse guardians of financial stability are not singing from the same hymn sheet.

Take unsecured consumer credit, the outstanding total of which is £1.15bn, a 13% increase on 1998-1999. Could this pose a systemic risk? Take your pick: for those of a pessimistic turn of mind there was Mr Davies's warning on Tuesday that it may well be so. He has ordered a review of unsecured lending practices in those institutions regulated by the FSA.

Others may prefer the verdict of the Bank, whose latest inflation report devoted just one insouciant sentence to the topic, noting such lending "remained high".

Finally, those of an unflappable disposition can turn to the chancellor himself, who insists repeatedly he has abolished the boom-bust cycle. Thus such lending cannot, by definition, be a problem.

Then there is the net shares boom. A potential problem? Not at all, according to the cheery Mr George, who on December 13 said: "On the whole ... the particular strengths of hi-tech stocks in equity markets provided a better underpinning of equity values than perhaps had been appreciated." Translated, practically a "fill your boots" endorsement.

A few days earlier Mr Davies's chief lieutenant for consumer protection, Christine Farnish, urged investors to think twice before lighting out for the net klondyke, reminding them that such shares may prove difficult to trade. Mr Brown, come March, was rather milder. Pressed during a radio interview, he confessed to being a cautious man himself and suggested others may take a leaf out of his book.

Then Tuesday rolled around and Mr Davies reassured MPs: "At this point in time, I'm not saying there is a risk of a systemic crisis ... If there were a re-rating of the dot.coms, a lot of investors would get their fingers burned but I don't think the fabric of the City would collapse."

So, depending on whom you ask, the boom-bubble is supported by the fundamentals - the Bank - a hazardous investment area requiring great caution - FSA consumer affairs - no real systemic threat - the FSA chairman - and something that could go either way, really - the treasury.

Finally, house price inflation and mortgage lending. Here, Mr Brown is worried enough by the boom in the south east to be planning measures in next week's Budget to take the heat out of the market.

Mr Davies is shoulder to shoulder with him; earlier this month he warned that outstanding mortgage debt - totalling about half a trillion pounds - had increased sharply and that "there ... [are] signs of a relaxation of credit standards which were the kinds of signs that we saw in the late 1980s boom".

But the Bank, eschewing its usual role of declaring the party over, noted in the February inflation report: "House price inflation is likely to slow as recent increases in interest rates feed through". The Bank added that its central assumption was that the rise in house prices would ease to below 10% this year and moderate further in 2001. So that is all right, then.

Despite these apparently divergent diagnoses Mr Davies's comments on mortgage lending disclose that they do share a common concern - terror at the prospect of another 1980s-style blow-out. Mr George was deputy governor of the Bank when the Lawson experiment went wrong; Mr Brown watched as the Tories were immolated by boom then bust and Mr Davies was on his way to the CBI, where he would see the devastation caused by the high-interest rate medicine needed to bring the fever under control.

But if the present boom disintegrated, who would be in charge of the rescue? The Bank remains "lender of last resort", but the FSA and treasury have important and wide-ranging roles in any crisis.

In the past the Bank has launched salvage operations pretty much unhindered. Next time it will be much more circumscribed, especially given its partners may not agree with the Bank or with each other as to the nature of the problem - or even as to whether there is a problem.

Finally, house price inflation and mortgage lending. Here, Mr Brown is worried enough by the boom in the south east to be planning measures in next week's Budget to take the heat out of the market. Mr Davies is shoulder to shoulder with him; earlier this month he warned that outstanding mortgage debt - totalling about half a trillion pounds - had increased sharply and that "there ... [are] signs of a relaxation of credit standards which were the kinds of signs that we saw in the late 1980s boom". But the Bank, eschewing its usual role of declaring the party over, noted in the February inflation report: "House price inflation is likely to slow as recent increases in interest rates feed through". The Bank added that its central assumption was that the rise in house prices would ease to below 10% this year and moderate further in 2001. So that is all right, then. Despite these apparently divergent diagnoses Mr Davies's comments on mortgage lending disclose that they do share a common concern - terror at the prospect of another 1980s-style blow-out. Mr George was deputy governor of the Bank when the Lawson experiment went wrong; Mr Brown watched as the Tories were immolated by boom then bust and Mr Davies was on his way to the CBI, where he would see the devastation caused by the high-interest rate medicine needed to bring the fever under control. But if the present boom disintegrated, who would be in charge of the rescue? The Bank remains "lender of last resort", but the FSA and treasury have important and wide-ranging roles in any crisis. In the past the Bank has launched salvage operations pretty much unhindered. Next time it will be much more circumscribed, especially given its partners may not agree with the Bank or with each other as to the nature of the problem - or even as to whether there is a problem.

fields.headline: Smile poaches Egg finance chief
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Egg
fields.trailText: The battle of the internet banks intensified yesterday when Smile, the Co-operative Bank's online operation, poached the finance director of Egg, the Prudential's subsidiary.
fields.body:
The battle of the internet banks intensified yesterday when Smile, the Co-operative Bank's online operation, poached the finance director of Egg, the Prudential's subsidiary.

Bob Head, 41, will become Smile's first chief executive, following a decision to give the separately-branded venture its own management structure.

When Smile launched in October last year, it declared that it was the first "real" internet bank, and claimed Egg offered "little more than an online savings account". However, it was yesterday taking a less combative stance.

Mr Head was involved in the creation of Prudential Banking, of which he was an executive director, and was also a founding director of Egg, playing a key role in its conception, launch and further develop ment, said the Co-op Bank. Smile went live on October 28. Its flagship product is a current account paying a high rate of interest on credit balances, and it also offers savings accounts, credit cards and personal loans.

The Co-op Bank has been spending millions of pounds on a high-profile TV advertising campaign to promote the brand but has not disclosed how many customers it has signed up.

Egg describes itself as "Britain's first internet bank" but Smile has attempted to wrench this title away by calling itself "the UK's first full internet bank".

It has said it is the first to offer all the products and services associated with a traditional bank. However, Smile does not yet offer mortgages, which the Prudential's subsidiary has sold for some time.

fields.headline: Company law reform 'too timid'
fields.standfirst:
Stakeholders lose out

E-finance: special report
BP Amoco
fields.trailText: Plans for the biggest shake-up in company law for 150 years, published yesterday, would retain shareholder value as the overriding business objective for public companies.
fields.body:
Plans for the biggest shake-up in company law for 150 years, published yesterday, would retain shareholder value as the overriding business objective for public companies.

Campaigners said that the decision could lead the government to abandon much of the stakeholder philosophy put forward by the prime minister when he was in opposition. A stakeholder scheme forces companies to address the concerns of employees and community groups along with shareholders.

But under the new plan directors would be expected to report on social and environmental issues as part of a drive for greater transparency, which includes publishing annual results first on company websites.

The report also sets out a raft of suggestions, including changes to the annual meeting, and suggests a much lighter approach to legal requirements for smaller companies.

The contentious two-year review of Britain's Victorian legal framework, launched by the then trade and industry secretary Margaret Beckett, has shied away from putting employees and other stakeholders on an equal footing with shareholders.

It proposes two ways of introducing stakeholder issues into the boardroom in what it describes as an "inclusive" approach. First, the law would make directors' duties explicit and include the need to con sider wider and long-term issues.

Second, companies would have to publish an operating and financial review (OFR) in their annual reports, which should include broad non-financial issues unless directors say they are irrelevant.

Bryan Sanderson, a BP Amoco managing director and review team member, said: "This will ensure that all those with an interest in the company have access to the information they need to understand the business and its performance."

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said: "The law needs to be modernised to provide a framework which encourages both competitiveness and accountability."

The report was also welcomed by business and the City.

But campaigners protested that the review had missed an opportunity to deal with inevitable conflicts between shareholders and other stakeholders.

Barry Coates, director of the World Development Movement, said: "There are some nice words but this is a real step backwards.

"In the real world there are choices to be made between profitability and people's welfare. The law is meant to enable some sort of balance but this is business as usual. It implies that directors are stupid and don't understand what is in the long-term interests of shareholders at the moment," he said.

fields.headline: Matalan
fields.trailText: Bargain fashion chain Matalan yesterday unveiled plans to create 2,000 jobs in 18 new out-of-town superstores in the next eight months.
fields.body:
Bargain fashion chain Matalan yesterday unveiled plans to create 2,000 jobs in 18 new out-of-town superstores in the next eight months.

Fashion retail is one of the toughest businesses to make money in and for any other chain such a plan would be regarded as a bold move. But Matalan has bucked almost every trend in its sector in the past 12 months.

The company is now the UK's fastest growing fashion chain. The outlets will be around 30,000sq ft - the same size as an average Tesco and half as big again as the chain's existing outlets.

The group, founded in 1985 by Liverpudlian ex-market stallholder John Hargreaves, and modelled on US discounter WalMart, was one of the few retail success stories last year.

While rivals struggled for sales, Matalan was raking in cash. Over Christmas its like-for-like sales climbed 19.2%. The product range covers womens, mens and kids clothing in own brand labels but also includes must-have labels like Wonderbra, Sloggi, Calvin Klein and Versace.

The company floated in May 1998 at 285p and its shares rocketed to £27 before they were split to improve marketability. Earlier this month they hit a peak of 662p - compared to a recalculated initial float price of some 50p - and yesterday they added 12.5p to finish at 530p. The bulk of the shares are still held by Mr Hargreaves - and his holding has created a scarcity value - but Matalan now has 1.7% of the UK fashion market and is valued at around £2bn (or more than rivals Debenhams, Arcadia and New Look put together).

The first of the new mega-store formats will open tomorrow week in St Helens, Merseyside with 100 new staff. The store count will reach 117 by the end of this year and the company plans to operate 200 outlets by 2005.

Most analysts remain big fans. Seymour Pierce, for example rates the group "a class act", with excellent trading. But it stops short of a buy recommendation - reckoning that the price is up with events.

webTitle: Stock exchange members vote to demutualise

fields.headline: Stock exchange members vote to demutualise
fields.trailText: The 298 members of the London stock exchange yesterday voted overwhelmingly to end almost 200 years as a mutual organisation and turn themselves into a public company, which will be worth around £300m.
fields.body:
The 298 members of the London stock exchange yesterday voted overwhelmingly to end almost 200 years as a mutual organisation and turn themselves into a public company, which will be worth around £300m.

Only a handful of votes were cast against plans to demutualise the exchange at an extraordinary general meeting of B shareholders, despite some opposition to the lucrative packages on offer to senior executives.

Sources said that the endorsement of the eight resolutions at the meeting were supported "all but unanimously", with about 99% of the votes cast in favour of the proposals that will see shares in the new company be put on sale either late next month or in early May.

Although the proposals were initially supported more enthusiastically by the exchange's bigger members, smaller firms also backed the call for change.

Sir John Kemp-Welch, chairman of the LSE said after the vote: "We are delighted that the proposals have received such strong support. Today's vote moves the exchange into a new era, providing a structure that will allow it to compete more effectively in the rapidly developing environment in which stock exchanges now operate."

First announced last July, demutualisation is intended to extend the exchange's commercial freedom and comes as rapid technological change and competitive pressures rev olutionise share dealing internationally.

Gavin Casey, the exchange's chief executive, has argued that his organisation needs to be able to move faster and with greater flexibility in order to meet the challenge from new entrants into the marketplace, especially Nasdaq.

The change of ownership structure will lead to windfalls for the 298 brokers and other institutions that currently own the exchange, each of which will get 100,000 shares, equivalent to 0.34% of the total.

Senior staff will be granted shares and share options worth up to £8m, but rumbles of discontent about the packages ahead of yesterday's vote came to nothing.

Only three exchange members voted against the deal, sources said.

fields.headline: Think small is the key
fields.trailText: The law should "think small first", according to yesterday's report, which says legal requirements should focus on the 99% of companies which are small and privately-owned.
fields.body:
The law should "think small first", according to yesterday's report, which says legal requirements should focus on the 99% of companies which are small and privately-owned.

Colin Perry, chairman of the CBI small companies council, said: "Our aim is to facilitate start-ups and entrepreneurial growth. This will produce a set of rules tailored to the needs of small private companies."

First, the law would be simplified for all private companies, requiring fewer shareholder meetings and relaxing the rules governing meetings and shareholder transactions.

Second, an even lighter regime would apply to the smallest private companies, especially those where the directors and shareholders tend to be the same people.

Third, new accounting requirements would mean the smallest companies no longer need an audit and a full audit would only be required above £5m sales. There should also be no distinction between accounts filed at Companies House and those prepared for shareholders.

But it is proposed to remove the option for "abbreviated accounts", which are considered worthless.

webTitle: Hopes rise Siemens' Tyneside plant may reopen

fields.headline: Hopes rise Siemens' Tyneside plant may reopen
fields.trailText: Hopes rose yesterday that a semiconductor plant, which stopped production with the loss of more than 1,000 jobs, could reopen.
fields.body:
Hopes rose yesterday that a semiconductor plant, which stopped production with the loss of more than 1,000 jobs, could reopen.

The Siemens factory near Newcastle upon Tyne ceased production at the end of 1998 after the German-owned electronics group blamed over-capacity and rapidly falling prices for semiconductor chips.

But Heinrich von Pierer, the company's chairman, said yesterday that it was close to finding a buyer for the £650m plant.

It was likely the plant at Wallsend would produce "Siemens technology, but also another technology", prompting speculation that the facility could end up being operated in a joint venture between Infineon, a Siemens semiconductor company, and an unnamed party.

Siemens UK chief executive Alan Wood said at the time of the closure: "We were all devastated by the closure of North Tyneside, but the reality is that the plant could not compete on the world stage without a joint venture partner."

Last year Siemens agreed to a government demand that it repay the £18m it received in grants for the factory.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
lastminute.com
Vodaphone
Reuters
fields.trailText: The high profile sectors of dot.coms and biotechs suffered stock market setbacks yesterday. After its storming stock exchange debut, Lastminute.com fell back sharply on day two.
fields.body:
The high profile sectors of dot.coms and biotechs suffered stock market setbacks yesterday. After its storming stock exchange debut, Lastminute.com fell back sharply on day two.

After being issued at 380p, the shares hit a high of 555p on day one, but yesterday they fell 75p, or 15%, to 412p. Some analysts blamed the decline on the negative press created from the company's allocation of tiny parcels of only 35 shares each to 190,000 small investors.

Smaller company shares closed sharply lower as high-flying biotech and technology shares were hammered in the wake of a dreadful overnight performance from the Nasdaq, which spilled over into today's session, dealers said. Biotech issues dominated the worst performers amongst the smaller stocks, unsettled by comments from US President Bill Clinton and the prime minister, Tony Blair.

The two leaders declared that in order to realise the full promise of the research, raw fundamental data on the humane genome, including the human DNA sequence and its variations, should be made freely available. These comments sparked a 12.5% dive for the Nasdaq biotech index, which spilled over into London.

Xenova was the worst affected, losing 65p to 292p, closely followed by Oxford Glycosciences, off 480p at £22.25 and International Biotech, down 45p at 237p.

Biotechs also featured heavily among the FTSE 250 fallers. Celltech, down 181p at £13.07p, and Shire Pharmaceuticals, off 184p at £12.00 both suffered from profit taking.

At the close, the FTSE 100 index was 40.1 points lower at 6,447.0, but staying above off its low of 6,396.1 recorded at 11.26am.

All the broader FTSE indices were weaker, with the TechMark 100 index one of the worst off, down 428 points on Nasdaq's decline.

Volumes in London were solid, with 1,868bn shares changing hands in 146,725 transactions.

Strong trading in market heavyweight Vodafone Airtouch helped inflate the volume figure, accounting for around 324m of the total shares traded.

Sema was at the top of the FTSE 100 fallers list, down 253p at 1,443 affected by Nasdaq's sell-off, and unsettled by news of a merger with US-based group LHS.

Media stocks suffered a further bout of profit taking as internet re-ratings benefits dropped away, with Pearson off 240p at £21.29, BSkyB down 128p at £19.17, and Reuters 81p lower at £14.03.

fields.headline: The prince of darkness
fields.standfirst: Douglas Gordon turned being a mobie addict into an art form. In 1996 it won him the Turner prize. Now the creator of 24 Hour Psycho is about to share top billing with Turner himself.  He talks to Jonathon Jones.
fields.trailText: Douglas Gordon turned being a mobie addict into an art form. In 1996 it won him the Turner prize. Now the creator of 24 Hour Psycho is about to share top billing with Turner himself. He talks to Jonathon Jones.
fields.body:
To get to Douglas Gordon's flat in a 19th-century Glasgow tenement you have to go up a spiralling staircase. You fumble for a light switch. You hear a door open above. Up there it's very dark.

This moment of anxiety recalls the installation Feature Film that Gordon created in London with Artangel last year, a film of conductor James Conlon's hands leading an orchestra through Bernard Herrmann's score for Hitchcock's Vertigo. The best joke was getting to it up a spiral staircase and realising halfway that you had "become" James Stewart trying to get up the stairs of the mission tower. You might also think of Robert Louis Stevenson's Kidnapped (Gordon, a Stevenson fan, has published a book called Kidnapping): there, the young narrator stays with his malicious uncle who sends him to bed at the top of the house. The staircase gives way...

At the top of the stairs, however, Gordon's flat is bright and modern, with lots of technological equipment and a fridge that appears to be full of personalised beer from the company that sponsored Feature Film.

Gordon's successes include the 1996 Turner Prize, the 1998 Hugo Boss prize - America's closest equivalent to the Turner - and a string of shows at European museums. He currently has a retrospective at the Musée d'Art Moderne in Paris, and later this year a show at the Liverpool Tate, a two-header with Turner. He characterises himself as "a mild mannered but incredibly competitive person", and he makes it clear exactly what the scale of this ambition is. He loves the work of Barnett Newman and Richard Serra, and says he's "competing against that, not against Damien and Rachel". Tough talk, but the show in Paris is special. Fascinating, disconcerting, it lingers in your mind like a nightmare.

Within the museum's vast space, he has built a funhouse - or is it a minotaur's labyrinth? The exhibition is called Sheep and Goats, a Biblical allusion that confused the French, who thought it had something to do with BSE. Inside, everything is dark, the walls painted black, the only light coming from monitors and projections hidden through the space. You are faced with a choice between a red and a blue curtain. There are secret doors, mirrors and passageways. Monitors display bits of Gordon's body fighting each other: a portrait of the artist as a divided self.

At the centre is a room where you watch films shown in Glasgow between December 1965 and September 1966, when Gordon's mother was carrying him in her womb; from Spartacus to that year's Bond - "My mum was a great Sean Connery fan" - to the Hammer shocker The Nanny.

Other surprises lie in wait. A photograph of the artist hitching, trying to attract motorists' sympathy with a sign that reads Psycho, leads to a remote space where his 1993 installation 24 Hour Psycho is showing in solitary menace. Yet the most uncomfortable thing in the show is a brightly lit space in which are written the names of all the people Gordon acknowledges knowing. The list is alienating, irritating, frightening. He does not know you. You are cast out.

To be an artist is to tell a story about yourself. In this show Gordon sets out his melancholy artistic autobiography which is also an essay about autobiography and the idea of the "retrospective". He is reluctant to admit it is autobiographical, which is typical of the misdirection that runs through his art. Yet he loves to recount the highlights of his life. It is no surprise when he says, "I didn't want to be an artist; I wanted to be a writer."

Slumped on a beanbag in his front room, not far from what Hitchcock in The 39 Steps called "the bright lights of Sauchiehall Street", he tells me his story. It goes like this: Douglas Gordon was born in Glasgow in 1966 to a Protestant family. His father was a pattern-maker in the city's shipbuilding industry. In 1972 his mother converted to the Jehovah's Witnesses, so he was brought up as a Jehovah's Witness and had no more birthday parties after that date. He knocked on doors and was inculcated with a literal belief in Satan. Gordon is close to his parents, who encouraged him to become an artist; he often discusses his work with them. His background is imprinted on everything he does. He met the devil in a bar in Berlin in 1998: "I saw him. With horns and stuff. Absolutely true. I'd still love to go back to Berlin."

Brought up in a God-fearing family, Gordon loved to watch film, mainly on TV. His art exults in the wickedness of cinema. There's a lassitude to the way he makes art, an explicit departure from the straight and narrow. He got the idea for 24 Hour Psycho sitting around at his parents' house watching a video of the film, slowing it down in an effort to see Janet Leigh more closely in the scene where Norman spies on her undressing. "I've never believed in that inspiration stuff," he says. "I think if anybody lounged around as much as I do and watched as much TV as I do they'd probably come up with the same works..."

Most of his film memories are of seeing films on television - John Ford's The Searchers was a family favourite and he has since proposed a version that lasts five years, the time it takes John Wayne to find the girl kidnapped by Apaches. He has a vivid inpression of Glasgow cinemas as exotic buildings. "Walking past a cinema in the old days when cinemas had production stills outside, I remember looking at A Clockwork Orange and being dragged away. I remember that, and also Last Tango in Paris - of course the stills would show nothing." When he was seven? And isn't this straight out of François Truffaut's Day for Night? "I've still never seen A Clockwork Orange properly. Last Tango's a different story - I've seen that too many times. I want my work to have the impact that I felt watching a movie in the afternoon, going in the sunlight. You come out and it's difficult to relate to people. I remember it vividly with Last Tango in Paris, being pretty shaken by it, coming out from the matinee - it was dark - going to a bar and having a drink. You look at a girl and what do you think about, compared with what you've just seen?"

It takes a while to realise this is the same film, with the same characters, at different times in the action. Gradually, the voices and shadows take on a structure. At the far left, a man is in a doctor's room being given bad news - the worst. He has less than 24 hours to live. He has been poisoned; there is no cure. The man rages. Up there it's very dark. The best joke was getting to it up a spiral staircase and realising halfway that you had "become" James Stewart trying to get up the stairs of the mission tower. You might also think of Robert Louis Stevenson's Kidnapped (Gordon, a Stevenson fan, has published a book called Kidnapping): there, the young narrator stays with his malicious uncle who sends him to bed at the top of the house. The staircase gives way... At the top of the stairs, however, Gordon's flat is bright and modern, with lots of technological equipment and a fridge that appears to be full of personalised beer from the company that sponsored Feature Film. Gordon's successes include the 1996 Turner Prize, the 1998 Hugo Boss prize - America's closest equivalent to the Turner - and a string of shows at European museums. He currently has a retrospective at the Musée d'Art Moderne in Paris, and later this year a show at the Liverpool Tate, a two-header with Turner. He characterises himself as "a mild mannered but incredibly competitive person", and he makes it clear exactly what the scale of this ambition is. He loves the work of Barnett Newman and Richard Serra, and says he's "competing against that, not against Damien and Rachel". Tough talk, but the show in Paris is special. fields.headline: Waiting for Mr Noble
fields.standfirst: If comedy is all about timing, Ross Noble is in deep, deep trouble.  Danny Wallace  reports
fields.trailText: If comedy is all about timing, Ross Noble is in deep, deep trouble.
fields.body:
The captain of the plane has just finished explaining why we are still parked up in Heathrow. We should be in the air, he says, but we're waiting for someone to arrive. That someone is Ross Noble, one of Britain's most gifted - and least punctual - comedians.

At 23, Noble has almost achieved his "lifetime ambition" of travelling the world, thanks chiefly to his talent and the willingness of foreign comedy clubs to pay for his flights and rooms. But Noble is no Vegas comedian with a sparkly suit and a dull line in universal material. His performances are usually wholly improvised and see him weaving gold out of the barest, blandest details of his audience's lives. A man who works in IT is as likely to spark off brilliantly surreal material as a man who feeds the elephants in a zoo.

It was this fascinating ability to think on his feet that got Noble shortlisted for a Perrier award at last year's Edinburgh festival. And now it's taking him to Budapest, then Warsaw. At least, that's the plan.

Finally, Noble boards the plane, a mass of blue coat and wild hair. "Sorry I'm late," he says as he takes his seat. "I got distracted by something."

Some hours later, waiting at a bleak Budapest tram stop for a once again very late Noble, I realise I should have checked whether or not he owns a watch. When he does arrive, he again mutters something about having been "distracted by something". He's brought a small MiniDisc recorder with him, to make his own comedy and travel programme for Radio 4, which he brings out at odd intervals and which attracts even more attention than his shock of brightly coloured hair.

The gig tonight is at a local theatre, the Merlin. We've a few hours to kill, and a few things to see, so we take it easy. Our tram eventually arrives, yellow, screeching and with blank, dour faces pressed up against each grimy and scratched window. Inside, the tram is just one slow-moving earthquake - a deafening mix of metal, stone and, bizarrely, bells.

As we shudder towards the centre of town, the sky is dark, but the river Danube darker. "It's not quite as blue as I'd hoped it was going to be, I'll be honest," says Noble, about to take the thought further but distracted instead by Gellert Hill, one of Budapest's most impressive landmarks. It's a cliff, well over 100m high, named after the Venetian bishop Gerardus, a man supposedly responsible for converting the Magyars to Christianity in the 11th century. Vengeful heathens finally took hold of Gerardus and, a local informs us, "tied the monk to a wheelbarrow, and tossed him off".

"So is that a statue of him up there at the top of the hill?" asks Noble in his Newcastle accent, "because if it is, d'you not think they should have put it at the bottom, all smashed up?" The man laughs uneasily, looks slightly confused and wanders away.

Twenty minutes later, Noble and I have clambered to the top of the hill, where we take in a view so picturesque that, as Noble points out, even the two teenagers sniffing glue a few feet from the summit can't spoil it. But it's a hard climb. "I don't blame that Gellert fella for taking the wheelbarrow option down," says Noble. "I can't face the walk, either."

Eager to escape the bitter cold, we take a bus towards a local market. Noble, it transpires, is a keen collector of knick-knacks, trinkets and - let's face it - tat. There are many stalls, but it soon becomes clear that Noble and I are the sole customers.

In one row of five stalls you might walk away with a gun, a dancing wind-up monkey, some Chinese pornography, an old toilet, a sofa or some Nazi paraphernalia. Noble, however, spots an old accordion. "Oh, listen, this always happens to me. I walk into a place like this, see something like that and instantly think that I've always wanted one. If we don't get away from this stall, I'll end up buying that accordion." We walk swiftly away. Within 15 minutes, at the other side of the market, Noble has bought a banjo.

We make it to the Merlin a little before nine. We would have been there earlier, but Noble got "distracted by something". It's an incredibly ornate building from the outside, but the stage is set up in a bare, L-shaped room, which Noble manages to use in a great piece of improvised comedy. Then he talks about the trams we took today, the baths we passed, the streets we walked and the hill we climbed.

The audience appreciate the effort and want to join in. "What's the story with that monk who jumped off the cliff?" asks Noble at one point. "He was pushed!" shouts a man in the audience, prompting Noble to launch into a fantastical story about monks with an interest in extreme sports, grassy knolls and bungee ropes made of tapestries.

Ninety minutes later, we've learnt much about Budapest, including the fact that Gerardus was pushed off the cliff not in a wheelbarrow but in an internally spiked barrel - something Noble later terms "a specific Hungarian monk-related disposal unit", which causes one man to slap another on the back then drop his pint.

The next morning we arrive in Warsaw after a painful 12-hour train journey. At each border, men in uniform would enter our tiny cabin and demand to see our passports, followed by more men in uniform - customs. Each group would wake us, stamp our documents and grumpily leave - a total of six times.

A cab takes us straight to Dziesieciolecia stadium, home to one of Europe's largest car-boot sales. Noble spots an antique mandolin. "Now, I have actually genuinely always wanted one of them," he says, "but I can't buy that, else I'll end up buying loads of other stuff I don't need." Within half an hour he is walking away with a white fur hat, some binoculars and the laser sights from a Russian sniper rifle. Each item is referred to in his show, in the basement of the Marriott Hotel - probably qualifying them as tax-deductible.

That night at Warsaw airport I lose sight of Noble as our baggage is being inspected but soon hear him trying to tell someone who patently speaks no English what he's doing with the laser sights, and how he's not a spy or anything. It's more than 30 minutes before he reappears.

By now we're supposed to be boarding. What happened? "Nothing," he says. "They let me straight through." So why the half-hour wait? "Oh, I just got distracted by something."

 Ross Noble's next UK gig is at the Komedia, Brighton (01273 647100), on May 20.

webTitle: Yorke sees United through in style

fields.headline: Yorke sees United through in style
fields.standfirst:
Cole 20, Keane 32, Yorke 70 | Batistuta 16
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Manchester United reached the quarter-finals of the Champions League last night in a manner which reminded the rest of Europe what they will have to do to wrest the trophy from their grasp.
fields.body:
Manchester United reached the quarter-finals of the Champions League last night in a manner which reminded the rest of Europe what they will have to do to wrest the trophy from their grasp.

After falling behind to a wonderful shot from Gabriel Batistuta, United were ahead by half-time, courtesy of goals from Andy Cole and Roy Keane, and then increased their lead midway through the second half when Dwight Yorke headed in at the far post from Ryan Giggs's centre.

Fiorentina played for the last half-hour with 10 men after Fabio Rossitto had been sent off, but for United there was the disappointment of losing David Beckham for next week's match in Valencia after a third yellow card.

Not that the early portents were encouraging for United. There was a swish and a snap about Fiorentina's play which slightly fazed Ferguson's players.

In the opening minute Batistuta announced himself with a snap shot into the side-netting and three minutes later a sweet combination of passes slipped through the middle of United's defence as if it were a revolving door.

Gathering a ball from Moreno Torricelli on the right, Batistuta laid it off to Predrag Mijatovic and the Yugoslav's pass found Rui Costa dashing between Jaap Stam and Henning Berg with only Mark Bosnich barring the way. Fortunately for United the alertness of their goalkeeper in narrowing the angle and diving at Portuguese player's feet denied Rui Costa a goal.

The scare, though, did wonders for United's concentration. After Cole had had a close-range shot blocked by Francesco Toldo, Yorke's tangled attempt to score from the rebound was cleared by Jorg Heinrich. Then a typical dash into the penalty box from the left by Giggs ended with Keane's goalbound shot being blocked before it could reach Toldo.

A goal from somewhere was clearly imminent. In the event one arrived in the 16th minute almost from nowhere. Batistuta, some 25 yards out, simply let fly and Bosnich barely had an inkling of what was happening until the ball struck the back of the net.

Not that Old Trafford was downhearted. United's attack was already in full flow and nobody seriously believed they would fail to score. Sure enough, Cole turned near the edge of the Fiorentina penalty area five minutes later to put United level with a low drive into the left-hand corner.

Batistuta met a corner with a glancing near-post header straight into the hands of Bosnich. At the other a cheeky lob from Cole caught Toldo off his line and the goalkeeper only just managed to tip the ball over the crossbar.

Then in the 32nd minute, from Beckham's corner, Berg sent a long, looping header against the bar and after it had bounced out Keane drove United in front with an emphatic shot which clipped the inside of the right-hand post.

Minutes later Beckham fouled Heinrich to collect his booking. Within seconds Beckham, living dangerously, raged at a linesman after a lunge by the German wing-back.

The half-time break quelled some mounting passions without dampening the ardour of the match. United, however, now appeared to have a firmer grip on the game than they had previously, with Beckham and Giggs ruling their respective wings.

Nevertheless Batistuta still posed a threat to United's progress, sending a header just wide of the near post on the hour. But in the 62nd minute Rossitto was sent off after crudely taking away Yorke's legs and United found themselves playing 10 men for the second Champions League game in a row.

 Miroslav Djukic, Kily Gonzalez, Juan Sanchez and a Mendieta penalty gave Valencia a 4-1 win at Bordeaux in last night's other Group B match. Sylvain Wiltord scored for Bordeaux, who had Nisa Saveljic sent off.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Bosnich; G Neville, Stam, Berg, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Cole, Yorke.

Fiorentina (3-4-1-2): Toldo; Repka, Adani, Pierini; Torricelli (Tarozzi, 65min), Di Livio (Amoroso, 65), Rossitto, Heinrich; Rui Costa; Batistuta, Mijatovic, (Chiesa, 63).

Referee: R Wojcik (Poland).

At the other a cheeky lob from Cole caught Toldo off his line and the goalkeeper only just managed to tip the ball over the crossbar. Then in the 32nd minute, from Beckham's corner, Berg sent a long, looping header against the bar and after it had bounced out Keane drove United in front with an emphatic shot which clipped the inside of the right-hand post. Minutes later Beckham fouled Heinrich to collect his booking. Within seconds Beckham, living dangerously, raged at a linesman after a lunge by the German wing-back. The half-time break quelled some mounting passions without dampening the ardour of the match. United, however, now appeared to have a firmer grip on the game than they had previously, with Beckham and Giggs ruling their respective wings. Nevertheless Batistuta still posed a threat to United's progress, sending a header just wide of the near post on the hour. But in the 62nd minute Rossitto was sent off after crudely taking away Yorke's legs and United found themselves playing 10 men for the second Champions League game in a row.  Miroslav Djukic, Kily Gonzalez, Juan Sanchez and a Mendieta penalty gave Valencia a 4-1 win at Bordeaux in last night's other Group B match. Sylvain Wiltord scored for Bordeaux, who had Nisa Saveljic sent off. Manchester United (4-4-2): Bosnich; G Neville, Stam, Berg, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Cole, Yorke. Fiorentina (3-4-1-2): Toldo; Repka, Adani, Pierini; Torricelli (Tarozzi, 65min), Di Livio (Amoroso, 65), Rossitto, Heinrich; Rui Costa; Batistuta, Mijatovic, (Chiesa, 63). Referee: R Wojcik (Poland).

webTitle: Adams returns to fire up Gunners

fields.headline: Adams returns to fire up Gunners
fields.trailText: Last week Arsène Wenger told Kevin Keegan to go to church and pray Tony Adams will be fit for Euro 2000. The England coach must have got down on his knees because Adams has recovered from a groin injury to play for Arsenal against Werder Bremen tonight.
fields.body:
Last week Arsène Wenger told Kevin Keegan to go to church and pray Tony Adams will be fit for Euro 2000. The England coach must have got down on his knees because Adams has recovered from a groin injury to play for Arsenal against Werder Bremen tonight.

The 33-year-old's return is timely, not just because Arsenal's defence has creaked in his absence but also for his powers of motivation. Wenger made it clear the excitement has been drained from European nights.

"We are playing European games almost every week and it is just not such an event now," the Arsenal manager said. "I think everybody feels that. There is no time to prepare. We just go from one match to another. Even the Champions League is not anywhere near as exciting as some people thought it would be and that is because of the league format rather than a knockout competition."

This will be Arsenal's 11th European tie of the season, two more than they played to win the Cup Winners' Cup in 1994. David Seaman has recovered from a neck injury to play in goal and there are slight doubts over Martin Keown (hand) and Emmanuel Petit (hamstring).

Bremen should not be written off whatever happens tonight. They overturned a 1-0 deficit against Parma in the last round and went through against Lyon despite losing the first leg 3-0 in France.

Arsenal (possible; 4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Grimandi, Adams, Silvinho; Parlour, Vieira, Petit, Ljungberg; Bergkamp, Henry.

webTitle: Anelka locked out and thinking of home

fields.headline: Anelka locked out and thinking of home
fields.trailText: Nicolas Anelka arrived at Real Madrid's training ground for a solo session on Tuesday only to find the changing rooms locked, then admitted that he may have to move on to revive his ailing career.
fields.body:
Nicolas Anelka arrived at Real Madrid's training ground for a solo session on Tuesday only to find the changing rooms locked, then admitted that he may have to move on to revive his ailing career.

"Maybe the best thing would be to look for another team because the situation here is very difficult," said Anelka, who had to head for home and run the gauntlet of reporters who have been doorstepping him for the past few days.

"I'm not looking for a move but it is a possibility that I'd return to France. Here it's very complicated to return to play. It's been seven months of problems since I arrived here."

Unconfirmed reports last night said the striker had taken a plane to Paris after being driven from his home in Madrid hidden in a car boot to avoid reporters.

The former Arsenal striker, now 21, was suspended without pay for 45 days after refusing to train through last weekend. "I don't want to quit Real Madrid," he added. "I just want to play football, although they won't let me. I don't have the slightest doubt about returning in a Real shirt, but I know it will be complicated."

Anelka was ordered to train alone last weekend after being dropped from the squad for criticising the tactics of the coach Vicente del Bosque.

However Real's president Lorenzo Sanz has tried to play down Tuesday's lock-out, saying the problem arose because Anelka had not told them he was intending to train. "I still believe in him," he added. "The talk about a transfer is nonsense, the situation will stabilise and everything will be fine. To begin with he must present his excuses, then we will talk."

Arsène Wenger, the Arsenal manager who bought Anelka for £500,000 and sold him for £23.5m, offered some comfort. "I would tell him to just keep working hard and, for the moment, not to talk to the press. The only way he can defend himself is to go back to playing well, but I don't believe he is getting the best advice."

Lazio's striker Marcelo Salas will miss Wednesday's Champions League match at Chelsea if Chile insist on him playing in a friendly against Ghana next Thursday.

Lee Sharpe will ask Bradford for a move unless he is given assurances that he figures in the manager Paul Jewell's plans.

Graeme Souness has announced that his longstanding associate Phil Boersma will join his coaching staff at Blackburn to work alongside the assistant manager Tony Parkes.

Celtic's director of football Kenny Dalglish is hoping to agree a joint-coaching initiative with the Serie A champions, Milan. "If it does come off it will be a further step in the right direction by Celtic to join the major players in European football," Dalglish said.

webTitle: Reds pay the penalty for Owen's miss

fields.headline: Reds pay the penalty for Owen's miss
fields.trailText: Liverpool 0 - 0 Aston Villa
fields.body:
Michael Owen, starting his first game since returning from injury, missed a penalty last night as Liverpool dropped two home points. Having impressed so often since the turn of the year, the Anfield club appear to be working studiously towards ensuring that their season ends in anti-climax.

While the solitary point they gathered from an untidy game was sufficient, just, to move them back into the Premiership's top three they have lost their way somewhat.

Blessed with a watertight defence, they are not losing - but it is wins they need as they seek the money pot of Champions League qualification.

Had their finishing not been so wretched, a win they would certainly have had. Not until the evening's final quarter did Aston Villa show any interest in building upon the one point they held at kick-off.

Liverpool's opportunity to collect a maximum return came and went just after the half-hour when they paid a high price for what many would see as a curious decision to allow Michael Owen to take a penalty awarded after Gareth Southgate had felled Patrik Berger.

After just 15 minutes of senior football in eight hamstrung weeks Owen - not Berger, not Emile Heskey - stepped forwards to place the ball on the spot. His kick was ferocious but struck the underside of the crossbar before dropping down.

Believing the ball had fallen behind the line, Owen, fleetingly, raised his arms in triumph; he was to be disappointed.

It was not Owen's night. The Boy Wonder missed several chances he would normally have been expected to take, most notably in the 13th minute when he latched on to Steven Gerrard's fine pass only to steer his shot tamely into the legs of the Villa goalkeeper Peter Enckelman.

The recovery of Owen welcome though it may have been for club and country, did no favours for Anfield's latest cult figure, the Dutchman Erik Meijer, whose reward for a tireless display against Sunderland at the weekend was demotion to the substitutes' bench.

As the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier embraces the system of squad rotation, many will be called upon but many more left disappointed in the years that lie ahead.

Heskey was another young man who was to endure a less than satisfying night.

The youngster tried manfully to suppress a natural instinct to drift out towards the touchline but, sadly, without too much success.

Villa's role was of a supporting nature but with Paul Merson and Steve Stone energetic and enthusiastic in central midfield their counter-attacks, rare though they were, did hold at least a measure of promise.

They went close just once, Julian Joachim drifting around Stéphane Henchoz only to cross tamely into the area when the goal lay at his mercy.

Owen should have won the game for Liverpool shortly before his inevitable withdrawal just after the hour.

Having found himself on the end of Heskey's nicely weighted and intelligent pass he should have done rather more than lift his shot over the crossbar from 10 or so yards.

The impressive David Thompson was to go a little closer shortly afterwards but Enckelman was equal to the task, throwing himself down to block one of only a handful of shots which Liverpool were to land on what proved to be a most elusive target.

fields.headline: Beautiful strangers
fields.standfirst:
David Jean-Baptiste Special Quintet
Boat Race, Cambridge
****
fields.trailText:
David Jean-Baptiste Special Quintet
Boat Race, Cambridge
****
fields.body:
David Jean-Baptiste, the British clarinettist and saxophonist currently living in New York, eclipses his own soloistic virtues by his encouragement of the gifts of his partners in a formidable mixed-nation ensemble. Its clout is a tribute to Jean-Baptiste's growing pulling-power since his musical adoption by the great US saxophonist and bandleader David Murray. The Special Quintet features the American James Carter on baritone sax, UK drum star Mark Mondesir, Ricardo de Santos on bass and an immensely promising local newcomer, pianist Zoe Rahman.

Since the quintet was assembled specifically for this short tour, and Mondesir was a late replacement, unfamiliarity and culture-gaps could have turned it into the kind of bemused supergroup that exercises its skills in parallel universes and never really listens to itself. But Jean-Baptiste's presence, his enthusiasm, and the deceptively transparent invitation to conversation in his writing and arranging makes the difference. With luck, somebody will have caught its exhilarating live work for a disc.

The tightness of the band generally sidelined preoccupations about solo stars, but James Carter's roaring baritone solos, a mixture of swing geniality and paint-stripping Coltranesque ferocity, were sensational throughout the show. Carter's building of solo odysseys from close-to-the-beat stalking, through whirling fast runs and out into blasting abstractions, and his urgent relationship with Mark Mondesir, put a crucial charge under the band. Jean-Baptiste, a sometime sax player, now restricts himself entirely to clarinet and bass clarinet, with a pure and penetrating sound on the former and a rich, reverberating eloquence on the latter that meshed expressively with Carter's guttural harangues. Jean-Baptiste uses the tone palette of his unusual group well, his arrangements imparting fresh resonances to fairly conventional funky and Latin themes, and borrowing elements from reggae, classical music and Eastern European folk without making them sound like jazz composer's tourism.

Zoe Rahman's subtle turns of the expected melody line and playful trills, where a stretch of Latin-piano chord-slugging might have done, also galvanise the band. Her poise, imagination and technique are clearly qualities on the rise. There's even some straight jazz grooving, notably on the occasional fast blues, and Carter's deep appreciation of the swing-sax tradition is set alight by it. Transatlantic jazz experiments are sometimes more convincing on paper than onstage, but the Special Quintet is one that gives it a good name.

 At the Bonington Theatre, Nottingham (0115-967 0114), tonight.

fields.headline: My boss is an ogre
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

When I first started my job five months ago my boss promised me a pay rise. He now says I am already paid enough and do not deserve one.

I run the business day to day. When I first started I was doing 40 hour weeks but now I work more than 50. He does not pay overtime rates and has this week now stated that we must give him two weeks notice before we can take holiday - can he do this?

I do not have a contract at present but can't believe it would be in my best interests to sign one. How do I talk to my boss? He doesn't listen to anything his employees say - just shouts at us all the time.

The solution

There are two aspects to your concerns. One is regarding your legal rights as an employee and the other to do with managing a difficult boss.

I'm afraid that legally your boss is doing nothing wrong. He should have given you a contract sooner and in theory, you could take him to an industrial tribunal for not having done so, but you would have little grounds for taking such action. He is also entitled to ask for two weeks notice before you take leave. And, he does not have to pay overtime.

As to whether or not you should sign the contract, I couldn't comment without seeing it. However, one thing you should check is the hours expected of you - make sure that you do not sign anything obliging you to work more than 40 hours a week. I suggest you contact your local ACAS public enquiry point (in the phone book) and they should be able to help sort out the rest of your employee rights (such as holiday allowance).

The real issue here, I think, is how you can better manage your difficult boss. You may be fighting a losing battle (some bosses are just beyond reason) but I think you should get your contract sorted (making sure that you are well protected) then sit him down for a planned meeting.

Explain how let down you feel by his backing out of the promised pay rise. Tell him, in a non-aggressive way, that without the rise, you do not feel able to do much more than your contracted hours. You might also mention how uncomfortable his shouting makes you feel. Try and keep positive and upbeat, emphasising the areas of work you are happy with (find some!).

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Threat to directory inquiry jobs
fields.trailText: British Telecom is piloting an automated directory inquiries system that could eventually cost 3,000 operators their jobs.
fields.body:
British Telecom is piloting an automated directory inquiries system that could eventually cost 3,000 operators their jobs.

The system is based on voice recognition technology and was introduced earlier this week in the Ipswich, Hemel Hempstead and Mansfield areas.

People calling a freephone number are asked to give the name and address of the person whose number they want. A computerised voice asks for clarification of any spellings it is uncertain of, and the system then searches for the number.

The pilot scheme will run alongside the existing 192 service until May after which customers will be asked for their comments.

BT initially tested the technology last year offering numbers solely in the Ipswich area, close to their research centre at Martlesham Heath.

After experiencing some problems in that trial, including innacurate recognition of certain accents, BT has widened the catchment area to see if the improvements have been effective.

The Communication Workers Union, which represents the 3,000 directory inquiries staff, expressed anxiety at the long-term effect on jobs.

Sally Bridge, a CWU national officer, said: "The telecommunications industry is increasingly reliant on technologies that cost jobs.

"The introduction of automatic number retrieval has cut the number of operators, and numbers are now available on the internet as well as via 192."

BT said that the technology might one day be used to replace 192 operators. "In this trial we are testing the technology, not the application of it to 192 specifically."
