webTitle: How BMW lost its way at Longbridge

fields.headline: How BMW lost its way at Longbridge
fields.standfirst: Rover crisis: The company's new owners were painfully slow to produce new models, and the brand suffered
fields.trailText: The Mini, the best loved car of the swinging sixties, was launched just in time to give the British motor car industry a much needed fillip.
fields.body:
The Mini, the best loved car of the swinging sixties, was launched just in time to give the British motor car industry a much needed fillip.

Its successor, still a year away, may come too late to prevent Rover's home production from terminal decline.

Rover's 300 franchised dealers yesterday bemoaned the 26% slump in sales last year, but blamed it on the "stop-go" attitude of BMW rather than any fault in the product. In the past 10 years, Rover has had three owners and could be heading for a fourth.

Alan Pulham, franchised dealers' director of the Retail Motor Industry Federation, admitted that people had lost confidence in the brand, "but that is because of the constant speculation which has come out of Germany".

BMW's uncertainty with what to do with Rover when it took over made the firm painfully slow in producing new models - a risky strategy in such a fiercely competitive market. The dealers believe that one of BMW's worst mistakes was to scrap the Mini's successor, the Metro, in 1998, before it had replaced it with the new Mini.

Mr Pulham said that the Metro was a cheap down-market car and "not exciting by today's standards". It did not appeal to those under 25, but had a large following among the "blue rinse" brigade.

They had nothing to turn to when the Metro was scrapped, which was one of the main reasons why Rover sales slumped so heavily last year.

Garel Rhys, director of car research at Cardiff business school, agreed that Rover did not have the following it once had and had gone into "disastrous decline".

There was nothing wrong with Rover's brand image in the early 1990s on the home market, but when BMW started to raise questions about the name, it undermined the car's standing with the public.

Mark Cowling, chief economist of analyst CAP Motor Research, said that BMW took over Rover knowing it would make losses. He conceded that Rover models "have been getting pretty long in the tooth, and that the new 25 and 45 cars are just remodelled Rover 200s and 400s".

The dealers agreed, but said that the Rover 75, launched at the motor show, was an excellent car that had not been given time to prove itself.

Mr Pulham also blamed BMW for not understanding the British market, where more brands were sold than in most countries. Britain, unlike many countries, had a big contract business. More than half of new cars sold each year were lease or contract cars, and Rover had been slow to make special deals for a volume purchase.

The days have long gone at Longbridge when "Red Robbo" - Derek Robinson, the communist shop steward - reigned supreme and British Leyland was often crippled by unofficial strikes.

If motorists complained of "Friday afternoon models", they usually meant that their cars were always in the garage for faults built in on the week's final shift at Longbridge. But for 10 years the plant has enjoyed remarkable industrial peace and its finished products have been of comparable quality to competitors. It is the image that is the problem.

Two models that offer a lift to Rover are the Land Rover and MG, but they are niche-market cars and not enough to turn the company around.

According to Mr Pulham, BMW had failed to decide what it wanted for Longbridge or to capitalise on the co-operation of the workforce. "One of the reasons it was interested in the first place was that Rover would fit into the bottom of the BMW range. But it has not been able to fathom quite where that is."

Perhaps it should not have launched the Rover brand, but stuck with "cheap and cheerful" Austin-Morris, he added.
fields.bodyText: The Mini, the best loved car of the swinging sixties, was launched just in time to give the British motor car industry a much needed fillip. Its successor, still a year away, may come too late to prevent Rover's home production from terminal decline. Rover's 300 franchised dealers yesterday bemoaned the 26% slump in sales last year, but blamed it on the "stop-go" attitude of BMW rather than any fault in the product. In the past 10 years, Rover has had three owners and could be heading for a fourth. Alan Pulham, franchised dealers' director of the Retail Motor Industry Federation, admitted that people had lost confidence in the brand, "but that is because of the constant speculation which has come out of Germany". BMW's uncertainty with what to do with Rover when it took over made the firm painfully slow in producing new models - a risky strategy in such a fiercely competitive market. The dealers believe that one of BMW's worst mistakes was to scrap the Mini's successor, the Metro, in 1998, before it had replaced it with the new Mini. Mr Pulham said that the Metro was a cheap down-market car and "not exciting by today's standards". It did not appeal to those under 25, but had a large following among the "blue rinse" brigade. They had nothing to turn to when the Metro was scrapped, which was one of the main reasons why Rover sales slumped so heavily last year. Garel Rhys, director of car research at Cardiff business school, agreed that Rover did not have the following it once had and had gone into "disastrous decline". There was nothing wrong with Rover's brand image in the early 1990s on the home market, but when BMW started to raise questions about the name, it undermined the car's standing with the public. Mark Cowling, chief economist of analyst CAP Motor Research, said that BMW took over Rover knowing it would make losses. He conceded that Rover models "have been getting pretty long in the tooth, and that the new 25 and 45 cars are just remodelled Rover 200s and 400s". The dealers agreed, but said that the Rover 75, launched at the motor show, was an excellent car that had not been given time to prove itself. Mr Pulham also blamed BMW for not understanding the British market, where more brands were sold than in most countries. Britain, unlike many countries, had a big contract business. More than half of new cars sold each year were lease or contract cars, and Rover had been slow to make special deals for a volume purchase. The days have long gone at Longbridge when "Red Robbo" - Derek Robinson, the communist shop steward - reigned supreme and British Leyland was often crippled by unofficial strikes. If motorists complained of "Friday afternoon models", they usually meant that their cars were always in the garage for faults built in on the week's final shift at Longbridge. But for 10 years the plant has enjoyed remarkable industrial peace and its finished products have been of comparable quality to competitors. It is the image that is the problem. webTitle: Fund managers warm to firms they once feared

fields.headline: Fund managers warm to firms they once feared
fields.trailText: Huge sums of pension fund money could be ploughed into fledgling companies following research which shows investing in start-ups to be less risky than widely thought and that start-ups have performed better than the stock market in the past five years.
fields.body:
Huge sums of pension fund money could be ploughed into fledgling companies following research which shows investing in start-ups to be less risky than widely thought and that start-ups have performed better than the stock market in the past five years.

The National Association of Pension Funds and the British Venture Capital Association, which commissioned the research, said the results, although not conclusive, would allow fund managers to place a larger amounts of investment funds in companies with only a short track record and go some way to satisfy the demands of the prime minister, Tony Blair, that investors back home-grown entrepreneurs.

Although some £28bn has been ploughed into 18,000 greenfield businesses since 1983 - a figure which is accelerating rapidly with dot.com fever - professional investors in Britain have backed away. Overseas funds account for nearly three-quarters of the seed-corn finance.

Despite predictions that the "bubble" in the price of quoted e-commerce shares in about to burst, fund managers are becoming more adventurous with some of their funds in an attempt to improve performance and beat their rivals.

One senior investment manager said: "I don't think we will all rush to throw money at start-ups but Tony Blair's call for greater involvement has resulted in positive steps being taken and there is undoubtedly a change of attitude." The government's effort to turn Britain into a nation of entrepreneurs will take a big step forward when Gordon Brown, the chancellor, eliminates the hurdles which institutional investors say are stopping them ploughing millions of pounds into business start-ups.

Less than nine months after Mr Blair issued a challenge to the big pension and insurance company investors to give greater financial backing to budding business, the treasury almost certain to rewrite the rules which fund managers claim act as a disincentive.

A spokesman for the treasury refused to indicate the timescale for action but said the department had been giving "careful consideration" to all aspects of the issue first outlined in the green budget last year.

Institutional investors claim that there are tax penalities which work against them supporting new businesses as well as problems over the valuation of these investments in their portfolios.

The prime minister last summer called on professional investors to help the Labour government realise its ambition to foster an entrepreneur-driven society by using a fraction of their £650bn of funds to support small businesses such as dot.com start ups.

The idea that institutions might "invest for Britain" sparked initial hostility and antagonism from fund managers, but relations between the government and major industry groups have started to improve of late.

fields.headline: BP poised for Atlantic win
fields.standfirst: Breakthrough in impasse with US regulator may allow oil takeover bid to proceed
fields.trailText: A breakthrough appears to have been made last night in the confrontation between American trade regulators and energy group BP Amoco over its £19bn bid for oil group Atlantic Richfield.
fields.body:
A breakthrough appears to have been made last night in the confrontation between American trade regulators and energy group BP Amoco over its £19bn bid for oil group Atlantic Richfield.

Earlier in the day the federal trade commission sought an adjournment of its anti-monopoly case against the two groups, saying that it had received "constructive proposals" which might allow the takeover bid to proceed.

Sources suggested that BP was prepared to sell off a huge chunk of the combined group to placate the Washington competition authorities.

It was understood the commission had made it clear that nothing less than a total divestment by BP of all of the combined group's Alaskan oilfields would be enough to gain regulatory clearance.

Such a sale was expected to be announced last night, with US group Phillips rumoured to be the likeliest buyer. The Alaskan operations are estimated to be worth £5bn-plus.

BP is thought to have been keen to settle the regulatory action as quickly as possible, given the return of oil as a hot political issue during a US election year as Americans come to terms with sharply higher oil prices. It is likely the group wanted the takeover sorted out ahead of an oil producers' summit this month.

But the size of the concessions it has had to make demonstrates that the "window" of lax regulation seen during the price slide of 1997-1999 has closed.

The huge global marriages seen in that brief era - such as Total Fina and Exxon Mobil - are unlikely to be repeated in the new climate.

The commission said last night: "In light of the substantial and constructive proposals made by the defendants, all parties have agreed to seek adjournment of the federal court proceedings... in order to conduct negotiations".

BP Amoco launched its bid for Atlantic in March last year, when oil prices had only just recovered from a crash to below $10 a barrel at the end of 1998. Since then they have recovered strongly, in large part due to a tough production cuts package by Opec, making regulators less tolerant of mega-mergers in the oil business.

Ironically the rising price seems likely to allow BP to take a more relaxed view of losing the Alaskan interests; not only will it get a better price than would have been the case a year ago but also revenues from remaining business in the combined group will be more buoyant, meaning the deal can make financial sense without the Alaskan businesses.

Atlantic is based in Los Angeles, and its petrol stations sell one in every four gallons consumed by Californian motorists This dominant position ruled out any bidder with similar retail interests in the state such as Chevron and Texaco, but last year it seemed that BP would hit few regulatory difficulties. However, fears of a dominant position in relation to oil refining on the American west coast prompted the commission to sue last month to stop the deal going ahead.

Offers by BP to dispose of 400,000 barrels a day of the combined group's 700,000-barrel daily output from Alaska were turned down.

 Shipping brokers reported a rise in tanker sailings from the middle east in anticipation of oil output increases after the 11-nation Opec summit due in Vienna on March 27, Reuters reported. The cartel has been under heavy pressure to raise production in order to stabilise oil prices.

fields.headline: Not a whole lotta shakin'
fields.standfirst:
Cooking with Elvis
Whitehall Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Cooking with Elvis
Whitehall Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Cooking with Elvis is one of the plays with which Lee Hall, British theatre's man of the moment and the pen behind the hit radio play Spoonface Steinberg, made his name.

It opened at Newcastle's Live Theatre in 1997 and stormed last year's Edinburgh Festival. For its London debut, millionaire stand-up Frank Skinner joins the original cast as a cake expert, Stuart, embroiled in a tug-of-love between a mum, a daughter and a tortoise. Dad, a former Elvis impersonator, has been brain-damaged.

Skinner's arrival has entailed cosmetic changes: "You Brummie bastard!" yells Sharon Percy's lively Gill, in a recent amendment. Skinner spends much of the show naked save for a gormless expression. His playing for laughs pays dividends, although he struggles with his character's switch from doltish bloke to sexual predator. Although Hall seems to be getting at something, it is difficult to know precisely what.

He mixes food, abundant sex, disability and rock'n'roll into an appetising broth. There are lip-smacking jokes: "Who do you think you are?", rails Stuart's wronged prey, "coming in here fucking me mother, shagging me and wanking me dad off? It's a good job I killed the fucking tortoise." But Hall is insufficiently sensitive to his play's concern, the sexual and emotional frustrations provoked when a husband and father is mentally and physically paralysed.

The highlights are interludes in which Joe Caffrey's Dad leaps from his wheelchair in the character of Elvis Presley. Are these speeches, in which mega-stardom and disability overlap, insights into the fantasies of a brain-damaged man? Possibly.

Their comic function is easier to fathom: when Stuart buries his face between his lover's legs, Dad/Elvis croons the "you're caught in a trap" line from Suspicious Minds. That we look forward to these brilliant if meaningless rock'n'roll interruptions indicates the slightness of Max Roberts' broadly comic production. Its self-reflexive format - each scene with an ironic title - backfires: more than a lightweight farce, yet less than a substantial comedy.

Entertaining, but audiences won't leave All Shook Up.

 This review appeared in some editions yesterday.

fields.headline: Ocean Colour Scene
fields.standfirst:
Astoria, London
***
fields.trailText:
Astoria, London
***
fields.body:
Just as we'll supposedly be reading newspapers on mobile phones within the next few years, so electronica will shortly be seeing off guitar bands. As if. The concept of white men thrashing Stratocasters may seem quaint, but the success of Travis and Stereophonics proves that millions still prefer their rock straight up, with a twist of denim. Ocean Colour Scene's five-night stand at the Astoria sold out without even a new release in the shops.

Their allure has its roots in the same fashion-spurning hemisphere as their friend Paul Weller, where it's okay to be sensitive as long as you get your round in. Sensitivity was bottom of the agenda for the beery house, though, which repeatedly erupted in moos of "we are the mods". They say bands get the fans they deserve, but the Oceans seem a bit hard done by, passionately balladeering about Leah Betts (One for the Road) while fans obliviously crowd-surf.

Of course, if you didn't know what Simon Fowler was singing, you'd be justified in taking this simply to be uplifting pub rock. The classic pub configuration - Fowler out front, loping bassist Damon Minchella and blues-influenced guitarist Steve Cradock on either side, drummer Oscar Harrison behind - emphasises their commitment to tradition.

But this kind of thing can be a cathartic release for both band and crowd, and numbers such as The Circle create a real rapport between the wide-eyed Fowler and his people. His hoarse delivery has the stamp of authenticity. He's lived, loved and ended up in the tabloids for it, and brings something of the experience to his performance. At any rate, the fans see him as theirs. Apparently, there are some for whom "dadrock" is more a compliment than an insult.

 Till Saturday. Box office: 0171-434 0403.

webTitle: Scottish Radio bids to take over Border

fields.headline: Scottish Radio bids to take over Border
fields.trailText: Scottish Radio Holdings yesterday launched a £116m hostile bid for Border Television, one of only two independent ITV companies left in the UK.
fields.body:
Scottish Radio Holdings yesterday launched a £116m hostile bid for Border Television, one of only two independent ITV companies left in the UK.

The company gave details of its unsolicited offer after a meeting between the two sides on Monday ended in Border directors deciding to fight the bid. The Scottish Radio offer is also understood to have elicited approaches to Border from Capital Radio, Scottish Media Group, Chrysalis and Kelvin Mackenzie's Wireless Group, raising the prospect of a bidding war.

Other candidates that have run the slide rule over Border include Guardian Media Group, publisher of the Guardian newspaper.

Shares in Border climbed 19% to £10.75, just a penny below Scottish Radio's all-paper offer of £10.76 per share. A cash alternative is on offer of £10.25 a share.

One beneficiary of a bid battle would be Labour peer and arts presenter Lord (Melvyn) Bragg - pictured left - a former Border director who still holds more than 100,000 shares.

Scottish Radio chief executive Richard Findlay called on Border to be "realistic" about its future as an independent company. "The whole media sector is consolidating and if they want to serve properly their viewers and listeners, shareholders and staff they are better off with us," he said.

Scottish Radio held talks with Border two years ago when the offer on the table was at £4 a share. The new bid is at a premium of 31% to the Border price last Thursday, the day before speculation over an impending bid forced Scottish Radio to make a statement.

A merged business would put Border's four radio stations in with the Scottish Radio's 15 franchises in Scotland and Ireland. Scottish Radio suggested that its long experience in the sector would enable it to make better use of Border's assets.

If successful, Scottish Radio, which also owns local newspapers and an outdoor advertising business, would retain the TV station. "It may be small but even a speck of gold glisters," Mr Findlay said.

Paul Corley, Border's chief executive, said the Scottish Radio offer did not represent fair value. "Everything has a price," he said. "But the board's stated aim is to remain independent and we have a very strong year ahead of us. Our existing radio businesses should begin to mature and we are going for new licences."

He expected changes to the broadcasting act next year to remove limits on owning both radio and ITV stations, which could send the value of smaller independents soaring.

If Border falls, Ulster would be left as Britain's only independent ITV contractor.

fields.headline: Between two stools
fields.standfirst:
Maxim Vengerov/Vagram Saradjian/Vag Papian
Barbican Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Maxim Vengerov/Vagram Saradjian/Vag Papian
Barbican Hall, London
***
fields.body:
When a star violinist like Maxim Vengerov decides to play chamber music, he can approach it two ways.

If he combines forces with instrumentalists of equal stature - Yo-Yo Ma and Daniel Barenboim, for instance, with whom he played piano trios last year - then the creative friction between them is fascinating in itself, and audiences go to watch the sparks fly.

If he chooses to play with less exalted partners, as Vengerov did at the Barbican last night, when he was joined by the cellist Vagram Saradjian and the pianist Vag Papian, then the end product ought to be something else - performances in which there is a unity of purpose, and a shared perspective on interpretation.

Somehow, though, things did not cohere as they should. That was not at all because Vengerov was hogging the spotlight - he is a wonderfully selfless chamber musician. But nothing joined up here; shared phrases seemed to stop and start as they were passed from voice to voice, musical paragraphs seemed detached from each other.

It was as if the three players were locked in their own separate musical worlds, each perfectly conceived in its own right (some of the playing, not just from Vengerov, was very fine), but without any shared experience, or points of contact with the others.

Their programme was a wonderfully simple one, pairing the two greatest Russian piano trios: Shostakovich's second, in E minor, and Tchaikovsky's A minor trio. Both were conceived as elegies for friends, the Shostakovich, composed in 1944 after the Eighth Symphony, for the musicologist and critic Ivan Sollertinsky, the Tchaikovsky, from 1881, for the pianist Nikolay Rubinstein. Both can deliver a massive emotional charge. Shostakovich's lament is deeply personal, Tchaikovsky's more grandly and grandiosely public, but here neither plumbed the depths as it could have done.

The way Vengerov shaped the main theme of Shostakovich's slow movement was compelling, just as his pizzicato beginning to the gruesome danse macabre of the finale had exactly the right detachment.

And there were similar snatches of poetry in the second work too - the return of the main theme in Tchaikovsky's first movement, the crisp characterisation of some of the variations in the second.

But there were too many earthbound passages as well when the music just did not take wing. The second movement of the Tchaikovsky is quite often brutally cut in performance, but Vengerov and his colleagues did every note of it; there were moments when I guiltily wished they had not.

 This review appeared in some editions yesterday.

fields.headline: Online sales prove a loser for Vauxhall
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Car maker Vauxhall's high profile move into online sales has netted less than 250 customers in four months. The dot.com initiative, which promised £1,000 off normal dealer prices and was backed by a TV advertising campaign featuring Griff Rhys Jones, was launched last November with a fanfare of publicity.
fields.body:
Car maker Vauxhall's high profile move into online sales has netted less than 250 customers in four months. The dot.com initiative, which promised £1,000 off normal dealer prices and was backed by a TV advertising campaign featuring Griff Rhys Jones, was launched last November with a fanfare of publicity.

But yesterday Vauxhall confirmed it had generated few sales from the move online. Only 2,000 potential customers have logged their details on the website and only 248 of the special dot.com branded cars produced for online sale have been ordered.

The range available includes so-called dot.com versions of the Corsa, Tigra, Astra, Vectra and Frontera. A spokeswoman said: "They were specially produced to appeal to retail customers." But their appeal has obviously been strictly limited.

Vauxhall chief executive Nick Reilly believes research will reveal why people are not pressing the "buy" button.

Steve Fowler, editor of consumer journal What Car?, said: "People are using the internet as a homework tool, but they are still reluctant to push the pay button when it comes to actually buying - particularly for such a major purchase as a car."

In fact, he said, few realised that Vauxhall's "buy" button merely puts the surfer in contact with the group's local dealer, who then arranges for a dot.com-specified car to be delivered to the applicant's home for a road test.

Despite the disappointing results of the initiative - which were revealed by online car magazine Hoot! - Vauxhall insisted the online experiment had not been a flop.

The company's spokeswoman said: "We did not set specific sales targets.

"This is not about volume sales. It has been a learning opportunity and tremendously useful."

She said the company intended to expand the range of models available online during the coming months.

But Vauxhall's online sales performance has not served to put off other industry players. Telephone insurer Direct Line and Humberside-based car dealer Dixon Motors have agreed to sell new and secondhand cars together online.

The deal, which brings together the UK's largest motor insurer with Britain's third largest car dealership, will put all mainstream motor brands on the internet by the summer and increase the price presssure facing car manufacturers.

"The site will instantly propel Dixon from its strong regional base to that of a national player in the auto motive sector," said managing director Simon Dixon.

"The objective is to bring an easy direct buying experience over the net akin to Direct Line's proven formula and to revolutionise car purchasing in the UK. The day of the hard sell on the forecourt is over."

Dixon was reporting a 21% fall in profits to £8.4m. The group sells 70,000 cars a year, but like the rest of the industry it has been hit by a belief among car buyers that prices are set to fall and that if they wait, they will pay less.

Details of the internet venture, however, pushed up Dixon shares 21.5p to 184p.

webTitle: Lastminute down to earth with a bump

fields.headline: Lastminute down to earth with a bump
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com's share price performed a sharp about turn yesterday after its soaraway flotation.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com's share price performed a sharp about turn yesterday after its soaraway flotation.

After the shares had been issued at 380p they had reached 487p by the close of the first day, valuing the company at as much as £835m. But yesterday they slumped 75p, or 15%, to close at just 412p, a far cry from the first day high of 555p.

Furious investors complained in net chatrooms about the much hyped flotation as they watched the profits from their small sharehold ings disappear quicker than one of the online travel agent's package deals.

Some analysts blamed the decline on the negative feelings created by the allocation of only 35 shares each to 190,000 small investors.

In the chatrooms, small investors were vociferous. Myfyr Madoc-Jones wrote on interactive investor international's website that lastminute.com was "a load of hyped rubbish".

He wrote: "That is my opinion of this company, and what I believe to be the true underlying value of their shares."

Another user of the iii.co.uk site, Daz Barry, said: "It is not the disappointment of having so few shares that pisses me off but having the capital tied up somewhere."

However, some smaller investors are unlikely to sell in large numbers given there would be little or no profit after fees and stamp duty. Retail investors cannot yet trade their shares anyway.

As well as travel deal, the company, which is not expected to be profitable until 2004, also sells gifts and theatre tickets, and markets restaurants.
